Africa News


April 1, 1997


Business and Finance;
Currencies: CFA Continues To Appreciate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 824 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The CFA franc appreciated further this week, opening on Monday at the nominal rate of 565.30 to the U.S. dollar, from

569.00 last week and 570.50 two weeks ago.

In Dakar on Tuesday, the currency exchanged at 547 (buying) and 577 (selling) to the dollar, from 554 (buying) and 584 (selling) to the dollar on the same day last week.

The Following were Tuesday's nominal exchange rates of African currencies against the U.S. dollar (current rates for the Ghanaian cedi, the Angolan Adjusted Kwanza and the New Zaire were not available):

2 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


Angola;
Angolan Leaders Agree To Set Up Unity Government


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

NEW YORK (PANA) - The Angolan government and the former rebel group, UNITA, have agreed to establish a government of national unity and reconciliation on April 11, the UN announced Monday.

The UN spokesman, Fred Eckhard, told correspondents that Secretary-General Kofi Annan had communicated the agreement to the Security Council. 

The formation of the government is a crucial aspect of the Lusaka Protocol, the peace accord signed in the Zambian capital in 1994 by UNITA and the Angolan government to end two decades of civil war.

Several attempts to establish the government in the past have failed due to UNITA's failure to send all its designated representatives in the proposed government to Luanda.

Eckhard quoted the secretary-general, who recently visited Angola, as saying that the decision to establish the unity government was a boost for the peace process.

"The secretary-general feels that while there are still significant aspects of the peace agreement to implement...the peace process is back on track," he said.

Annan convinced the UNITA leader, Jonas Savimbi, to send the representatives to Luanda when he visited Angola from March 22-24 as part of his African trip.

Meanwhile, the Security Council has welcomed the decision to form the government on April 11, and voted to renew the mandate of the more than 6,000 UN peacekeepers in the country.

The short renewal is to enable the council to closely monitor the situation.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


3 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Higher Education Consultation Begins


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - At least 200 African policy makers, university rectors and researchers began in Dakar on Tuesday a regional consultation aimed at shaping the continent's higher education agenda in the next century.

The meeting, attended by ministers from virtually all sub-saharan African states, is to be officially opened on Tuesday afternoon by the Senegalese president, Abdou Diouf.

Federico Mayor, the Director-General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), which is funding the meeting, will make a keynote address during the consultation's official opening. 

The meeting is part of Africa's preparations for the September 1998 World Conference on Higher Education in Paris.

In his intervention during the meeting's first general discussion, Zambia's minister of higher education, Syamukayumbo Siamujaye, criticized international donors, saying they denied funds to higher education so as to make African states perpetually dependent on Western aid.

He also said the structural adjustment programmes had aggravated the situation of higher education in most of the African states.

Siamujaye appealed to UNESCO to take action to redress the situation which he termed as a "conspiracy" by international donors.

Meanwhile, the Cameroonian minister of higher education, Peter Agbo Tabi, suggested that the Dakar meeting would have been worthwhile if finance ministers were also invited.

He warned that African states will not achieve the scientific and technological progress for the 21st century if policy makers continued to deny funds to the higher education sector.

Another speaker, Prof. Eshiwani George of Kenyatta University in Kenya called for a re-orientation of the continent's education system towards mathematics and science.

He said the neglect of these subjects risked to marginalize the continent even further in the next century's scientific and technological progress.

Penda Mbow, from the University of Cheikh Anta Diop in Dakar, decried the marginalization of women academicians, especially in Francophone African universities.

She appealed to UNESCO to redress the situation so that women can also participate fully in the decision making process of academic institutions.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 1, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Exchange Expects Record Business


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe Agricultural Commodity Exchange (ZIMACE) has expressed optimism about the possibility of another successful marketing season this year despite the cloud of uncertainty that currently shrouds crop estimates.

ZIMACE administrator Ian Goggin said on Tuesday, while there was still uncertainty in the market, particularly in the case of maize, indications were that trading would be heavy this year, buoyed by firming commodity prices. 

Except for maize, Goggin said most prices were expected to remain bullish, continuing last year's trend which saw prices performing above expectation.

"All things being equal, we expect a large crop this year, especially for soybeans and wheat, and we are more than ready to handle what comes our way," he said.

The outbreak of grey leaf spot and frog eye diseases, which hit most parts of Zimbabwe, is expected to have a considerable negative impact on maize forcing farmers to revise their estimates downwards by about 25 percent of total output for the crop.

Earlier, crop forecasts indicated that Zimbabwe's maize production in 1996/97 would surpass the 2.6 million tons produced last year and come close to the three-million ton mark.

Soybean is projected to reach 120,000 tons, up from last year's 53,000 tons.

Meanwhile, statistics released last week show that commercial farmers are expecting another bumper harvest this season.

For example, 258,000 tons of seed cotton were expected from both large and small scale farmers, coffee production is forecast at 12,000 tons while milk production was estimated to exceed 195 million liters.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


5 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
World Bank, IMF Urged To Be Flexible On Africa's Debt


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The World Bank and International Monetary Fund need to be more flexible if Africa is to benefit from their initiative for debt relief, a senior U.N. official has said.

The official, Kingsley Amoako, was speaking Monday at the opening of the Conference of African Finance Ministers, organized by the U.N. Economic Commission for Africa. 

Amoako, the organization's executive-secretary, said if the debt relief effort was implemented without flexibility, "it would end up like the mountain that gave birth to a mouse."

Africa's total debt was estimated at 340 billion U.S. dollars as at the end of 1996.

The initiative to reduce this significantly was launched in September 1996. It concerns relief for the highly indebted poor countries. Amoako said the World Bank and the IMF had done well in "moving ahead" with the initiative.

However, he said assuming the effort achieved its objective, "a final concern would be how to make sure Africa does not find herself in the same situation in the future."

He said that the decision of the ministerial conference on the initiative would form the basis for further interaction between African countries, the donor community and multilateral financial institutions.

Conference documents say that nine of the 42 sub-Sahara African countries are relatively free of external debt. They state that 32 countries are moderately indebted and the remaining 11 highly indebted.

Of the 33 countries expected to benefit from the initiative, 16 are potentially eligible.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 1, 1997


West Africa;
General Warns His Troops Against Marrying Liberian Women


BYLINE: Nicholas Ibewuike, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian troops on peace-keeping operations in Liberia have been barred from marring Liberian women, Nigeria's semi-official newspaper, Daily Times, reported Monday.

"You get married to a Liberian, you discharge from the army and leave the barracks a freeman," Maj. Gen. Victor Malu said. 

Citing Malu, the force commander of West African troops Peace Monitoring Force in Liberia, it said he was speaking with Nigerian journalists on a conducted tour of operations carried out by the force, known as Ecomog.

But a correspondent of News Agency of Nigeria, who was among the entourage, said the warning was an existing army regulation.

"It is not peculiar to Liberia alone but to any other country Nigerian troops are serving," Malu said.

The newspaper said Malu was speaking against the backdrop of the birth of a good number of children fathered by Nigerian soldiers of Liberia mothers.

"We are here to make peace, not babies," Malu said.

Africa News


April 1, 1997


Science and Health;
Zimbabwe's Black Rhino Population Increasing


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HWANGE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Emerging from near extinction, Zimbabwe's black rhino population is now increasing by at least 10 percent annually, due to an improved habitat and increased security.

Reporting this Monday, the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency quoted the warden for Sinamatella Intensive Protection Zone Camp in the Hwange National Park, Norman English, as saying that extensive security measures had resulted in zero poaching activities in the area for the past two years.

"I can assure that the problem of poaching is under control because of increased patrols," he said. 

The Zimbabwe Defence Forces are helping in controlling the poaching under a programme code named "Operation heritage."

"The National Parks Department and its associates is effectively monitoring poaching activities using helicopters and foot patrols," he said.

Most of the country's black rhino are located in the camp. Citing security reasons, English would not give the current figure of rhinos at the park.

"The total number of rhinos in the park is classified information," he said.

In all of Zimbabwe, there is an estimated 300 rhinos out of a population of 2,000 just a few years ago.

Meanwhile, Matabeleland North Provincial Warden Donald Mutape said the dehorning of the black rhino had been stopped as a policy issue.

"There is need to research on the full impact of the dehorning exercise before it is continued," he said.

Dehorning was used as a means of discouraging poachers which sought the horns. Now, Mutape said, only the rhino collaring exercise is being applied to ensure detection.

Mutape said five white and one black rhinos remained in the rest of Hwange National Park.

Although poaching is under control, five elephants were killed in 1997. Mutape said elephant poaching was minimal because of the risks involved.

"Bearing in mind the huge national parks area under our jurisdiction, the problem of poaching is well under control," he said.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

8 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
UN Says Annan's Africa Trip A Success


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - The first official trip to Africa by Kofi Annan, as United Nations secretary-general, since assuming office in January, was a big success his spokesman, Fred Eckhard, has said.

Eckhard told PANA in New York that the breakthroughs in the Angolan peace process and the crisis in the Great Lakes region marked the highlights of the trip.

"For those two reasons, it was substantively a successful trip," Eckhard said. 

Annan returned to New York on Friday, after an 11-day trip that took him to South Africa, Namibia, Angola and Lome, where he attended a summit of the Organisation of African Unity's central organ for conflict resolution.

In Angola, he met with UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi and convinced him to end the stalemate in establishing a government of national unity. He also persuaded Savimbi to reconcile with the Luanda authorities by sending UNITA representatives to join the proposed government.

With UNITA representatives now in the Angolan capital, the U.N. announced Monday that the government would be established April 11.

Formation of the government would mark the high-point of the implementation of the Lusaka protocol, the peace agreement signed by the parties in 1994 to end two decades of civil war in Angola.

"The secretary-general feels that while there are still significant aspects of the peace agreement to implement, the peace process is back on track," Eckhard said.

Also at the Lome summit, the Zairian government and the rebel forces, who have been fighting since October agreed, to meet this weekend for talks in South Africa.

Eckhard described this deal as the "second gratifying aspect of the secretary-general's trip."

The meeting will be presided over by Mohammed Sahnoun, the Algerian diplomat who is the joint representative of the Organization of African Unity and the U.N., within the framework of the U.N. peace plan.

The five-point plan includes an immediate cease-fire and withdrawal of all external forces from the region, protection of refugees and displaced people, respect of Zaire's sovereignty and the convening of an international conference on peace, security and development in the Great Lakes region.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

9 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia News Roundup


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Lusaka - 1. PETITION AGAINST PRESIDENT CHILUBA REKINDLES POLITICAL DEBATE: The resumption of the petition by some opposition parties against President Chiluba's identity has renewed political debate in the country over presidential qualifications.

The petitioners contend that President Chiluba is not a born Zambian and should therefore have been disqualified from contesting the republican presidency.

Witness have started testifying in the case, including Luka Kafupi, a man claiming to be Chiluba's biological father. However, along with the case come many conflicting statements from the hordes of witnesses, the latest being a one who stated that President Chiluba's father was actually a Mozambican. 

2. ZDC COMES BACK TO LIFE: After four months of self-imposed 'hibernation' following a devastating election defeat, the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) has began to show signs of coming back to life. The party which had hoped to win or at least get a respectable number of parliamentary seats after last November's elections, has began holding provincial party elections which will lead to national elections.

Party president Dean Mung'omba said that the ZDC still had the potential to be in government and that now was the time to begin serious preparations for the 2001 presidential and parliamentary elections. He also said that if the last elections had not been rigged, as has been alleged, the ZDC would have been in power today.

3. STAGE SET FOR THREE-SEAT PARLIAMENTAY BY-ELECTIONS: The MMD's popularity will be subjected to another test next month when three parliamentary by- elections will be held to fill seats that fell vacant after the deaths of the incumbents - all of whom were MMD members of parliament.

The test will, however, be somewhat eased for the MMD because the major party, UNIP, has resolved not to take part in any election because they contend the 1991 elections were rigged. Other parties like the National Party, which has five seats in parliament, has said it would take part.

The MMD is unlikely to have any difficulty in reclaiming the Petauke seat in the Eastern Province and the Mwembeshi seat in Central Province. But the contest for the Zambezi East seat in the North Western Province is expected to be tough particularly because the NP is fairly strong in the region.

4. ZAIRE CONFLICT CONTINUES TO WORRY ZAMBIANS: The escalated war in Zaire, Zambia's northern neighbour, has heightened concern in the country because of the fear that Zambia would not be able to cope with an anticipated influx of refugees and fleeing solders. Government has already made preparations to evacuate Zambians at the Embassy in Kinshasa and at the consulate in Lumumbashi, Zaire's second largest city which is under serious threat of being captured by rebels.

The greatest fear, however, is that the fleeing Zairean soldiers could easily come into Zambia with their arms and increase the already high crime rate in the Copperbelt Province, which borders Zaire's Shaba Province, the new focal point of the rebel advances.

5. THE BLIND REFUSE TO BE REPATRIATED: Blind people with no jobs but who earn their living through begging on the streets in towns and cities of the country, have refused to be repatriated to their home villages where they could live more decent lives. A spokesman for an association that looks into the interests of the blind, says that very few, if any of the blind men and women would agree to go back to their respective home villages.

Seek Peace Association chairman, Joseph Sakala, says even if the blind would want to go back to their homes, there was no guarantee that their lives would change for the better because many of their relatives were ignoring them.

In the past, several attempts have been made to repatriate the blind, but many of them have returned to the cities where there has been an extensive campaign discouraging people from giving alms to beggars.

6. NEW EXPORT/IMPORT ROUTE CHEERS TRADERS: Zambian traders have been cheered by the reopening of the railway route from Zambia, eastwards through Malawi to the Mozambican port city of Beira. The traders hope the re-opening of the route will provide a relatively cheaper alternative export and import route for goods to and from Asia, the Middle East and the Far East.

Until now, the main routes have been the northwards railway to the Tanzanian port of Dar es Salaam and the road southwards to South African ports. The traders also hope that the Zambian government will quickly rehabilitate the road from Lusaka to Chipata, the Eastern Province capital which links the Beira railway line.

7. RIVER WEED SPREADS AS SOLUTION FOR ERADICATION ELUDES EXPERTS: A notorious weed that is choking several parts of Zambia's third largest River, the Kafue, is still a menace. It is now believed to have spread to the largest river, the Zambezi. A new chemical has just been applied to a portion of the weeds on an experimental basis but there is not definite whether this latest of many experiments will solve the problem.

The weed has been seen in some parts of the Zambezi River, and particularly near the Kariba Dam which generates most of Zambia's electricity needs. It is feared that if the weed is not controlled quickly near the dam, it could adversely affect electricity supply to the country.

8. ZAMBIANS FEAR FOR NATIONAL SOCCER TEAM TO PLAY IN ZAIRE: Many Zambians, including officials of the Football Association of Zambia, fear for the safety of the national soccer team which is scheduled to play a World Cup qualifying match in war-torn Zaire on April 6.

The Football Association had been hoping that FIFA, the world soccer governing body, would shift the venue of the match from the Zairean capital Kinshasa to another country, but FIFA has insisted that the match be played in Zaire. The concern now is that some key Zambian players, especially those based abroad, would refuse to travel for the match. Already the captain of the side, Kalusha Bwalya, has indicated that he might not be available for the match.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


10 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


Zambia;
Zambians Still Divided Over Death Penalty


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

Lusaka - A woman raped and then strangled, a house broken into and all the occupants shot dead, a grandmother and her three grandchildren found murdered with some of their organs missing, and a jilted woman pours boiling cooking oil on her lover to "teach him a lesson".

An increase in such grisly crimes has Zambians split in their opinions as to the abolishment of the death penalty. Whenever the subject is discussed, no conclusive resolution is reached with often the only agreement being to agree to disagree.

Since the declaration of Zambia as a Christian nation when the Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) came into power in 1991, there has been pressure on the government to abolish the 'un-Christian' death penalty. This 'Christian voice' however, was not loud enough when the Constitution Review Commission sat to receive submissions reviewing the republican constitution in 1992-94. The death penalty was retained for those convicted of treason, murder or aggravated robbery. 

Six years were to pass, however, before President Chiluba would assent to the first executions. In January this year, along with the release of some 600 prisoners in a presidential amnesty to mark the opening of parliament, the announcement was made of the execution of eight convicts. The Zambia charter of Amnesty International condemned the executions, as did some other local human rights organisations, saying the age of capital punishment was long gone and Zambia too should do away with it.

Today the debate is becoming more tense. The Christian community is pressuring for the abolition of the "inhuman and barbaric" practice while pressure from the opposing view seems too strong to be ignored by the government. Father Peter Henroit of the Jesuit Centre for Theological Reflection said: "the resumption of capital executions is unnecessary and is not in agreement with basic Christian values nor with the justice and peace of the Gospel of Jesus." He said the death penalty cannot serve as a deterrent to criminal activity because "there is no proven connection between executing criminals and restraining or preventing future criminal activity."

He also said that the agony of the innocent subjected to violent crime is not lessened by "violently killing other persons". Executions in Zambia are by hanging. Father Henroit contends that "official killings" are an affront against the human dignity of both those on whom this is inflicted and those in whose name it is employed. He also argues that capital punishment is sometimes effected on innocent people and, seemingly, especially the poorer members of society who cannot afford competent legal defence in court proceedings.

He says that the death penalty has no place in modern standards of governance and that Zambia should take a leaf from South Africa which abolished the death penalty with the fall of apartheid. "Executions occur today only in dictatorial states such as Nigeria, fundamentalist states such as Saudi Arabia and violent states such as the USA."

He points out that as a Christian state, Zambia should adhere to Bible principles and teachings which include compassion, forgiveness of sinners, forgiveness of enemies, being non-vengeful, non-condemning and non-violent. He notes: "Surely in a country like Zambia that claims to be a Christian nation, the execution by the death penalty has no place whatsoever."

A renowned psychiatrist agrees that the death penalty must be abolished. Not so much because Zambia is Christian nation, but because, he believes, a majority of persons convicted commit the crimes when they are not in the right frame of mind. Professor Haworth, who has dealt with the cases of over 250 death row convicts, notes that from the time a person commits a crime to the time that he or she is hanged, there is a notable difference in character. This, he contends, reflects that the person being sent to the gallows is not necessarily the same person (mentally), who committed the crime. Among the death-row convicts who have gone through his therapy is Edward Shamwana who was convicted for treason but pardoned by then president, Kenneth Kaunda, in 1991. Shamwana is now chairman of one of Zambia major opposition political parties, the National Party, and a renowned lawyer.

A representative of the Law Development Commission says that Zambians should not be driven by the motive of revenge but should reflect on the consequences of such a punishment. Dr Kabange Sipula argues that capital punishment "is the ultimate organised crime by the state" and should be done away with. He agrees with Father Henriot that "democracy is about a gentle society". He adds that "judges are not mortal gods who know what is best for human life".

But those in support of the death penalty are just as vehement. A Lusaka lawyer, John Kasaila, argues that the only solution to the control of murder is by killing those who commit the crimes because for now there was no other way out.

Another lawyer, Lee Habasonda, agrees and adds that Zambia is not ready for the abolition of capital punishment. He says: "We are a poor country. We cannot maintain a prison on the expense of innocent people." He argues that a person who has no respect for another person's life does not deserve to live. He adds: "Until such a time when Zambia attains a level of (financial) stability, we cannot import the concept (of abolishing capital punishment). Executions are not a new or strange thing, but a form of cleansing of unnecessary characters."

A senior member of the ruling MMD also argues for the maintaining of the death penalty. Paul Tembo, the MMD national vice-secretary and a former deputy finance minister, says there is no proof that prisons in Zambia serve as reformatories. He says that prison in Zambia is meant to punish convicts and so saw no reason why someone sentenced to death should be kept in prison for long. Tembo, a Christian, also points out that it was also important to consider what effect the keeping alive of a convict would be on a society that knows this person as a serial killer.

Another lawyer, Richard Mukelabai, who was a commissioner of the Constitution Review Commission, is even more angry with those who contend that executions should be abolished. He says: "These criminals are lucky I don't have a gun. Every Zambian must be armed to protect himself otherwise Zambia will operate by the law of the jungle." But Professor Haworth argues that the best way of reducing crime in the country is not by arming its citizens, but by having a well-managed and well-equipped police force.

The ordinary Zambian has, however, taken the issue in his own hands as has been witnessed recently when the death penalty was effected without having to take culprits to court. Robbery suspects, if caught, are usually beaten or burnt to death if the police do not arrive on the scene on time to save them. Although cases of mob justice, especially that of burning suspects, is somewhat on the wane, many people still believe in beating up thieves, or killing them if possible, because of the dissatisfaction with some court sentences.

While government is concerned about the evident rise in murder cases, it is also hearing the cry to abolish the death penalty. And this especially with Zambia being a signatory to the international covenant on civil and political rights which supports the right to life and in consequence the abolition of the death penalty.

Between 1991 and 1995, 3,488 persons were murdered and of these only 167 were female victims. During the same period, those killed by firearms was 1, 915 and aggravated robberies recorded totalled 14,621.

Ministry of Home Affairs permanent secretary, Kalambo Mwansa, notes that since Zambia is a signatory to the covenant, "it is under obligation to progressively bring about the abolition of the death penalty, but this should be done by also ensuring that measures to satisfactorily protect and compensate victims of crime and abuse of power are progressively implemented as required by international law."

The progress in which this law is implemented, however, remains to be seen. Although the MMD government has an overwhelming majority in parliament, a position which would normally pave the way for an easy enactment of a law to abolish the death penalty, the circumstances over the issue are not, per se, political. There are bound to be deep divisions, and arguments, for or against, would be across political allegiances. Against this background, it may still be some time before Zambia finally abolishes the death penalty.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

11 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


Ethiopia;
Alleged Red Terror perpetrators face trial


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Thirty-three people accused of alleged involvement in the murder and brutal physical damage of many persons here in Woreda 25 of the capital were tried yesterday at the Federal High Court.

The alleged culprits include Ato Muluneh Mengistu, then chairman of the woreda revolutionary guard and member of the campaign coordination committee. 

The first bench of the Federal High Court levelled 15 different types of charges against the alleged culprits whom it accused of totally or partially murdering members of a certain political circle by organising campaign coordination committee authority in the woreda.

According to the charge document of the Special Prosecutor, the defendants had prepared investigation and torturing centres in all kebeles in the woreda, organised search and death squads and thereby accused internal and external bodily harms to persons.

Among the defendants are two women who, the Special Prosecutor believes, had allegedly caused severe bodily harm to persons by slashing them tying hand-to-leg.

The court, based on the demand of defendants for government-sponsored defence lawyers, has ordered the Prison Administration to prove whether the persons are financially capable to hire lawyers.

The Special Prosecutor said only 22 of the accused were present at yesterday's court proceeding, urging that arrest warrants be issued to police to bring the remaining ones to a court of justice.

The court has accepted the appeal on the issuance of arrest warrants and adjourned the trial to May 30.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

12 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


South Africa;
Tutu Launches Statement-Taking Programme


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, chairperson of the Truth And Reconciliation Commission, on the launch of the TRC's designated statement-taking programme in Durban, April 1, 1997.

The Truth and Reconciliation Commission today announces a major drive to ensure that every South African who was a victim of a gross violations of human rights during the apartheid era has an opportunity to relate his or her story to the Commission.

The Commission is using R2,4 million in donor funding to enter into partnerships with Non-Governmental Organisations around the country so that we can launch an extensive campaign to gather statements from people in communities throughout the country.

Between now and the end of June, up to 300 "Designated Statement-Takers" from NGOs will join the TRC's statement-takers in reaching out to thousands of South Africans. Until now, most of the approximately 9,000 statements which have been given to the Commission have been collected by our own statement-takers. Individuals will also be able to fill out statement forms on their own. 

The campaign will help the Commission to fulfil the mandate laid down by Parliament in the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act. This law, which established the Commission, requires us to --

Establish "as complete a picture as possible of the causes, nature and extent of gross violation of human rights" during the apartheid era, and to Facilitate "the gathering of information and the receiving of evidence from any person, including persons claiming to be victims of such violations..."

While most people know the Commission through the widely-publicised hearings in which victims relate their experiences, in fact the public hearings make up only one part of the work of the Human Rights Violations Committee. For every one person who gives testimony, there are five others who have given us statements.

Every statement given to the Commission enjoys the same status, whether or not the person who has made it appears at a hearing. Most important in the long term, it is the making of an accurate statement to the Commission -- and not an appearance at a public hearing -- which qualifies a victim to be taken into account for the reparations and rehabilitation measures which Parliament will decide upon after the Commission finishes its work.

The DST programme will be co-ordinated by a Community Liaison Officer in each of the Commission's four regional offices. It is being made possible by funding provided by the Ministry of the Flemish Community of Belgium, and we thank the Belgian Government -- and its Ambassador in South Africa -- warmly for their support. We are particularly grateful for their concern that everyone making a statement should be able to do so in their mother tongue.

Based on the experience of our own statement-takers, the Designated Statement Takers from NGOs will be trained to receive the stories of people's experiences. These DSTs will be based in the offices of the relevant local organisations and will therefore be more accessible to members of the public. People will be able to recount their experiences in their preferred language, and the DSTs will record them in English in the necessary format for the date- processing requirements of the Commission.

We are deeply grateful for the willingness of NGOs to enter into agreements with us to carry out this campaign. It is an indication of the premium we place on our relationship with NGOs -- and of our belief in their central role in civil society -- that we are relying largely on them for the implementation of this crucial project.

The TRC is approaching the final stages of its term of operation. It is now more important than ever that every person, institution and organisation which may have information about gross violations of human rights furnishes it to us without delay. If we are to present as complete a picture as possible about gross violations of human rights, then individuals, NGOs, political parties and community organisations must make information at their disposal available to us.

The Commission has deliberately chosen KwaZulu-Natal for the launch of this project, because it is here in particular that we have found that people have been slow to come forward to make statements, either because they are fearful or because of the remoteness of some areas from urban centres.

We have made some important progress in persuading the Inkatha Freedom Party to assist by presenting their viewpoints to us: the leader of the IFP made an extensive presentation to us last year; IFP members, albeit in limited numbers, have made statements about the violations they have suffered; and recently we had a breakthrough when IFP members on the East Rand came forward to give us their perspectives on that conflict. In addition, the IFP will encourage its members to come forward to be considered for reparation and rehabilitation measures.

However, we have also had setbacks: we have had to cancel a special hearing devoted to atrocities carried out by ANC supporters in KwaZulu-Natal because of lack of co-operation from within IFP structures. This hearing, scheduled for this month, was to have been the first devoted solely to violations committed by supporters of one party.

The Commission does not belong to the Commissioners, or to any group, or even to the parties which constituted the Government of National Unity when the Commission was established. It belongs to the nation, and it is the nation's instrument for building national unity and reconciliation. We cannot present a balanced picture of the past if we receive information only from a limited range of sources or organisations.

We make a special appeal to those who have not yet done so: come and make your statement to the Commission.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 1, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Zaire Emergency Fact Sheet No. 7


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency for International Development, Bureau For Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) , ZAIRE - Complex Emergency, Fact Sheet 7, Fiscal Year (FY) 1997 April 1, 1997. Note: The last fact sheet was dated March 27, 1997.

Background: In mid-October, 1996 fighting broke out in South Kivu, Zaire between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance) led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting spread north, west, and south, with the Alliance gaining territory on all fronts. 

The Alliance now controls the eastern fifth of Zaire. On March 15, the Alliance captured Kisangani, an important commercial and strategic military center and forces are advancing towards Lubumbashi. Both President Mobutu Sese Seko and Kabila sent representatives to an OAU summit on Zaire which began on March 26 in Lome, Togo. Both sides agreed in principle to a ceasefire and negotiations, subject to consultations with authorities in Zaire.

Numbers Affected: The initial fighting caused Rwandan and Burundian refugees to flee, forcing over 890,000 Rwandans to return to Rwanda, 64,000 Burundians to repatriate and hundreds of thousands of refugees to flee west, scattering in small groups deeper into Zaire. There are 39,000 registered internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Kisangani. Missionary sources report that 4,000 IDPs have left Kisangani to return home.

Recent estimates of the scattered refugee concentrations include: 6,000 - 8, 000 in Punia; up to 3,000 in Lodja, 250 km west of Kindu; 274 in Tingi Tingi camp; and another 1,700 in Amisi. Refugees are clustered at three main points along the 125 km rail line west of the Zaire river: approximately 26,000 are gathered at Lula, seven km south of Kisangani; some 25,000 are clustered at the village of Kisesa, near km 25; and another 30,000, including several thousand unaccompanied children, are at the Village of Bar, near km 41. Local villagers report that less than 100 refugees remain between km 52 and km 82. Press sources reported on March 31 that approximately 30,000 Rwandan refugees appeared 50 km west of Goma.

Current Humanitarian Situation: The refugees at Lula are in relatively good condition and have received food and water. However, Alliance military authorities insist that the refugees must be moved further south for security reasons. At km 25, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) are developing water sources and providing medical services to refugees. Many of the refugees at km 41 appear severely malnourished and are unable to walk any farther.

Very few refugees there have cooking posts, plastic sheeting, and other personal items. The U.N. World Food Program (WFP) provided dry food rations to the refugees at km 41 on March 30 via the local Red Cross. At km 52, two small family units are receiving WFP rations, water, and other assistance from local church groups.

On March 31, a medical team was sent to retrieve refugees south of km 52, who are reportedly in serious condition. According to refugees, the former Rwandan army (ex-FAR) and Interahamwe militia members have separated from the refugees gathered along the rail line.

WFP reports sufficient food stocks, including a barge which is traveling up the Zaire river toward Kisangani, with 260 metric tons (MT) of food. The foraging of the refugees, ex-FAR, and Interahamwe affected villages between Ubundu and km 52. WFP plans to provide food for work distributions to affected populations, in exchange for help in improving the road parallel to the railway line. The U.N. Coordinator for eastern Zaire, Filippo Grandi, is seeking Kabila's approval to repatriate refugees by air and road through Kisangani. The Government of Rwanda has requested a tripartite agreement with the Alliance and UNHCR governing the repatriation of refugees. In the meantime, UNHCR is planning the repatriation logistics.

U.S. Government (USG) Assistance: On March 14, USAID's Disaster Assistance Response Team (USAID/DART) arrived in the region to help advance relief efforts in eastern Zaire. USAID/DART has recently installed an information officer in Nairobi and a field officer in Goma. On March 30, USAID/DART visited major refugee concentrations along the railway line south of Kisangani, accompanied by WFP and Alliance officials.

BHR/OFDA and the State Department's Bureau for Population, Refugees, and Migration (State/PRM) have provided funding to the International Committee of the Red Cross to assist internally displaced Zairians and repatriating Rwandan refugees. State/PRM has also approved a $3 million contribution to UNHCR for repatriating refugees. Between December and February, BHR's Office of Food for Peace provided roughly 1600 MT of food to eastern Zaire from the Rwanda Regional Program.

Total OFDA Assistance (to date). . . . . . . . . . . . $5,000,000

Other USG Assistance (to date) . . . . . . . . . . . . $4,750,000

TOTAL USG FY 1997 Humanitarian Assistance (to date) . $9,750,000


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
