Africa News


April 2, 1997


South Africa;
All at sea on our 75th anniversary (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Cape Town - The pitiful state of the SA Navy is graphically illustrated by the armada of modern warships currently in Simon's town for the navy's 75th anniversary celebrations

The arrival of warships from a dozen foreign nations for the SA Navy's 75th anniversary celebrations this week has once again highlighted the depths to which our once proud maritime service has sunk. When it comes to equipment, that is. 

Some of the world's great maritime powers such as the United States, Britain, France and Russia will be represented.

>From the southern hemisphere, Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay are among those who will take part.

All these nations have provided modern frigates or corvettes for the international fleet review in Table Bay on April 5.

South Africa, by contrast, can muster only its ageing strike craft and a variety of service vessels. President Mandela, foreign navy chiefs and other dignitaries will view the flotilla of ships from SAS Protea, a hydrographic survey vessel. Quite clearly, South Africa will be Cinderella at its own ball.

The South African Navy needs new equipment urgently and it is not merely a matter of appearances.

This country has a vast coastline to patrol, harbours and priceless resources to protect.

While the navy remains in its present moribund state, foreign nations are free to plunder our fishing resources with impunity, ships transporting cargo such as dangerous nuclear waste can defy international territorial limits and we are pressed beyond limits to fulfil our international obligations in respect of sea rescues.

With 75 years of proud tradition behind it, the SA Navy is the logical service to undertake all these duties. But it must get modern equipment.

If not, this week's celebrations could well translate into a wake.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 2, 1997


Business and Finance;
Unit trust investors pay more as VAT imposed


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Unit trust investors will be paying more for their investment from this month.

Since yesterday, the cost of buying unit trusts has risen following the Government's decision to impose Value Added Tax (VAT) on initial charges levied by unit trust management companies, bringing the amount to a maximum of 5,462 percent from 5 percent.

VAT will be imposed on two thirds of the initial charge levied. 

Association of Unit Trusts executive director Colin Woodin told the Cape Argus that the increase in initial charges would not affect investors severely because the marketable securities tax on share transactions had also been reduced at the same time.

The effect of the imposition of VAT on investors was smaller than the cuts in marketable securities tax, which had been reduced from 1,5 percent to 0,25 percent over the past few years, he said.

The marketable securities tax is the amount investors pay when they purchase shares, and the initial charge "is that part of the selling price that the investor pays for his units which covers the costs to the management company of marketing the trust," Mr Woodin said.

"It is going to cost the investor that little bit more to buy units," he said.

Mr Woodin said the investor who spent R100 a month on unit trusts would now pay R5,46 to cover the management company's marketing costs.

Investors who made big investments could negotiate lower rates, Mr Woodin said.

He explained that the calculation of VAT on initial charges was the result of long negotiations between the Association of Unit Trusts and the revenue authorities and recognised the work done by the unit trust management companies.

"The Government is insisting that VAT is applied to anything where work is done or value added to something," Mr Woodin said.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


38 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 2, 1997


Chad;
Amnesty Says 'Hope Betrayed' in Chad


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

London - Despite the repeated promises of the Chadian government, 1996 and the first months of this year have been marked by an increase in human rights violations, Amnesty International said today in its new report entitled, Chad: Hope betrayed, made public following the recommendation of the working group of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to keep the examination of the human rights situation in Chad in the confidential procedure for another year.

In its report, the organization points out the institutionalization of the practice of extrajudicial executions. In November 1996, a written instruction by the Commander of the Specialized Units of the gendarmerie ordered the security forces to "eliminate any suspected thief". This instruction received on several occasions the support of the state's highest authorities. Scores of people have been extrajudicially executed over the course of the last few months. 

Only after the adoption of a resolution by the European Parliament condemning extrajudicial executions in Chad did the Chadian Prime Minister, Koibla Djimasta, announce on Radio France International(RFI), that the measure was no longer in force. However, despite this, the practice of these illegal acts has not stopped. Information received by Amnesty International confirms that extrajudicial executions are continuing, in secret, after dark. At the beginning of March 1997 several bodies were found in the river Chari.

"For many years, hundreds of men and women, including Bichara Digui, a political opponent, have been killed and not one perpetrator of these violations has been brought to justice," Amnesty International said.

The phenomenon of "disappearances" has continued. The organization has received no news of four people, including Ibrahim Souleymane, who " disappeared" in August 1996 after being handed over to the Chadian authorities by the Sudanese authorities.

People continue to be held without trial, despite several protests by Amnesty International and other human rights organisations. Several people, including Job Mbanboungue, a Gendarmerie warrant officer, and Abel Djimon, a clerk in the public prosecutor's department, have been held without charge since November 1996; they are suspected of having distributed the written instruction of the Commander of the Gendarmerie to physically eliminate those accused of theft. Amnesty International considers these detainees to be prisoners of conscience.

Scores of people have been detained without charge or trial at Faya Largeau since 1995. During its April 1996 mission, Amnesty International again raised its concerns in relation to these arbitrary arrests followed by torture and ill-treatment. Despite the assurances of the Minister of Justice that he would investigate the circumstances of the arrests and that the detainees would be released if no charges were being brought against them, these people are still detained without charge or trial.

A number of human rights defenders, including members of the movement, Tchad Non Violence, Chad Non Violence and the Ligue tchadienne des droits de l'homme (LTDH), Chadian Human Rights League, continue to be harassed by the security forces. Some, including Abdallah Issa Idriss, president of the regional branch of the LTDH at Faya Largeau have received death threats, Lazare Tikri Serge, General Secretary of Tchad Non Violence was attacked by members of the Agence nationale de securite (ANS), National Security Agency. He was accused by the ANS of being a spy after he refused to go with them to the Gendarmerie. In February in Moundou, Firmin Nengomnang, a member of the LTDH, was beaten with rifle butts and threatened with execution by members of Chadian security forces.

Amnesty International has received many new testimonies of routine recourse to torture and ill-treatment, including rape. This practice has increased since the order given to the security forces to kill suspected thieves. In Moundou, in Logone Occidental, at least three young women were raped by members of the security forces between September and December 1996. Three prisoners who escaped from prison at Faya Largeau told Amnesty International that during the first three months of their detention they were tied "with chains and were not allowed outside". Several victims of extrajudicial execution bore signs of torture.

Inhuman conditions of detention and ill-treatment after arrest are often the cause of death of detainees. In November 1996, Mahamat Ahmat Hanat was tortured to death at the Fourth District police station in N'Djamena. When the security forces realized that the prisoner had died of his injuries, they left him without explanation at the central hospital mortuary.

Amnesty International also condemns human rights abuses committed by armed opposition groups. The Forces armees pour la Republique federale (FARF), Armed Forces for a Federal Republic, are accused of having tortured and killed several civilians, including two women, in the two Logone regions over the last six months.

In October 1996, the organization published a document on Chad entitled, Chad: A country under the arbitrary rule of the security forces with the tacit consent of other countries, which criticized other governments, including those of China, France, Sudan and the USA, with regard to security and police transfers that have contributed to human rights violations in Chad. In December, the French authorities informed Amnesty International in a letter that France had ceased to supply weapons and ammunition to the Chadian army years ago and that the human rights situation had considerably improved in the country.

"French security equipment -- such as handcuffs, vehicles, telecommunications systems -- are constantly used in Chad and contributes to human rights violations," Amnesty International said.

New testimonies received by the organisation show prisoners, including prisoners of conscience, being forced to do work for the French military aid mission at Faya Largeau.

The organization calls on the Chadian authorities to take all necessary steps to build a state of law and to release all prisoners of conscience.

"The Commission for Human Rights at its next meeting in April should examine the human rights situation of Chad through the public procedure," Amnesty International said.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


39 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Finance Ministers Conclude Addis Meeting


BYLINE: UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2987 words


 

Addis Ababa - The sixth session of the African Ministers of Finance came to an end here at the headquarters of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA) after three days of exhausting deliberations whose implications have the potential for bringing about a sea-change in the way Africa does business.

Financial reforms and the debt overhang provided the framework for Ministers' debate. They were joined by the World Bank, the IMF and the African Development Bank (ADB) and leaders of capital markets and banks from around the world. Among them: Stanley Morgan, Lehman Brothers, the International Bank of Settlements (BIS) and the Nordic Investment Bank (NIB).

Visible as in no other conference in the history of ECA, managers of emerging African stock exchanges brushed shoulders with governors of central African banks and academicians. The Conference adopted two resolutions and a declaration. 

Resolution 1: Growth and development finance in Africa and financial sector reforms

The Conference of African Ministers of Finance,

Aware of the importance of the financial sector in Africa, its fragile nature in most African countries, and the need to enhance its role both in the mobilization of domestic and external resources,

Recognizing the importance of continuing with the implementation of and deepening financial sector reforms in many of our countries, the need for enhanced autonomy of central banks and the importance for coordination between monetary and fiscal policy,

Noting the important role capital markets are playing in other regions of the world in the mobilization of domestic and external resources needed to support the development process and in attracting foreign investment,

Conscious of the fact that a reformed, efficient and buoyant financial sector can substantially contribute to the development of a country and its integration into international financial markets,

Aware of the importance of micro-financing to the alleviation of poverty in the region,

Recalling resolution annex II on the "Problematique of financing the development process in Africa" adopted by the fifth session of the Conference of African Ministers of Finance in March 1994 in Libreville, Gabon which called upon African countries to intensify efforts to improve the institutional framework needed for effective intermediation in African countries and resolution 2(IV) on "The role of indigenous banking and financial institutions in the mobilization of financial resources for development" adopted by the fourth session of the Conference in December 1991 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia,

Having reviewed the state of development finance in Africa and noted the decline in traditional sources of foreign assistance to the continent and the need to find substitute sources of funding for their development process,

Considering the dependency of the majority of African countries on external assistance and that official development assistance to African countries has in recent years either declined or stagnated in real terms,

1. Urges African countries to continue with their economic and financial reforms, with a view to achieving sustainable development for their economies and for their effective integration in the world economy and among themselves;

2. Calls upon African countries to implement appropriate measures to reduce gradually their heavy dependency on external financing and to improve mobilization of domestic savings and non-debt creating flows and to explore the potentials for privatization as a way of promoting the development of capital markets;

3. Urges African countries to adopt internationally accepted best practices with regard to management, prudential supervision and regulation of their banks and non-bank financial institutions;

4. Welcomes the steps taken by a number of African countries to improve the efficiency and transparency in the management of their money and capital markets and to create new ones where they do not exist;

5. Further calls upon African countries to intensify their efforts in deepening and broadening and strengthening the process of financial intermediation in their countries;

6. Encourages African countries to establish regional stock markets, particularly where individual countries lack the capacity to establish their own;

7. Appeals to the international community to step up significantly their financial support to African countries in the implementation of their economic and financial reforms ;

8. Urges the Economic Commission for Africa, the Organization of African Unity and the African Development Bank to continue to assist African countries, in collaboration with other agencies including the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, in their mobilization of domestic and external resources needed to support development, financial sector reforms and in the development of their money and capital markets;

9. Urges the international community to assist African countries in building the human capacities and statistical capabilities needed for economic advancement;

10. Appeals to the international community to assist African countries with financial support in building micro-financing institutions.

Resolution 2: The debt problem and its impact on Africa's development process

The Conference of African Ministers of Finance,

Concerned that despite notable efforts made by African countries to reform their economies and the support of the international community, the debt problem continues to be a major constraint on the economic and social development of many African countries,

Considering the amount of resources devoted by African countries to servicing their external debts which could be used for the development of their social sectors and improvement of their infrastructures,

Aware of the impact of the debt overhang on the continent's capabilities to attract non-debt creating flows, and in particular foreign direct investment,

Noting that official development assistance to African countries has either declined or stagnated in real terms,

Recalling resolution I(IV) on the "African debt problem" adopted by the fourth session of the Conference of African Ministers of Finance in December 1991 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia and resolution annex I on the "Treatment of the debt of African countries" adopted by the fifth session of the Conference in March 1994 in Libreville, Gabon as well as the declaration on "Africa's external debt" adopted by the ECA Conference of Ministers in May 1995 all of which urged African countries and their development partners to find a lasting solution to the problem within the framework of promoting sustainable development in Africa,

Further recalling the various resolutions of African Heads of State and Government and the United Nations General Assembly on the same issue,

Appreciative of the efforts of the multilateral institutions and the international community to assist in finding a lasting solution to this problem as partially reflected in the Initiative for the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPCs) launched in 1996 by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund,

Considering that a lasting solution to the African debt problem can be achieved in the context of a broad framework of budgetary discipline and prudence, proper recording and development of debt management capacity, donor assistance and resetting national priorities and for providing significant resources to these countries which will assist them to achieve sustainable growth and development and thereby enable them to move out of the debt and poverty trap,

1. Calls upon African countries in collaboration with the international community and multilateral institutions to intensify their efforts to find a durable solution to the problem;

2. Commit ourselves to continue with economic and financial reforms, enhance our debt and macroeconomic management capacities and the exchange of information on debt management, in order to contribute to the achievement of debt sustainability in our countries;

3. Urges the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the African Development Bank and other multilateral institutions to exercise more flexibility in particular with respect to the stringency of the ratio of total debt in net present value terms to exports in eligibility conditions for access to the HIPC Initiative in order to allow as many reforming African countries as possible access to the facility;

4. Stresses the importance of advancing the completion point for countries with a demonstrated record of a strong performance record over a prolonger period;

5. Appeals to the non-Paris Club bilateral creditors to take effective measures to reduce the stock of debt of African countries owed to them;

6. Further appeals to the multilateral financial institutions and international community to continue to support African countries with concessional financing including grants necessary for them to accelerate the pace of economic and social development and rehabilitate their social sectors, especially education and health, and improve their infrastructures.

ADDIS ABABA DECLARATION OF THE AFRICAN MINISTERS OF FINANCE ON GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT FINANCE IN AFRICA AT THE TURN OF THE CENTURY, FINANCIAL SECTOR REFORMS AND THE AFRICAN DEBT PROBLEM

We, the African Ministers of Finance gathered at Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, from 31 March to 2 April 1997, for the sixth session of the Conference of African Ministers of Finance, have reviewed the state of development finance, financial sector reforms and the African debt problem.

Within this context, we have undertaken a constructive dialogue with our development partners on a number of developmental issues of importance to our continent.

Furthermore, we have reaffirmed our commitment to economic and financial sector reforms, and in collaboration with our development partners, to finding a lasting solution to the African debt problem.

The important issues discussed included the role of multilateral financial institutions and bilateral creditors in Africa's development; financial sector reforms and the development of capital markets, within the framework of mobilization of resources needed to support Africa's development; and the continuing debt problems of African countries.

We acknowledge that in view of the weakening of traditional sources of development support and mechanisms for channelling financial aid, the conspicuous challenge that will face many of our countries will be finding substitute financing needed to spur growth and to reduce poverty.

We are aware that the challenging task of mobilizing domestic resources and attracting foreign investment will have to be intensified for gross domestic savings rates to be raised to higher levels needed to support a higher level of investment and growth. The need for reforming our financial sectors and developing viable money and capital markets has therefore to be perceived in the context of both raising domestic savings ratios and attracting foreign investment. Accordingly, the deepening and broadening of Africa's financial sector and development of efficiently functioning capital markets will need to be a major priority as Africa moves to the twenty-first century.

We acknowledge the role multilateral financial institutions have played in assisting Africa to mobilize resources required to support development and in undertaking economic and financial reforms. We urge them to continue to provide a greater proportion of the concessional finance and grants needed to support our infrastructural development and delivery of social services. We also call on them to assist Africa to build the appropriate capacities required for the continent to be able to attract non-debt creating resource flows.

We have also reviewed the African debt situation and noted with concern that despite notable efforts by African countries and the international community to reduce the burden of debt service for African countries, the stock of debt (in net present value terms) to exports ratio continues to increase. The stock of debt is estimated at US$340.5 billion at the end of 1996 and total debt service payments amounted to US$24.0 billion.

It is in this context, that African countries have welcomed the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPCs) Initiative launched by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in September 1996; more also that the Initiative for the first time has provided for relief on multilateral debt. This Initiative is a partial reflection of the commitment of the international community to finding a lasting solution to the African debt problem.

However, the eligibility conditions and debt sustainability analysis for Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative (HIPC) should be more flexible. The HIPC has targeted only 41 countries of which 33 are in Africa and is possible that about half may benefit from the facility. With only 9 African countries from which data is available classified by the World Bank as relatively free of external debt problems and 32 classified as "severely debt distressed", the African debt problem will continue to stifle Africa's development and poverty eradication efforts.

We continue to be concerned that the magnitudes of the debt are obviously unsustainable. African countries continue to devote a large proportion of their resources to servicing their external debts, when their social sectors and infrastructures are in dire need of rehabilitation and reconstruction. We call on our development partners to assist the region in finding practical and lasting solutions to the twin debt and poverty problems.

We acknowledge that in the medium to long term, Africa's development will need to be enhanced by intensifying domestic savings mobilization and local investments efforts complemented by non-debt creating flows, including foreign investment. It is in this respect, that many of our countries have put significant efforts to attract foreign investment, including comprehensive revisions of our investment codes. Liberalized macro economic policies and political reforms currently being implemented are also intended to provide the necessary environment conducive to both local and foreign investment. We commit ourselves to continuing with these reforms and call on the donor community to support our efforts to attract foreign investment as well as opening up their markets to Africa's exports.

The challenges of globalization and liberalization of the world economy as well as financial markets dictate that our countries adapt rapidly to these developments if our continent is to become an effective partner in the international economy. We are committed to the process of ensuring that Africa moves in that direction and call on the international community to supplement our efforts with significant resources and appropriate support.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

April 3, 1997


West Africa;
Faso Compaore Confers With Abacha


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso is in Nigeria on a two-day official visit featuring talks on bilateral and regional affairs with his host, Gen. Sani Abacha, sources at the presidency in Abuja said Thursday. 

After his arrival late Wednesday, Compaore held a closed-door meeting with Abacha.

Nigerian officials said the talks were on how to strengthen socio-economic relations between the countries, both members of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States.

Before returning home, Compaore was also expected to travel Thursday to Nigeria's northern city of Kaduna, to visit the on-going 7th OAU All-Africa trade and tourism fair.

Burkina Faso is among African countries participating at the 10-day exhibition, which winds up on Sunday.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


41 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


Nigeria;
Lagos Authorities Peg House Rents


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The military administration in Lagos has set up 29 tribunals to enforce government-approved rents as part of an effort to protect embattled tenants from greedy landlords in this city, Nigeria's economic hub.

Lagos state Military Administrator Mohammed Marwa administered the oath of office on the tribunal chairmen on Wednesday, after unveiling the Rent Control and Recovery of Premises Edict 1997. It came into effect March 21. 

He described the edict as "citizen-friendly," with provisions that could improve the often strained tenant-landlord relationship. He said it would also improve the demand/supply situation of housing delivery in this city of some six million people with acute accommodation problem.

Marwa said the law was not targeted at landlords or the tenants but would benefit everyone. If everyone cooperated, he added, the tribunals would not have cause to apply the sanctions.

Penalties range from a fine of 20,000 naira to two years in jail for offenders (85 naira = 1 U.S. dollar).

Under the law, it is illegal for a landlord or his agent to demand or receive advance rent in excess of six months from an in-coming tenant, in respect of a one-room and a room and parlour apartment.

A maximum one-year advance rent is stipulated for all other categories of apartment.

Until now, there was no ceiling on advance rent. The result was that some Lagos landlords demand up to five years' advance payment from new tenants. Cases of unlawful eviction of tenants were also rampant.

But the new edict prescribes a 20,000-naira fine or three years in prison for any landlord found guilty of using "tactics of demolishing or modifying a building with a view to ejecting a tenant."

A landlord who presents a "fake tenant" to obtain a court judgment for the ejection of a bona fide tenant can, on conviction, be jailed for two years. The law is silent on any option of fine for this offence.

A landlord who declines rent from a tenant for no justifiable reason would be made to receive the money through the rent tribunal but less a 10-percent penalty surcharge.

The law, which categorizes buildings in Lagos into zones and different rates, applies to accommodation with a yearly rental value not exceeding 250, 000 naira as at 1996.

The fixed rents range between 55 and 60 naira a room in rural areas to 650 naira in metro Lagos. The rents for a three-room apartment range from 1,500 to 10,600 naira a month.

Although many Lagos tenants have welcomed the government move, they warn that implementation could be a problem. They cite previous failed official attempts to peg rents in the city.

Part of the problem with rent edicts in the past was that some desperate tenants even connived with landlords to pay amounts higher than what the law stipulated.

While, the Marwa administration has given an assurance that this would not be the case now, observers say a lasting solution to the perennial accommodation crisis in Lagos would be a deliberate policy, involving both the government and the private sector to make housing more available and at affordable prices.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Human Rights Charter Under Fire


BYLINE: Matilda Moyo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabweans have joined the continent's academics, jurists and human rights activists in advocating changes in the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, which they say is fraught with contradictions.

They note that it is vague and serves the interests of political leaders rather than protect the ordinary citizen for whom it was drafted.

"The heads of state had no other human but themselves in mind when they drafted the charter," said Nicholas Ngwabi, a local activist, at a recent human rights workshop in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city.

The charter, which was analyzed by activists at the workshop, contains provisions which accord certain fundamental rights to individuals and societies to be adhered to by the 41 OAU member states which have ratified it. 

"The document has never been used and looking at it, its easy to see that it is inaccessible to the ordinary man," said Cousin Zilala, the Zimbabwe Human Rights Association education officer.

He points out the case of Nigerian writer and Ogoni activist ken Saro-Wiwa and nine others who were executed by the military regime in 1995 for their activities.

Article 7 of the charter states that "every individual shall have a right to have his cause heard."

There is a general feeling that Saro-Wiwa's case was not adequately attended to.

Zilala said the charter's major weakness is that it contains provisions for compiling reports to a commission made up of 11 members who are appointed by heads of state and endorsed by the entire OAU summit to implement and monitor the charter.

"The members are of the highest reputation, morality, competence, integrity and impartiality," says the charter.

However, critics say because the commission is appointed by heads of state it owes its allegiance to the leadership. They also argue that the requirement that complainants indicate their names, age, profession and address makes them vulnerable to intimidation when the commission's chairman consults the state concerned.

The charter places restriction on continental arbitration in that domestic remedies have to be exhausted before cases of human rights violations are brought before the commission.

"The commission can only deal with a matter submitted to it after making sure that all local remedies, if they exist, have been exhausted unless it is obvious to the commission that the procedure of achieving these remedies would be unduly prolonged," says the document.

Issues of complaint should also not be those already dealt with by member states, leaving no room for those who feel unjustly treated to seek audience with a higher court.

Before each session, the secretary of the commission compiles a list of complaints and transmits them to members of the commission who select the cases to be dealt with. A complaint is only considered if a majority of the commission's members so decide.

Although there is no clear criteria for the selection process on the cases that are considered, the reports should be compatible with the charter, and information should be sourced from personal knowledge not the media.

The charter has no provision for enforcement of the commission's adjudication and plans of an African court have proved not feasible.

Experts say while there is room for states to submit complaints of human rights violations by other states, the mechanism has never been utilized because of the commission's strong links and loyalty to heads of states.

"It seems at the outset to contain absolute rights but then towards the end places limitations and circumstances for derogation," Zilala said.

While article 9 accords individuals the freedom to receive information, express and disseminate their opinions, this should be done "within the law" of the respective country. Article 10 allows freedom of association, but with a proviso that this should be in accordance with the country's law.

The charter gives all people a right to existence and self-determination although it has failed to protect the cause of minority groups.

Zilala said some people have tried to use it as a charter on human and people's rights, but the commission asked them to define what a "people" are, adding that the definition of people can be altered depending on the circumstances.

They liken the charter to the seven commandments in George Orwell's novel, Animal Farm, which eventually justified wrongdoing by the leadership through provisional clauses.

The activists feel the charter, which was drafted in an attempt to uphold human rights within an African context, has failed to fulfill its purpose and it is a shallow echo to the United Nations declaration of human rights.

"The African charter is a non-starter and is totally unrealistic and impractical," said Clemence Moyo, Zimrights Matabeleland regional chairman.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


Southern Africa;
COMESA States Ponder Future Relations With Europe


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) has urged its member-states to propose suitable solutions that will replace the financial assistance to be reviewed by the European Union (EU) by the year 2000.

The organizations acting secretary-general, Erastus Mwencha, said in Lusaka Thursday that it was quite clear from the European Union's green paper that the preferences which COMESA member-states have enjoyed will come to an end in the year 2000. 

Speaking at the opening of the three-day COMESA inter-governmental committee meeting, he said the restructuring of the relationship between the Union and the African Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States was important and requires thorough deliberations.

In September 1998, the 15-member EU is expected to begin formal negotiations on the future relations with its 70 ACP states. Since 1975, the relationship between them has been governed by the Lome Convention which is to cease in year 2000.

Mwencha appealed to the meeting to also study the recommendations by COMESA governors of central banks on the introduction of the COMESA dollar as a new unit of account to replace the PTA (UAPTA) which was phased out in 1996.

The meeting will be followed by the third COMESA council of ministers meetings which will culminate into the summit of heads of state and government scheduled for April 10.

Among the issues to be discussed at the summit are the notices of Lesotho and Mozambique to withdraw from the organisation.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


East Africa;
Postal Services To Speed Up Interstate Cash Delivery


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - East African Postal Administrations would jointly introduce a Speed Cash Interstate Service, effective from this week.

The public relations manager of Tanzania Posts Corporation, Wilfred Miigo, said the service would initially be operated in Dar es Salaam, Nairobi and Kampala.

Miigo said the services would involve cash remittance of an amount not exceeding an equivalent of 300,000 Tanzania shillings (about 500 U.S. dollars) per single order. 

He added that the customer could remit up to two orders per day amounting to 600,000 shillings (1,000 dollars) only using local currencies of Tanzania, Kenya and Uganda in the transaction.

Explaining the procedures, Miigo said a customer in one country would remit cash to another country by using his country's local currency. Payment will be made in local currency of the destination country.

The amount to be paid would be based on the conversion rates issued daily by the respective central banks of each country on the payment day. Cash remitted between the capital cities of East Africa will be paid within 48 hours only.

Miigo said the Tanzania Posts Corporation finalized the formalities of introducing the service, which would initially commence at the Dar Es Salaam General Post Office.

He said that the service would be extended to the department branch offices outside Dar Es Salaam and to regional posts offices after performance evaluation of the service to be undertaken in July 1997.

Miigo also said that the decision to introduce the speed cash interstate service at the three capitals of East Africa was made during the 6th tripartite meeting held in Nairobi, Kenya, March 4 to March 12.

He said the meeting was attended by all Chief Executives of the postal and telecommunications administrations of East Africa with the Tanzania team being led by Postmaster General Suleiman Msofe.

Tanzania Communications Commission, as the regulator of such service in Tanzania, was represented by E.N. Madeje and F.B. Mdachi, a director of Postal Affairs and senior legal officer respectively.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


Zaire;
Annan Lauds African Peace Effort On Zaire


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan has commended African leaders for their efforts to end the five-month war in Zaire, where anti-government forces are trying to overthrow President Mobutu Sese Seko.

"I want to applaud Africa leaders for having come together to try and solve the crisis in Zaire," Annan said in reference to the recent summit of the Organisation of African Unity on conflict resolution in Lome.

"It is a major test for the continent and I applaud their efforts," he said in a live radio programme with broadcasters on five continents, Wednesday. 

During the broadcast, which originated from the studios of U.N. Radio in New York, Annan fielded questions from correspondents of radio stations in Australia, Germany, India, Japan, Kenya, Netherlands, South Africa and the United States.

Annan, who attended the Lome summit, said he was encouraged by the result, and that based on the agreement signed between the Zairian government and the rebels, he expected the parties to agree on a cease-fire and commencement of talks soon.

The U.N. announced Tuesday that the parties had agreed to begin talks in South Africa this weekend.

On the alleged involvement of the government of Angola and the former rebel group Unita in the Zairian crisis, Annan said he had warned both President Eduardo Dos Santos of Angola and Unita leader Jonas Savimbi to stay away from the conflict.

"I have indicated to them how dangerous it would be if they and other governments in the region were to get involved in the conflicts in Zaire.

"They both indicated to me that they were not involved and that they were equally concerned about the developments in Zaire," said Annan, who recently visited Angola as part of his African trip.

Asked about the proposed deployment of U.N. observers to Sierra Leone to help implement the country's peace agreement, Annan said that the deployment would be made as soon as the U.N. was able to secure the consent of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF).

The lack of consent from the rebel group, which signed a peace agreement in 1996 with the Sierra Leonean government, to end five years of civil war, has delayed the deployment.

"I am aware of the change in the leadership of RUF and my special representative in Sierra Leone is in touch with the new leadership," Annan said.

"We have indicated that when the new leadership is established our military experts will brief them on our operational concept and the plans we had in mind for the implementation of the peace process and we will move ahead with the deployment," he added.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Unesco Says Goree Symbolizes Slave Trade


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (Unesco) has re-affirmed that the island of Goree, west of the Senegalese capital, Dakar, is a landmark of the 18th century European slave trade in Africans.

Unesco Director-General Federico Mayor told journalists Wednesday in Dakar that nothing could reverse the historical importance of the island from where thousands of Africans were shipped into servitude across the Atlantic Ocean, by European slave dealers.

Mayor, a Spaniard, was commenting on the recent controversy generated by a section of the French media, which claimed that the importance of Goree in the slave trade had been exaggerated by Senegalese authorities. 

Goree is one of Unesco's World Heritage sites. Mayor likened the island to Hiroshima, in Japan, where thousands of people were killed by United States atomic bombs in the Second World War.

Mayor announced that Unesco had provided 160,000 U.S. dollars for the construction of the Goree-Almadies memorial. This monument is to serve as a permanent symbol of the abominable trade of Africans, now in the diaspora.

Turning to Unesco's "Culture of Peace" projects which have been introduced in several conflict-ridden African countries, Mayor brushed aside arguments that these could not succeed without self sufficiency.

"These are arguments of self-seeking dictatorial elites whose intention is to perpetuate themselves into power," Mayor said.

The peace project got a boost when the U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan spoke of it in his first address.

"This shows that the entire U.N. system is behind the peace culture project, " Mayor said.

The project also enjoys the backing of African states, including Senegal and Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe will become the current chairman of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) in June.

Asked to assess the Culture of Peace Project in Burundi, where there are still reports of ethnic killings, Mayor said although Unesco condemned such actions, it was not discouraged.

"Through our House of Peace in Bujumbura, we shall continue to promote dialogue between the various Burundian ethnic groups and encourage free expression for all," he added.

Mayor denounced the suffering innocent Burundian civilians were going through because of the regional sanctions which were imposed in July after Maj. Pierre Buyoya grabbed power in a military coup.

"These people are innocent. Humanitarian assistance must be independent from political considerations," he said.

On his expectations of the ongoing African regional consultation on higher education, Mayor said he expected a consensus on certain principles which will be incorporated into the documents of the 1998 World Conference on Higher Education in Paris.

On the funding of higher education, Mayor said there was need for major African industrialists and other businessmen to join in funding of university research.

While donors were willing to fund university research projects, he said, there was a limit to external aid.

In addition, he said, international donors will find it unacceptable to finance research in countries where governments invested heavily in "weapons of destruction" instead of education.

Mayor was in Dakar for the four-day African Regional Consultation on Higher Education. This meeting is preparing a continental position for next years world conference on the subject, scheduled for September 1998.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


Science and Health;
FHI Study Examines N-9 Effect on STDs


BYLINE: Family Health International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

RESEARCH TRIANGLE PARK, NC - A two-year study to determine whether vaginal contraceptive film containing spermicide used with condoms prevents the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) has concluded that the spermicidal film is safe to use but does not confer any additional protection to women from HIV, gonorrhea or chlamydia infection beyond the protection provided by condoms.

Family Health International (FHI), a nonprofit research organization that specializes in reproductive health, collaborated with the Cameroon Ministry of Public Health to conduct the study in the African country. The research, designed to assess a spermicidal film containing nonoxynol-9 (N-9), did not address whether N-9 film used alone offers STD protection. Ronald E. Roddy, MPH, an FHI epidemiologist, and Leopold Zekeng, PhD, a Cameroon ministry HIV specialist, were the principal investigators. 

Latex condoms offer the best STD protection for people at risk, but many women are unable to persuade their partners to use them. FHI believes protective measures that are used and controlled by women are urgently needed.

"Unfortunately, the news is not good for women, since we had hoped N-9 might increase their available options for HIV protection," said Willard Cates Jr., MD, MPH, FHI's senior vice president for biomedical affairs. "We must accelerate research dedicated to finding new methods for women at risk of HIV and other STDs." HIV is the virus that causes AIDS.

N-9 is available worldwide in many formulations, including foams, gels, suppositories and creams. Women who use diaphragms, for example, typically apply N-9 cream or jelly to the diaphragm, and some latex condom lubricants include N-9. None of these other products were examined in the study. Also, the study only examined women and did not consider whether N-9 film protects men.

The study was supported by a $1.6 million grant from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID). "We believe this is the most thorough examination to date involving an N-9 spermicide and the role spermicides play in protecting women against STDs," said Dr. Cates. (MORE) " This finding raises doubts about the additional benefit from using N-9 film as a prophylactic against STDs with condoms. It does not alter our advice to people who are at risk from infection with HIV or other STDs - they should use latex condoms correctly and consistently," he said. An alternative option for many women is to use the female condom, which may provide STD protection if used consistently and correctly. Abstinence or a mutually monogamous relationship between uninfected partners are the most reliable ways of preventing STD infection, he added.

Earlier, smaller N-9 studies had suggested that N-9 may reduce the risk of bacterial STD infections, but were inconclusive about whether N-9 prevents HIV infections. The new study involved 1,292 sex workers in Cameroon who volunteered at clinics to take part in the study between March 1995 and December 1996. To be eligible, the women could not be infected with HIV at the time they entered the study. Of the eligible volunteers, 478 completed the study who were provided a contraceptive film containing N-9 and 463 completed the study who were provided a placebo film that did not contain a spermicide.

Each woman who asked about participating in the study received counseling to discourage her from continuing as a sex worker (prostitution), an activity that places one at great risk of acquiring HIV or other STD infections.

Volunteer participants who remained at risk were given condoms and urged to use them with every act of intercourse. They received a new supply of condoms frequently, and were examined monthly and treated for infections.

"The Cameroonian study staff strongly urged volunteers to practice safer sex," Dr. Cates said. Volunteers from the cities of Yaounde and Douala received thorough counseling and were asked to return monthly for medical attention, which FHI believes significantly reduced the risks they otherwise would have faced. "Study participants were helped to adopt protected behaviors, which reduced their rate of infection by more than 50 percent," Dr. Cates said.

For the women completing the study, 147,996 acts of sexual intercourse in the group using N-9 film and condoms were compared with 146,942 acts in the group provided with the placebo film and condoms. The rate of HIV transmission was nearly the same for both groups. For 100 women using N-9 film and condoms for one year (100 woman-years), 6.7 became infected with HIV, compared with 6.6 HIV infections using the placebo film and condoms.

The comparable rates for gonorrhea infections were 33.3 infections for N-9 and condoms to 31.1 for placebo film and condoms per 100 woman-years. Infection rates for chlamydia were 20.6 for N-9 and condoms and 22.2 for placebo film and condoms per 100 woman-years. (MORE) A theoretical concern has been whether frequent use of N-9 may increase the risk of STD infections, since frequent use of the chemical may cause sores that could enhance transmission. Women in the study reported using the film more frequently than do most women who use N-9. This study did not show any increased risk of HIV or other STD infections from using N-9 film, although genital lesions (sores) did occur slightly more often among women who used N-9. There were 42.2 lesions per 100 woman-years among women using N-9 and condoms, compared with 33.5 lesions among women using the placebo film and condoms.

The study has certain limitations. Because of the paramount concern for the safety of participants, they were counseled to use condoms every time they had sex, the only proven method of protection. Since few women reported using film without condoms, the study cannot conclusively address whether N-9 film alone offers any protection from HIV or other STDs.

Worldwide, about two thirds of all HIV-infected people live in the sub- Saharan region of Africa. One benefit of the study, Dr. Cates said, is that it demonstrates that HIV prevention research among people at high risk of infection can be done according to the highest ethical standards.

Based in North Carolina, FHI is a research and technical assistance organization dedicated to improving reproductive health worldwide, with an emphasis on developing countries. The film used in the study is made by Apothecus Pharmaceutical Corp., Oyster Bay, NY and is available under the brand name of VCF Vaginal Contraceptive Film.

For more information, please contact: Nash Herndon, FHI, 919-544-7040; Pat Randall, NIAID, 301-496-5717; Deborah Santemma, Apothecus Pharmaceutical Corp; 800-227-2393. This release is available at FHI's website at http://www.fhi. org/general/newsrel.html


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 3, 1997


Ethiopia;
650,000 people to get access to medical services


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

BAHIR DAR (ENA) - More than 650,000 people in the Amhara Regional State are to get access to medical services next year in their respective localities, the regional health bureau said.

Head of the bureau, Dr. Girma Kebede said 124 medical centres are under construction in farmers villages at a cost of 10.7 million birr allocated by the government, the social rehabilitation and development fund and the Amhara Development Association. 

He said the health services coverage in the region would reach 41 per cent from the current 37 per cent when the construction of some of the health centres completed next June.

According to Dr. Girma, the construction of the Akesta and Sekota hospitals which began two years ago is to be completed next month while an agreement is to be signed with a new contractor to finish the work of the Mota Hosptial.

Meanwhile, an auction is being held for the construction of a hospital and nine health stations in different towns of the region at a cost of over 13.7 million birr.

Only nine hospitals, 53 health stations and 564 clinics are rendering medical services to the more than 14 million people of the region.

Torrential rains kill cattle

DIRE DAWA (ENA) - An unknown number of head of cattle were killed by torrential rains in Erer woreda, Shenele zone.

The woreda council said the unspecified head of cattle died because they were unable to resist the rains accompanied by hail-storm for their resistance had been weakened due to lack of fodder and drink caused by drought.

An animal disease which broke out after three consecutive days of rain in the area, is killing domestic animals, said Ato Abdi Gisale of the woreda council.

Africa News


April 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Private sector capital rises by 15.2 billion birr in Addis


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Addis Ababa regional trade industry and tourism bureau said the capital of the private sector has shown an increase of 15.2 billion birr over the past four years.

The capital was less than 2 billion birr four years ago, the bureau said adding the boom was mainly due to the new economic policy and the mushrooming of joint stock companies. 

Ato Estifanos Senbeta, head of the bureau, told ENA the trend that signifies a fast increase of money circulation in the economy is very encouraging.

Within the period of four years, Ato Estifanos said, the private industrial sector capital has grown to 8.7 billion from the initial 1.1 billion birr.

The aggregate capital of companies engaged in non-industrial sector has grown from 500 million to 7.1 billion birr while that of individual businessmen increased to 1.4 billion from the initial 300 million birr, Ato Estifanos said.

April 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia's Tourism Potential 'Not Properly Exploited'


BYLINE: Derese/T/Wold, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - A senior official of the Ethiopian Tourism commission ways that although the tourism industry in Organized form dates back to three decades, not enough was done to properly exploit the tremendous potential which it represents due to various man-made and natural constraints.

Ato Yousuf Abdulahi, the Commissioner, observed when opening a two-day Ethiopian Hotels and Restaurant Association workshop at the Ghion Hotel here yesterday that on account of the government's free market economy numerous private hotels and tour operators are engaged in the industry and helping revamp the sector. 

Ato Yousuf urged the participants to live up to their task by improving their services, developing their services, developing legal working relationships with concerned bodies and regulating service rates.

The purpose of the parley is to explore ways and mean of removing problems encountered in the past. Conference sources were confident that this will be achieved.

Ato Moges Kifle, Chairman of the Association and General Manager of the Ibex Hotel, said on his part that the association was formed three years ago with a view to upgrading local hotel and other catering services by exchanging information and ideas with similar international groups and help alleviate existing problems.

He stressed the need for better quality hotels to accommodate the ever increasing influx of tourists into the country. He was of the view that complaints about too many hotels in the market were quite groundless.

The parley which is expected to end today, will discuss various issues including the vast opportunities for the expansion of the tourism industry, trained manpower and hotel management, the control of illegal tourism trading and problems facing tourists as well as others.

A reliable source within the commission told reporters that more than 107, 000 tourists visited the country in 1996 alone.

Africa News


April 3, 1997


Ethiopia;
Alleged Red Terror perpetrators appear before court


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Alleged Red Terror perpetrators in woredas 1 and 12 here in the capital whom prosecutors accused of committing crimes against suspected members of the EPRP appeared before court yesterday.

The Special Prosecutor accused the defendants of torturing, killing, and forcing suspected EPRP members to roll naked over stinging nettles.

The defendants included Ato Ergete Medibew who was chairman of the Woreda 1 Administration and Revolutionary Campaign Coordinating Committee and 79 others who served at different capacities at woreda and kebele levels. 

The charge filed against the defendants said they committed serious criminals acts including killing, torturing and imprisoning people involved in a certain political circle.

The defendants allegedly cut to death an old man in his neck with a broken glass, inflicted serious damages into external and internal organs of others. They are also accused of allegedly carrying out the Red Terror and other similar campaigns in which many citizens lost their lives, the charge filed by the special Prosecutor said.

The prosecutor accused Ato Ergete Medibew and accomplices for allegedly notoriously shooting many people to death at midnights near the Nigerian Embassy, Habet-Giorgis Bridge, St. John church and Afincho Ber.

The prosecutor also levelled 67 charges against the then chairman of the Woreda 12 urban dwellers association and revolutionary campaign coordinating committee, Ato Shiferaw Metaferia and 46 accomplices.

The charges included the killing of 74 people and causing disability to others.

The prosecutor has made particularly Mulugeta Sebisibe and Kassahun Gebre- Tsadik responsible for the killing of 24 people in September, 1980.

The defendants from Woreda 12 were also accused of forcing Kelemua Tekle to roll naked on stinging nettles, wounding and disabling her by torture, the charge said.

The charge made responsible the defendants for hunging and repeatedly burning Mekonen Assefa in October 1978. the brutality of the defendants made Mekonen to become deaf, loose his teeth, and incapacitated in his spinal cord, the charges said.

The court adjourned the proceeding to May 14 and June 4 on which defendants from Woreda 1 and 12 will be tried respectively.

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - A meeting of jury panel for selecting best inventors of Africa who will be awarded gold medals, opened here yesterday at the African Unity House.

The endeavour, he said, was undertaken in recognition of the role that science and technology plays for the development and socio-economic integration of the who is supervising the renovation indicated.

The house which was designed and built by an Indian architect on 275 square metres of land costs 800,000 birr to be renovated.

Arthur Rambor known for anti-monarchist poems, had been exiled into Aden shortly before he came to Harar as an agent for a French merchant.

Arthur's house in Harar is being visited every year by 2,400 local and foreign tourists.

Sports - Soccer;
Jomo refused to pay SAFA their 10%


BYLINE: Leo Gama, African Eye News Services


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Nelspruit - The Vice- President of SAFA Lowveld, Themba "'Shoes" Shub e has accused Jomo Cosmos boss, Jomo Sono for refusing to pay his association their 10% share from the gate takings during the Africa Cup game played at the Kanyamazane stadium in Nelspruit a forth night ago.

Cosmos hosted Eleven Men in Flight from Swaziland in this game and according to Shube, Sono collected R 54 354 from the gate takings - the association was due to receive R 5 435 which Sono is allegeded to have refused to pay. 

Shube told City Press that Sono told them that Mpumalanga's MEC for Sports( Arts and Culture, Lassy Chiwayo instructed Sono not to pay the association their 10% because his department played a major role in bringing Cosmos to play at the Kanyamazane stadium..

"Sono refused to pay the association stating that he got instructions from Chiwayo not to pay us - to me that is totally unfair because the association also played an important role in arraging the game and besides it is a normal procedure that the association receives a 10% share in any game at the stadium.

"So there is no way that we can give Sono a special treatment here," said Shube.

Africa News


April 3, 1997


South Africa;
69-year-old 'rapist' aquatinted after girl admits to lying


BYLINE: Benjamin Shabalala, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Nelspruit - The Nelspruit Regional Court aquatinted a 69-year-old pensioner of raping his 13-year-old neighbour on Thursday after the man cross questioned the girl himself and got her to admit that she had made up the charges against him.

The 13-year-old girl, who is a minor and may not be identified, told police earlier that the James Shabangu had raped her repeatedly on three consecutive days. 

The girl alleged that every time she went to play with Shabangu's granddaughter, he would send his granddaughter out on errands and drag the 13- year-old into his bedroom to rape her.

The bedroom is only metres from her own house.

During cross-examination, Shabangu asked the girl why, if he had raped her so near home, she had not cried out for help.

He also asked why, if he had raped her over three consecutive days, she had continued to come to his house of her own free will and had not informed her family sooner.

The girl could not answer and under further cross-examination admitted that she had made up the charges at the prompting of her older sister, Zodwa.

She failed to give the court an explanation or motive for making the charges up.

Magistrate Albertus le Roux admonished the girl for wasting the courts time but did not press perjury charges against her. Le Roux ordered that all charges against Shabangu be dropped immediately.

After the hearing, Shabangu told African Eye News Service that "rape IS a problem, but it is an almost universal thing in our communities. Unfortunately that's just the way it is." - African Eye News Service

55 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Zaire Emergency Fact Sheet No. 8


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . ZAIRE - Complex Emergency, Fact Sheet 8, Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, April 3, 1997. Note: The last fact sheet was dated April 1, 1997.

Background: In mid-October, 1996 fighting broke out in South Kivu, Zaire between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance) led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting spread north, west, and south, with the Alliance gaining territory on all fronts. The Alliance now controls the eastern fifth of Zaire. On March 15, the Alliance captured Kisangani. As the Alliance advances towards its next stated goal of Lubumbashi, it has already seized Kamina, a strategic rail junction located to the northwest of Lubumbashi, and Kasenga, 200 km northeast of Lubumbashi. Talks between Alliance and Zairian government authorities are expected to begin in South Africa on April 5. 

Numbers Affected: The initial fighting caused Rwandan and Burundian refugees to flee, forcing over 890,000 Rwandans to return to Rwanda, 64,000 Burundians to repatriate and hundreds of thousands of refugees to flee west, scattering in small groups deeper into Zaire. There were 39,000 registered internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Kisangani and missionary sources report that 4,000 IDPs have left Kisangani to return home. Recent estimates of the scattered refugee concentrations include: 6,000 - 8,000 in Punia; up to 3,000 in Lodja, 250 km west of Kindu; and 1,300 in Mbuji-Mayi, Kasai- Oriental province, with another 8,000 more reportedly en route. At least 80, 000 refugees are clustered in several groups along the 125 km rail line west of the Zaire river between km 19 and 52 south of Kisangani. According to refugees, the former Rwandan army (ex-FAR) and Interahamwe militia members have separated from the refugees gathered along the rail line. On March 31, the United Nations (U.N.) High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported that 20,000 - 30,000 fairly healthy refugees emerged at the village of Karuba, 13 km west of Sake. Another 2,500 emerged at Tongo, west of the former camps of Katale and Kahindo, north of Goma.

Current Humanitarian Situation: On March 31, the Alliance ordered refugees at Lula, seven km from Kisangani, to join refugees located at km 25. Only 700 of the most vulnerable refugees remain at Lula. At km 19 and 25, relief workers set up systems to chlorinate and filtrate water from tributaries of the Zaire river. Many of the refugees at km 41 appear severely malnourished and are unable to walk any farther. Very few refugees there have cooking pots, plastic sheeting, and other personal items. On April 1, a WFP train carried 120 metric tons (MT) of food for refugees concentrated along the rail line. WFP reports sufficient food stocks, including a barge which is traveling up the Zaire river toward Kisangani, with 260 MT of food. UNHCR submitted a plan to the Alliance and to the Government of Rwanda for repatriation of refugees along the rail line, but has not yet received a response. In the meantime, UNHCR has flown 2846 refugees from Tingi Tingi and Amisi to Goma, where they are repatriated and admitted to Gisenyi hospital in Rwanda. UNHCR began trucking the refugees in Karuba and Tongo directly to the Rwandan border on April 1, with 4750 transported on April 1 and 2. In March, 8627 Rwandan refugees repatriated from eastern Zaire. Zairians are also receiving assistance. Foraging by the refugees, ex-FAR, and Interahamwe affected villages between Ubundu and km 52. WFP plans to provide food-for-work distributions to affected Zairian populations, in exchange for help in improving the road parallel to the railway line.

U.S. Government (USG) Assistance: On March 14, USAID's Disaster Assistance Response Team (USAID/DART) arrived in the region to help advance relief efforts in eastern Zaire. USAID/DART installed an information officer in Nairobi and a field officer in Goma. On March 30, USAID/DART visited major refugee concentrations along the railway line south of Kisangani, accompanied by WFP and Alliance officials. Two doctors from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention arrived on April 3 and will be seconded to UNICEF/Goma. BHR/OFDA and the State Department's Bureau for Population, Refugees, and Migration (State/PRM) have provided funding to the International Committee of the Red Cross to assist internally displaced Zairians and repatriating Rwandan refugees. State/PRM has also approved a $3 million contribution to UNHCR for Rwandan refugees repatriating from eastern Zaire. Between December and February, BHR's Office of Food for Peace provided roughly 2,500 MT of food to eastern Zaire from the Rwanda Regional Program.

Total OFDA Assistance (to date). . . . . . . . . . . . $5,000,000

Other USG Assistance (to date) . . . . . . . . . . . . $4,750,000

TOTAL USG FY 1997 Humanitarian Assistance (to date). . $9,750,000


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


South Africa;
Budget battles (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - The Western Cape has defiantly produced its first deficit budget ever, putting it on course for a collision with central government

The Western Cape budget delivered by Finance MEC Mr Kobus Meiring yesterday was, inevitably, bound to say as much about politics in the province as about its fiscus.

In the event Meiring took the unprecedented step of budgeting for a deficit - of R247 million - in a blunt signal that the National Party-dominated provincial government feels it has been unfairly treated.

At issue is the equity formula for allocation of money to the provinces, being applied for the first time this year. Central government argues, in essence, that the formula will address historic imbalances. 

Meiring says that rigid application of the five-year equity plan during a time of low economic growth will kill the proverbial goose that laid the golden egg. The Democratic Party hits out at central government's " mechanistic approach" to the issue.

The ANC in the Western Cape claims that the province's allocation of R2 197 a person this year is above the national average of R 1 755 a person anyway.

Whatever the political arguments, there is little doubt that the ordinary person in the Western Cape will be hit by the budget. There will be fewer hospital beds for the ill, less equipment for schoolchildren (who will be in bigger classes) and an end to many construction projects and the jobs they provide.

One can only hope that central government and the provincial authorities will bear these people in mind as they head for an inevitable clash.

Pretoria can help by ensuring that plans for provincial revenue generation are brought to rapid fruition. And the NP in the Western Cape would do well to reflect on the fact that the province's voters are looking to it to find solutions, not scapegoats.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Black groups' stake in LA Retail grows


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Cape Town - Black empowerment groups are to take a bigger share in fast- growing LA Retail Stores following the clothing chain'sR116-million takeover of Skye Products.

LA Stores managing director AK Peer said told the Cape Argus yesterday that several empowerment groups, including Cape-based Brimstone Investments, the National Empowerment Corporation and the trade-union controlled Community Growth Fund had taken "a nice chunk" of the group's capital through a share issue to fund the deal.

The R115,6-million purchase of Skye will be financed by the issue of 4 million shares at R4,25 each to Skye's controlling shareholder Brian Zylstra and Skye management, and the issue of 24,6 million non-voting shares at R4 each to institutional investors and empowerment groups. 

Mr Peer said all the major institutions had taken a stake. He would not give details of the shareholdings but market sources said though the deal would dilute the Peer family's stake slightly, AK and Fuzzy Peer would still hold a majority interest.

Like LA Stores, Skye is not a manufacturer but a distributor of branded clothing and also of footwear, supplying more than 3 000 retailers as well as national chains such as Edgars, Total Sports and Sales House. Brands distributed include Mille, Jump, Brentwood, Saucony and Dickie.

All the clothing and 25 percent of the footwear is made in South Africa.

The deal includes a guarantee of Skye making profits of R22 million before tax in its current year which ends in February. In its last financial year, the group delivered profits of R17,5 million before tax, on turnover of R110 million.

Mr Peer said 85 percent of Skye's products were aimed at the mass market and a partnership with a black company "made good business sense".

"Also, we have similar management styles," he said.

The businesses would keep their separate identities and management teams. Each would continue to design, develop and market its own products, Mr Peer said.

LA Stores' Samson brand of workwear would move into Skye's branding division. The Samson brand was inherited from clothing company Ensign when LA Stores listed through the Ensign cash shell on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange in October.

LA Stores' shares were trading yesterday at R5,90, more than double October's listing price of R2,76.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


South Africa;
Allie Fataar: good memories, few regrets from a teacher in exile


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Cape Town - Banned former refugee educationist, Allie Fataar, who was forced to flee South Africa to avoid being sent to Robben Island, was honoured with a belated hero's welcome and life membership of the New Unity Movement (NUM) while celebrating his 80th birthday at Easter.

Allie's eyes beamed with pride while tributes poured in, recalling the dark days of the apartheid era when he and his wife, Ursula, fled into exile 29 years ago.

Tributes were heaped on him by a panel of political comrades, theologians, educationists and civil rights leaders at a special birthday celebration in the Athlone Civic Centre on Good Friday to commemorate his role in helping to liberate South Africa from apartheid.

Allie vividly recalls the price he had to pay for becoming the secretary of the anti-apartheid teacher fraternity association, the Teachers' League of South Africa, and for entering the extra-parliamentary political arena as a founder member of the Non-European Unity Movement, later renamed the New Unity Movement. 

Speaking in an interview in his flat in Wynberg, Allie, a former English master and senior assistant to the principal at Livingstone High School in Claremont, told how his persecution began when he was banned in 1961 under the Suppression of Communism Act and how this was followed by years of persistent security police harassment.

"It was ironic that I had to leave the country on the same day that I was to be inducted as the deputy principal of Livingstone High," he said. "I had to flee into exile in 1964 when I was told that members of the Special Branch would be there to arrest me for allegedly violating my banning order."

Allie's flight from South Africa led to great financial hardship and eventually to an upheaval which scattered his family to three continents. With the benefit of hindsight, however, he says he has few regrets.

He believes it did lead to new opportunities in Botswana, Zambia and Zimbabwe which would not have been available to him in South Africa - where key posts were reserved for whites in terms of the of job reservation system.

Beyond South Africa's borders, Allie advanced progressively to key administrative posts such as a senior inspector of schools, curriculum developer responsible for developing an English syllabus for pupils from Grade 1 to Cambridge O-level (school leaving certificate) and a technical educational controller.

He said: "I would never, never have had these opportunities in South Africa.

"It broadened my educational horizons from being teacher to an educational administrator. I can truly say I am a teacher of southern Africa."

But things were not always that rosy. As a refugee, Allie initially had to work in a shop in Lobatsi, Botswana, until word spread that he was a qualified teacher. After being appointed to his first teaching post, he never looked back and went on to other posts of advancement in Zambia and Zimbabwe.

While Allie has many nostalgic memories of his pupils, he believes his best class was in 1967 at the SerUwe Swaneng School in Botswana in 1967, where pupils came from a seriously deprived environment. His policy was to teach pupils and to push them up the educational ladder to top levels in a variety of academic fields.

"Adversity was the finest master and the strong desire of my pupils to be diligent pupils and to do well was absolutely overwhelming," Allie said.

His finest memories, however, are of his 27 years in Cape Town while he was teaching at Livingstone, the high school he attended as pupil.

"For us at Livingstone there was liberation with education unlike almost every other black school in the country which had succumbed to the ideas liberation first and education later.

"Many of my ex-students are scattered around the world. Years after teaching them I have heard from them in a variety of key posts in Africa, Europe, Australia, Canada and even on Christmas Island!"

With enthusiasm, Allie says he is looking with renewed hope to the upliftment of South Africa and its people.

Apart from his achievements, Allie is a devoted father to his five sons.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
