Africa News


April 3, 1997


Sports - General;
Cape Town may surprise snide critics


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - As Cape Town gets into the swing of winning the hearts and minds of visiting International Olympic Committee members, one of the toughest challenges it faces is countering the perception that its shortlist ranking was merely a "concession".

This perception, especially prevalent in Europe, has been reinforced by the influential German sports newsletter Sport Intern.

Editor and publisher of the newsletter Karl-Heinz Huba is rather condescending about Cape Town's inclusion in the shortlist. This, he concludes, "was a concession which was met with a great deal of sympathy". 

He goes on: "That the gesture will be sufficient to qualify Cape Town as the venue for the 2004 Games is, however, extremely questionable.

"The reservations do not only result from the question of what will happen in South Africa after Mandela', but also the question raised within the evaluation commission as to how a possibly luxurious Olympic Village could exist alongside the slums of Cape Town."

Huba rates Rome as the best of the five and comments favourably on the other three Athens, Buenos Aires and Stockholm.

The Europeans are no doubt as pleased as punch at Sport Intern's assessment but there is an argument that Cape Town could benefit from being discounted by its European rivals on the grounds that it is unlikely that Africa is able to mount a competitive bid.

The Bid Company is, in fact, mounting a fiercely competitive bid and is going all out to convince individual IOC members to vote for a unique proposal which will reinvigorate Olympic ideals and offer a fresh vision for the Olympic Movement in the next millennium.

By all accounts, Europe is not expecting a sophisticated lobbying exercise and there is at least a chance they will be taken by surprise.

In this sense, the perception that Cape Town's inclusion in the race is merely a concession is being strongly countered in this final lobbying stage among the people who really matter the voting members of the IO

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
KWV fights to keep conversion on schedule


BYLINE: Dennis Cavernelis, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - A strong risk existed that the wine industry could lose out on business opportunities if KWV's conversion from a co-operative to a company was delayed, KWV counsel Philip Ginsburg told the Cape High Court.

He was arguing yesterday against an application by Agriculture and Land Affairs Minister Derek Hanekom for an order effectively delaying the conversion.

The Co-operative Wine Growers' Association of South Africa and the KWV Group Co-operative are asking the court to sanction a change in KWV's legal status from a co-operative to a company. 

In December, 83,8 percent of wine farmers representing KWV voted for the change. The co-op also asked the court to approve its application for the Wine and Spirits Control Act to be amended to allow KWV to become a private company and for confirmation of a reduction of share capital in terms of the Co-Operatives Act.

The Minister is asking that KWV's application be postponed until affidavits are produced that could affect the court's decision to sanction the conversion.

Mr Ginsburg said the proposed scheme of arrangement had been properly approved by special resolutions passed at meetings held by KWV, as set out in an earlier court order. He said new business opportunities beneficial to the wine industry and South Africa as a whole could be lost if the conversion process was delayed.

Theo Beckerling, SC, for the Minister argued that if KWV was converted to a public company it would no longer be qualified to carry out the powers and duties vested in it by the Wine and Spirit Control Act.

"Its assets are intended to serve the interests of the industry as a whole, and are not intended for the sole use and interest of KWV's members," he said. The hearing continues today. Mr Justice W J Louw is on the Bench.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

61 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


South Africa;
W Cape education, health, housing spending slashed


BYLINE: William-Mervin Gumede, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Cape Town - The Western Cape government has slashed education, health and housing spending in its budget tabled in the provincial legislature.

The budget, unveiled yesterday by provincial Finance Minister Kobus Meiring, makes provision for a R247-million deficit. A request for more money was turned down by national Finance Minister Trevor Manuel. 

The education budget is cut by R347-million, the health budget by R250- million, the agriculture budget by R23-million and housing, local government and planning by R9,6-million. But the police budget was almost doubled from R3,7-million to R6,3-million and welfare spending has been increased by R80- million. The sport and recreation budget has been increased by R13-million to R20,9-million. Of this amount, R11-million is earmarked for the Olympic Bid.

Transport and public works spending increases by R80-million to R750,9- million. Of this, R93-million will go to "special" Olympic projects, R50- million to transport projects and R43-million to sports priority projects.

Mr Meiring said the number of beds at Groote Schuur and Tygerberg hospitals would be cut to 1 000 and 1 200 respectively. School class sizes would increase to save money and payments to old-age homes would be pegged at 1996/7 levels.

Other cost-cutting measures included the scrapping of all new construction projects and capital expenditure other than for computers and medical equipment.

"It is a very sad day for the Western Cape and a very difficult year, perhaps the most difficult year in our history," Mr Meiring said. "On one hand our block grant is cut while on the other we are not yet allowed to augment our own income."

Mr Meiring did not rule out the possibility of taking Constitutional Court action to secure more money for the province.

The province budgeted for total spending of R9,525-billion. The bulk is for health (26 percent), education (35 percent), social services (23 percent) and transport and public works (eight percent).

The central government will fund 91,93 percent of this, while provincial income, mainly from hospital fees and car licences, makes up 5,28 percent. The balance is set off against the deficit (2,59 percent) and provincial revenue account income (0,2 percent).

Mr Manuel has said the overall allocation to the province increased in nominal terms from R8 378-million in 1996/97 to R8 757-million for the 1997/98 financial year. The Western Cape allocation of R2 197 for every person was much higher than the national average of R1 755 a person, he said.

Mr Meiring said that if non-discretionary allocations of R1 183-million - which included R971-million for improvements of conditions of service and R120-million to improve social pensions - were taken into account, the province was allocated R780,5-million less than last year.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


South Africa;
'Third force' feared in Flats drug war


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1787 words


 

Cape Town - The conflict between Cape Flats gangsters and Pagad seems to be intensifying in the number of attacks and counter-attacks and in the weapons being used.

Staff Reporter JOSEPH ARANES spoke to the two parties and the police to establish whether an all-out war could be averted

Just after midnight on Wednesday last week, Aaron Mapeko, an alleged Mitchell's Plain drug dealer, and his family were in bed about to go to sleep when all hell broke loose.

Unknown attackers lobbed a petrol bomb and a handgrenade at their house and raked it with gunfire. Fortunately, nobody was injured.

On the other side of the Peninsula, People against Gangsterism and Drugs (Pagad) leader Abdus-Salaam Ebrahim had just switched his Lansdowne house lights off and gone to bed when he and his family were woken by two explosions. 

Again, unknown attackers had tossed two M26 grenades at the bedrooms of the house.

Although the explosion shattered the windows and damaged the house, Mr Ebrahim and his family were not hurt.

During the past seven months the number of attacks has increased dramatically.

Initially most were directed at the homes of alleged drug dealers and gangsters, creating the perception that there were people who wanted the gangsters to retaliate.

Both Pagad and the Community Outreach Forum (Core), the organisation representing gangsters - who say they have reformed - allege a "third force" is responsible for the attacks, a claim the police are investigating.

Guns, grenades and home-made bombs were used in the attacks.

A worrying factor is that homemade explosive devices have become more lethal and powerful and it is more luck than anything else that many have failed to ignite, thus not causing injuries or deaths.

Under the banner of Core, most of the attacks were condemned, but no retaliatory action was taken.

Core continued spreading their gospel of peace and claimed that a "third force" was responsible for the attacks.

During the past weeks, more and more Pagad supporters have become targets of gunmen who sometimes carried petrol bombs and grenades too.

Pagad has condemned the attacks and vowed to continue with its anti-drugs campaign in spite of the intimidation.

Mr Ebrahim said his organisation believed there were forces intent on undermining the Government and who were using the gangsters as tools to achieve that objective.

"Core is small fry in this equation, this fight is bigger than many people think.

"There are agencies who want to destabilise the Government and throw the country into civil war."

He said agencies of the previous government were still intent on getting back political control and were trying to use Pagad's campaign to create disillusionment.

Mr Ebrahim alleged there were people in Parliament who were involved in the drug trade and that several economic giants were guilty of committing atrocities against people.

These people needed to appear before the Truth Commission so their illegal activities could be exposed.

"These crimes are worse than the apartheid crimes as people are still being drugged and oppressed.

"Pagad is not anti-government, but we are out to save the country from destruction and stop the intelligence agencies, local and international, from destabilising the country."

He said they had a simple message for the Government - get rid of drugs.

"The Government must also get rid of corrupt criminal justice officials and use the necessary force to deal with the problem as 'third force' elements are trying to undermine them," said Mr Ebrahim.

While Core does not agree with Pagad's strategy of marches and threats, it believes, too, that there are other forces with devious motives using the conflict to cause mayhem and strife on the Cape Flats.

Core spokesman Ernie "Lapepa" Peters said that while they agreed with Pagad that drugs were unacceptable, marches would not rid society of this evil.

"Pagad should be promoting peace and educating people about the evils of drug abuse.

"As drug dealers we have stated on numerous occasions that we are prepared to stop dealing if we are given a chance to find an alternative income.

"We are prepared to sit around the table with Pagad and the government to discuss their concerns and come up with solutions to this crisis.

"But the continuous threats and attacks on homes of merchants are testing our resolve, as an organisation committed to peace, to the limits."

Mr Peters said if the attacks continued it would become more difficult for Core to control their members, many of whom were intent on retaliating.

"The gangs are looking to Core for leadership and we are calling for peace, but all these attacks and public threats to the lives of our members and the fact that the police have not arrested anyone for the bombings are placing us in a very difficult position."

He said information from their sources within the police indicated that police got orders from their top structure not to arrest or act against Pagad members.

"Both the National Party and African National Congress are using this tension between Pagad and Core as a political football and don't want to find ways of resolving it.

"The NP controls the provincial government and the ANC rules nationally, but both have failed to come up with mechanisms to deal with the problem."

He said both parties were sitting on the fence watching developments and would get involved only if they thought they could gain political mileage and votes from it.

Both had skeletons in their cupboards which they wanted to keep there and the only way of keeping them locked away was for them to do nothing.

Although the police have come in for a lot of criticism from all sides for their handling of the situation, they say they are doing their best to keep the peace, arrest the offenders and prevent an all-out war between the groups.

Head of the violent crimes unit Leonard Knipe said the police were extremely concerned that the conflict could escalate and were putting as many resources and personnel as possible into the field to avoid that happening.

He said it should be remembered that the police were dealing with highly sophisticated networks of drug smugglers and bombers which were difficult to police.

"But we have made several arrests and confiscated numerous firearms, explosive devices and drugs.

"It would appear the attacks are being carried out by different groups of people and allegations of 'third force' involvement are being taken seriously and investigated," said Director Knipe.

He said homemade bombs being used were becoming bigger and more powerful and could be made by almost anyone with a little knowledge of chemicals as the substances could be bought at any good hardware store.

Although the police have appealed to people with information about bomb- makers to come forward, people were reluctant and genuinely scared as the danger of having their own houses blown up or shot at was very real.

Director Knipe said that in spite of this, police were conducting their work in a professional manner and were having phenomenal success in arresting people.

"We are scared that open warfare could erupt between the groups and we are doing everything in our power to prevent this.

"We have arrested several Pagad supporters for the illegal possession of firearms and gangsters are being arrested," he said.

Police statistics showed serious violent crimes were down, with 572 people arrested in connection with 256 cases last year, compared with 460 people arrested in 1995 in connection with 549 cases.

Several known gang leaders and alleged drug dealers were being investigated and several cases were pending.

But Director Knipe said not many of the other top gangsters and drug dealers had cases against them.

"We have taken out several middle men and while we don't believe the big guys have stopped their activities, we have just not linked them to cases yet.

"And this is not because of a lack of trying on the part of the police.

"We can lock them away only if we catch them and we are endeavouring to do just that," he said.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


63 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 3, 1997


South Africa;
Tourism fiasco at Cape Point


BYLINE: Chene Blignaut and Peter Goosen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Cape Town - Tourists and conservationists say the revamped Cape Point tourist complex is a fiasco, with visitors having to put up with traffic chaos, aggressive baboons, long queues and the stench of raw sewage.

Problems at the new R13-million complex have drawn increasing complaints from visitors, especially foreigners. Cape Point, one of the Peninsula's premier tourist sites, had 750 000 visitors last year.

The R3,5-million funicular which takes visitors to the viewing site at the point has carried 150 000 passengers since it opened in December but has been plagued by breakdowns. 

Other facilities, too, cannot cope. The sewerage system serving the new complex has broken down and the smell of raw sewage pervades the area.

There is a severe lack of parking and the restaurant and fast food shop appear unable to cope with demand.

In spite of the best efforts of a "baboon chaser", increasing numbers of aggressive baboons are posing a threat to visitors.

Environmentalists have warned it will cost millions to rectify all the problems without disturbing the environment.

The developer, Concor, has acknowledged that facilities are inadequate in peak periods and says further development is needed to cope with increased demand. The Cape Metropolitan Council, the "owner" of the reserve, says the complex was never designed to handle the numbers now visiting.

Conservationists predicted many of the problems when the complex was being planned, but they were ignored by the developers. They fought to the bitter end to prevent the restaurant complex being built on its present site because the area was too small. Their worst fears are now being realised. Waste from the restaurant kitchen shares a soakaway sewer with the complex's toilets and the system is blocked.

The narrow entrance road to Cape Point is often congested for kilometres with cars parked on both sides. The main parking area is too small to cope with cars and up to 20 tour buses at a time in a space designed to take eight.

Plans for another parking area at Cape Point or at nearby Rooikrantz and a shuttle service have also been condemned by conservationists. Long queues form at the fast food shop and 200-seat restaurant, which battle to cope.

Peter Salter, chairman of the Simon's Town Flora Conservation Group, said the decision to move the restaurant from the Homestead to its present site was taken without public participation.

"We warned what would happen when you concentrate all your facilities in one small area at the Point."

Former Simon's Town councillor Diane Salter said Cape Point could not possibly cope with the large numbers of visitors. "We feel very sorry that these issues were not looked at more closely in the beginning, but what's done is done. We now have to focus on how the increasing numbers should be managed."

Concor director Leo Rohrig acknowledged there were problems with facilities which were inadequate during peak times. "But you can't lay out a facility according to peak demand. It will be boring and empty for the rest of the year."

Concor and the Cape Metropolitan Council could not have predicted the dramatic increase in visitors from 350 000 in 1994 to 750 000 last year, he said.

He said the sewage problem could be overcome technically at a cost of no more than R200 000. The sewers would be doubled to take care of future growth.

Mr Rohrig confirmed that the funicular occasionally had technical problems which he blamed on its complicated alignment and the fact that it was locally made.

He said there was no way parking could be increased because of physical constraints. He urged people to go by bus during peak hours.

The old Homestead restaurant in the centre of the nature reserve was never considered as the site for the new restaurant, but was now being looked at as a relief measure during peak periods, he said.

"Limits on the size of the restaurant were imposed by conservationists.

"In fact the development had been delayed a year and costs had increased by 30 to 40 percent as a result of having to implement conservationists' proposals," Mr Rohrig said.

Cape Metropolitan Cpuncil chief executive Stewart Fisher said the problem was caused by large numbers of visitors.

He said: "Our mandate here is to assist visitors to experience the beauty of the place in a manner that has minimum impact on the environment rather than to establish a high acreage of fast food outlets for visitors."

He said despite warnings, visitors still fed baboons which had become demanding and perhaps appeared intimidating.

"One alternative that has been suggested is that the entire baboon population be eradicated. This is obviously unacceptable."

Dr Fisher added that all the problems could be rectified without having a major impact on the environment and the unspoilt nature of the reserve.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

64 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Nigeria Ponders Tough World Cup Encounter With Guinea


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The sporting mood in Nigeria Friday was one of hyper-expectation as the country's highly-favored "Super Eagles" take on Guinea's "Syli Nationale" Saturday in a crucial World Cup African Group qualification match, which the Nigerians must win to keep their France '98 hope alive.

After an unimpressive 2-0 win against Burkina Faso and a disappointing 1-1 draw with Kenya, the 1994 Africa Nations Cup champions are literally walking a tight rope.

They now trail two points, behind the Syli stars, who have the maximum six from two games played by each of the four countries that make up the group. 

According soccer buffs, the pressure is certainly on the Nigerians, who must win all their games, including Saturday's match against Guinea, to qualify for France '98.

Raheem Adejumo, president of the Nigeria Olympic Committee concedes that much in his goodwill message to the Eagles.

He said the Nigerians should be guided by the same spirit that gave the country's Under-23 squad Olympic soccer gold in Atlanta, United States, in August 1996.

On paper, Nigeria, parading an array of foreign-based stars, such as Austin "Jay Jay" Okocha, Daniel Amokachi, Emmanuel Amunike, Finidi George, Tijani Babangida and team captain Uche Okechukwu, to name but a few, should overrun the Guineans.

But many Nigerians are worried that on current form, the Syli stars "are no push overs" to have topped the group.

"The Eagles must approach this match with utmost caution else the World Cup ticket will just slip off our hands," one fan counselled.

Team selection could also pose a problem, with the 23 players invited to national camp jostling for the 11 shirts.

Part from the precautionary measures by Nigerian soccer administrators was the decision to camp the Eagles in Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, away from Lagos distractions.

The Syli stars also worked with the same theory, training in Mali ahead of Saturday's encounter.

Both teams flew into Lagos Thursday for the make or mar soccer battle at Nigeria's national stadium in Lagos.

Team captain Titi Camara, who stars for Nantes of France, was the toast of soccer fans as the Guineans breezed into the Nigerian commercial city late Thursday. His team, too, boasts a number of other foreign-based professionals.

Camara believes his colleagues are not intimidated by Nigerian big names.

"The game is for 22 players," he said. "We are determined to win here (Lagos), because that will make our qualification easier."

Such is the magnitude of the herculean task facing the Eagles.

The burden lies squarely on the shoulders of the Eagles' new French coach, Phillipe Troussier.

The Frenchman, also called the "White Witchdoctor," after his exploits of African soccer, is barely one month on the 10,000-U.S.-dollar a month job.

He admits the task would not be easy. "When people say we (Nigeria) will win, I feel flattered," he said. "But when they begin to talk about the (goal) margin, I become uncomfortable. Of course I know we will win, but it's going to be tough."

Many Nigerian fans, fired by patriotic feeling, have predicted a margin of 3-0 or 4-0 against Guinea, but analysts caution that football is not mathematics.

"Anything can happen, especially when the home team is playing under intense pressure," a sports commentator said.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 4, 1997


Zaire;
Zimbabwe Grants Asylum To Zairian Refugees


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe has so far this year granted asylum to 10 refugees fleeing civil war in Zaire and anticipates more as Zairian rebels, who have already captured four towns, are advancing and have rejected United Nations pleas for a cease-fire.

Zimbabwean commissioner for refugees, Samuel Mhiribidi, said the country, which until 1995, accommodated over 200,000 Mozambican refugees, had structures in place if there was need to provide a safe haven for more Zairians.

"We already have a few Zairian refugees who have been coming here even before the start of the present conflict and there are more still coming," he said. 

An official of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said not more than 10 Zairians had been granted asylum in Zimbabwe since the beginning of the year.

However, over 6,000 people fleeing fighting in Zaire have so far crossed into neighbouring Zambia since October last year, and Zambian authorities say around 500 Zairians are entering the country daily.

Zairian rebels started their armed onslaught in October accusing authorities of denying them citizenship.

Since then, fighting has intensified with the rebels capturing a number of towns making government forces and civilians to flee to safety in neighbouring countries.

Zimbabwe has said it will only consider granting asylum to Zairian refugees who can prove that they have been denied refugee status in countries which share borders with conflict-torn Zaire.

Mhiribidi said anyone who got to Zimbabwean border posts seeking refugee status had to be allowed in the the country and the apply for asylum from within.

"The immigration people know what to do with people who come to them as refugees. We have had several seminars with them on the subject," he said.

Zimbabwe is currently faced with a convoy of trucks belonging to Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko's son Nzanga, who is stranded at the Zambian town of Livingstone seeking authority to enter the country in transit to South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


66 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Frontline Politician Dies


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Mazi (Mr) Samuel Gomsu Ikoku, a renowned Nigerian politician and member of the current military regime's Transition Implementation Committee is dead. He was aged 71 years.

Nigerian special duties minister, Laz Unaogu, confirmed that Ikoku died "in active service" Thursday. He said the politician was in eastern Nigeria, his home region, to monitor the local council by-elections, held in parts of the country Thursday. 

Ikoku or "S.G," as he was fondly called by admirers, was a graduate of the London School of Economics. He was considered to be one of the first Nigerians to earn a masters' degree in that field.

He joined politics at the age of 18 years in 1946, and subsequently defeated his father in a national election in 1957.

He was a member of the federal parliamentary opposition Action Group founded by the late Nigerian politician Obafemi Awolowo in the government of the First Republic (1960-1966).

During the Second Republic (1979-1983), Ikoku co-founded the socialist- oriented Peoples Redemption Party with the late Malam Aminu Kano. But he later broke ranks to join deposed president Shehu Shagari's erstwhile National Party of Nigeria.

A controversial politician and public affairs commentator, Ikoku had often made it clear his philosophy in life was anchored on two concepts -- " nationalism" and "humanism."

He ran as a candidate for the Action Group in an election in 1957 and defeated his father Alvan Ikoku, one of Nigeria's renowned politician and educationist, then a member of the defunct National Council of Nigerian Citizens, founded by Nnamdi Azikiwe, the first Nigerian head of state, who died in May 1996.

During the Nigerian civil war (1967-70), when the eastern region of the country led by the dominant Igbo group tried to secede from the federation, Ikoku, an Igbo, was on the federal side.

He was Nigeria's representative in France, where he campaigned against Paris' recognition of defunct Biafra.

Ikoku was also in Addis Ababa, as a member of the Nigerian team during peace talks to end the war.

The outspoken politician was detained briefly by the Muhammadu Buhari regime over his 1984 book, "Nigeria: Fourth Coup d'Etat," in which Ikoku advocated diarchy (civilian-military government) as a system of government for the country.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Congolese Rector Calls For Regional University Courses


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Rector of the University of Brazzaville, Prof Matondo Hubert, has called for the regionalization of certain specialized courses such as computer science as a cost cutting measure in the sector of higher education.

"It would be self defeating for each of countries in one region, such as central Africa, to introduce similar courses. The best option should be joint centers for such specialized fields, " he told PANA on Friday in Dakar.

He said specialized regional university centers would even reduce the urge by parents to send their children abroad for such studies. 

"We have the required competence in our respective countries. What we need is to pool our resources to set up good regional institutions so that our children don't have to go to foreign countries where xenophobia is increasing, " he said.

Matondo was in Dakar for an African regional consultation on higher education, which was organized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

On the financing of higher education, the Rector said governments should continue funding university education, although internal efforts should be made by the institutions to generate funds through consultancy and research.

He cautioned, however, that the search for self-financing should not be at the expense of the mission of university to offer education, research and service to the society.

He spoke against the tendency of African governments to rely on international aid to finance higher education.

On what problems Brazzaville university faced, he said what he feared most was the rising trade unionism among students, which has gained intensity under Congo's new democratic era.

He said he understood the concern of students about unemployment. "In the past you went to the university to get a job. Now this is not the case."

Meanwhile, the Deputy Vice-Chancellor of Kenya's Nairobi University, Prof. Florida Karani, said the regional consultation in Dakar had enabled academicians and decision makers to "take stock of the state of the art" in the high education sector.

"The meeting helped in clarifying certain issues, including the financing of higher education, curriculum and science and technology, which our scientists need to identify and adapt whatever is relevant to our African needs," she said.

On the often repeated complaint that women academicians were disadvantaged, Karani said the consultation in Dakar had provided an opportunity for the evolving strategies to reverse that anomaly.

She urged African states to introduce affirmative actions as an interim measure to bridge between women and men academicians.

"Governments would be better off if they increased the participation of women in development. Ignoring women, who constitute 50 percent of human resources is elf-defeating," she said.

Prof. Lydia Makhubu of the University of Swaziland said that students at the institution she heads were very active in the ongoing debate on democracy in the kingdom.

However, she said this has not disrupted the university. On the representation of women at higher levels of universities, Makhubu said the situation was improving in certain countries but not in others.

"There also several women rectors in South Africa and as you can see Kenya is doing well. Progress is slow but it is there."

Assessing the meeting in Dakar, Makhubu said that basing on what transpired during debates, "we shall come out with well INL002 from SSS.072 (970404-16: 01) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG071G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) focused recommendations to guide us in future."

The preparatory meeting for next year's World Conference on Higher Education ends on Friday evening after the adoption of the "Dakar Declaration on Higher Education In Africa" and a plan of action.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe's Elephant Hills Hotel Assumes New Look


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Elephant Hills Hotel in the northern resort town of Victoria Falls has assumed a new identity. It will now be called Elephant Hills Intercontinental Victoria Falls, following a strategic alliance agreement between owners Zimbabwe Sun and the Southern Sun Group of South Africa. 

Zimbabwe Sun Public Relations Manager Ray Mawerera said Southern Sun were the franchise holders of the Intercontinental Brand and the agreement would enable Zimsun to use it in Zimbabwe.

"The agreement covers human resource and infrastructural development and puts us on the intercontinental map," Mawerera said.

"We realized that strategic alliances are the future since tourism is increasingly becoming competitive and that a well known brand like Intercontinental is easier to sell," he added.

Elephant Hills Hotel becomes the second hotel under Zimsun to assume a new brand name after the Monomatapa in Harare changed to Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza Monomotapa in 1996, following a franchise agreement with Holiday Inn worldwide.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


69 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe & South Africa Sign Textile Agreement


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe and South Africa on Thursday signed the eagerly awaited agreement on textiles and clothing in a move widely regarded as the turning point in trade relations between the two neighbors.

The latest development follows a breakthrough in August 1996 on the ongoing bilateral trade talks when Zimbabwe's industry and commerce minister, Nathan Shamuyarira and his South African counterpart, Alec Erwin, signed a memorandum of understanding on the two commodities. in Pretoria.

The memorandum of understanding, among other things, signalled agreement in principle on the rules of origin in relation to clothing and textiles as well as preferential tariff and quota levels for Zimbabwean clothing and textile exports to South Africa. 

The memorandum, which was scheduled to be implemented from September 1, 1996, had to be delayed due to some technical procedural matters.

These have now been resolved and the two ministers said in a joint statement released at the end of talks held in Harare on Thursday that tariff preferences would be reinstated with immediate effect.

It was, however, agreed that the implementation process would be monitored closely to ensure smooth operation and the ministers noted that the latest initiatives could go a long way in narrowing the trade imbalance that had threatened to put a dent on relations between the two countries.

With regard to agricultural products, agreement on trade quotas was reached on a number of items although there were still a number of outstanding matters on which announcement was expected when the ministers meet in South Africa in May.

However, little progress was made on "other products," with the two sides agreeing that the issues under this area should be addressed in the context of a memorandum of understanding which is expected to be signed at their next meeting.

The memorandum of understanding would include all areas that had already been agreed to and will also cover investment and technical co-operation.

Trade is heavily skewed in favour of South Africa which posted a net surplus of seven billion Zimdollars (636 million U.S. dollars) in the first 10 months of 1996.

Zimbabwe's business community had over the past five years accused South Africa of unfair trade practices following the removal of tariff preferences the Zimbabweans used to enjoy prior to the expiry in 1992 of the 1964 trade agreement between the two countries.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


West Africa;
Abacha, Compaore Urge Zaire Cease-fire


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian head of state Sani Abacha and his Burkina Faso counterpart, President Blaise Compaore, have called for an immediate end to hostilities in eastern Zaire.

The two West African leaders said this was crucial for a negotiated settlement between the Kinshasa government and the Democratic Alliance for the Liberation of Congo (Zaire) led by Laurent Kabila. 

This appeal was contained in a joint communique Thursday at the end of Compaore's two-day visit to Nigeria.

Abacha and Compaore attended the two-day March 26 Lome Summit of the Organisation of Africa Unity's conflict resolution committee on Zaire.

At that meeting, African leaders managed to bring Zaire's opposing sides together for the first time, after which they also agreed on early talks to end their five-month war.

Although the first round of peace talks brokered by the United Nations and the O.A.U. are due to start Saturday in South Africa, reports from Zaire speak of apparent confusion within the Kinshasa government, while Kabila's alliance forces continue their advance.

Abacha and Compaore also expressed concern at the recent escalation of the fighting in the horn of Africa. They called on African states to seek urgent solution to the problem using existing O.A.U. conflict resolution mechanism.

Both men called for the strengthening of continental economic integration through the OAU and sub-regional bodies such as the Economic Community of West African States, Ecowas.

"Effective bilateral and regional cooperation among the brotherly countries of the sub-region are necessary prerequisites for regional economic integration," they said.

Abacha is chairman of the 16-nation Ecowas, which is mediating the conflict in a member country, Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


United States and Africa;
Consolidated Great Lakes Report No. 29


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4627 words


 

Washington DC - GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency

Situation Report #27, Fiscal Year (FY)1997, April 4, 1997. Note: The last situation report was dated March 28,1997.

Background

Sporadic ethnic violence against the Banyamulenge and the Banyarwanda, Tutsis of Rwandan origin, has erupted in the South Kivu and Masisi regions of Zaire since 1959. The violence escalated in 1995 and 1996, as the former Rwandan army (the ex-FAR) and the Rwandan Hutu militia (the Interahamwe), living as refugees in Eastern Zaire, attacked the Banyarwanda in the Masisi region. Subsequently in October 1996, the Government of Zaire (GOZ) sanctioned harassment of the Banyamulenge in South Kivu, provoking the fighting which broke out between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Banyamulenge rebels on October 14, 1996. The fighting began near Runingo refugee camp in South Kivu, Zaire, forcing about 220,000 refugees to flee the Uvira/Bukavu region. The Banyamulenge joined forces with other Zairian rebels to form the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance), led by Laurent Kabila, a veteran foe of Zairian president Mobutu Sese Seko. The fighting spread, moving up the eastern border of Zaire from South Kivu, and south from Rutshuru to Goma, in North Kivu. On November 14, the Alliance counter-attacked against ex-FAR and Interahamwe elements in the Mugunga refugee camp in the Goma area, forcing them to retreat west and compelling hundreds of thousands of refugees to return to Rwanda. Other refugees fled north and west into Zaire and remain there. Since then, Alliance troops have steadily advanced across Eastern Zaire: they captured Kisangani on March 15 and Kamina and Kasenga in late March, expanding theircontrol to an area 1,600 km long and 600 km west into Zaire. Lubumbashi, the second largest city in Zaire, is their current objective.

USG Humanitarian Assistance for Fiscal Year (FY) 1997 (to date): $129,859, 997

Numbers Affected

In Zaire - Refugees: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) estimates 376,590 Rwandans and about 44,000 Burundians are stranded in Eastern Zaire. Of the 100,000 refugees who fled from Tingi-Tingi on March 1 to Ubundu, about 80,000 crossed the Zaire River and have gathered at Km 25, Km 41, and Km 82 on the rail line south of Kisangani. The 57,000 refugees estimated to have gathered near Km 25 are the healthiest, while the 31,000 near Km 41 and 82 are in urgent needof food, water, and medicine. On March 22, ex-FAR and Interahamwe elements reportedly separated from the refugees, with one armed group allegedly heading towards Opala, an inaccessible area about 100 km west of Ubundu. In the last two weeks, the U.N. airlifted 2,846 refugees from Tingi-Tingi and Amisi. On April 1, about 25,000 refugees appeared in Karuba, 13 km west of Sake, and are being repatriated to Rwanda, the UNHCR reported. Another 2,500 emerged in Tongo, to the west of the old Katale and Kahindo refugee camps north of Goma. In Ikela, 300 km southwest of Kisangani, about 4,000 refugees have reportedly gathered. In Mbuji-Mayi, Kasai-Oriental, there are reports of 2,000 refugees, and 40,000-50,000 are moving towards Angola. They are believed to be the group from Shabunda/Kindu. At least 100,000 refugees in Eastern Zaire are unaccounted for. Zaire - Internally Displaced (IDPs): 39,000 IDPs were registered in Kisangani, and missionaries in the city report that4,000 left to return to their homes. The U.N. estimates there are about 300,000 Zairian IDPs in Eastern Zaire. In Rwanda: According to the UNHCR, 1,033,405 Rwandan refugees returned to Rwanda from Eastern Zaire and Tanzania from November to December 1996, bringing to 1, 300,582 the number of returnees in 1996. From January to March 1997, another 75,947 refugees returned from Eastern Zaire and Tanzania. There are 9,000 Burundian refugees in Rwanda, the UNHCR reports. In Burundi: Of the 143,000 Burundian refugees originally in the Uvira area of Zaire, some 93,000 refugees have returned to Burundi. From January through March 1997, 8,192 Burundians returned from Tanzania, and 5,764 returned from Zaire. In Tanzania: 13,500 Burundians have arrived in Tanzania from the Uvira region of Zaire. In all, there are about 281,000 Burundianrefugees in Tanzania, and 87,957 Zairians, for a total of 368,957. Elsewhere in the Region: 4,820 Zairians remain in Uganda, down from 11,000, the UNHCR reported. About 7,500 Zairian refugees have fled to Zambia, most of them arriving in Mpulungu. The Government of Sudan is host to 10,000 Zairian refugees in the Bazi area of Western Equatoria.

Zaire

Current Situation

Alliance troops continue to advance in the south in a pincer movement toward Lubumbashi, moving simultaneously along the Zaire-Zambian border and along the railway south of Kabongo. After seizing Kamina, the Alliance appears to be isolating Lubumbashi from the rest of GOZ-controlled Zaire.

In the northern part of Alliance-controlled territory, rebel officials in Kisangani have delayed humanitarian efforts to repatriate some of the tens of thousands of Rwandan and Burundianrefugees who had fled the Alliance's advances since late1996. In the past week, the Alliance ordered the 26,000 refugees who had gathered in Lula, 7 km south of Kisangani, to retrace their steps south along the railway that runs to Ubundu. Citing security concerns, Alliance commanders appear to want the refugees to gather for repatriation at Ubundu, 125 km south of Kisangani.

The Alliance concerns may stem from a battle fought on March 22 between ex- FAR/Interahamwe members and the Alliance about 52 km south of Kisangani, according to Zairian eyewitnesses who spoke to the USAID/Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) on March 30. The Zairians reported that 98 people were killed in the battle. The encounter allegedly marked the end of the ex- FAR/Interahamwe control over the refugees who are now gathered along the rail line, awaiting repatriation. Some of the Rwandan fighters are also believed to have blended in with the refugees, but most have supposedly fled west towards Opala.

The U.N. humanitarian coordinator for Eastern Zaire continues to await Kabila's approval for a U.N. plan that envisions Kisangani as the base for repatriating the refugees along the railroad. The city has an international airport, unlike the grass strip at Ubundu, an alternative staging area. Complicating repatriation plans, the Government of Rwanda (GOR) has requested that a tripartite agreement among the GOR, the U.N. and the Alliance be signed before repatriation could begin.

As of April 3, refugees were grouped near two kilometer markings along the rail line: about 50,000 generally healthy people at Kisesa, near Km 25, and about 30,000 at Biaro, near Km 41. The last group was in poor shape and included several thousand unaccompanied children. At Km 82, there about 1,000 refugees. Local villagers told USAID/DART they had buried about 200 corpsesin recent days. From Tingi-Tingi and Amisi, relief workers flew 2,846 refugees, most of them ill or weak, to Goma for eventual repatriation to Rwanda. The evacuation by air was completed on April 3.

The USAID/DART is travelling regularly between Goma and Kisanganito coordinate relief efforts with the U.N. to determine how best to assist the refugees and IDPs. After the Alliance seized Kisangani on March 15, USAID/DART also succeeded in securing the Alliance's clearance for the WFP's first food flightto Kisangani from Mwanza, Tanzania. On March 19, a WFP- chartered aircraft delivered 35 MT of food to Kisangani.

A group of about 25,000 Rwandan refugees appeared on March 31 in Karuba, west of Sake, and Tongo, west of the former Katale and Kahindo camps. The refugees, reportedly in good condition, wished to go home. The UNHCR is organizing a gradual repatriation, which would involve 3,000 people crossing daily into Rwanda from Goma. On April 1 and 2, the UNHCR repatriated 4,750 Rwandans from Karuba and Tongo by truck.

Reports have reached relief agencies of a mass of 40,000-50,000 refugees heading south from Mbuji- Mayi to the Angolan border. They may be part of the refugees who had fled Shabunda and Kindu earlier this year.

The U.N. Special Rapporteur for Human Rights said in Geneva on April 2 that the Alliance had "undoubtedly" committed massacres during the past six months. He recommended that an internationalinvestigative team be sent to Eastern Zaire.

Relief Efforts

As planning and negotiations with the Alliance continue, the broad U.N. aims in Eastern Zaire are to provide assistance to therefugees, to enable them to regain the strength to repatriate on foot east to Rwanda and Burundi. Seasonal rains, combined with Alliance stipulations, are complicating the tasks of planning, transporting, and distributing relief assistance. Many bridges also require repairs in the wake of the fighting. U.N. logisticians inspected the road from from Lobutu to Walikale, concluding that a 30-km stretch required repairs.

The U.N. plan for repatriating refugees from Eastern Zaire has three parts. The first, the evacuation of people from Tingi-Tingi and Amisi to Goma, ended April 3. Contingent on Alliance approval, the second part would involve passenger flights between other parts of Eastern Zaire in Alliance control: Bunia, Kalemie, Kindu, Uvira, Bukavu, and Goma, and other accessible airstrips in areas where refugees are located. The third part involves the bulk of the 80,000 refugees grouped along the railroad south of Kisangani. The UNHCR plans to airlift up to 20,000 of the most vulnerable from Kisangani to Kigali, if the Alliance provides access to the airport in Kisangani. The remainder would walk and be trucked to the Rwandan border.

After delays, a train from Kisangani transported 120 MT of pulsesand cereals for distribution at km 82 on March 27. A second train with another 120 MT delivered food along the rail line on April 1. USAID/DART reports that food stocks are adequate for the refugees along the railroad.

In March, the U.N. repatriated 7,209 refugees from towns in the Goma region, including Kisharu, Tongo, Kalengera/Rugari, Sake/Mugungu, Karuba, and Kalungu. In Kingulube, east of Shabunda, the UNHCR and WFP have set up five way stations in preparation for the transit of refugees.

In Kisangani, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)is leading efforts to assist IDPs, reestablish water and sanitation services, and set up an emergency supply line to the area. The ICRC has received formal Alliance permission to fly toKisangani, Kalima, Kindu, Shabunda, Beni, and Bunia, and it plans to investigate the condition of the refugees and several thousand IDPs in the Kalima-Kindu area. The ICRC is planning twosets of way stations: along the 700 km route from Kisangani tothe Rwandan border, and to the south, on the route from Lulungeto Fizi and Uvira. In GOZ territory, ICRC workers commute daily from Ndola, Zambia to Lubumbashi.

Political Developments

Talks between the GOZ and the Alliance are set to begin April 5 in South Africa, according to news reports. The delegations do not include President Mobutu or Kabila. The arrangements emergedfrom a meeting in Lom', Togo, where the Organization of African Unity (OAU) held a summit on the Zaire crisis. Mohamed Sahnoun, OAU and U.N. Special Representative to the Great Lakes, will lead the talks, his spokesman said.

In Kinshasa, President Mobutu on April 2 appointed Etienne Tshisekedi, a veteran rival, as prime minister. He replaces Kengo wa Dondo, who resigned in mid-March. In Goma on March 26, an Alliance spokesman rejected any proposal to share power with Mobutu's party.

Rwanda

Current Situation

A cabinet reshuffle in the GOR on March 28 resulted in the dissolution of the Ministry of Rehabilitation and Social Integration (MiniReiso), with its responsibilities being absorbedby the Interior Ministry. This is significant, as MiniReiso worked most closely with the relief community.

Violence in Rwanda continues. On April 2, five people in Ruhengeri prefecture were killed and two were kidnapped. Elsewhere in the prefecture, three people died in a battle between security forces and "criminal elements," Radio Rwanda reported. Five people, including three civilians, died in fighting on March 24 between GOR security forces and the Interahamwe in Runda commune, Radio Rwanda reported. The U.N. reported that on March 19, unknown gunmen killed five Hutu and Tutsi children in a school in Kibuye prefecture.

A report released by the United Nations Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) states that human rights has "drastically deteriorated" since the new year. In January, HRFORreceived reports of at least 424 killings, the highest number since early 1996. Of the 424 killings, 228 were in Ruhengeri prefecture alone. Most relief efforts and human rightsmonitoring have been curtailed after foreign humanitarian workers in Rwanda were killed in January and February. The victims included a Canadian priest, three Spaniards who worked for Medicos del Mundo (MDM), and two expatriate human rights monitors and three Rwandans working for HRFOR.

Relief Efforts

Regular U.N. convoys transporting humanitarian assistance under military escort are underway between Kigali and Cyangugu, Kibuye, Gisenyi, and Ruhengeri. The WFP has also instituted regular flights to Gisenyi and Cyangugu.

Changing circumstances and renewed relief efforts in Eastern Zaire have increased refugee repatriations to Rwanda. WFP has moved 60 MT from the border crossing at La Petite Barri re in Rwanda to Goma, and M'decins Sans Fronti res (MSF) and Food for the Hungry will be responsible for administering medical assistance to returnees.

The WFP reports that the price of staple foods has increased 30% from the same time last year. The increase resulted from the mass repatriations from Zaire and Tanzania, from poor harvests inRwanda and southern Uganda, and from the trade embargo against Burundi.

International Criminal Tribunal on Rwanda (ICTR)

In Arusha, Tanzania, the trial of former Interahamwe leader Georges Rutaganda has been postponed until May 27, to enable the court to combine his case with two others. Rutaganda faces charges of genocide and crimes against humanity. The tribunal has indicted 21 people.

Burundi

Political Developments

The Government of the Republic of Burundi (GRB) reported fightingbetween security forces and rebels in Mitonto village, Rumonge commune, Bururi province, on March 27. Official accountsof the death toll differ, with state radio reporting 140 dead, and an army spokesman claiming 57. The army also reported that Hutu rebels killed five people in the Kinhama neighborhood of Bujumbura late Sunday. The victims were reported to be Hutus who had recently returned from refugee camps outside the city.

Two anti-tank mines exploded in Bujumbura on March 25, killing atleast 20 people. One mine detonated as a minibus drove over it. Authorities announced one arrest.

Questions remain unanswered about the GRB's claim that rebels killed 135 people and wounded 144 in Buganda commune, Cibitoke province, on March 19. Government authorities reported on March 13 that a plot to kill Buyoya had been foiled. The announcement came several hours after three land mines exploded in different parts of Bujumbura, killing seven people.

Relief Efforts

The GRB recently announced the establishment of regroupment camps in Bujumbura Rurale and Bururi provinces. The practice of regroupment is already being enforced in the provinces of Karuzi, Kayanza, Cibitoke, Bubanza, and Muramvya. Local press reports state that, in practice, military authorities inform Burundians living in particular areas to move to the regroupment sites. If the peasants do not move to the camps, the military considers them rebels, and they risk being killed.

Although conditions in the camps are satisfactory in the beginning, the health of the population is prone to deteriorate from the effects of crowding, inadequate potable water, poor sanitation, lack of medical care, and inaccessibility to farm land.

Recently the acceleration of forced displacement of the population has imposed a growing burden on the relief community, imperiling their neutrality.

A recent Food and Agricultural Organization/WFP study found that food security in Burundi has deteriorated. Civil strife, population displacement, and the regional economic embargo have reduced food supplies and increased food prices. It has been noted, however, that it is difficult to separate the economic consequences of civil strife in Burundi from the effect of the embargo. Although the sanctions have exacerbated the difficulties resulting from shortages of food and medicines, shortages existed before the embargo was imposed.

African leaders will meet in Arusha on April 8 to evaluate the effect of the sanctions against Burundi. The leaders will examine the measures taken by the GRB towards establishing democracy, peace, and reconciliation, to determine progress made in these areas.

Tanzania

As of March 24, there were 361,699 refugees in Tanzania: 273,742 of them Burundian; the rest Zairian, the UNHCR reported. The populations are as follows: Ngara camps: 97,600; Kibondo camps: 103,647. Both areas hold only Burundians. In the Kasulu area: 116,699, including about 44,204 Zairians; Kigoma camps: 43,723 refugees, almost all Zairian. Tanzanian authorities are reportedly planning to mount a search operation for Zairian refugees who left the Kigoma holding center, and to place them inrefugee camps.

USG Assistance

The USG first responded to the crisis in the Great Lakes region with a series of disaster declarations, necessary to begin USG emergency assistance. U.S. Ambassador to Rwanda, Robert Gribbin, declared the first disaster in the region on November 7, 1996, noting that the refugee crisis in Eastern Zaire posed a humanitarian emergency for Rwanda.

U.S. Ambassador to Zaire, Daniel Simpson, followed on November 12, citing the violent breakup of refugee camps in Eastern Zaire. On November 25, U.S. Ambassador to Burundi, Morris Hughes, determined that Burundi's continuing civil strife warranted USG assistance.

In response to the stated needs, BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda from October 26, 1996 to February 26, 1997, and an assessment team to Zaire from February 12-26, 1997. The current USAID/DART was deployed to Nairobi on March 14 and is working in the region. The USG pledged $140 million in humanitarian assistance to the region on November 18, 1996. The USAID/DART has installed an information officer in Nairobi and established afield office in Goma. This week, the Department of State Bureauof Population, Refugees, and Migration approved a $3 million contribution to UNHCR to assist in repatriating refugees from Eastern Zaire.

USAID FY 1997 Assistance to date:

BHR/OFDA Assistance Rwanda To date, BHR/OFDA funding has been obligated as follows:

Grant to Action Aid for shelter in Kibuye: $774,700

Grant to AMREF for medical services: $212,129

Grant to ARC for water/sanitation/health: $3,094,857

shelter/water/sanitation/food/non-food activities: $1,967,853

distribution: $650,189

BHR/OTI Assistance

BHR/FFP Assistance

In FY 1997, BHR's Office of Food for Peace (BHR/FFP) has committed 96,000 MT of P.L. 480 emergency Title II commodities for WFP. These commodities, valued at $72,500,000, will assist refugees and displaced persons in Rwanda, Zaire, Burundi, Uganda,and Tanzania.

BHR/FFP Assistance: $72,500,000

State/PRM Assistance

To UNHCR, for emergency assistance: $20,000,000

To IRC for its reintegration programs in Rwanda: $2,500,000

State/PRM has also made $3,000,000 available to the UNHCR to assist in the repatriation of refugees from Eastern Zaire.

TOTAL USG HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE TO DATE IN FY 1997:$129,859,997


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997

72 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Ethiopia;
Agency forecasts heavy rain this 'belg' season


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The national meteorological Service Agency reported that heavy rainfall is expected in the remaining belg season in southern Ethiopia, Borena, Bale and Somali regional states.

Experts of the agency forecasted that peasants in southern Ethiopia need to be advised to sow short-term and drought resistant seeds to ward off damages. 

Ato Zewdu Tessemma, team leader of weather forecast and early warning and Ato Engeda Maesha, team leader of agricultural meteorology, told the Ethiopian News Agency that rain is expected in south-west, south and south- east Ethiopia due to the movement towards the North of the inter-tropical convergence zone from Kenya, Uganda and south Sudan.

Accordingly, 100-200 mm of rain is expected this month in South and North Omo, South Oromia, Borena and Bale, the experts said.

They also disclosed that 60-100 mm and 40-90 mm of rain is expected in south Ethiopia zones, western, middle and eastern Oromia, and Somali as well as in Gambella, Benshngul-Gumuz, Amhara and southern tigray regions respectively.

The experts said 10-30 mm of rain is also expected in Afar and eastern, middle and western tigray regions.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Ethiopia;
Corner stone laid for construction of residential houses


BYLINE: Derese T/Wolde, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - A corner stone laying ceremony for the construction of 25,000 residential houses was conducted here yesterday at Taffo peasant association kebele in Woreda 28.

The project, which is said to be the first of its kind, is believed to greatly alleviate the existing housing problems in the metropolis. it was learned that the project is being undertaken by a private firm called Ayat Real State Development Organization. 

The corner stone was laid by Ato Taddesse Haile, General Manager of the Ethiopian Investment Authority in the presence of representatives from Region 14 administration and other invited guests.

According to Ato Ayalew Tesema, chairman of the Board of Directors of the organization, the project will have four phases and be completed in seven to ten years of time. the project will also include necessary facilities, such as education, health, market centres and other services, it was reported.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


74 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Ethiopia;
Deputy PM lauds roles of defence force in nation's development


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

DEBRE ZEIT - Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence, Ato Tefera Walwa yesterday underscored the significant contribution the national defence force made in ensuring peace and stability of the main economic growth the nation registered over the past few years.

Ato Tefera made the remark at a panel discussion he held with the staff of the Ethiopian Air Force on their second day of observance of the Air force's first annual day celebrations. The panel was organized to brief the Air-force staff on the socio-economic conditions of the country and the governments five-year peace, democracy and development programme as well as to discuss what role the defence force in general is expected to play in the former, according to organisers of the panel. 

Ato Tefera told the gathering that comparing the country's overall picture prior to the coming of the EPRDF with present trends, the nation as a whole could be said to have achieved a rapid, double digit economic growth the attainment of which, had been a direct result of the closer and democratic working relationships between the people and the government. "The army's contribution has been particularly conspicuous in protecting the development process from anti-development elements", he said.

"The spirit of democratic cooperation and trust demonstrated by the people and government of the FDRE which brought about all this success over the past few years is exemplary and the general staff of the Air-Force and their officers and commanders should continue to develop closer, democratic relationships so as to continue to achieve the remarkable results they are already registering in their services to the country and the people," he added.

Expounding at length about the significant economic growth the country has achieved, Ato Tefera said that the economy grew by a hefty 10.4 per cent which demonstrated that "we have proved a rapid, sustainable development." He noted that unlike the past, the country has now reached a point where no such thing as budget deficits are observed. "In fact we are in surplus and efforts are being made to turn the budget surplus to other development expenditures," he added

Nothing that the country has reached a stage of food self sufficiency and has surplus production of grains which could be exported, Ato Tefera indicated that the inflation rate also stands either at zero or negative, and in short that it is only normal. One era where he talked of problems was concerning balance in imports and exports, which problem he attributed to the country's reliance on only agricultural products.

The annual day celebration will continue today and ceremonies to be conducted include exhibitions and graduation ceremonies for pilots and technicians.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 4, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia, DPRK to cooperated in construction, irrigation fields


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Prime Minister Meles Zenawi yesterday expressed Ethiopia's wish to further strengthen relations with the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea (DPRK).

Prime Minister Meles said at a meeting with the visiting DPRK deputy prime minister and foreign minister Mr. Kim Young Nam that Ethiopia gives high regard to its relation with DPRK - a spokesman to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has said.

The DPRK deputy premier and foreign minister has on his part expressed his country's wish to strengthen ties with Ethiopia and appreciated the latter's efforts for the respect of peace and stability in the sub-region. 

In a related development, the governments of Ethiopia and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea have agreed to cooperate in the areas of construction and irrigation development activities.

During talks, Ethiopian foreign Minister Ato Seyoum Mesfin and Vice Premier and Foreign Minister of the DPRK, Mr. Kim Young Nam, said the two sides have reached upon an agreement to collaborate in the fields of engineering(construction) and irrigation.

According to the spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the two sides have also agreed that the 7th Ethio-Korea Joint Ministerial Commission meeting be held in Pyongyang, DPRK soon.

The senior government officials of the two countries have reached consensus to further strengthen the existing bilateral cooperation, especially in the fields of economy, based on the south-south cooperation, according to the spokesman.

Mr. Kim has told Atop Seyoum that his government has a strong desire to reunify the two Koreas.

Ato Seyoum on his part told the vice premier of DPRK that Ethiopia will support the peaceful reunification of the two Koreas based on the interests of the people of the two nations.

Mr. Kim Young Nam arrived here yesterday heading a seven-member delegation in a two-day working visit to Ethiopia.

He was welcomed on arrival at bole International Airport by Ato Seyoum.

Mr. Kim has visited Nigeria, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Uganda and Angola and that the delegation headed by him is to leave today for new Delhi to attend a conference on Non-Aligned Movement.
