Africa News


April 4, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Ethiopia's Goshu Art Gallery Celebrates First Anniversary


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - Many people complain that young Ethiopian artists are trying so hard to pass on a message--at a high price -- with little emphasis on basic technique that their work ends up 'heavy' and lacking that certain " flare" that makes one's heart miss a beat.

The art exhibition of eight young Ethiopian artists--graduates of the Addis Ababa Fine Arts School in the '80s and early '90s-- at Goshu Art Gallery(29 March-15 April) though, comes very close to this 'unconventional' assessment that most of us laymen use and that would certainly offend many 'learned' artists. 

Behailu Bezabih had six works on display, priced from 2500 to 700 birr, most with a 'light' theme. These, which included 'Modjo' and 'the son of Aba Mamo' --the lowest priced piece at the exhibition-- is balanced by a more serious theme conveyed ("life is a mystery") in 'who saw the joker'.

Tesfaye Woldeselassie seven pieces on display (priced from 2500 to 1500 birr) show a marked inclination to traditional themes such as in 'Grinding Coffee', the 'Water Carrier'-- and in the abstract piece simply titled 'shield'. Daniel Taye and Samuel Sharew , had five (priced between 1000-3000 birr).


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


153 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Ethiopia;
Children: They're Ours And We're The Answer


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2027 words


 

Addis Ababa - "...Protect children and adolescents from all forms of negligence, discrimination, exploitation, cruelty and oppression." States Article 227 from the 1989 Convention on the Right of the Child.

This refers to the raising of our children but does it mean that society is also responsible for those that we have not nurtured, that are not our own. Whose responsibility are the 40,000* children that spend their days wandering the streets of Addis Ababa clutching shoe-boxes, cartons of cigarettes or simply with a hand out-stretched?

If the words street-child conjure up a pathetic picture of a ragged , scarred, diseased 'untouchable', or an aggressive abusive hardened criminal, that is nothing but a burden on the community , then we are failing to comply with the international convention that Ethiopia has ratified and see these victims as children. 

More than that, we are being worryingly short-sighted if we do not realise that reducing the 40,000 children on our streets is part of a long-term solution to many social ills. Fewer street children means less poverty and less begging; less children resorting to criminal behaviour to support themselves so a safer environment and a less fearing community. Neither would so many girls resort to prostitution for an income - less child exploitation and rape; with this, so would we limit the spread of HIV and AIDS. Most of all, we would not be nurturing people to rely upon society's support - that escalating circle of dependency would be broken. Simplistic maybe, but those major social problems could be significantly reduced if we agreed to take constructive action and responsibility for the coming generation of homeless.

There is another side to street children. They are a nuisance. You become inhumanely hardened to the big, doleful eyes staring pleadingly up at you or the more aggressive attitudes. Constant callings, shrieking, swearing, eradicates your sympathy; catching hold of you and sticking a fist into your bag makes you even less willing to help. For farenji, the hassles from street children are even more acute. Of course, they believe foreigners to be rich, possibly a route out of their seemingly doomed existence. They can be less sure that habbasha will give them money - nationals are, apparently just as likely to give them a kick. Abera in Piazza explained that some tourists have shown violence to him and his friends. The reason?

"Well," I was told as if it was blatantly obvious, "the foreigners that treat us like that are just crazy ! They expect foreigners to delve into their pockets and produce the goods and it's difficult to refuse knowing that they might not get any more bread that day. However this only endorses their misconception that all foreigners are infinitely wealthier than their Ethiopian counterpart, it makes walking the streets more restricting for foreigners and it hardly encourages the potentially affluent tourism industry here.

The trouble is, that the type of help that the children receive is not properly organised or monitored. Tourists have handed out sterling notes and dollar bills. Dawit proudly displays his swanky digital watch, a gift from some thoughtful Americans. We too are escalating the problem. Doling out money does nothing to constructively relieve the suffering on the streets. According to GOAL-Ethiopia's research, few children take the money to their families. It would be better to give donations to organisations that can constructively tackle the issues.

However, street children are not the burden that we assume they are. Those children do have things to offer - lots, but we've failed to cultivate it. that's 40,000 minds and imaginations that are redundant. Had they been born into more fortunate positions, what would they have made of their lives and given to society?

Unlike us, children etching a living from the street do not see their future as hopeless. They still hold aspirations. Dawit Yirga, who must be one of the sparkiest kids roaming Arat Kilo, is working to be a doctor. GOAL children hope to be masons, labourers, businessmen and even pilots. They seem to know better than most their objectives in life. It illustrates that given the chance, they would contribute to, not be a drain upon society.

It is essential to see past the "street kids facade." To see them playing at the GOAL Drop-in-Centre, they are ordinary adolescents: being child-like, competitive, laughing, cheering each other on, encouraging. They seem very supportive of each other, a replica of 'normal' society. In fact, they are probably better at functioning in society than most of us, since they always operate in groups to share out money and protect each other. The problem arises when we try to integrate them into a society with such ingrained prejudices against them.

The solutions? Horrendous stories circulate: children are taken out of Addis to areas accessible at night, such as Wolleka, Shashemene, Debre Zeit, to be dumped and left prey to the maulings of hyenas. One child told me how he had managed to jump out of the truck he had been jostled into at the traffic lights. Two boys wandered into GOAL, feverish with malaria; they said that they had hitched back from Goffa where they had been stranded fifteen days earlier. Others are not so lucky. Unofficial sources have even suggested that up to 1000 children are carted off each month. Even if these are just rumours - despite the evidence to prove they are not - they highlight the problem. That children are roaming the streets at night; that children need protection from abuse and that there is something, be it older street gangs, the public or formal institutions, that children are very, very frightened of. No child whatever their history, should be exposed to this. This sort of solution hardly makes use of all that the children have to offer.

There has been more constructive help given to street children. In 1990, a mobile unit was formed by the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs in conjunction with Radda Barna, to help provide support for poor families. The government is aware of the problem, it is motivating international NGOs to support indigenous NGOs in tackling the issue of children on the streets. Although it conducted a nation-wide survey eighteen months ago to give technical advice, it does not have the resources to do much itself. It does run some form of night shelter in the worst areas such as around the Mercarto, Meskal Square and Cherkos, where children pay between 75 cents and three birr per night. Just to sleep in safety.

UNICEF together with University College Cork, in Ireland conducted an extensive survey of street children, but that was in 1993.

Newly recruited police are being trained at the Kolfe Police Training Centre to see children as vulnerable, requiring protection and help. Hopefully this will soon be incorporated into the national police-training curriculum.

HOPE Enterprises provides day-to-day relief with a feeding centre on Churchill Road which provides on average, 500 meals per day to those lucky enough to receive a meal ticket from a passer-by.

GOAL-Ethiopia, one of the few NGOs dealing with hard-core street-children, runs a drop-in-centre to keep children off the street during the day. Medical, educational, washing, counseling and meal services are provided, as well as job-training and placements. A savings scheme encourages children to learn how to use their money. Three night shelters can accommodate 75 children and altogether, 369 are registered in their programme. But as they are well aware, this is by no means enough.

Most NGOs focus on methods to prevent children taking to the streets, such as Terre des hommes, Lausanne's Disrupted Families project. Forum on Street Children is the only well-promoted, indigenous NGO devoted solely to helping street children.

What this identifies is that there is dispersed help but it is not far- reaching enough. No-one is capable of successfully working alone in this issue: if NGOs, the government, private organisations and society, all entered into support together, pooled their resources; if everyone was determined to make a concerted effort, together, solutions could be more easily solved, funds more easily found.

The problem lies with us, with the community, with refusal to accept that these children are the victims of our war-torn past. It is our attitudes that have to change. It is time that we stopped blaming the children for their situations, stopped viewing them as unsettled trouble-makers that are unreconcilable with society. If every business and company in Addis Ababa took the initiative to take on just one street child as a trainee, it would take 100s if not 1000s off the streets, opening up possibilities of employment. Projects involving the community are vital. Schemes such as Terre des hommes' plan to initiate a bed-and-breakfast service using the residents of Addis TAbaba, or the already functioning GOAL library service open not just to GOAL children and staff but to members of the local community and run by volunteers from the kebele are the way forward to draw these estranged vagrants back into our world. As Ato Bekele, the manager of GOAL's street children project, stated:

"Awareness and advocacy of street children is very low. This is an issue which must be addressed."

The street children at GOAL said they wanted to help other street children, to provide clothes, food and shelter, to rehabilitate and share the skills they have learned, when they grow up. We cannot wait that long. It is up to all of us to be committed to bring about change and now, before any more lives are wasted. It needs mass promotion and national corroboration.

At present, we cannot guarantee that those 8-15 year olds will ever get themselves into a position where they are able to provide others with the opportunities that they have received through GOAL, but they are determined not to remain the way they are. And we must be as committed and resolute as they are.

Whose responsibility are they?

"It is the duty of the family, of society and state to guarantee children and adolescents with absolute priority."

-------

* Surveys by MOLSA, UNICEF and GOAL-Ethiopia put the official number of street children at between 25-40,000.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Ethiopian Roundtable on Culture and Economic Development


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Ethiopian Economic Association (EEA) held a roundtable discussion on the interrelationship between culture and economic development on March 20, 1997 at the National Hotel here in Addis Ababa.

Among the distinguished academics and other intellectuals present were Dr. Yonas Admassu, Ato Tekalege Gedamu, Dr. Yeraswork Admassie and Dr. Berhanu Nega, who is the current president of the EEA.

Dr. Yonas Admassu, a lecturer at the Institute of Language Studies of A. A. University, made the observations quoted below:

"Scholars and policy makers are much inclined to make esoteric discourses on development without taking into account cultural influences on economic development. Subtle implications of Ethiopia's heterogeneous cultures and sub- cultures for socio-economic development do not fit into the multiple sets of economic models which have much more to do with western realities than with the peculiar socio-cultural assets of the country. Though we usually try to think of economic development in terms of statistics and figures, lack of sound understanding of the complex cultural values makes our efforts to bring about economic development futile in most cases." 

On his part, Ato Tekalegn Gedamu, Chief Executive Officer of Abyssinia Bank, had the following to say:

"Ethiopia's long standing practice of administration, well-developed social values and quality of human resources could be regarded in a positive sense as valuable assets, which could be harnessed towards the attainment of socio- economic progress. However, some social traits have been abused for too long and governments are generally bent on ruling rather than administering people judiciously. The culture of envy, the still undeveloped tradition of thrift and the like have posed obstacles to economic progress."

Similarly, Dr. Yeraswork of the Dept. of Sociology and Social Anthropology , A. A. University, made the following incisive comments:

"One serious impediment to socio-economic development is the lack of a favouable political and economic environment which discourages those who want to work. The obstacle is not only the existence of people who do not want to work but also the prevalence of an unfavorable climate which frustrates those who are able and interested to work. There should be a well-defined system of incentives and accountability which would encourage those who want to commit themselves to constructive ventures. Bureaucratic red-tape should be curtailed and the law should provide protection for entrepreneurial individuals. Such malpractices as nepotism, favoritism, corruption and patronage should be eradicated."

The EEA's recognition of the importance of the interrelationship between culture and economic development should be greatly appreciated. Ethiopians who have had the privilege and advantage of modern education are generally aware of the negative influences of culture as they are generally speaking in a position to compare traditional social culture with modern social culture which they have come to know through their education. One of the remarkable features of traditional social culture in Ethiopia is the persistence of its influence even on those who are educated. One such influence, inherited from traditional church schools, is the inability to accept the possibility of being excelled by others.

In traditional church schools, outstanding "Kine" (double entendre) scholars are so much envied by less gifted pupils that their lives are often at risk, frequently being poisoned by those whose envy assumes homicidal proportions. The same is also true of competition in the political arena where ambitious individuals resort to force of arms to gain political ascendancy. Hence, in Ethiopia what may be termed a warrior culture is deeply embedded in the cultural consciousness of the society.

The negative influences of the deep-rooted culture of envy are also clearly manifested in the economic and commercial sphere where smear campaigns are run against economically successful people by less successful ones although the manner of acquisition of wealth by the former may be perfectly legal.

On the other hand, the fatalism of the broad masses poses a paradox which is quite difficult to unravel. This has led some to make the general observation that envy and "warriorism" are much more pronounced among social elite groups, be they traditional or modern, than among the vast majority of the Ethiopian people.

However, since the social elite groups are products of the society at large it would constitute a contradiction to contend that the masses are devoid of envy and the warrior culture. A more accommodating line of reasoning would be to regard envy as the antithesis of fatalism in a society where both co-exist. A negative reaction against those who have succeeded in life which is thought to be essentially pre-determined by fate is quite possible in a dialectically dual co-existence. So, envy may be seen as a conscious or unconscious revolt against fatalism.

Generally, several more negative cultural traits in the Ethiopia society could be identified besides "warriorism" and green envy, including the following:

* excessive conformity

* religiosity

* over-dependence on parents, relatives and on the society at large ( the latter giving rise to high social dependency)

* indolence and lethargy (especially in urban culture)

* docility

* pretentiousness

* distrust of intellectual investigation

* unworldliness (as manifested in downgrading of material possessions)

* subjective reasoning

* excessive gossiping and backbiting

* conspicuous consumption to impress others (related to pretentiousness)

* duplicity

* bribe-taking and giving

* nepotism

* ethnocentrism

Hence, an Ethiopian sitting at a dinner table with other Ethiopians would find it embarrassing to be the first one to start eating. Similarly, educated Ethiopians discussing work-related matters with their bosses would rather not risk offending the bosses by saying something opposed to the bosses' ideas. Religiosity may be manifested in not working on all the Saints' Days which, according to some estimates, may number as many as 270 in a single year!

Overdependence shows up in lack of critical and independent thinking and in social dependency, including the culture of begging. Non-nutritional manifestations of indolence and lethargy originate from the cultural traits of fatalism and unworldliness. Docility emanates from fatalism, acceptance of the natural order of things and as protection against potential retaliation for covert envy and coveting which may be discovered by the envied. Pretentiousness is everywhere to be seen in Ethiopian culture. A hungry Ethiopian may refuse an invitation to a glorious meal lest he should be judged as one who has not enough to eat at home. A girl may spurn the advances of a boy she secretly admires for fear that he may think her to be cheap. Lavish weddings prepared to impress guests have bankrupted many couples and parents.

The negative consequences of all these generally undesirable cultural traits on economic development have been obvious enough. Leaders who take political power by force (warriorism) very often refuse to work and cooperate with people who are much better educated, more experienced and intellectually more gifted for fear that they may be outshined by them (envy), with dire implications for the formulation of sound and practicable economic policy. Ethiopian leaders often equate setbacks in intellectual arguments with defeats in battle. Similarly, the negative consequences of the cultural traits of indolence, religiosity, overdependence, excessive conformity and conspicuous consumption on output and productivity, the degree of social dependency, entrepreneurial initiative and domestic savings have been quite significant although the extent of their influence may be difficult to quantify.

What should we do about all these bad cultural trails? The task of doing something about them squarely rests with the elite groups, especially the modern ones. "Warriorism" as a means of access to political power should be replaced by free and fair elections; envy of the green type should give way to constructive competition; getting to know a prospective marriage partner should not take an eternity because of cultural pretentiousness and getting married should be no more than a ten-guest and a-hundred-birr affair! So the advice would be:

"Work hard, get married simply, continue to work hard for your family's and your own sake (and, one should add, your country's sake), and if you are politically ambitious and have the qualities needed, try to get elected by majority vote. Say your prayers everyday, but don't use sham prayer and worship as a cover-up for indolence. By all means, make money, but don't steal it by any means. Let merit be your guiding principle and eschew favourtism of all kinds. Try to keep fit and healthy so that you may do all these yet another day".


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Ethiopia's Mohammed Idris -- "Making Music for the Eyes"


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1827 words


 

Addis Ababa - Lifts breaking down are usual occurrences, but their significance is magnified when you find yourself having to walk up eleven floors. So when I finally made it to the apartment of film maker Mohammed Idris, it was with a slight reluctance that I shifted my attention from my cold drink to the video deck where his wife, Halima Mussa was putting on the " Dawn of Hope".

The "Dawn of Hope", a documentary directed and produced by Mohammed Idris won the Magna Matre at the World Film Festival 1985 in Czechoslovakia organised under the theme "Bread and Peace". Revolving around the 1984 Ethiopian famine, the film would certainly be regarded as a 'propaganda' piece had it not been for a unique blend of the tragedies of famine and searching for an explanation as to why it occurs in the land of the Nile. 

However, that was not the best film he had done, Mohammed is quick to say. Retired from the Ministry of Information since 1994, Mohammed's involvement as a consultant in the new film "Endurance" ife of the renown track-star Haile Gebresellasie makes this statement understandable. Hard though it might be to believe, working with Haile was not what made Mohammed say, "Really Allah loves me," when he first heard of the project. What got him so excited was the chance to work with the director Leslie Woodhead --with whom he had made three other films including "Kwegu" (about a little known tribe in Ethiopia) that won first prize in 1985 at the Festival de Luchon Grand Prix Du festival in France.

"After I had signed the contract, Leslie said, 'The ball is in your hands Mohammed' and so I went and I could not sleep." Mohammed felt a big responsibility weighing down on him and said to himself, "Leslie is alien to our culture so I must bear all the responsibility. This is a project (that) I shouldn't work for money." So when Leslie Woodhead gave him a rough outline of the script, Mohammed had to, in his own words, "invent the cultural aspects (with) Haile as the central character with all 'Ethiopianness' revolving around him. To show Haile as a rural 'geter' boy and his mother as a real Ethiopian 'geter' woman. To depict not as a single individual woman but a character (that) depicts Ethiopian women fully and Ethiopian rural life. The very difficult scene that Leslie had thought would be was the funeral service (for Haile's mother) but that went well. We had to bring a coffin and put stones in it and we had to bring 'alkash' mourners. We brought in relatives and they started shedding their tears and it became perfect." What Woodhead had brought with him on August 1996 was really the bare outline as Mohammed shows the papers with dates and a line or two scribbled next to them reveal. But this was the way Woodhead usually worked and Mohammed was not surprised. "When we were shooting 'Kwegu' we flew from here by helicopter and landed at the Omo river. And we don't know whether our characters are there or not leave alone the cinematic aspects of the film. The anthropologists asked for a few characters--they were there--we took off all the gears (and) the helicopter went. It came back after a month and we had a brilliant film." His appreciation of Woodhead is returned as can be seen from the latter's observation as written in his book "A box full of spirit". "He (Mohammed)" Woodhead wrote," was one of those people with a talent for friendship. Walking down a street in Addis with Mohammed was like strolling through a familiar village. In the bank, a dramatic circular tower like a trendy cathedral, he moved quickly between embraces and hellos to track down our bundles of low denomination notes, vital for porterage and gifts. At the Red Cross offices, more handshakes and we'd come away with two huge tents. Permits and paraffin, Mohammed had fixed it all. But his major achievement was the helicopter." Mohammed's dark face loses its huge perfect smile when he mentions that he had lost the certificate for his part in 'Kwegu' following the confusion after the death of his first wife Bezunesh Bekele-- one of the country's leading singers. But the cloud soon lifts from his face as making himself comfortable on the sofa, he talks about his career that has made him a household name.

Born in 1941, Addis Ababa, Mohammed Mussa Idris graduated from the then Haile Selassie University in 1968 with an advanced diploma in Amharic and English. He then taught in elementary and high school for the following seven years before taking an intensive one year radio journalism diploma course. Mohammed does not see this move in the light of an unpredictable career change. "I can't say it was mere luck," Mohammed remarks, "because it was my educational background--English and Amharic composite major-that really pushed me to journalism. The other thing is I am somewhat a poet. I won first prize in a poetry competition in the university. I was also president of the Ethiopian Muslim Students Association. I was so popular and people were encouraging me as a poet and as a writer. I was also writing for the Addis Zemen before joining the Ministry of Information."

When he joined Radio Ethiopia as head of the Amharic section, Mohammed introduced the programme 'Know Your Country' -- a programme that made his reputation. Getting the chance to travel extensively, Mohammed wrote for Menen magazine and contributed to television as well--and co-produced programmes with for example with Addis Ababa Bank. Also responsible for the broadcast of special programmes (on holidays and such) Mohammed found himself having to do some quick thinking before presenting what was to be his best piece. The feature in question was about Emperor Theodros to be broadcast on his hundredth anniversary. However, Theodros was not a favorite of Emperor Haile Selassie, Mohammed noted, and those heads who knew the young journalist's desire to bring forward 'provocative' programmes would not let this pass. After putting it off for three years, Mohammed finally got his chance. One day his boss flew to France on Ethiopian Airlines' inaugural flight and the timing was perfect as it coincided with the 103 anniversary of Theodros. So Mohammed approached Negash Gebremariam who loved the programme but stated that he was worried about one part where Catholicism (an accusory statement referring to the wearing of modern clothes) was mentioned. There was no time to take a close look at the programme and so when the latter went to lunch, Mohammed went to the deputy to tell him he had received the go- ahead. The programme was a success and the studio received many calls including one from Gondar that inquired whether "his majesty was still on the throne." Not surprising then that the studio heard from the prime minister and Mohammed was told by his bosses, "Its a good programme but don't repeat it.".

When the revolution came though, the staff found themselves not only 'confined' to their programme but under bosses that knew little about the work. "We had 'guards' no 'bosses'," Mohammed said, "and we had to teach them about film, about radio, about production. It is very hard to explain to them what you are making. It is heavier than the production itself." In 1975 though, Mohammed was unwillingly transferred to television where he was made current affairs head. He remembers being called to the office by one of his seniors and told, "Look Mohammed, you are very good in radio--that means you are good in sound. If you just add pictures you will be a filmmaker." So Mohammed traveled to the war front with cameraman Elias Birru to make documentaries for the government. And at the back of his head was his own documentary, 'The scare of war' that would show the war for what it was without taking sides. Another idea for a film made following Woodhead's 'formula' for a 'drama doc' has also been shelved for the time being.

"The events were moving so fast and I was always moving with (them)." Once, Mohammed was asked to do a photographic exhibition under the title "Peace". But he found that when he finished one chapter and felt ready to stage the exhibition , he was told the situation was different. After he was asked to change it three times, Mohammed did what he considered to be a great blunder for someone who was a member of the Blue Nile Toastmasters and so knew about communication--he blew up at the minister. Mohammed was not punished for his outburst but rather compensated. He was given the chance to go to England to produce a BBC 'under the sun' trilogy--A woman who smiles, Duca and Gadi go hunting, and Our way of living. These were based on the life of the Hamer tribe and won several anthropological awards. Mohammed was also involved in the making of three films in the Granada Disappearing World Series--The Migrant, The land is bad, and Nitha.

A man with extensive experience in film making in Ethiopia and with still much to offer, Mohammed is unsure about the country's new crop of would-be film makers. And it is not only the high expense involved that has added him to the long list experts who do not see an 'heir' in sight. "I see one obstacle," he noted, "Whenever there is a setting it is always a bunna bet (a drinking house). They don't choose good sites. Always they talk about relationships of male and female. Always they show love--that is good I am not against love--but when a man loves a woman and a woman loves a man you show the life style of these two. But they don't show you why she loves that man. Everything is superficial. They don't show the effort that he makes or she makes in his or her work." But not everything is wrong with what the young generation Tis doing. "I see better techniques than in my time," Mohammed added, "so by the time they reach my age I am sure these youngsters will make a good film."


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


156 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Ethiopia;
Inadequate Facilities on Sidist-Kilo Campus of University


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1334 words


 

Addis Ababa - On Sidist-Kilo Campus of A.A. University there is little to show for the government's professed commitment to greater investment in human capital.

The buildings are generally in a poor state of repair. The library (Kennedy Memorial Library) is overcrowded and poorly lit. The periodicals section of the library is laughable, pathetically cluttered with nothing more than dirty and crumpled local newspapers. None of the well-known international newspapers and magazines such as the "Herald Tribune", the "Guardian", the " Washington Post", "Newsweek" and "Time" are visible anywhere in the room. Most of the visible stocks of books are mouldy with age. Computers seem to be unheard of here. 

However, students try to make the most of what is available. They are dour and quiet. Humping over their notes and books, they look quite industrious and intent. It is difficult, though, to fathom what is going on in their minds. Do they have the elementary and secondary educational background to cope with the demands of higher education? How are their language skills? Do they find it difficult to understand everything they read? Is their mathematics strong enough to enable them to grapple with differential and integral calculus? Is their approach to acquiring knowledge based largely on rote memory or have they developed the mental skills to work out problems on the basis of creative and logical reasoning? What is their average IQ? Do they get adequate nutrition commensurate with the enormous intellectual efforts expected of them? Do they have reasonably decent accommodation? Is there anybody, like a psychological counselling expert, to give them tips on how to manage their personal lives and say some comforting words when they are faced with emotional crises?

Or maybe they are just too tough to require any such schmaltzy treatment! However, all the questions raised above are of great relevance to the objective of creating a national intelligentsia of the right caliber, because in education quality is much more important than quantity. Students do not become academic superstars by miracle. To attain such a status, they must be taught by good teachers and must have access to good educational and supportive facilities? For example how many of them have heard of the Internet and how many know that they can now use it as an important source of information? How do you expect them to have heard of Dolly (the first ever animal (a sheep) cloned from a mature cell) if they are not provided with international newspapers and magazines such as the ones mentioned above. Talk to them about the "millennium bomb" and don't be surprised to see at least some of them look blank. Similarly, you can't blame a student for saying in English, "I haven't many money so I can't to buy many furniture" if he or she was taught English in high school by a person who had only a smattering of the language.

The price of not investing sufficiently in the development of human resources can be very high in terms of forfeited economic and social growth. With little or no economic growth, resources available for human resources development become even more meagre. This in turn negatively affects economic growth, setting in motion a perniciously vicious circle. Politics often stands in the way of creating the necessary awareness about the importance of realizing the true value of human resources development. Educated and experienced people may be relegated to the fringes of the decision-making process by less educated and experienced people for fear that they may become dangerous political competitors. This in fact may be thought of as being the first link in the circular chain of human resources underdevelopment. With the best and the brightest barred from the decision-making process, the economy is often mismanaged and growth is arrested, making it impossible to make more resources available for investment in human capital. In turn, this undermines the quality of education and training, demeaning the role of educated, trained and experienced people. This becomes a bogus justification for not paying all that much attention to human resources development. Then people would dare to say: "The university has been around for about fifty years, but the standard of living of the people in the country has been declining during almost all those years. What price university education? It is better to be a "weyalla" and earn more!"

So the first logical step to augment investment in human capital in Ethiopia would be to demonstrate, in no uncertain terms, the power of quality education and work experience by concretely showing what well-trained and experienced personnel can do in terms of bringing about economic prosperity in the country such has been the experience of the South-East Asian countries, where mostly technocrats and talented people are in the driver's seat. We need to have our "wonder boys" and girls in agriculture, industry and finance. Not that such "wonder boys" do not sometimes drive the economy to the ground ( remember the Mexican financial crisis?) , but on average their track-record is one of indisputable distinction. One of the good qualities of most well- educated officials is that when they make mistakes, they can quickly trace where they have gone wrong and often offer apologies and resignations!

But who is going to realize the immense potential lying hidden in the toiling university students at Sidist Kilo and improve the facilities available to them so that they may one day become our "wonder boys and girls" ? The task falls squarely on the shoulders of those at the helm. They must bring about tangible economic prosperity, through comprehensive economic growth and development, and not be satisfied with self-deceiving showcases of sham economic well-being. To do this, well-educated and experienced personnel should be fully integrated into the decision-making process at all levels.

In the meantime, though, there are quite a few small things we can do to improve the facilities on Sidist-kilo campus. Here they are:

* improve access to periodical, newspaper and magazine information in the periodical section of Kennedy Library by making arrangements with the foreign community in Addis Ababa to kindly make such publications available after use;

* improve the poor lighting in the library by replacing done-for light bulbs and grimy shades which blot out the light

* Give the buildings a fresh coating of paint

* Work out schemes whereby computers could be used to facilitate the work at the book circulation desks;

* create conditions whereby students may have easy access to the services of the Internet.

These may sound like very small improvements, but they would go a long way towards making life more tolerable on Sidist-kilo campus. For bigger improvements, we need a much larger budget allocation and this can only come from the higher-ups.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 4, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Salim Urges Participation in All-Africa Trade Fair


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Addis Ababa - The secretary-general of the Organisation of African Unity, Dr. Salim Ahmed Salim, arrived in Kaduna State, Nigeria on March 29th, to attend the opening ceremony of the 7th OAU/AEC All-Africa Trade Fair.

In statements at the ceremony, Salim called upon the African Business Community to take full advantage of the fair. he urged member states to buy each other's goods and stressed the need to allow "bona fide" African business people to travel freely within the various regions. 

Dr. Salim further noted that for African goods and people to move freely throughout the continent, Africa needed, without delay, to address the problem of transport and communication facilities. Convinced that Intra- African trade was the most feasible strategy of launching Africa into the emerging international economic order characterised by liberalisation, competition and globalisation, the secretary-general called for a reassessment of policies and strategies affecting Africa.

This year's Trade Fair is unique in that it has, for the first time, a component of the tourism and travel sector. Dr. Salim called upon organisers of a Workshop on Tourism Development in Africa to endeavour to come up with implementable recommendations for the benefit of Member States interested in doing business in this sector.

The OAU head also advised participants of the Women in Business Workshop scheduled for April 4, to assist in ways in which women entrepreneurs could build upon their remarkable success in cross-border trade and business activities.

LANGUAGE: English

158 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 6, 1997


South Africa;
News Release On Amnesty Decisions


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Cape Town - Statement from the Amnesty Committee of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, April 8, 1997

(The following summary of the applications, and the main points of the decisions and reasons therefor, is given purely to assist those journalists needing a quick initial summary of the applications and is not a binding document with any legal status.)

The Truth and Reconciliation Commission announces the granting of amnesty to three African National Congress members from North-West Province and to a Conservative Party and Volksfront member from the Eastern Cape.

It also announces the denial of amnesty to two applicants from the Free State, one an ANC member who killed a municipal policeman and the other a man who took part in a "gruesome and brutal attack" on people whom he alleged were suspected to be IFP members.

Amnesty has been granted to Peter Lebona, Thabo Solomon Lekitlane and Elias Busakwe, ANC members from Kanana, Orkney, who killed Zenzile Charles Dlamini, the leader of a vigilante group in their township who admitted sexually assaulting a woman, in July 1991.

It has also been granted to Saint Michael Schutte, a Conservative Party and Volksfront member from Stutterheim, Eastern Cape, for possession of seven AK- 47s and 235 rounds of ammunition. 

Amnesty was refused to:

-- Derrick Tshidiso Kobue, an ANC member who killed Bothetsa Sekatame, a municipal policeman, in Kroonstad in December 1991.

-- Justice Sekgopa, who took part in the killing of Shelly Erica Basson, Anthony , Mark Casey, Johannes P van Niekerk and Michael F Belelie at Mashongoville in the Odendaalsrus district in September 1990.

Details of the cases follow:

1. Peter Lebona, Thabo Solomon Lekitlane and Elias Busakwe:

The three men have been serving 10-year jail sentences for the murder of Dlamini, who was at one stage also a member of the ANC but later established a vigilante group called Kofifi.

The Amnesty Committee noted in the reasons for its decision that evidence had been led of various acts of harassment in the form of assault and rape committed by Dlamini, predominantly on members of the ANC and its Women's League. The applicants contended that they perceived Dlamini's gang to be collaborating with police, and that they suspected the gang was aided and abetted by the police.

The Committee said it was common cause that when Lebone and Lekitlane were taking Dlamini to the local police station -- after the latter had admitted sexually assaulting an elderly woman and grievously assaulting her husband -- Dlamini pulled out a gun. Before Dlamini could fire, Lebone fired a shot at him, using a firearm which Busakwe had supplied earlier. Then Lekitlane had stabbed Dlamini with a knife. Other members of a group accompanying Dlamini to the police station also took part in the attack.

The Committee found:

"Given the above facts, it is quite evident that the deceased and his gang disrupted meetings of the ANC, thereby impeding the ANC in their exercise of free political activity. They committed atrocious acts against members of the ANC and were generally perceived as an anathema in the community. The local community and the ANC leadership perceived them as collaborating with the local police to inhibit them from exercising free political activity in the township. We therefore find that the primary aim of the deceased's group was to and did in fact impede members of the ANC from exercising free political activity."

The Committee said the killing of Dlamini by Lebone and Lekitlane was "an act associated with a political objective" and accordingly granted amnesty. It said although Busakwe did not physically take part in the killing, he admitted facts which connected him to the murder, and he complied with the requirements for amnesty.

2. Saint Michael Schutte

Schutte did not appear at a public hearing of the Amnesty Committee because his offence was not a gross violation of human rights, as defined in the legislation governing the Commission.

He bought the AK-47s on a visit to Mozambique in September 1993, and was arrested carrying them at the Lebombo border post upon his return to South Africa on September 28. He was due to have stood trial in Nelspruit this month.

He said in his amnesty application that the weapons were bought with the intention of defending the white community of Stutterheim in the event of a civil war after the 1994 election, and of promoting the aims of the right- wing parties to which he belonged.

3. Justice Sekgopa

Sekgopa is serving 27 years' imprisonment on four counts of murder and one count of malicious damage to property.

Reviewing the evidence, the Committee said Sekgopa and other members of a crowd attacked the victims with pangas, knives, sjamboks and other weapons. Ms Basson's genitals and breasts were mutilated. The Committee said:

"It was submitted on behalf of the Applicant that his motive for participating in the gruesome and brutal attack on the deceased was that he believed that the deceased were members of the Inkatha Freedom Party who had come to attack his community...

"The Committee has grave difficulties with this argument because there is no shred of evidence to suggest that the Applicant and/or his co-assailants could have believed that the deceased were members of the IFP at all...."

After reviewing the evidence in relation to perceptions about the IFP, the Committee said it was "quite evident that the Applicant committed the offences for which he has applied for amnesty in an indiscriminate manner against private individuals." The Committee continued:

"This was a clear case of mob violence in which the applicant participated. There was no suggestion of prior common purpose on the part of the participants. We accordingly cannot accept the evidence of the applicant when questioned, that he participated in the attack in order to kill apartheid. There had been no prior discussion or agreement amongst the participants to achieve any political objective. Furthermore, the nature of the attack was such that there was no proportionality between it and the supposed political objective, namely, sending a message to the Government that apartheid be abolished."

4. Derrick Tshidiso Kobue

The Committee said evidence in this application was that Mr Sekatame had intervened in an argument between Kobue and his girlfriend in a restaurant/shebeen and threatened Kobue with a gun. Kobue, an ANC Youth League and Self-Defence Unit member, had run away and, when Mr Sekatame emerged from the restaurant, Kobue had his comrades had followed him and stabbed him.

The Committee noted that Kobue advanced as a reason for the killing the fact that the deceased was a policeman and that some policemen co-operated with the Three Million Gang, a declared enemy of the ANC in Kroonstad. Kobue also testified that the killing was on instructions from his commander in the Self-Defence Unit.

The Committee found:

"The reason advanced by the Applicant for the killing, namely that he had killed him because he was a policeman and collaborated with the Three Million Gang, seems improbable..."

However, the Committee said it had no other evidence before it in the case, and went on to examine the Applicant's evidence more closely. It concluded:

"There is nothing in the advanced reasons that could have given the applicant any reason reasonably to conclude that the deceased was a collaborator with the Three Million Gang, nor that he was perceived to be an enemy of the ANC and its structures by virtue of his office as a policeman and this evidence is accordingly rejected."


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

159 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Science and Health;
Banjul Launches Battery Disposal Program


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

BANJUL, Gambia (PANA) - Authorities in the Greater Banjul area have introduced measures to reduce threats posed by the proliferation of used batteries which degrade the environment.

Used and decayed batteries, which are abundant in many African urban centers, ooze chemicals which cause mental retardation in children, thereby hampering their progress in school.

Environmental authorities in the Kanifing Municipal Council (KMC), a suburb of the Gambian capital, have erected metal containers at strategic points where people can dump used batteries. 

These containers are about a meter above the ground and have an accessible hole at one side. The rectangular shaped containers are clearly marked "KMC Battery Disposal Bins."

The initiative is significant in that it may well be the first of its kind in the sub-region. The scheme is being run by Gamworks agency and the National Environment Agency.

Gamworks, more often referred to as AGETIP in French speaking African states, was set up by government to administer World Bank funds allocated to urban development projects.

The coordinator for technical services at the National Environment Agency, Modou Sarr, says the batteries would later be collected from the metal boxes and transported to a final dump site.

Sarr said that in order to ensure greater environmental safety and security, the huge hole that serves as a dump would be reinforced with internal concrete walls to hold the decomposing batteries, thereby protect neighborhood environments.

The site will be located away from human settlements to ensure better protection of the population against known hazards.

The facility is estimated to cost 109,000 dalasi (about 10,900 U.S. dollars) of which Gamworks contributed 80 percent and the environmental agency the remaining 20 percent.

Sarr said the scheme was mooted by a German woman in Kololi, just outside Banjul, who first took the initiative of collecting used batteries.

She sought and received help from school children whom she paid money whenever they brought her used batteries collected in and around the vicinity of Kololi.

Sarr said the woman succeeded in collecting a large quantity of such batteries for which no proper storage had been found.

"Even the Bakoteh refuse dump was found unsuitable for the batteries, which contain dangerous chemicals such as cadium, mercury and lead," Sarr said.

He said the KMC provided a shed where the batteries were temporarily stored while awaiting the final construction of the permanent facility.

Expounding on the dangers of used batteries, Sarr said "small children who usually play with batteries are certainly unaware of the dangers inherent in both mercury and lead."

He said this lack of awareness had, in the past, been the main factor preventing the required cooperation between institutions and the public.

However, he remains optimistic that with the project firmly in place, Banjul residents will respond positively to rid their city of the harmful batteries.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Science and Health;
African Anesthetists Told To Come Together


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean Vice-President Simon Muzenda told African anesthetists Monday they should pool resources, particularly in the professional economic field, in line with current international trends.

Opening a four-day All-Africa Anaesthetic Congress, Muzenda said an example was the European Union which had brought prosperity to member countries. 

"For example if an essential drug list, such as we have in this country, were compiled for anaesthesia and anaesthetic related drugs, which was acceptable to a whole vast area of Africa, that area would then become a desirable market," he said.

If huge sales were made, the cost of the drugs would fall, benefiting all, including the pharmaceutical companies.

A regional grouping would also benefit anesthetists in the field of education.

Muzenda said because rewards outside the universities were great, many academics were always leaving for greener pastures. Academics, particularly in medicine, made considerable financial sacrifices in order to study their subjects and teach them to the leaders of tomorrow.

"In Africa, if academics find themselves financially unable to provide what most professional people accept as their due, such as a car and a house for themselves, they will either moonlight or, if they are more honest, leave the job altogether," he said.

The congress, being attended by anesthetists from all over the world, is the first to be held in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
