Africa News


April 7, 1997


South Africa;
South Africa To Chair Non-Aligned Movement


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - A ministerial meeting of the Non- Aligned Movement (NAM) opened Monday in New Delhi, India, during which South Africa is expected to assume leadership of the 113-nation group.

From New Delhi, the South African High Commission in India, said that African delegates had endorsed South Africa to take over from Colombia, whose Foreign Minister Maria Emma Mejia has already met with Alfred Nzo, South Africa's Foreign Minister. 

Nzo, who arrived in India on Saturday, has also met with various other foreign ministers. He has participated in an informal meeting of former NAM summit hosts, including Indonesia, India, Egypt, Cuba, Algeria, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Sri Lanka and Colombia.

"Great excitement was expressed about the prospect of South Africa hosting the next NAM summit towards the end of 1998," the High Commission said.

The New Delhi ministerial meeting will be discussing the envisaged restructuring of the United Nations -- especially the expansion and role of its Security Council, which President Nelson Mandela is adamant should be more representative of NAM member countries.

Other issues will include total nuclear disarmament; better utilization of potential and resources by developing countries; efforts to ensure that developing countries are equitable partners in the the process of globilization; and coordinated efforts to preserve the global ecological balance.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Business and Finance;
Tripartite Africa Labor And Social Commission Meet Opens


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity said Monday that African could succeed in confronting the challenges of conflict and economic integration if they employed good government and the rule of law.

If efforts at achieving peace, development and integration are to succeed in Africa, Salim Ahmed Salim said, "our countries should also ensure speedy promotion of good governance, characterized by accountability, probity, transparency, equal application of the rule of law, and clear separation of powers."

He termed this elements as "an objective and a condition for rapid and sustainable development." 

Salim, the secretary-general of the organization, was addressing the opening session of the 20th ordinary session of the O.A.U. Labor and Social Commission, a tripartite organ of the continental body.

The six-day meeting will deliberate on employment, enhancing productivity and women's empowerment in Africa.

Salim said confronting the challenges of peace and other development issues calls for addressing squarely the scourge of conflicts in the region.

He said that conflicts in Burundi, eastern Zaire, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Somalia, and Sudan were "a big drain on the scarce resources that Africa can ill-afford to lose."

Africa, he said, could take the cue from Europe, the Americas and Asia to cope with "the other important challenge confronting our continent" -- economic integration.

He said pooling resources to be competitive in the world market required the participation and close involvement of all African interest groups: the government, workers and employers.

The United Nations Economic Commission for Africa and the International Labor Organization also appealed for governments to provide an environment for economic reforms that will sweep away unemployment.

The commission's chief of administration and conference services division, Jacques Diouf, told the gathering that Africa's officially recorded unemployment, which stood at 22.8 percent in 1990, was expected to reach 30 percent by the year 2000.

He said youth unemployment in the 15-25 year age groups, covering also "the rapidly increasing university students in Africa," was expected to grow faster than in any other group in the coming 30 years.

During this period the continents projected population of poor, Diouf said, would rise from 216 million in 1990 to 304 million in the year 2000, accounting for half of Africa's total population.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Southern Africa;
Civil Wars Frustrate Comesa's Development


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, Comesa, said Monday that the economic development in most of its member states had declined because of the civil wars.

The organization's acting secretary-general, Erastus Mwencha, said that the gross domestic production (GDP) of most of its members had declined steadily from 1990 to 1994 due to drought and wars. 

He told a Comesa Council of Ministers meeting in Lusaka that in 1990 the total GDP which was 78.3 billion U.S. dollars declined to 66.1 billion in 1994.

However, he said that much progress had been made with regards to intra- Comesa trade. In value, this had increased from 834 million dollars in 1985 to 1.7 billion in 1994.

He said that in 1995, GDP grew by an additional 6.1 billion dollars, representing a growth rate of 9.5 percent. Preliminary estimates for 1996 post GDP growth at 1.6 percent.

Officially opening the meeting Zambia's vice-president, Godfrey Miyanda, called for quick resolutions of conflicts in the region.

A number of Comesa states, including Burundi, Somalia, Sudan and Zaire are engulfed in civil strife in which hundreds of thousands have been killed and displaced.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Zaire;
Zairean Peace Talks Under Veil Of Secrecy


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The Zairean peace talks continued late Sunday with no details being revealed on the content or progress made during the past two days of discussions.

The discussions attended by representatives of the Zairean government and rebels of the Democratic Alliance for the Liberation of Congo (Zaire) are being chaired by the United Nations and Organization of African Unity representative for the Great Lakes region, Mohamed Sahnoun of Algeria.

But nothing is filtering out of the talks. South African Foreign Affairs spokesman Pieter Swanepoel would not confirm whether the discussions would continue today. He also declined to reveal any details about the substance of the negotiations to date. 

The hosts have consistently avoided providing details on the talks, taking the standpoint that it was up to the negotiating parties to release such information.

The negotiations officially opened Saturday at an undisclosed location in Pretoria, where delegations of the Zairean government the anti-government alliance failed to commit themselves to a peaceful settlement to the war.

However, the leader of the alliance delegation, Bizima Karaha, commended the Zairean government for agreeing to take part in the talks.

"We are here because we believe those brothers of ours, for the first time, have realized that they can't make it with mercenaries and genocide. They can only make it with us if they want to survive," he said.

Zairean Foreign Minister Kamanda wa Kamanda gave the assurance that his delegation had no pre-conceived ideas.

"We are going to start these negotiations with a totally open mind to look for peace and to safeguard the unity, integrity and sovereignty of our country," he said.

South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki -- who has played a leading brokering role in the process leading to the current talks -- expressed confidence that the two parties would rise to the challenge of finding a peaceful solution. "We believe the outcome will make a critical contribution to the common and historical challenge to bring to fruition the African renaissance," he said.

Meanwhile as the rebels press even closer to Zaire's second largest city, Lubumbashi, reports say that 60 British troops arrived in the Congolese capital, Brazzaville, for a possible evacuation of British nationals from Zaire.

They joint other soldiers from Belgian, France and United States who have taken similar precautions.

Some 250 U.S. troops on land are backed by another 1,400 marines on board the helicopter carrier, Nassau, crusing off the coast of Congo.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (03/31 - 04/06)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Geneva - 30.03.97 -- James Baker in Western Sahara.

The foreign minister of the SADR announced that James Baker was expected to visit the Western Sahara in the third week of April. In a press statement, Bachir Sayed affirmed that the SADR welcomed this visit, attached high hopes on it to reach a solution to the Sahara issue and deliver the peace process from the crisis which was caused by the intransigence of the Moroccan side. 

02.04.97 -- Baker's Mission

James Baker III was at UN Headquarters for a full schedule of briefings ending with a meeting with the Secretary-General. Kofi Annan asked him to go to the region to assess the situation and to advise him whether or not a settlement plan can be implemented, Mr. Baker said. He has also to advise him on any additional initiatives that can be taken.

The UN Secretary-General Personal Envoy planned to go to the region as soon as he could make arrangements with the parties involved, but he did not specify what countries he would visit. "It seems to me the constellations are such that there should be the potential for some possibilities here," Baker said. "All I can tell you is I will give it my very best effort." Mr. Jensen, the Acting Special Representative for Western Sahara, continues doing the day- to-day work as head of the Mission.

02.04.97 -- Recognition Retired

Guinea-Bissau announces that it does no more recognize the SADR. It is the 4th African country, after Burkina-Fasso, Congo and Benin, which retired its recognition in the last months.

New England Africa Peace Tour

African scholars and activists touring almost 40 college and university campuses throughout New England, USA, April 7-11, 1997, are available for media assignments and interviews in the region. The Africa Peace Tour is sponsored by the American Friends Service Committee (AFSC), an international Quaker relief, development and advocacy organization involved in Africa and concerned about Africa's relationship with the U.S.

The Africa Peace Tour will be hosted by colleges and universities in Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts and Maine, including Brandeis and Tufts in the Boston area, Bryant and Brown in Rhode Island, the University of Vermont in Burlington, and Wesleyan and Yale universities in Connecticut.

The group includes nationals from Zaire, Burundi, Liberia, Nigeria, Ghana, Algeria, Western Sahara, Sudan, Mauritania, Mozambique, Mali and South Africa.

Contact: J. Ron Byler, 215-241-7060, or Aishah Shahidah Simmons, 215-241- 7056, both of AFSC.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Malawi;
Malawi News Roundup


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2600 words


 

Blantyre - 1. DEATH OF FORMER SPC

The former Secretary to the President and Cabinet, MacDonald Banda, died March 23 in a car accident. Banda, who was SPC from 1992 to 1994, was the last SPC under the former one party regime and he was replaced when the ruling UDF came to power.

At the time of his death, Banda, a carrier diplomat, was working as Investment Manager with Press Corporation Limited. Thousands of people paid their last respects to him on March 25 at his home in Nathenje, Lilongwe where his remains were buried. 

2. AIR MALAWI SLASHES REGIONAL FARES

Air Malawi is offering a 30% discount on all its African regional routes to six cities from April 1 to May 31. The airline's Planning and Marketing Manager, Jasson Siska, said the discount was a marketing strategy aimed at fending off the stiff competition prevailing on domestic and regional routes with more people opting to travel by bus.

The fairs cut will be applicable on the air line's routes to Harare, Lusaka, Nairobi, Dar es Salaam, Johannesburg and Maputo. Siska said the national flag carrier had also embarked on a phased development programme aimed at improving customer delivery services and the general welfare of the company's staff.

3. POPULATION CENSUS NEXT YEAR

A national population census, slated for mid '97, will not take place due to financial hiccups and lack of manpower at the National Statistics Office.

Commissioner for Statistics, Lloyd Golosi said preparations for the census, which were supposed to have been completed, have just started. A donor who is to sponsor the K30 million (US$2 million) exercise has not yet been identified.

Lloyd Golosi said, however, there were indications that the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) , might co-fund the census with the Malawi government as it did in 1987. "We need 25 vehicles, one for each district, and map assistants also for each district and we are still preparing for the task. At the moment, we only have 12 vehicles," he said.

According to the 1987 census, the country's population was 8 million. It is estimated that the population has since shot up to 12 million. Malawi has a fertility rate of 3.2%.

4. CIVIL SERVANTS TO STRIKE APRIL 7

The Civil Service Trade Union has declined a government offer to increase salaries by 10 to 47 percent, giving it one week to reverse the decision, and implement what is known as the Chatsika Report salaries in full or face a nationwide strike.

At a rally in Blantyre, union president, Thomas Banda also announced that civil servants would start a go-slow from April to put pressure on government. "The go-slow is aimed at making the government come to its senses before destruction," Banda said.

Government says implementing the Chatsika recommendations in full, estimated at a cost of K1 billion, will badly hurt the economy and set inflation and interest rates spiraling. The government also says the Chatsika wage increases would result in high tax increases and could cause labour instability in the private sector which in turn could discourage investment.

The Office of the President and Cabinet warned in a statement last week that the consequences of implementing the Chatsika salaries now are that both the private sector and the public service would be worse off than before. Instead, the OPC said, government would adopt a phased approach and award average increases ranging from 47% at lower levels to 10% at higher.

Banda however warned the government to implement the 29 cost-saving measures the union presented to government in 1995, which include trimming embassies,ministries and ministerial allowances and tax exemption packages.

5. WIFE OF BUSINESSMAN KILLED IN POLICE SHOOT OUT

Police on March 23 shot dead the wife of a Blantyre businessman in a shoot- out allegedly because the car she was driving had been one used in an armed robbery .

South African born, Angela, 22, wife of Kwacha Ghambi, met her fate as she was about to open the door of her car near a popular night spot in the heart of Blantyre. She was pronounced dead on arrival at the Adventist Health Centre.

The Blantyre police alleged she was killed by stray bullets as they were trying to defend themselves in a scuffle with her husband. According to police, events culminating in the late night shoot-out were sparked off by a highway robbery at gun-point, in which a car belonging to a business magnate was intercepted on the road to the airport by four people in a Mercedes Benz. The car Mrs. Ghambi was driving was not a Mercedes Benz.

The four are said to have robbed the driver of the vehicle of some K8,000 (US$660). Police then mounted a hunt for the suspect Mercedes Benz, which they found at the night spot.They shot at the car which was carrying no passengers.

The row with Ghambi erupted when police told him they were arresting him.

6. K20,000,000 WASTED IN PAY FRAUD

Finance minister Aleke Banda has said there were serious irregularities in civil service wages and salaries which have made government overshoot its budget annual wage bill by K400 million (US$28.25 million). He said the scam was discovered following a probe into what he called "month to month inexplicable fluctuations in funding requirements".

He said the irregularities ranged from the retention of retired workers on the payroll to payment of people working for private contractors. Irregularities also included "deliberate fraudulent acts such as payments to employees who had been officially identified as deceased, retired, dismissed or resigned, payments that did not match grades, manipulation of details, absence of employment numbers and the duplication of payment vouchers.The probe revealed that the Ministry of Works was the biggest culprit in the, scam followed by Health.

The salary irregularities pushed the wage bill from K1.5 billion (US$100 million) to K1.9 billion.

7. MUTHARIKA PROBE OVER

A probe into allegations of mismanagement and misappropriation of Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa), funds by Secretary General Bingu Wa Mutharika is now over. A report of the findings is to be presented to the ministers' council.

Commerce and industry minister, Chakakala Chaziya, said Mutharika would be called before the council on April 7 in Lusaka, Zambia. He will be asked to explain what he knows about the allegations which prompted the probe and his being sent on forced leave by the council when it met on January 16-17 in Lusaka. The Council appointed Joel Mwencha, a Kenyan, acting secretary general.

Mutharika has denied the allegations and threatened to take the council to court, saying it did not have the mandate to determine his term of office, conditions of service or send him on forced leave. He also said the council had no powers to institute a probe. Chaziya, however, said the council was fully in its right to act as it did.

8. DONORS, GOVERNMENT IN TUG-OF-WAR

Donors and the Malawi government are engaged in a tug-of-war over a provision in the National Roads Authority Bill (1997), which is scheduled to be debated in the current sitting of parliament. The European Union and the World Bank are not happy with a provision which cabinet inserted into the bill giving the Minister of Works control of the Authority.

The provision of the bill restrains the Board from disbursing any money or authorising payment without the minister's consent. "The Board shall not disburse any money or authorise the payment of any money to any contractor engaged unless the minister has certified in writing that work has been carried out to the required standard," the provision reads.

Head of the European Union in the country, Balduin Zimmer, has since called for the removal of the provision. "We feel that the minister's involvement in the disbursement of funds and authorising of payment is interfering with the independence of the Board," Zimmer said. This, he said, will also drag out the work because there will be thousands of contractors and it would take longer for the minister to consent to them all.

But the Minister of Works and Supplies, Abdul Pillane, said the government will maintain the provision. He said, however, that the bill will be tabled in parliament and if members vote for its removal, government will have to oblige. The National Road Authority Bill (1997), is to establish a board to manage and control the Authority and a fund responsible for generating money. The Authority's basic aim is to oversee the maintenance, rehabilitation and development of public roads.

9. MCP IN LAST BID FOR PRESS TRUST

The opposition Malawi Congress Party has applied for a judicial review of the Press Trust appeal case, arguing that the ruling was based on erroneous interpretation or failure to interpret sections of the Constitution and Parliamentary Standing Orders.

The application comes barely a month after the Malawi Supreme Court of Appeal ruled that the Press Trust Reconstruction Act (1996) is valid. The Supreme Court of Appeal on January 31 dismissed a High Court ruling of July 1 1996 that the act was invalid.

Hearing of the applications is set for April 21.

Lawyers for the MCP have filed summons for the review of judgement based on 19 grounds. These claim, among other things, that the Supreme Court judgement ignored the rights of Press Holdings Limited to hold property and not to be arbitrarily deprived of it.

In their application, the lawyers note that having found that former president Kamuzu Banda and incumbent Finance Minister Aleke Banda held shares in trust for MCP, and thereafter for the people of Malawi, the court should have proceeded to find that in 1982 Kamuzu could not have formed a valid trust. This was because the property, which purported to be the Trust Fund, was not his. The lawyers further argue that in this regard the court should therefore have found that the Press Trust Deed of 1982 was null and void.

They argue that if the court had established that, the logical conclusion would have been that the Press Trust Reconstruction Act was of no effect, as it purported to transfer assets from trustees of a nonexistent trust, to another set who had nothing to take over.

10. SECOND HAND CLOTHES KEY TO 1999 ELECTION

The sale of second hand clothing holds the trump card for any political party to win the 1999 general elections and it could thus be suicidal for government to ban this trade. This view was articulated by the Investment Promotion Manager for Malawi Investment Promotion Agency (MIPA), Nebert Nyirenda during a meeting with private sector and business executives.

Nyirenda was addressing concerns raised by representatives from the textile industry. They put down their poor performance as being due to the flooding onto the market of second hand clothing, popularly known as KAUNJIKA, and said it would be very crucial and sensitive to completely ban trade in second hand items when the country is expecting to hold general elections in 1999.

The sensitivity of the subject becomes even more pronounced in the wake of government's widely proclaimed programme of poverty alleviation, he said. "We are looking forward to other alternatives to solve this problem." He suggested that one way of ensuring survival in the textile industry was to explore regional and international markets that could absorb Malawi's manufactured goods.

11. OPPOSITION PARTIES RETURN TO PARLIAMENT

The opposition MCP and Aford, have ended their nine month parliamentary boycott following clergy -mediated talks April 2 between the three parties represented in parliament.

The two parties said during the talks which were led by Bishop Felix Mkhori and attended by President Bakili Muluzi, that they had agreed to amend section 65 (1) of the Malawi Constitution which relates to the president's powers on the appointment of cabinet ministers. The meeting mandated whips of the three parties to suggest to the House areas of the section of the constitution that needs to be amended and how this could be done. For his part, Muluzi said he would no longer appoint cabinet ministers from other parties without consulting officials of the parties concerned.

MCP and Aford had been boycotting parliament in protest against Muluzi's retention and appointment of cabinet ministers from Aford after the breakup of the two parties' ill-fated coalition. MCP and Aford's return to parliament comes in the wake of several unsuccessful attempts by the church, the Public Affairs Committee and other institutions to bring the three parties to the negotiating table.

To contact or subscribe to Malawi News Online, email: AfricaNN@inform-bbs. dk.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Business and Finance;
Malawi's 97/98 Budget Highlights


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Blantyre - Finance Minister, Aleke Banda, has unveiled the 1997/98 budget, promising poverty alleviation and sustainable economic growth with incentives for new investments and export-based industry.

Banda announced no increases in PAYE income tax, but revealed new surtax on previously untaxed locally consumed tea, coffee, cooking oil and such services as photocopying, rental of registered conference halls and theatres, office cleaning and maintenance services. Banda said new taxes were necessary to offset those taxes that have been reduced to encourage local industry to grow. 

He said import duty on raw materials used in manufacturing would be removed to create more room for domestic manufacturers to compete against imports from countries where Malawi has bilateral regional agreements. The maximum tariff rate has been reduced from 40 to 35% to reduce the cost of imports. A 10% surtax has been imposed on cooking oil while at the same time input surtax on crude oil has been reduced from 25 to 10%.

Duty on imported cigarettes has been pushed up from 10 to 35% , while duty on imported beer, vinegar and wine has gone up from 10 to 25%. Banda said this would boost revenue while supporting local industry. Imported fruits will also attract a 10% surtax.

He also announced a 10% reduction of the surtax on the hotel industry, from the previous 20% which had been criticised by the industry.

The export levy on tobacco, tea and sugar has been reduced from 8 to 4% and the same duty has been applied to exports of coffee, not previously taxed.

To offset revenue losses, which the country faces as a result of the duty and tax incentives, Banda announced an increase in with-holding tax from a general rate of 15 to 20% on rents, royalties, fees and commissions, public entertainment and interest payment by banks. There would be no exemption on with-holding tax except where the recipient is not subject to tax.

To help promote investment, the government has reduced to zero percent corporate tax on firms manufacturing in Export Processing Zones.

New investments between US$5 million and US$10 million would be given the option of paying a reduced 15% corporate indefinitely or taking a five year tax holiday, while new investments in excess of US$10 million would be given a similar option but with a tax holiday of 10 years.

Overall government expenditure for fiscal 1997/98 amounted to K9,794 million of which 77% is for recurrent expenditure and 23% for development expenditure.

Budget allocations for the four priority areas of education, health, agriculture and works have grown from 31% in the 1996/97 budget to 37% in 1997/98.

Banda said the deficit including grants (K1,748 million), is projected to increase from 3.8% of the GDP in 1996/97 to 4.3% of GDP in 1997/98 due to an anticipated decrease in foreign grants.

To contact or subscribe to Malawi News Online, email: AfricaNN@inform-bbs. dk.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

168 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Zaire;
Declaration Of The Civil Society Of Kinshasa


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Washington - We, Associations and Federations of the Civil Society of Kinshasa, assembled in the Fatima Parish Hall on this Friday, the 28th day of March, 1997, in order to examine the situation which prevails in Zaire:

Considering the expressed will and united efforts of the Zairian People, even to the supreme sacrifice, to bring about a Just State of Zaire;

Considering that the Power in control, which did not issue from a democratic mandate, intends to maintain itself for a long time to come by means of all sorts of subterfuges, in defiance of the rights of the People to choose their own leaders;

Given that the rebellion in the territory of the Republic of Zaire has in no way offered proof of its engagement in the democratic process initiated by the Sovereign National Conference;

Considering the allegations of massive violations of the rights and liberties of the Human Person in the areas controlled by the "Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire" (AFDL):

Considering that the negotiations, such as they are, carried on without the participation of the victims - the People - run the risk of failing to win the support of all;

Considering that if Elections are not quickly organized, another dictatorship may take the place of the first;

Faced with the menace of partition - geographic, political, linguistic, economic - of Zaire, devised by external forces with the complicity of certain sons of the country;

Let us make known to the Community national as well as international - our position:

1. Let Us beseech the immediate cessation of hostilities throughout the national territory and encourage negotiations capable of creating conditions favorable to the immediate organization of Free Elections, unequivocal and democratic, at once, throughout Zaire.

2. Let us denounce and condemn every ideology that promotes the belief that Power is assumed or preserved at the point of a gun.

3. Let us denounce and condemn every act or declaration which would limit the breadth of fundamental freedoms gained, or hamper the process of democratization defined by the Sovereign National Conference.

4 Let us denounce negotiations ongoing or to come, as well as the sharing of powers, between the two armed groups, while excluding their victims - the People;

5. Let us denounce the setting up of a Committee of Negotiators and the proposal of a National Council, without the effective participation of the Civil Society;

6 Let us denounce and condemn every effort toward partition - geographic, political, linguistic, economic - of Zaire, devised by outside forces and relayed to the Interior by nationalists among the groups of the kind springing up in the east or west;

7. Let us condemn the psychosis of civil war, the looting, and the partitioning of Zaire consequent on a military presence massive and suspect of exterior influences at the national frontiers, notably in the Republic of Congo.

8. Let us call urgently for the participation of Zairian Organizations for Human Rights in every commission of inquiry, ongoing or to come, concerning massive violations of the rights and liberties of the human person, throughout the whole extent of the national territory; and in the case of the nature of these violations, in the zones under the control of the AFDL.

9. Let us urge the immediate formation of a responsible Government, in order to bring the People quickly to the "Elections Now and Throughout Zaire."

The Civil Society intends to pursue the struggle for the formation of a democratic order in Zaire, and will constantly make public its proposals for the urgent and effective holding of these elections.

ISSUED AT KINSHASA, MARCH 29, 1997. scanned and translated by AFJN

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378; Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email: afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Sports - General;
Games plan: how they made it happen


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Cape Town - At the outset, back in 1995, Cape Town's Olympic planners had only one table, one telephone and a few chairs.

Their barely furnished office on the 17th floor of the Civic Centre must have seemed as inauspicious a setting as you could find for the origin of the multi-billion rand blueprint that, within a year and a half, would successfully project Cape Town's worldly aspirations, and earn it a place on the shortlist for the 2004 Games.

What they did have, aside from an unnervingly compelling calendar of deadlines, was plenty of bright ideas.

The genesis of the Olympic plan always had everything to do with the overarching project of reshaping Cape Town, turning it into a dynamic, fair, vibrant, efficient and growing city, and deliberately altering features of the cityscape born of apartheid.

The philosophical gist was there, but the mechanics, the detail, were absent. 

To spend an hour, today, with the planners in their Foreshore eyrie, spectacularly high above the gleaming expanse of Table Bay, it is inconceivable that there might ever have been any significant doubts.

But there have often been times, moments of frenzy or anguish, when they have had to steel themselves to pause and invoke what team leader Peter de Tolly calls "oriental calm".

He has also always insisted that "we must ultimately ensure that we have fun here".

These are no doubt elements the Deputy City Planner has brought to the project from his considerable experience at home and abroad in planning and urban design.

With degrees in architecture and urban design from the universities of Cape Town and Toronto, he has practised as an architect in Cape Town, and as a consultant urban designer/city planner in Toronto, where, among other things, he played a key role in the Canadian city's waterfront development.

Latterly, he was involved in the revitalisation of Cape Town's central city area, and in developing the city's world-class Waterfront.

He has extensive experience in strategic urban growth and change management.

His team comprises:

* Fellow City of Cape Town secondee Nicola Lloyd is a senior planner with a master's degree in urban and regional planning, whose wide experience on inner and outer metro projects includes work on the redevelopment of District Six, and the building of the acclaimed Hartleyvale hockey venue.

* Mary Jane Morris, an environmental specialist seconded to the Bid Company from Caltex, is a botany and geography graduate of the University of the Witwatersrand, and holds an honours degree in geography and environmental studies. She gained extensive experience in Environmental Impact Assessment during a six-year stint with an international firm of consultants, and is committed to "ensuring sound environmental practice in the bid".

* David Maralack, who holds master's degrees in urban development planning from the University of London and in city and regional planning from the University of Cape Town, has had varied experience as a planning consultant, town planner, researcher and teacher in South Africa and the United States. He is presently working on his PhD dissertation through the University of Minnesota.

* Derek Thomas, an architecture graduate from Oxford and a practising architect for 30 years, has spent much of his professional life focusing on what he describes as "socially responsive and cost- efficient architecture". He has considerable expertise in mass housing, and is responsible for the Olympic villages in the bid plan.

* Jac Snyman, an architecture graduate of the University of Cape Town, is an urban designer on secondment from the City of Cape Town. He has been involved in the plan for Kalk Bay harbour, and has worked on the Culemborg/Black River project.

It was when this team sat together in the early days of the bid that a fourth pillar of Olympism - human development - was added to the international movement's long-established triad of principles: sport, culture and environment.

But what did "human development" mean in a real terms? How would it mesh with the dynamics of Cape Town, and the practical needs of putting on the biggest sporting spectacle in the world?

Nicola Lloyd recalls some of the first discussions, "when the idea of providing a developmental stimulus emerged, but, as Peter kept stressing, placed in the context of the metropole's future growth".

David Maralack says it "amounted to posing questions about what Cape Town should be in 20 to 50 years from now, irrespective of the Games, and then asking how the Games could be used to kick-start these things".

Once the Olympic planning was synchronised with the overarching, long-term progressive city plan, the Metropolitan Spatial Development Framework, its potential as an impressive stimulus, as the key to making things happen, emerged all the more clearly.

Jac Snyman describes how, once this basis was established, sites were identified against a checklist of factors such as availability of land, sports needs, transport, housing, redressing the apartheid legacy ... but, most importantly, as individual elements of a plan to make human development - socially and economically - a real goal.

These were "exciting times", the planners remember, but difficult times too.

Winning public support was vital, and tiring. Each of the team spent at least three nights of the week during that period "out in the communities ... getting bashed", David Maralack recalls wryly. It was often discomforting, but it paid dividends.

There were also those deadlines. Derek Thomas says that to get the Cabinet's approval - a critical element - "we had to provide budget assessments in as much detail as we could, but invariably we had to resort to generic, conceptualised assessments based on the floor area of facilities and little else.

"It was tough, and we had only a matter of weeks to get it done."

At the same time, a mammoth and difficult consultation process was launched, with the added complication, Nicola Lloyd recalls, of there being no democratically elected local authorities in the Peninsula. This was before the local elections which brought in the present six councils, and the planners were having to work with no fewer than 39 indecisive and politically weak transitional bodies.

Mary-Jane Morris was tasked with launching complex and sensitive environmental assessments, and engaging the Green sector in a project the bid team believed would provide invaluable opportunities for establishing new standards in environmental protection and planning.

>From early 1996, planning activity became frenetic.

The Atlanta Games loomed in July - and it was important for the bid team to be there to learn lessons - and, a month later, the submission of the minutely detailed, 700-page Bid Book to the IOC in Switzerland.

Four months after that - in December - the IOC evaluation commission would touch down to cast a critical eye over all that had been done.

Overseeing the whole, Peter de Tolly's mind was fixed on maintaining the vision of a dynamic city of the future, catalysed by Olympic planning, a vision of making the bid philosophy a real, achievable goal.

"If you look at the civic structure of the city of the past 350 years, there are things which contain the essence of what makes this a great place.

"Now it is one of our responsibilities to create a new framework for the next 350 years.

"When it comes down to it, it's the absence of that vision that makes cities the sad places they often are.

"The work of this planning team has been a magnificent opportunity to provide the thrust to make all the difference to this city."

And it is, he says, "like a cosmic kick in the butt".


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


170 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


United States and Africa;
Portnet officials aid duty evasion, says US


BYLINE: Richard Mkhondo, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Washington, DC - The United States says goods imported into South Africa for shipment to the members of the Southern African Customs Union (SACU) are susceptible to extensive duty evasion.

In its annual appraisal of foreign trade barriers, the Office of the US Trade Representative said Portnet customs officials facilitated the evasion of customs duties by grey-market importers.

"According to sources, malfeasance within the South African port system is exacerbated by corruption within the ports of entry of South Africa's Southern African Customs Union partners (Namibia, Botswana, Swaziland, and Lesotho), where imported goods are occasionally repackaged as items made in one of these respective countries and exported to South Africa, where they evade customs levies due to the SACU accord," the report said. 

The 1997 National Trade Estimates Report on Foreign Trade Barriers, released at the weekend, said that over the past year several South African importers had complained about illicit imports and import duty evasion.

"Importers of agricultural products, poultry, and manufactured goods have asserted that a lack of adequate funding, training and staffing has led to a problem of inefficiency and malfeasance among the port customs inspectors and within the state-owned port and cargo handling company, Portnet," the report said.

"Finally, illegal shipments overland through Mozambique account for a high share of illegal imports and contraband trade. Importers and foreign customs officials have estimated the percentage of intercepted illegal imports into South Africa at less than 10 percent," the Office of the US Trade Representative said.

It acknowledged that the South African Government was aware of the problems with its customs service and was attempting to redress them through co- operation with international organisations and training programmes with US, British and European customs services.

"Nonetheless, the problem of illegal imports and customs evasion will take many years to overcome, as the Government of South Africa struggles to direct limited funding and inadequate available human resources across a wide area of law enforcement needs."

The US government said several US companies claimed that import surcharges remain in several industries, but the charges cited appeared to be excise taxes that were applied in a non-discriminatory manner to domestic as well as foreign producers.

For example, although the government reduced the tariff on instant-print cameras from 6 percent to zero on June 28 last year, instant-print cameras and instant-print film continued to be classified as luxury items and remain subject to high excise taxes of 37,5 percent and 32,5 percent respectively.

Although these excise taxes are non-discriminatory, US producers claim that there are no domestic producers and that the high taxes induce circumvention by illegal importers.

"Extensive circumvention of customs collection at South African ports of entry may allow some foreign importers to avoid paying the high tax, giving them an advantage over those importers paying proper excise taxes," the Office of the Trade Representative said.

The SACU, created in 1910, provides for the duty-free status of goods from Namibia, Botswana, Swaziland and Lesotho.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 7, 1997


South Africa;
Root out the bent cops (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Crime committed by police members has increased dramatically in the Western Cape.

Now police commissioner Leon Wessels has promised a 'ruthless crackdown'

The entire fabric of society becomes severely threatened when those who are supposed to be public protectors and preventers of wrongdoing themselves turn to crime.

There are few things more abhorrent to the law abiding than policemen abusing their enormous powers by getting involved in a wide range of heinous offences. 

At a time when people at every level of society are wringing their hands nervously over soaring crime, revelations of offences committed by police will add hugely to their anxiety and to the flight of many talented South Africans to safer countries overseas, to the detriment of the economy.

Provincial police commissioner Leon Wessels is absolutely correct in describing the actions and behaviour of police involved in a range of violent and white-collar crimes as "shocking".

Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi has revealed just how corrupt police have become: more police have been arrested on charges of corruption in the past two years than in the previous 40.

Why? What has caused a section of the law enforcers to become as depraved as the law breakers? Are policemen so poorly paid that stealing and taking bribes are not longer a temptation but a perceived necessity? Are they stuck in the same socio-economic abyss that causes ordinary citizens to turn to crime? Have they been so disillusioned by the example set by peers and superiors involved in dirty tricks, torture and murder that the line between right and wrong has become blurred? Are they so demotivated they just don't care?

Commissioner Wessels promises a ruthless crackdown on police crime and no mercy for the perpetrators. But if the rot is to be stopped, the root causes must also be identified and removed.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 7, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Yusuf Williams: 38 years later, 'Black Caruso' is happy to be home


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Cape Town - Acclaimed tenor Yusuf Williams, who was dubbed Cape Town's Black Caruso by arts critics, has paid a nostalgic visit to the Mother City on a foreign passport - 38 years after he and 24 members the Golden City Dixies were stranded in Sweden while touring Europe.

Clasping a handful of press clippings to verify his tale and looking 20 years younger than his age of 61, he recalled how autocratic South African consular officials terminated the tour and froze their passports in Stockholm - catapulting the the Dixies overnight from the stage into the international political arena.

The incident, in the heyday of apartheid, caused a storm of protest and while mounting political pressures led to the South African government chartering an aircraft to fly them back, it left a permanent scar on Williams and several other stars who opted to remain behind in Sweden. He remained there for 11 years, working in a variety of stage shows, until, in 1970, he teamed up with a German band touring Sweden and migrated to Munich, where he became a German citizen and married Elke. They have a daughter Yasmin, now 11. 

Briefly changing the topic he said: "I used to be a bodybuilder and I've kept young by doing a lot of deep breathing exercises and sticking to the right diet. I walk a lot and still do regular training in the gym and push- ups at home to keep fit. I've maintained a strict diet of three meals a day, starting with a light breakfast of muesli, yoghurt and bananas, following this with salads for lunch and rounding the day off with a decent variable supper."

During his 27 years in Germany he has demonstrated his versatility as an entertainer. It was there that he switched to his adopted and popular stage alias of Joe Curtis, singing swing, calypso and even Stevie Wonder songs with equal facility. Over the years he honed his act to become one of the most popular singers on the circuit. Williams made his stage d but as an Eoan Group tenor, playing to full houses in the Cape Town City Hall as a principal singer in Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana. At the time he was hailed as one of the greatest operatic discoveries on the continent of Africa and his mentor and tutor, Eoan Group director Joseph Manca, who discovered him while adjucating performers at competitions at the annual Coon Carnival, groomed him for a career as a tenor and a baritone.

"But the opera season was short," said Williams, "and my environmental and personal circumstances were such that I was forced me to earn a living from singing. So I switched to swing to earn an income from my talents."

The lure of the bright lights as a stage and variety show entertainer appealed to him and capitivated his interest.

He says he has no regrets about switching from opera to popular songs.

"The main thing is that I was still able to sing a song like Granada once in a while on stage and bring the house down. I kept going and have never had a dull moment in my life, earning my living entirely from stage appearances.

"When I first switched from opera to swing I soon found I had an aptitude to mimic Mario Lanza, Frank Sinatra and Louis Armstrong and my renditions of songs by such evergreen singing greats had a great appeal for audiences everywhere.

"When our passports were frozen we learnt that we had another more pressing problem. Everything had not been going as smoothly as it seemed on tour. For instance, we suspected that our mail had, for some unknown reason, been withheld from us and our suspicions were vindicated when we located a pile of our letters in a hotel office and opened them.

"We then learnt that our families in South Africa had not been paid the money we had earned in terms of an agreed stop-order arrangement made prior to our departure. This, indirectly, led to the breakup of my first marriage."

He shrugs his broad shoulders: "All that is behind me now. A lot of of troubled waters beneath the bridge as they say. The main thing is I have come back and while the place has changed, the people are still the same and as warm-hearted as ever as I remembered them.

"Many of the children of the people who were uprooted from District Six, where the Eoan Group had its base before it was demolished and moved to Athlone under Group Area Act, have spoken to me. Some of the old stalwarts of District Six have also reached out to me via radio programmes in Cape Town. As a result I have been overwhelmed with heaps of invitations, some of which I cannot honour because I am currently booked for a number in live shows in Germany."


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 7, 1997


South Africa;
Freeway plan to give route across Cape Flats


BYLINE: Peter Goosen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Cape Town - One of the biggest public participation programmes in the Western Cape has been launched to find a corridor across Grassy Park and the Philippi horticultural area to carry a new freeway, the "missing link", from Vanguard Drive to Prince George Drive.

The new 4,5-kilometre freeway, an extension of the existing R300, the Cape Flats freeway which at present ends at Vanguard Drive, has the potential to save thousands of kilometres and litres of fuel by giving commuters a more direct route across the Cape Flats.

People living in Mitchell's Plain will have a direct route to their traditional shopping areas of Kenilworth and Wynberg and people from the southern suburbs a shorter route to Cape Town Airport. 

At the same time the new freeway will relieve the unacceptable situation of 7 000 vehicles travelling daily through the Philippi horticultural area "rat run".

To make the process of deciding on an acceptable corridor as transparent as possible, an ambitious public participation programme was launched in November last year. More than 170 groups and organisations took part in the talks and workshops.

The planning of the freeway is being undertaken by the Cape Flats Consortium which consists of representatives of the Cape Metropolitan Council, the Cape Town City Council, the South Peninsula Council, two firms of consulting engineers, Jeffares and Green and Fongoqa, Skade Toyi and Associates and Sakaza Communications and Public Relations.

Jeffares and Green director Frank Steele said the study would include details on how the corridor would affect the communities through which it would pass and the environmental and economic impact of the route.

"Although it's still very early in the process, all indications are that the freeway will have tremendous benefits," he said.

It was hoped that the planning process would be complete by the end of the year and, if and when the freeway was built, it would more than likely be built in stages because of the high costs involved.

Jeffrey Kleinsmith of Sakaza said there were concerns. High on the list was the potential impact the freeway - passing through a highly sensitive area such as the 2 720-ha Philippi horticultural area - would have on the environment, agricultural potential and future development.

So far the public participation process had resulted in the Cape Flats Consortium having been mandated by a representative group of farmers to present a number of potential road alignments to the landowners, taking into consideration all the concerns expressed.

Similarly, the Grassy Park, Lotus River and Parkwood communities had been consulted.

"Their concerns about safety, access, crossings for their children, the impact on housing and business are all being considered in the preliminary design stage," Mr Kleinsmith said.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 7, 1997


South Africa;
Pagad condemns panga attack


BYLINE: Ashley Smith, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Cape Town - Pagad has condemned panga-wielding Hard Livings gangsters headed by Rashied Staggie for allegedly attacking about 120 people, including women and children, at a drug awareness meeting in Manenberg.

Police spokesman Hendrik Pistorius said two members of People Against Gangsterism and Drugs were shot in the stomach outside the Manenberg People's Centre hall during ensuing mayhem yesterday and taken to hospital.

About 10 people in the hall were injured when they were hit with chairs and bricks, kicked and punched. 

Nobody appears to have been hurt by the pangas.

Earlier the meeting had been guarded by four members of Pagad's "G-force" self-defence unit, but reinforcements arrived later.

Pagad's national co-ordinator, Abdus-Salaam Ebrahim, said he was attacked by about five gang members.

He was injured on the head and in the back when he was hit with a chair and punched after the gangsters told him: "Jy's wit bene" (gangster slang for " you are going to die").

Other people at the meeting, including a 10-year-old boy and several women, were injured when they were kicked and hit with bricks.

A masked Pagad supporter said her husband was standing outside the hall before the incident when he overheard one of the gangsters asking the police: "Wat maak julle hier?" (what are you doing here).

She added that several gangsters then chased her husband but were unable to catch him.

A woman who was badly cut during the attack said she had been standing at the entrance when the alleged gangsters walked in, led by Mr Staggie and Ernie "Lapepa" Peters, leaders of the Community Outreach Forum of gangsters who say they have reformed. Mr Staggie is known to be a leader of the Hard Livings gang.

She said she was punched and hit in her back with a chair after gangsters asked her: "Why didn't you ask us for permission to have this meeting?"

She said the gangsters went for Mr Ebrahim with a panga. Another victim said he was kicked "all the way from the hall to the outside of the centre by gangsters".

Fearing for their lives, Pagad supporters fled the hall, but outside they were confronted by more than 350 local residents, who shouted abuse and hurled stones at them.

The streets of the Cape Flats township, traditionally the headquarters of the Hard Livings gang, erupted in chaos as police escorted a heavily armed convoy of Pagad supporters out of the area.

As the supporters left with faces covered and shotguns drawn, residents and gangsters shouted abuse and pelted their vehicles with stones.

The police fired several shots when they came under attack by the mob, who screamed: "Why are you protecting these bastards?"

A Manenberg resident said Pagad had taken a "big risk" by coming to the area after the killing of Hard Livings co-leader Rashaad Staggie during a Pagad march in Salt River last year.

Mr Peters claimed that Pagad had booked the hall under "false pretences" by using the name of "some welfare organisation".

He said Mr Staggie had led a group of residents into the centre and they had been pushed around by Pagad supporters before the scuffle broke out.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 7, 1997


South Africa;
Troops Into Wartorn Flats


BYLINE: Ashley Smith, Johan Schronen and Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Cape Town - Police and troops moved into the Cape Flats today to head off more violence after a man was killed and five people were injured in attacks on the homes of alleged drug dealers early today.

The attacks follow an attack in Manenberg yesterday on supporters of People Against Gangsterism and Drugs by the Hard Livings gang, who invaded a drug awareness meeting.

Two people were wounded by gunfire at the meeting and a number of others injured when they were attacked by gangsters allegedly led by Community Outreach Forum leader Rashied Staggie. 

Five Pagad members were arrested after the clash at the Manenberg People's Centre and four other Pagad supporters were arrested there later.

Police Superintendent Hendrik Pistorius said the homes of three alleged drug dealers were shot at in Mitchell's Plain and Steenberg early today.

In one of the attacks, Jerome Williams of 130 Flora Street in Steenberg died when he was wounded in the chest.

Other attacks had taken place in Heideveld and Athlone, he said.

Among those injured in the attacks today were 10-year-old Monique Philander and Ismaile English, 15.

Provincial police spokesman John Sterrenberg said patrols had been increased on the Cape Flats around flashpoints from Manenberg to Retreat and Steenberg.

"Our members have been bolstered by Defence Force troops while we are busy re-evaluating our strategy today to address the current situation," he said. This would involve talking to the groups involved in a bid to end the bloodshed.

"Four of the victims yesterday were neighbourhood watch members who tried to intervene during the clashes," said Superintendent Sterrenberg.

"After this weekend's attacks we have arrested nine people and confiscated three heavy-calibre handguns."

Yesterday afternoon five Pagad members were arrested after a tense confrontation between gangsters and the anti-drug group in Manenberg.

The five, Moegamat Sieed, Moegamat Saban, Ismaile Sieed, Adenaan Daniels and Ali Williams, appeared in the Wynberg Magistrate's Court on charges of public violence. They were not asked to plead and were released on R600 bail.

Superintendent Pistorius said he did not know why only Pagad members had been arrested in Manenberg, as it was alleged that gangsters were responsible for the confrontation.

Pagad supporters who met in the Gatesville mosque after they were escorted out of Manenberg by a strong police contingent said they were unhappy with the way police handled the incident.

A masked Pagad man said the police had not protected defenceless woman and children from gangsters inside the centre.

Pagad national co-ordinator Abdus-Salaam Ebrahim, who was also injured in the attack at the centre, said that the gangsters were "crazy" if they thought they could scare the anti-drug movement by attacking woman and children

He appealed for calm.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
