176 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Science and Health;
Getting Community Priorities Right


BYLINE: Florence Bamanyaki, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Nairobi - Given that majority in a community may not see health, as medically understood, as a priority, planners and workers in this field should therefore not assume that people are ready and waiting to participate in community based health care activities.

Community must determine their own needs, priorities and capabilities, and any projects should capitalize on those priorities and capabilities.

This is one of the most famous guiding principles in most Community serving and based organizations and indeed it did crop as a binding force to the participants of the first Community Based Health Care, (CBHC) conference held in Nairobi from March 17 to 21, 1997.

Lately, it has been plain to see that this principle has been closer to theory than practice because participation, which is community involvement, seems o be induced and driven by donors and intermediaries such that there is undirected accountability. 

Undirected accountability, because leaders and Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) are usually not accountable to the communities they are intended to serve, and what is more, the normal traditional functions are professionalised thus giving even greater foundation to a rigid vertical process - the top-down approach.

One Omondi, a Kenyan Community resource person says he is disillusioned with the way his services are overlooked by leaders and NGOs. He adds that it is especially difficult to create a partnership when NGO executives "drive pajeros at the expense of the communities they are supposed to help."

A senior programme manager of Action Aid-Kenya, Shahanah Ahmed observes that community problems can be anticipated only if leaders and NGOs "listen to the people" and emphasize qualitative research methods to understand the causes and possible solutions to the problem.

Emphasizing health information systems, Ahmed feels that computerization in community based organizations (CBOs) are a bit out of place considering that a feed back of research findings to the communities is important.

The Action Aid manager notes that since information should be used to break poverty cycles, there is need to encourage manual analysis in rural and peri- urban areas and that the information released should "satisfy as well as dissatisfy the stake-holders so that change occurs. Stake-holders in this case are the community members, CBOs and the donors.

The first CBHC conference dwelt mainly on ways of making health a reality for all beyond the year 2000. About 400 participants drawn from Africa and the rest of the world convened at a Nairobi hotel to design an accord, the Nairobi Accord, that will ensure Health For All (HFA) beyond 2000.

On the other hand, one wonders whether the accord would help nurse the grudge community health workers have against community based organizations and health systems as most of them are volunteer workers.

A cross-section of community resource persons interviewed by APS did not seem pleased about working for charity. Most of them made reference to their dire poverty and the amount of time and dedication they had put into community health work.

Grace Ogola, a community health worker in Western Kenya expressed satisfaction in her voluntary health work, adding that she had learnt a great deal through conferences and seminars such as the CBHC conference. She, however, called for more incentive so that she can perform better.

Paul Okello, another community health worker in Kenya's western district of Siaya, felt that the key to good health in African communities is food security. Relating to his own district, Okello told this writer, people never saw the importance of food security and the nutritional value of food.

He appealed for more awareness building on the matter.

He also expressed disappointment at the poor involvement of the communities in health programmes, saying that the people know themselves better and therefore can define their most pressing needs. Okello observed that when all is said and done, CBOs and governments should work towards poverty alleviation, adding that people will respond better in good economic conditions.

Grace Mundeta, a Zimbabwean health worker said volunteer health workers ought to be remunerated as a matter of incentive, encouragement and appreciation. Mundeta revealed that in her country volunteer health workers often lied that they were receiving salaries to save themselves from public ridicule.

With only three years to 2000, health deteriorating at a frightening rate, encroaching poverty and expanding slums, it is still uncertain that there will be light at the end of the tunnel even beyond the next millennium.

Giving a community the onus to decide its needs, priorities and capabilities can be frustrating because most Africans are more concerned with ensuring day-to-day necessities like food and water, according to Director General, African Medical Research Foundation (AMREF)-Kenya, Michael Gerber.

Gerber actually describes this situation as "community imperialism" that has caused "sustainable development fog" because, he says, it is apparent that socio-economic factors influence people's decisions regarding how they will live and where they will situate their dwellings.

Alluding to an education system where a teacher had to ask pupils what they felt like doing, which is most unlikely, Gerber feels that while it is important to first determine local priorities and disease causation, the majority of a community may not see health, as medically understood, as a priority.

Gerber points out that in his analysis, CBOs and health workers should not assume that people are ready and waiting to participate in community based health care activities. The problem really is that most community leaders are merely "watchmen" protecting their positions and wealth, according to United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) Director of the country support team for East and Central Africa, Dr. Miriam Were.

Dr. Were maintains that communities should assess their priorities and be their own leaders with "developing concerned persons" facilitated by government and NGOs to deal with community problems in a mutually respectful context.

Speaking on the role of traditional healers, Dr. Were observed that numerous studies indicate that people often go past hospitals to a traditional healer because it is there that they will find a "personal touch" -"people are tired of machine-based approaches that may keep you alive without giving life to your years," she adds.

Expressing the advantage traditional healers have over the

health systems, Dr. Were says managers of health care approaches have been too ignorant to plan health care services that are socially and psychologically relevant, acceptable and usable by people for whom they are planned.

Acknowledging that over 70 per cent of Africa's population

live in rural communities and villages, Dr. Were feels that

since a sick person may not get the personal touch throughout

the health system, the community level should provide it by

dealing with people one knows and only a few at a time.

A top-down approach on communities certainly will not

work! Rather, a community based strategy must be employed

recognizing that individuals are already making decisions for

themselves regarding CBHC and only programmes consistent with

their interests will ultimately be sustainable.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Farmers' Home-Grown 'Solution' To Drought


BYLINE: APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1827 words


 

Nairobi - With recurrent drought in various parts of Africa, farmers are increasingly concerned about the gradual disappearance of traditional food crops and are trying to set up new mechanisms to conserve and utilize the varieties in their farms and communities. Our APS Correspondent explores some of the issues affecting agricultural biodiversity.

For a long time in the drought-prone district of Chivi in Zimbabwe, farmers agonized as they sought suitable seeds for the type of land and climate in their district. Government extensionists promoted high-response varieties of maize which were often unsuitable as they required optimal growing conditions. Small grains like sorghum and millet were ignored despite being more suited to the irregular rainfall and poor soil-types.

Gradually, the farmers established local seed fairs which with time have become very popular. At the fairs, farmers not only exchange seeds but also share knowledge on farming practices that are relevant to the area. 

At one of the fairs, up to 50 varieties of sorghum, millet, beans and bambara nuts were exhibited and exchanged. Further, farmers identified more varieties that were no longer found locally but which they believed were available in neighbouring districts, prompting a wider search for and exchange of seeds.

In Tharaka Nithi, Eastern Kenya, a similar seed fair was held last year, with 119 farmers displaying 141 locally grown varieties of 12 crops. Another one held last month came at a time when most posts of the Eastern region were hit by severe droughts. Fairs have become an important way of conserving biodiversity.

But why all the fuss about conservation of seeds? The history of food production goes back between 10,000 to 15,000 years, according to Dynamic Diversity, a booklet by the Intermediate Technology Development Group (ITDG), which is working to help reverse the decline in crop diversity. Quoting Fowler, C. and Mooney, P.R. in their book, The Threatened Gene: Food, Politics and the Loss of Genetic Diversity (1992), the publication states that 'systematic production of food began through the innovation of hundreds of thousands of people in many different social and ecological circumstances."

From many thousands of species of edible plants around the world, farmers and food providers developed and nurtured several hundred species from which they created millions of varieties of useful plants. Consequently, the domestication of the world's major food crops is regarded by many to have been the catalyst for the greatest transformation in human civilization - the advent of settled agriculture.

In another book, Regenerating Agriculture: Policies and Practice for Sustainability and Self-Reliance (1995), Pretty J.N. adds that the type of agriculture which was developed was diverse, location specific and complex. " This agriculture is now mainly found in less fertile areas such as uplands, savannas, swamps, near-deserts and forests, predominantly in the South."

It is significant, however, as it provides food for nearly 35 per cent of the world's population and is dependent on farmers' crop varieties which are well adapted to the growing conditions in these areas. In this type of agriculture, farmers integrate resources from the farm and the wild, diversifying their livelihood base in addition to planting crops. This enables them to survive fragile and challenging environments and ensure a year-round balanced diet as well as augment their income. Maintaining diversity is, therefore critical to ensuring food security.

The biodiversity of food species, sometimes referred to as agricultural biodiversity or the genetic resources for food and agriculture, is an important subset of general biodiversity. In addition, it is the basis of food security. Biodiversity makes it possible to produce food of desired qualities and taste.

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), the consultative Group on International Agriculture Research (CGIAR) and the World Trade Organization (WTO) play a significant role in developing global systems that affect the biodiversity of food species.

FAO is the principal inter-governmental institution concerned with agricultural biodiversity. It achieved the agreement of 148 countries in June 1996 to a global Plan of Action for the conservation and Sustainable Utilization of Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (GPA), which contains activities on in situ conservation, among others. This is to be taken forward at subsequent negotiations in the FAO Commission on Genetic Resources of Food and Agriculture (CGRFA).

This commission is extending its brief from covering only plant genetic resources to include domestic animal diversity (from which FAO already has an international programme), fish genetic resources and forest genetic resources.

The Commission is also the forum in which the International Undertaking on Plant Genetic Resources (IU), which includes a commitment to farmers' rights, will be negotiated. FAO is also a key proponent of sustainable agriculture and rural development through various of its programmes and is implementing a code of conduct for responsible fisheries, among other relevant programmes.

The Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) was negotiated in Rio De Janeiro at the Earth Summit in 1992. The CBD's controlling body, the Conference of the Parties to the Biodiversity Convention (COPS), meets annually and reviews progress in the development and implementation of the Convention. One aspect of this mandate is to consider agriculture biodiversity. It receives reports from FAO on current negotiations.

It is hoped that the revised IU from FAO, including Farmers' Rights, will be included as protocol to the Convention. However, there are fears that the increasing influence of the World Bank, the Group of 7 and the World Trade Organization (WTO) on the conventions would mean that farmers will get little recognition for their contribution to biodiversity conservation. Furthermore, the United Nations General Assembly is reviewing progress of the Earth's Summit's Action Plan (Agenda 21), in 1997, five years after Rio, a fact which may affect how agricultural biodiversity is governed in the future.

The second key institution is the Consultative Group on International Agriculture Research (CGIAR). Its overall purpose is to promote international research on sustainable improvements in the productivity of agriculture, forestry and fisheries in countries in the south, in ways that enhance nutrition and well-being, especially of low-income groups of people.

CGIAR comprises 16 International Agricultural centres and has a system-wide Genetic Resources Programme managed by one of the centres, the International Plant Genetic Resources Institute. The CGIAR, collection, which is now held in trust by FAO. The CGIAR is the major influence on agricultural research internationally but urgently needs to develop their programmes in ways that are more responsive to the majority of poor farmers, herders and fisherfolk.

On the other hand, World Trade Organization (WTO) incorporates the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) which since the Uruguay Round Table of negotiations, now trade liberalization and the removal of subsidies and protection from local food production.

Another of its mandate is to promote a Trade Related Intellectual Property Rights system (TRIPs) which favours the development of patents, or other effective systems of intellectual property protection, for living organisms of which a review is due in 1999.

There have been so far three major conservation approaches: in situ, ex situ conservation and conservation in genetic 'reserves'. In situ conservation is achieved through maintaining and developing biodiversity in farmers' fields and gardens, on rangelands and in coastal gardens. The genetic resources develop through utilization and selection.

On the other hand, ex situ conservation is mainly done in genebanks or in living collections away from production systems that developed the resources. This type of conservation has received a lot of attention in recent years. However, this approach can only preserve materials taken from farms and the local environment, it cannot develop diversity. It may be of interest to explore this conservation concept within communities to support local production systems, according to the authors of Dynamic Diversity. The third option is the formation of genetic reserves, usually in remote environments, which discourage communities from developing their crop varieties and animal breeds.

However, to achieve improved conservation of agricultural biodiversity, policies and programmes need to among other measures. promote the conservation, development and legal use of a wide range of biodiversity of food species in ways which encourage the local improvements of genetic resources; increase consumption of locally produced food and generate among consumers awareness of the importance of maintaining agricultural biodiversity; Emphasize in situ conservation and utilization, maintaining dynamic diversity rather than freezing and losing diversity in genebanks (ex situ genebanks should only be used as a backup to the living, dynamic and evolving collections used and nurtured by food providers) and increase recognition and rewards to women who have been the principal nurturers and developers of the biodiversity of food species.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


178 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Zaire;
Archbishop's Easter Appeal For Zaire


BYLINE: APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1920 words


 

Nairobi - Barely a week before Zairean rebels and government were certain to meet face-to-face in South Africa to try and negotiate a peace settlement of the Zairean crisis, the country's Roman Catholic archbishop has appealed for an end to the bloody conflict that has left the lives of ordinary persons in complete disarray.

Distressed by the suffering endured particularly by ordinary people caught up in the current strife in Zaire, the Catholic Archbishop of Kinshasa, Frederic Cardinal Etsohou has appealed to the government forces and rebels to end the fighting in the eastern part of this Central African nation and help facilitate talks due in Pretoria,South Africa on April 5.

In an Easter Day meeting with journalists in the Zairean capital on March 30, the Cardinal said his greatest wish was for an end to the war because people were suffering so much.

"I call on the people of Zaire, Burundi, Rwanda, Uganda ... everyone to stop the war, and also for Western nations to stop selling us arms. We don't need weapons, we need implements to work the land and to develop African countries," Cardinal Etsohou said in Kinshasa. 

His appeal came against a background of reports that rebels, led by Laurent- Desire Kabila, currently controlling much of eastern Zaire are grabbing more territory in southern Zaire's mineral-rich Shaba region ahead of peace talks that began in South Africa over the weekend.

According to rebel and independent reports, the guerrillas have seized Kasenga, a town near the border with Zambia, 216 kilometres north-east of Lubumbashi, Zaire's second largest city.

The rebels, who now control a quarter of the vast country, said they captured the town with little resistance from government forces, claims that were confirmed by humanitarian workers in the area.

Kasenga gave them an "open door" to Lubumbashi, the province's capital, and they were advancing beyond the town, the rebels said, although the chief of staff of the Zairean military, General Mahele Lyeko, insisted on March 29 that Kasenga was still under government control.

The Defence Ministry early last week reported heavy fighting around the town of Moba, on Lake Tanganyika, 150 kilometres south of Kalemia, in Shaba province, and later said it had retaken the town from the rebels.

The fall of Kasenga would mark a significant advance by the rebels, led by Laurent-Desire Kabila, at a time when rebel representatives and Kinshasa authorities are meeting for negotiations.

That meeting was agreed to at a special Organization of African Unity (OAU) meeting in Lome, Togo, on March 26, the first face-to- face meeting between the warring parties since the rebels took up arms last October.

The archbishop's call also came after Mobutu's camp received a major jolt when a long-time supporter of the strongman threw his sympathy to rebel forces.

Speaking in Kinshasa, former prime minister Jean Nguza Karl-I-Bond urged his followers to "no longer obey the regime" of the dictatorial president who has run Zaire for 31 years. He said that he was quitting as leader of the Conclave Political Forces, a coalition of political parties that have been close to Mobutu, and charged that Mobutu was maintaining "political confusion" over Zaire.

Weakened by cancer, Mobutu, 66, has rarely been seen in public since he returned to Kinshasa on March 21 from France to deal with the rebel offensive that has cost him the eastern quarter of Africa's third largest country.

Karl-I-Bond, who hails from Shaba, urged his supporters to "welcome the rebel chief" to Lubumbashi, the provincial capital, where inhabitants have been awaiting Kabila's arrival for days.

He said he was withdrawing support for Mobutu after he reappointed Kyungu Qu Mwanza as governor of Shaba province. Mwanza had the same job until 1991, when he was ousted after friction between Shaba and East Kasai natives.

"I will say to my activists that this governor is Mobutu's governor," he said. "They are now free to do what they wish and side with Kabila. They can welcome him, because my party has become an independent force."

The new developments also come as the Kinshasa government remained in a political paralysis, unable to name a new prime minister since the resignation of the cabinet shortly after Mobutu returned to the country from abroad on March 21.

Meanwhile opposition groups meeting at the parliament in Kinshasa on April 2 named Etienne Tshisekedi as Zaire's Prime Minister, a proposal that was okayed by President Mobutu Sese Seko's signature, but little else was heard by way of official comments. Tshisekedi, a minister many times before breaking with Mobutu in the 1980s, replaces Kengo wa Dondo who resigned on March 24. The transition period gives the opposition power to propose the new prime minister to the president.

But in a warning to Zaire's opposition leaders before they announced their choice of premier, the rebels' Voice of the People radio said on March 29 that "any adventurer" who agreed to be Mobutu's prime minister would pay dearly. It called on the main opposition leader, Etienne Tshisekedi, not to accept the "poisoned chalice" of the premiership after previous premier Kengo wa Dondo was forced to resign.

The rebels' "justice minister", Kongolo Mwenze, said last week that if Tshisekedi became premier, he would become "an enemy" who would have to be beaten.

Apart from Kabila, Tshisekedi is the only figure powerful enough to run against Mobutu, observers say.

Mobutu, now one of African's perennial figures, seized power in 1965, after independence had been followed by civil war. The then army commander abolished political parties and finally established a single party, the Popular Movement for the Revolution (MPR).

His one-party rule was bolstered by prosperity from the rise in the prices of copper, one of the many valuable minerals abundant in this Central African state.

In 1975, however, copper prices collapsed, helping lead to massive foreign debt in Zaire that had a major impact on both domestic and foreign policy. The situation also suffered from the government's corruption and doctrinaire nationalistic effort to "Zaireanize" the economy.

In 1990, Mobutu yielded to international pressure and announced a transition to a multiparty system. But this is precisely the system that has failed to create the accountability and debate that would lead to reforms, spawning instead a rebellion that people here seem to be favouring as much out of weariness as political conviction.

All hopes are now pinned on the face-to-face talks, the first between the two sides since the rebels launched their offensive six months ago, for the Mobutu regime to save face.

But rebels are not expected to walk easily to the conference table, their intransigence clearly built on their military successes. In the past six months, they have seized a quarter of Zaire, in the east and south-east where the mineral wealth of the central African state is concentrated.

These resources, the bedrock of Zaire's economy, range from copper, the leading mineral, to cobalt, industrial diamonds, zinc, tin, manganese, gold and cadmium. And the resources are of prime importance to the global economy as 60 per cent of the world's cobalt, 90 per cent of the world's small industrial diamonds and a significant proportion of the world's copper come from Zaire.

The seemingly relentless rebel offensive has also trapped an estimated 100, 000 Rwandan Hutu refugees, causing an ongoing row between the United Nations refugee agency and the rebel leadership over how best to help them.

UNHCR official Filippo Grandi said the rebels were insisting that refugees camped near Kisangani move south towards the river port town of Ubundu. "We prefer to assist them on the spot as we cannot make them walk in their present state," Grandi said.

Around 100,000 exhausted, sick and desperate refugees have set up makeshift camps between seven and 40 kilometres south of Kisangani after leaving the river port of Ubundu around 10 days ago. The World Food Programme (WFP) managed to reach them with 120 tonnes of food aid by train on March 27 and 28, their first supplies for a month.

The rebels are refusing to allow them to cross the recently taken city of Kisangani on their way home to Rwanda.

Grandi said the UN agency had agreed to ask the refugees to move a few kilometres back from a rebel military position. "But we can't force them to," he added.

The UN wants to evacuate the most vulnerable refugees back to Rwanda using Kisangani airport.

"With five planes, we can take between 1,000 and 1,500 vulnerable people every day," Grandi said.

The others face a gruelling journey, he added. "We will transport them by truck through Kisangani, but without stopping until we reach 60 kilometres, on the road to Lubutu." There, the refugees will have to dismount and hike for a further 40 kilometres as the road is impassable, Grandi said.

Further truck journeys, with periods of arduous long walks where the road is again impassable, await the refugees before their distant goal of Bukavu, on Rwanda's border with Zaire.

The agency believes that it can repatriate 1,000 refugees a day with this plan. "Therefore, it could take, at best, between two and three months. But this plan has first to be approved by the (rebel) Alliance," Grandi cautioned.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
'Be Prophetic', Christian Communicators Urged


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

ACHIMOTA-GHANA - Christian communicators in Africa have been urged to emulate the prophets of old and wage a relentless war against ethnic and religious conflicts, plight of refugees and injustices.

Mr. Kofi Totobi Quakyi, Ghana's Minister of Information made this call here when opening a three-day seminar under the theme Towards Promoting Human Dignity in Africa - A challenge to the Church and Christian Media.

The March seminar, attended by 30 participants from eight African countries was sponsored by the World Association for Christian Communication in Africa (WACC-AR).

Quakyi told participants drawn from Ghana, Togo, Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Sierra Leone, Kenya, South Africa and the Gambia that there were many social vices on the continent which dehumanize man, adding that "God created all of us in His image and we must not destroy, dehumanize and degrade the image which is molded in beauty and love." 

The Ghanaian Information Minister also cited the abuse of the environment as another act of human indignity and urged communicators to educate the people on the need to preserve forests and trees from total destruction.

The minister lamented diseases that are killing Africans. He also deplored the influx of young men and women to the cities in search of employment, and their gradual lure to drug-related crimes, robbery and prostitution among others.

"Girls between the ages of 14 and 16 give birth and are abandoned in various places. The result is that these children are also abandoned in various places. Why should this happen? You as Christian communicators have a daunting task to stop indignity against man. When you see things happen rise and save the lives of the people as the Lord told Prophet Habakkuk - 'Write down clearly on clay tablets what I reveal to you so that it can be read at a glance," the Information Minister challenged journalists.

Quakyi said promoting human dignity is not an easy task and therefore urged communicators to show love, decency and affection for their fellow beings.

He regretted that many of the tribal conflicts in Africa were fanned by journalists, charging that had they taken the trouble to soberly reflect on the events and suggested a constructive approach instead of destructive, negative methods, most lives would have been saved.

"You all know that information is power but power is used to promote peace, love, unity and understanding. Any communicator who uses his penmanship to foment trouble or divide the people is not promoting human dignity and therefore is the son of perdition," he said.

He further challenged Christian communicators to be real apostles of communication by delivering the exact message without adulterating it. " Remember what the Lord told Moses when he asked him to go to Egypt and ask King Pharaoh to unchain the Israelites from bondage. 'Let my people go.' This was the concise and precise message from God. Moses did not change it. He delivered it with courage and fortitude. I charge you to be good communicators and not bad ones."

Minister Quakyi reminded the participants that bad communicators are those who never tell the truth for fear of being arrested or persecuted. Indeed bad communicators are those who cause havoc and instability, he added.

Underscoring the role of obedience in communication, the Ghanaian minister urged journalists to be dedicated, committed, fearless and truthful. "Finally, take note that a man's dignity is his greatest pride but when that dignity is dented or smudged, he ceases to be a whole man," he challenged.

The seminar chairman Rev. David Dartey, who is the General Secretary of the Christian Council of Ghana said events in Africa were gloomy and urged the churches to provide material and spiritual needs for the people. "You must endeavour always to show concern to the poor, the marginalised, the sick, and the hungry by ensuring that life is made meaningful to them."

The seminar deliberated on the dehumanising tendencies in Africa with particular reference to Ghana and the West-African sub-region, factors responsible for the erosion of human dignity in Africa and the state of the media in Africa with particular reference to issues on human dignity in Ghana and the sub-region.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 7, 1997


Central African Republic;
Rebels, Peacekeepers Hold Talks


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

BANGUI - Mutinous soldiers from the Central African Republic have held a series of talks with African peacekeepers to restore relations after violence the previous weekend which left some 20 people dead, the peacekeepers' chief said on March 29.

General Edouard Nkili, head of the African peace force, said he had held several rounds of talks with the mutineers after the previous weekend's clashes between rebels and troops from Chad who comprise part of the peacekeeping mission.

Nkili said the peacekeepers "have not come to the Central African Republic to make war," and stressed that his men were trying to persuade the rebels to disarm, but that no weapons had yet been handed over despite the March 30 deadline. 

A spokesman for the rebels said they "were not taking any notice of the timetable (for peace)," and that they "did not know what disarmament they were talking about."

About 450 peacekeepers, with equipment from France, were deployed in February to oversee agreements that ended the last two-months' mutiny after an intra-African diplomatic effort to end the crisis, which had begun over salaries, but ended up in a bid to oust President Ange-Felix Patasse after the mutineers had accused Chadian soldiers of supporting his regime.

Last February, following a January accord, opposition parties were called to join a coalition government, and parliament voted in favour of an amnesty for anyone liable to prosecution over the last mutiny.

But the hostilities broke out again the previous weekend in and around the Bangui district of Petevo, one of the strongholds of the 500 soldiers who rebelled last November to demand the ouster of President Patasse, despite efforts to restore harmony to a country wracked by three separate army mutinies last year.

Bangui's streets were deserted on March 23 because of the escalating violence, and other members of the 700-strong MISAB contingent were out in force.

Witnesses reported that some Chadian shopkeepers had been taken hostage by the former mutineers, after the ex-mutineers claimed that their Kasai barracks had been targeted by three mortars, fired either by the MISAB force or the presidential guard.

Both sides have accused each other of provocation. But local sources said the ex-mutineers were attempting to advance on an old armaments factory in the northwest of the city which serves as headquarters for the peacekeeping force's 150-strong contingent from Chad.

Those killed included two who had opened fire on the six-nation MISAB forces and five civilians hit by stray gunfire, the sources said.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Racism Charges Against Ethiopian Jews


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

TEL-AVIV - Adisn Masala, the first Ethiopian Jew elected to the Knesset (Parliament) in Israel says it is not justifiable to call the general Israel population racist.

"I cannot say the general Israeli population are racist; true some individuals are very racist and call black Ethiopian Jews nick names, but the majority of the population are certainly not racist."

His sentiments come in the wake of revelations of racism in Israeli army ranks which have resulted in nearly 20 suicides among Ethiopian Jews serving in Israel's conscript army in the last three years alone. 

An Israeli soldier of Ethiopian Jewish extraction named Elan Tamana is the latest suicide case to hit the army. Israel's Ethiopian community blame racism in the army, a charge borne out by Tamana's sister who said her brother regularly complained to her that his platoon comrades regularly called him "niger" or the Israeli word "kushi". They chided him to bring his own cup from home and not use their cups and plates.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu angrily branded racism in the Israeli army as "an aberration," following a visit by another Ethiopian Israeli soldier who complained that he was denied medical treatment at a military hospital because he was black.

Early last year, former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres expressed his bitterness, saying he too would feel aggrieved following reports in an Israeli daily that blood donated by Israeli's Ethiopian community was regularly destroyed by the Israeli Blood Bank service, who attributed the practice to fears that such blood donated by the black community was more likely to carry infectious agents like HIV or Hepatitis-B.

Prime Minister Peres said he understood the anger of the black Jewish community after several thousands of them went on the rampage in Tel Aviv to protest what they said were wide-spread racial segregation against their community, most of whom arrived in Israeli in a mass airlift in the late 80s.

There are some 62,000 Jews of Ethiopian extraction in Israel. Most are poor and have made little headway socially since they arrived in Israel.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Algeria;
Opposition, Fundamentalists Differ On Elections


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

ALGIERS - One of Algeria's main opposition parties, the Socialist Forces Front (FFS), has decided to take part in the June 5 general elections, but Muslim extremists have said they will boycott the same.

FFS first secretary Seddik Debaili said after a meeting of his party's leadership on April 12 that the party will campaign on the theme of peace for Algeria, and reserved the right to pull out of the poll if democratic principles were not respected.

The elections had been imposed by the regime of President Liamine Zeroual and were not the solution to the country's civil war, he said. 

The FFS's decision means that most of the legal political parties will run in the general elections, unlike the presidential elections in November 1995 and the referendum a year later, which extended Zeroual's constitutional powers.

The June 5 poll will give Algeria its first elected assembly since the annulment of the first round of elections in January 1992, which the now- banned Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) was poised to win. That move sparked off the conflict which has killed an estimated 60,000 people.

But on April 1, the outlawed FIS reiterated that it will not field any candidates in the June 5 general elections. "FIS representatives have absolutely no intention to stand in these elections -- and with no other parties whether they share our ideology of not," one of FIS leaders told the daily Al-Alem-Siyassi, which did not reveal his identity.

This statement refutes persistent reports in the Algerian press recently which suggested that FIS candidates might stand on the electoral lists of other parties, particularly those which, like the FIS, signed an "appeal for peace."

"This declaration is nothing more than a political manoeuvre destined to win greater popularity and credibility or Ennahda by attracting the FIS's large following with something non-existent," the anonymous FIS leader was cited as saying in reply to Ennahda leader, who recently said his party was prepared to include FIS candidates on its lists.

The FIS decision came one month after reports reaching here that its executive bureau in exile had undergone a reshuffle that had left at the top its Germany-based leader, Rabah Kebir.

A communique issued in Bonn spoke of "a structural readjustment" within the leadership which had created a seven-man executive committee - all newcomers with the exception of Kebir, whose deputy would be Abdelkrim Ghemati.

It said it was "open to all the cadres and active members of the FIS as long as they respect its political line and its legitimate" leadership in the persons of Abassi Madani and Ali Belhadj, both imprisoned in Algeria.

Newcomers to the leadership in exile, include Djaafar el-Houari, the former president of the Algerian Brotherhood in France (FAF) who fled to London after being expelled in 1994 to Burkina-Faso.

Another is Abdelkrim ould-Adda, who with Anwar Haddam represented the FIS at the signature of a "national pact" with the Algerian opposition in January 1995 in Rome.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Cameroon;
Elections Announced, Strife Rocks Cameroon


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

BAMENDA-CAMEROON - Parliamentary elections in the West African nation of Cameroon will take place on May 17, President Paul Biya has announced here. Elections were last held in 1992.

The announcement coincides with reports of serious civil disturbances in the north western district of Bamenda which is predominantly English speaking. Anglo Cameroonians regularly complain that Francophone regions monopolize power and state resources at their expense. 

The government says 10 people including gendarmes were killed in the civil disturbances in Bamenda at the end of March. The opposition in Cameroon says the troubles were fomented by the government of President Pauyl Biya as a pretext for postponing elections.

Earlier the Cameroon Minister for Information Augustin Konchu Kumenyi said investigations were still being carried out to determine if the disturbances in Bamenda originated from the aspirations of English speaking separatists. He said the government had sent more troops to Bamenda to ensure that peace prevailed.

Other reliable sources say the disturbances in Bamenda were the work of a group called the Southern Cameroon National Liberation Army (SCNLA), whose mainly youthful conscripts were now being rounded up by the army. Reports from the region say there are as many as 500 members of the rebel outfit still at large.

In 1961, Southern Cameroon sometimes called Western Cameroon formerly under British rule (anglophone Cameroon) decided in a United Nations sponsored plebiscite to quit the Federation of Nigeria and instead join the francophone Republic of Cameroon in a federation of equal status.

During the disputed elections of 1992 it became clear that the incumbent President Paul Biya could face greater challenges from anglophone Cameroon following the post-election declaration that the former Southern Cameroon was a mere captive nation within the 36- year-old union.

Indeed in April 1993, over 4,000 delegates from all the 13 divisions of anglophone Cameroon met at the All Anglophone Conference held at the Buea Catholic Mission at which speaker after prominent speaker declared in essence that "we (anglophone) have been treated like the jetsam and flotsam of life."


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Ivory Trade Lobbyists Raise Dust


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

HARARE - As Zimbabwe prepares to host the 10th Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) in June this year, bullish animal rights groups in the West are on the offensive against the country's attempts to lobby for resumption in ivory trade.

The groups, who claim to be saviours of wildlife, are even attempting to convince about 1,500 delegates from 136 countries to move the conference from Zimbabwe to another country which supports the ban.

They have even extended their pressure to influence donors and Western governments to cut aid to countries defying their dictates.

However, local wildlife experts accuse the groups of putting animals before human beings by imposing strict protectionist measures at the expense of the welfare of the people and the ecosystems. 

Of concern to Zimbabwe is the 1989 ban on international trade in ivory which has also affected Botswana and Namibia with equally huge populations of elephants.

The ban was initiated in the hope of controlling poaching which has been responsible for the sharp decline in animal numbers particularly in East Africa.

The three Southern African countries have in the past unsuccessfully lobbied for the down-listing of the elephant from Appendix I which bans any trade to Appendix II which allows for regulated trade under strict conditions.

A lifting of the ban during the conference would enable Zimbabwe to resume trade of its stockpile of 40 tonnes of ivory, which would fetch millions of dollars that could benefit the cash-strapped National Parks Department and help fund other government social welfare programmes.

One of the most vocal opponents of Zimbabwe's lobby is Species Survival Network, a consortium of over 30 non-governmental organizations and leading animal groups active internationally, whose principal function will be to ensure that the 1989 bans stay.

"This they will seek to achieve not by calm reasoning but by whipping up public anger to such a fever pitch that would-be traders will need skins like bull elephant hide if they remain stout in their resolve," Africa Resource Trust, a locally-based Southern Africa conservation trust warns.

But local conservationists and government argue that elephants in most of Southern Africa are not an endangered species and are in fact a danger to the environment and human life because of their large and increasing number which is now out of control.

Communal Areas Management Programme for Indigenous Resources (CAMPFIRE) director Taparendava Maveneke says although elephants in Africa are not healthy in numbers, Southern African countries' elephants populations are increasing to the extent of threatening the survival of other wild species and the whole ecosystem.

At 65,000, Zimbabwe carries twice the number of elephants it can handle at its optimum level of 35,000. Because of their large numbers, the animals have become a menace.

People are being trampled to death or left maimed for life. Crops and the natural vegetation is destroyed while homes are damaged. As a result people live in constant fear of the animals.

Maveneke says the groups who practice "environmental colonialism" still regard the concept of a Dark Africa where western "romanticists" disguised as tourists visit to have a taste of the "wilderness."

"It is Western romanticism to equate people with animals and they say culling is inhuman because they just want to come here to take photographs of our wildlife and get satisfied while local people are denied a source of income," he adds.

He notes that such groups use the political vote in their countries to influence their governments to withdraw support to organizations which they label as supporters of the killing of animals as if it is murder.

The United States' largest animal rights group is reported to be campaigning to discredit CAMPFIRE and put an end to funding for the programme from the United States Agency for International Development (USAID).


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Christians Warn President Abacha


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

LAGOS - Nigerian Christians have warned the country's military strongman not to try and convert himself from a military ruler into a civilian president as this west African country prepares for transition to democracy next year.

In a statement issued here on March 21, the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN), an umbrella grouping Christians in the country, said that it " strongly" advised Abacha not to follow the trend of other African generals- turned presidents.

The association "strongly counselled the federal military government not to imitate those African countries where Military Heads of State took off their military uniforms and became civilian heads of state," said the statement, which was drawn up at the end of the CAN's national executive meeting here on March 19. 

Speculation has been rife in Nigeria for months that Abacha, who seized power in November 1993, will contest presidential elections due in October 1998, as the final stage in a transition to democracy in Africa's most populous nation.

On February 5, Abacha refuelled speculation that he may run for the presidency, saying the matter depended on him alone, according to the Nigerian press.

"The decision is my own constituency's. It is not new in Africa, neither is it new in the sub-region, that military people have stepped into politics," he told the Washington Times newspaper.

With that little phrase in his first interview in two years, picked up by the state News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) here, he thus sparked a new wave of intense debate on his plans.

Under a programme for a gradual transfer of power to an elected civilian government, presidential elections are due to take place in Nigeria in late 1998. The military will hand over power to an elected president on October 1 that year.

Speculation over an Abacha candidacy was first sparked last September by a comment by former Supreme Court head Mohammed Bello.

"According to the Constitution, all Nigerians have the right to participate in such an election, General Abacha is Nigerian. (A decision to run) would be nothing extraordinary, particularly in Africa where this sort of example is common," Bello said.

Abacha's regime seized power in November 1993, five months after a previous military junta annulled the results of a civilian presidential election, whose presumed winner Moshood Abiola is still in prison despite local and international uproar calling for his release.

Nigeria's junta has since come under intense criticism for its record on human rights.

But the Christians stressed that such a move in Nigeria would be "fraught with perilous and far-reaching consequences, which will drastically impede the progress to healthy democracy and shake political stability to its roots."

The CAN statement also warned Nigeria from joining the D-8 ministerial meeting early last January in Istanbul, Turkey. Other countries in the D-8 are predominantly Muslim Bangladesh, Egypt, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Pakistan and Turkey.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


186 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 7, 1997


Libya;
Vatican Appoints Bishop For Libya


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

VATICAN - As part of its efforts to strengthen Catholicism in predominantly Muslim Libya, the Holy See recently appointed Rev. Fr. Sylvester Carmel Magro as Vicar Apostolic for Benghazi in the north-east.

According to the Vatican's weekly L'Osservatore Romano, English edition, the appointment was made on March 10.

The Catholic church weekly says the new appointment fills the gap left after the Libyan authorities expelled Bishop Giustino Guilio Pastorino, a member of the Order of Friars Minor (O.F.M.) or Franciscans, from the country in 1970. 

The new Vicar Apostolic joins another Franciscan Bishop Giovanni Innocenzo Martinelli, the lone Catholic bishop, who is Vicar Apostolic for Tripoli, Libya's capital.

The alteration of church structures will certainly encourage the growth of understanding between Catholic hierarchy and the authorities, and a greater appreciation of the co-operation offered by men and women religious and, in general, by all the Catholics in the country, who are fully involved in the life of their society, the weekly notes.

Libya has an estimated 50,000 Catholics served by 12 priests and 80 religious women (nuns). There are 44 centres providing social assistance and health care, the church paper further says.

With the start in the recent years of great development projects, workers from various countries have come to Libya, spurring the church to increase her efforts for the Christian formation of newly arrived families, according to the weekly.

The history of Christianity in North Africa, naturally brings to mind the church of St Augustine and the martyrs of the first centuries of Christianity.

The Christian faith later benefited from the apostolic activity of the sons of St Francis who, down the centuries, have maintained a discreet, hard- working presence even in the changed political and religious context of those lands.

Christianity was fully integrated into the local situation, respectful and respected, and has left ancient traces such as the church of St. Mary of Angels, dating back to 1645 and located in the capital, Tripoli.

L'Osservatore Romano says Libya is becoming an important ecumenical meeting point. Hundreds of thousands of Egyptian citizens reside there, many of whom are Coptic or Orthodox Christians.

Meanwhile, the Holy See on March 10 established diplomatic relations with Libya and immediately appointed Archbishop Jose Sebastian Laboa as the Apostolic Nuncio in the north African country.

"The Holy See hopes that the establishment of diplomatic relations will reinforce and increase the bonds of friendship and co-operation which have existed for centuries between Catholics and the Libyan people," L'Osservatore Romano reports.

Statistics provided by the World Christian Encyclopaedia indicate that 98.1 per cent of Libya's 4 million people are Muslims. The Christians represent about 1.7 per cent comprising mainly Catholics and Orthodox.

Islam spread into this north African country from Arabia and Egypt in the second half of the seventh century, according to the encyclopaedia, edited by Rev. Dr. David Barrett.

The author says; "In north Africa, Christianity has had an ancient history, being the scene of the church's early expansion and the home of some of its most distinguished theologians."

However, the combination of a failure to convert the Berbers and internal divisions due in part to Donatism weakened the church and made it impotent in the face of Muslim expansion in the seventh century, Dr. Barrett notes.

The region today has almost no indigenous professing Christian believers and Christianity is made up of Catholics and Orthodox from Greece and the Near East, in addition to a decreasing number of Protestants and Anglicans from Europe and North America, says Dr. Barrett, who researched on churches and religions in the modern world between AD 1900-2000.

The expulsion of Italian colonists and American and British military personnel, together with Egyptians since 1974, has radically reduced Catholic, Orthodox and Protestant communities, the survey further says.

And Barrett adds; "before the departure of Italians at the beginning of 1970, the Catholic church was divided into four ecclesiastical jurisdictions, namely the vicaries of Benghazi, Derna and Tripoli and the Prefecture of Misurata."


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


187 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Zaire Emergency Fact Sheet No. 9


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . ZAIRE - Complex Emergency, Fact Sheet 9, Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, April 8, 1997. Note: The last fact sheet was dated April 3, 1997.

Background: In mid-October 1996, fighting broke out in South Kivu, Zaire between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance) led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting caused Rwandan and Burundian refugees to flee, forcing over 700,000 Rwandans and 62,000 Burundians to repatriate by the end of 1996. Hundreds of thousands of refugees also fled west, scattering in small groups deeper into Zaire. The fighting spread north, west, and south, with the Alliance gaining territory on all fronts. The Alliance now controls the eastern third of Zaire. On March 15, the Alliance captured Kisangani. As the Alliance advances towards its next stated goal of Lubumbashi, it has already seized Kamina, a strategic rail junction located to the northwest of Lubumbashi, and Kasenga, 200 km northeast of Lubumbashi. The Alliance captured Mbuji-Mayi, the diamond capital of Zaire, on April 5 and Kipushi, 30 km west of Lubumbashi, on April 7. Talks between Alliance and Zairian government authorities began in South Africa on April 5. 

Haut-Zaire Province: Approximately 89,000 Rwandan refugees are clustered in three groups along the 125 km rail line west of the Zaire River, south of Kisangani: 57,000 at km 25, 31,000 at km 41, and 1,000 at km 82. Humanitarian agencies have set up food, water sources, medical facilities, and services for unaccompanied children at each site. Relief organizations are concerned about high rates of severe malnutrition, dehydration and high fever, presumably caused by malaria. The United Nations (U.N.) High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) repatriation plan, approved by the Alliance on April 5, envisions flying the most vulnerable refugees from Kisangani to Goma, where they will be trucked to Gisenyi, Rwanda. Rwandan army soldiers will then screen the refugees at the Nkamira transit center before they are transported home. UNHCR hopes that the balance of the refugees can also be repatriated by air. Displaced and war-affected Zairians are also receiving assistance. Missionary sources report that 4,000 of the 39,000 registered internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Kisangani have returned home. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is also planning to airlift some of the remaining IDPs to Goma or Bukavu. Foraging by the refugees, ex-FAR, and Interahamwe has affected food availability in villages between Ubundu and km 25. WFP has begun food distributions to these affected Zairians. To help coordinate movements of refugees and IDPs, the British Overseas Development Agency is establishing an air logistics center in Goma and a ground logistics center in Kisangani.

Kivu Province: On March 31, UNHCR reported that 20,000 - 30,000 Rwandan refugees emerged at Karuba, 13 km west of Sake. Another 2,500 emerged at Tongo, west of the former camps of Katale and Kahindo, north of Goma. Once the refugees are screened by Alliance forces, UNHCR trucks them directly to the Rwandan border. On April 4 - 5, 4,166 refugees repatriated, including 151 unaccompanied children, 3,819 refugees from Karuba, 168 from Tongo, 19 from Sake, and 12 spontaneous repatriations.

Kasai-Oriental Province: Before the Alliance seizure of Mbuji-Mayi, there were reports of 2,000 refugees near the town. At least 30,000 refugees are moving towards Angola. They are believed to be the group who fled the Shabunda area camps in South Kivu. U.S. Government (USG) Assistance: On March 14, USAID's Disaster Assistance Response Team (USAID/DART) arrived in the region to help advance relief efforts in eastern Zaire. USAID/DART installed an information officer in Nairobi, a field officer in Goma, and a field officer in Kisangani. On April 5, USAID/DART assessed the condition of refugees at km 25, accompanied by UNDHA and EU officials. Two doctors from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention arrived on April 5 in Goma and have been seconded to UNICEF. BHR/OFDA has provided grants to ICRC to assist internally displaced Zairians and repatriating Rwandan refugees and to Save the Children/UK for assistance to vulnerable Rwandan and Zairian unaccompanied children. The State Department's Bureau for Population, Refugees, and Migration has provided funding to ICRC and to UNHCR for IDPs and refugees in eastern Zaire. Between December and February, BHR's Office of Food for Peace provided roughly 2,500 MT of food to eastern Zaire from the Rwanda Regional Program.

Total OFDA Assistance (to date). . . . . . . . . . . . $5,548,118

Other USG Assistance (to date) . . . . . . . . . . . . $7,750,000

TOTAL USG FY 1997 Humanitarian Assistance (to date). .$13,298,118


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 8, 1997


Sudan;
New Information On Situation In Sudan


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Geneva - Brief reminder of the situation: The Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, a member of the network, expressed its grave concern over a wave of arrests made within the month of January. Between 7 and 13 January 1997, forty-eight people were arrested by the authorities in Khartoum and were being held without charge. In several cases, families had not been informed of the whereabouts of the detained. On 20 January 1997 Dr. Nageeb Nagmadin Hassan El Toum, one of the arrested persons was moved from an unknown detention centre to the ghost house at Kober Prison. Abdella Malik, one of the forty-eight people arrested, was released on 21 February 1997.

New information: According to new information received from the Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, El Fadil Mahir and, Dr Osman Sourkati, were released on 7 February 1997 and Suoudi Darag, Sidig Youssif, Gamal Adbel Rahman, El Hag Karoum, Kamed Abdel Rahman El Sheikh, Mohamed Ismael El Azhuri, Mohamed El Mahdi, Dr Abdullah Malik were released on 10 March 1997. 

The other 37 persons arrested, including Dr. Nageeb Nagmadin Hassan El Toum, are still in detention.

Case SDN 050297.2 Second follow-up of Case SDN 050297

The International Secretariat of OMCT has also received new information on the following situation in Sudan.

Brief reminder of the situation: The Sudanese Victims of Torture Group informed the International Secretariat of the arrests, detentions and fear of torture of sixty-one people in and around Khartoum at the end of January and the beginning of February. The whereabouts of the sixty-one people was unknown. Mohmed Babiker Mukhtar and Dr Mohmed Suliman were released on 21 February 1997.

New information: According to new information received from the Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, Dr Salah Haroun and Mrs Samira Karar were released on 7 February 1997. Furthermore, Amin El Shawafa was released on 23 February 1997, and Abdel Monem Ahmed El Hag was released on 10 March 1997.

The other 55 people are still in detention.

Case SDN 240297.1 Follow-up of Case SDN 240297

The International Secretariat of OMCT has also been informed of the release of Omer Kokoug, one of the detainees in Sudan on whose behalf we requested your intervention.

Brief reminder of the situation: The Sudanese Victims of Torture Group expressed its grave concern over a new wave of arrests made during the period of 17-21 February 1997.

The detainees were : El Rasheed Mohmed El Hassan (labourer); Madani El Urdi Hasheesa (lawyer from Hasaheesa); Abdel Wahab Ahmed Salih; Abdel Karim Abdel Noor; Usama Sidig Yousif (student at the Ahliya University); Ibrahim Hussain; Issam Hassan Farah Shorbaji (law graduate, Cairo branch, Khartoum); Mohmed Tag Elsir (Faculty of Arts, Cairo branch, Khartoum); Yousif Mohmed Salih (Faculty of Arts, Cairo branch, Khartoum); Tarig El Amin (Faculty of Medicine, Khartoum University); Mamoun Karar (graduate, Cairo University); Emad El Amin Abdulla (Faculty of Medicine, Khartoum University); Hassan Ahmed Osman (Sudan Air - dismissed); Adil El Mardi (National Water Corporation); Hassan Khidder (Khartoum Council); Omer Kokoug (teacher, Chinese Training Institute, Omdurman); Yassin El Tayeb, Mouawya (lived in Kloakla) and Mohamed Ibrahim Abdu Mustafa, also known as Kabagh (businessman).

New information: According to the new information received from the Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, Omer Koloug was released on 10 March 1997.

The other 18 people arrested are still in detention.

Action requested in connection with the three above-mentioned cases: Please contact the Sudanese authorities urging them to:

i. take immediate measures to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of all people still detained and immediate locate their whereabouts if still unknown;

ii. immediately release all the detainees if they are being detained without valid charge or, if such charges exist, to bring them before a competent and impartial tribunal and guarantee their procedural rights at all times;

iii. open a full impartial inquiry into the all the events and allegations of violations of fundamental rights, including acts of presumed torture, identify all those responsible and bring them to trial and apply the penal, civil and /or administrative sanctions provided by legislation;

iv. guarantee in all circumstances respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in accordance with national laws and international standards.

Addresses: His Excellency Lieutenant General Omar Hassan al-Bashir, President of the Republic of Sudan, People's Palace, PO Box Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22385 PEPLC SD or 22411 KAID SD - Fax : +249 11 71 724

Brigadier Bakri Hassan Salih, Minister of Interior, People's Palace, PO Box 281, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22842 WZARA SD or 22604 IPOL SD - Fax : +249 11 71724 / 76554 / 77900 / 73946 / 70186

Mr. Abdel Basset Sabdrat, Minister of Justice and attorney-General, Ministry of Justice, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22459 KHRJA SD (via Ministry of Foreign Affairs) - Fax : +249 1174 063

Mr. Ali Osman Mohamad Taha, Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, PO Box 873, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22459 KHRJA SD or 22461 KHRJA SD - Fax : +249 11 74 063 The Diplomatic Representatives of Sudan in your country.

Geneva, 8 April 1997

Kindly inform us of any action undertaken quoting the exact number of this appeal in your reply.

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/

Africa News


April 8, 1997


South Africa;
ANC W.Cape Condemns Move To Budget For A Deficit


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - Today the Standing Committee on Public Accounts and Finance in the Provincial Legislature began meeting to discuss the delayed provincial budget tabled by MEC Meiring on 2 April. A general discussion was held and three votes were discussed i.e. PUBLIC WORKS, ROADS AND TRANSPORT, AGRICULTURE and the ENVIRONMENT, CULTURAL AFFAIRS AND TOURISM VOTES.

The ANC expressed its concern that the standing committee was at no point consulted concerning the budget crisis. This once again showed a failure on the part of the executive to involve the legislature. We expressed our deep concern at the decision by MEC Meiring to budget for a deficit and thus did not accept the explanation by treasury officials that nothing in current legislation prevented the province from taking this step. ANC members of the committee have thus called on the chairperson Mr Arnold De Jager (NP) to invite the director general of state expenditure, Mr Hannes Smit to appear before the committee. 

In regard to the vote on transport, roads and public works, ANC members called on the department to make available a draft asset register by June of this year.

It has emerged very clearly that the MEC for Education and Culture has no plan on the table concerning the spending of the R13 million allocated for culture. This programme has increased from R300 000 to R13 million from last year and cannot be justified in the context of a deficit. It clearly is nothing more than a cultural discretionary slush fund. The ANC will be formally moving that R12 million is cut from this vote.

It is clear that scope exists for savings in all these votes in regard to posts which are FUNDED BUT NOT YET FILLED. In the public works vote, 500 posts are funded but not yet filled. In Agriculture, 239 posts are funded but not yet filled. The ANC is convinced that savings can be effected by not filling all these posts. If a total of 1000 posts are not filled across all votes a saving of at least R100 million is possible. We have requested full information concerning the number of severance packages granted in the province and how much this will save the province. This information has not yet been made available.

We will make further proposals during the week aimed at trimming R55 million from the budget and hope they will be accepted.

Issued by Tasneem Essop, MPL and ANC Spokesperson on Finance

7 April 1997


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


190 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Concern On Radio Ukhozi


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC in KwaZulu Natal is gravely concerned about the drop of listenership of Radio Ukhozi from 5,7 m to 4,7 m listeners. This is a drop of a million listeners. 

Radio Ukhozi is the main source of information to the poorest of the poor in KwaZulu Natal. To ascribe this massive drop to the mushrooming of community radio stations alone is to avoid the real issue.

The problem lies in the quality of service rendered by Radio Ukhozi. There is a remarkable drop on the standard of service rendered by Radio Ukhozi. This is coupled by the fact that listeners now have a choice of community radio stations. This situation may be worsened by the fact that SAPA has severed its relations with the SABC.

The ANC suggests that the SABC management must undergo introspection of the way Radio Ukhozi is managed, resourced, programmed and how personnel is deployed according to their skills and experience. It is also a fact that Radio Ukhozi is the biggest and the most profitable among all other stations in the SABC KwaZulu Natal region and throughout South Africa.

It is therefore crucial that those who are at managerial positions, especially the news section in KwaZulu Natal SABC region, are proficient also in Zulu. This is for practical reasons and the monitoring of the presentation of programmes.

There must also be an acceptance that Radio Ukhozi is not a personal property of the SABC management. The SABC must accept constructive criticism from the public and not always adopt a defensive posture.

Issued by the ANC KwaZulu Natal Department of Information and Publicity. Date: 7 April, 1997.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


South Africa;
Expulsion Of Sifiso Nkabinde


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC National Working Committee (NWC) meeting in Johannesburg today, Monday 7 April has taken a decision to expel Bhekumuzi Gabriel "Sifiso" Nkabinde from the ANC with immediate effect.

Irrefutable evidence brought to the NWC's attention has established that Nkabinde has not been a bona fide member of the organisation but was infiltrated by the apartheid security establishment, as an agent provocateur, to destabilise and destroy the ANC from within as well as forment inter- communal so-called "black on black" violence.

Among others he was tasked by his handlers to perform the following tasks:

* provide information on the activities of the ANC including leadership structures into which he was infiltrated. 

* report on the activities of our erstwhile army Umkhonto We Sizwe and popular self-defence units.

* and furnish information on the activities of the mass democratic movement.

Nkabinde operated under the alias of Derrick Nene with the agent number SR 4252. The ANC is in posession of the names of his handlers and reports he submitted.

The ANC has information that leads us to believe that Nkabinde was involved in activities that led to destabilisation in some parts of Kwazulu/Natal that could have resulted in the deaths of some of our members and supporters.

The NWC has had to act with urgency regarding this matter because activities he is currently involved in, are aggravating the problems in KwaZulu/Natal particularly the Midlands region. As such his continued presence in the midst of the ANC would have afforded him the cover to further undermine peace and stability in the region and the province.

His expulsion from the ANC removes him from any and all other positions that he may have held on account of his false membership including the KwaZulu/Natal provincial legislature.

The ANC demands that all security force members who have been his handlers now and in the past come forward with a full disclosure.

Issued by the ANC National Working Committee c/o Department of Information and Publicity PO Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107 7 April 1997


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Egypt;
Egyptian Rights Group Protests Torture of Detained Students


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Geneva - The International Secretariat of OMCT requests your URGENT intervention in the following situation in Egypt.

Brief description of the situation: The Egyptian Organization for Human Rights (EOHR), a member of the network, has expressed its grave concern for the students, Mustafa Zedan, Ahmad Taha Qandeel, Mohammed Abdel-Haleem, Tamer Soliman, and Mohammed El-Ba'ali, who were arrested and tortured by Egyptian security officials between 26 and 30 March. According to the information received, they were arrested following their participation in peaceful demonstrations at the Cairo University.

On Wednesday 26 March 1997, security forces arrested Mustafa Zedan, and Ahmad Taha Qandeel as they were taking a taxi after leaving the university. At dawn on Thursday 27 March 1997, security forces raided the house of student Mohammed Abdel-Haleem and arrested him after searching the house and confiscating some materials. 

On 27 March 1997, these three students were referred to the State Security Prosecution which ordered a detention of 15 days pending investigation. They were accused of possession of leaflets and other printed materials that " would disturb peace and harm public interest."

Furthermore, on 30 March, the security forces arrested a further two Tamer Soliman, and Mohammed El-Ba'ali. On 31 March, they were referred to the State Security Prosecution, which ordered their detention for 15 days pending investigations. They were accused of the same charges. According to the information, they stated before the State Security Prosecution that they were subjected to two hours of severe torture in the Giza office during the state security investigations, including electric shocks, beating and kicking.

According to the information received, all of the students mentioned above were involved a demonstration at the Cairo University protesting the settlements policies of Israel.

Furthermore, according to the information received, in connection with the above-mentioned demonstration, the house of the student Samah Helmi was raided by security forces at dawn on 29 March, but she was not arrested because she was not there. Shereen Megahid was referred to the disciplinary board and on 30 March, the University vice president summoned the father of student Areeg Ibrahim, who reportedly had been subjected to strong pressure by the university authorities.

The International Secretariat expresses its grave concern over the physical and psychological well being of the students mentioned above. The Secretariat also underlines that the arrests, harassment, and torture are clear violations of constitutional rights to peaceful assembly and free expression of opinion and of Egypt's international obligations as a State party to Convention Against Torture the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR). These treaties forbid the practice of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, which are, by virtue of Article 151 of the Egyptian Constitution, part of Egyptian law. These arrests also violate article 21 of the ICCPR which affirms the right to everyone to association and peaceful assembly.

Action requested: Please write to the authorities of Egypt urging them to:

i. take all the necessary measures to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of Mustafa Zedan, Ahmad Taha Qandeel, Mohammed Abdel- Haleem, Tamer Soliman, Mohammed El-Ba'ali, Samah Helmi, Shereen Megahid, and Areeg Ibrahim;

ii. order the immediate release of the students arrested in the absence of valid legal charges or, if such charges exist, bring them before an impartial and competent tribunal and guarantee their procedural rights at all times;

iii. open a full impartial inquiry into the events, identify all those responsible and bring them totrial and apply the penal, civil and /or administrative sanctions provided by legislation;

iv. ensure in all circumstances respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in accordance with national laws and international standards.

Addresses: His Excellency Mohammad Hosni Mubarak, President of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 4Abedine Palace, Cairo, Egypt. Telex : 93794 WAZRA UN

His Excellency General Hassan al-Afly, Minister of the Interior, Ministry of the Interior, Al-Sheikh Rihan Street, Bab al-Louk, Cairo, Egypt. Telex : 21361 MOICM UN - Fax : + 202 355 7792

His Excellency Mr. Faruq Sayf Al-Nasr, Minister of Justice, Ministry of Justice, Midan Lazoghly, Cairo, Egypt. Fax : + 202 355 8103

Geneva 7 April, 1997 Kindly inform us of any action taken quoting the exact number of this appeal in your reply

Ben Schonveld Projects Manager OMCT-SOS-Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140 OMCT is: l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture The World Organisation Against Torture

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/
