193 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Media Groups Wants Sierra Leone Reporters Freed


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), and Robert Menard, general secretary, Reporters Sans Frontieres, April 4, 1997, to His Excellency President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah of Sierra Leone.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) and Reporters Sans Frontieres(RSF), independent organizations working to defend press freedom worldwide, wish to protest the detention of Expo-Times publisher Ibrahim Seaga Shaw and editors Gibril Koroma and Abayomi Charles Roberts.

According to our information, Shaw, Koroma, and Roberts, of the privately owned biweekly newspaper Expo-Times, have been detained in Pademba Road prison since 19 March 1997. In court the prosecutor accused them of having " obtained secret official documents and extracts containing secret military information which might be used directly or indirectly by an enemy against the State." If convicted of treason, the journalists face a prison sentence of up to 15 years. 

The journalists' arrests are believed to be in connection with an article published in the 19 March issue of Expo-Times titled "Abacha's Gangsterism." The article alleged that the arrest in Nigeria, of Revolutionary United Front (RUF) leader Foday Sankoh was a stratagem to remove Sankoh from his position as the head of the RUF. Nigerian authorities and the management of the RUF have denied the information published in Expo-Times.

According to the Sierra Leone Association of Journalists, in a recent issue the newspaper clearly stated that its intention was not to disturb diplomatic relations with Nigeria. Shaw, Koroma, and Roberts have appeared in court on four separate occasions and the court has denied all the journalists' applications for bail. The journalists are expected to appear in a higher court on 7 April.

As nonpartisan groups of journalists dedicated to the promotion of press freedom worldwide, CPJ and RSF condemn the arrests of Shaw, Koroma, and Roberts and their continued detention as grave attacks on press freedom and a blatant violation of their right to hold and express opinions and ideas.

This right is guaranteed by Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind," and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, to which Sierra Leone is a signatory. CPJ and RSF call on Your Excellency to remember that the manifesto of the Sierra Leonean People's Party, on the basis of which you were elected, states that "every effort will be made to upgrade our mass media facilities to 21st century standards, with emphasis on community style radio and a vibrant and free press."

Moreover, CPJ and RSF remind you that the United Nations Commission on Human Rights says "detention, as punishment for the peaceful expression of an opinion, is one of the most reprehensible ways to enjoin silence and, as a consequence, a grave violation of human rights."

Your Excellency, CPJ and RSF strongly urge you to do everything in your power to ensure that Shaw, Koroma and Roberts are granted bail and guaranteed a fair trial. We thank you for your attention to this matter and welcome your comments.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Ethiopia;
The Week in Brief


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Addis Ababa - Investment Promotion Conference: Expo'97

Trade Exhibition was opened in Makale by FDRE President Negasso Gidada during the week-end on the eve of the much awaited Tigray Investment Promotion Conference.

The ten-day event, in which no less than 65 domestic and foreign producers and service rendering institutions are displaying their ware, is aimed at introducing local exporters and the community at large with the long catalogue of products and services on display.

Jointly organized by the Tigray Development Association and Africa International Business, the exhibition was visited by Dr. Negasso Gidada, senior regional and federal government officials as well as hundreds of investors who arrived in Makale to attend the investment conference. 

Meanwhile, about 500 investors and other guests visited some typical development projects in Makale and its environs. this included the Mesebo Cement Factory Project, the Makale hydro-delctric power distribution station, privately owned bicycle assembling plant, the Makale University College, the Alula Aba Nega International airport Project, and an industrial zone awaiting the active involvement of investors.

Environmental policy to be applied

The Council of Ministers unanimously voted for the practical application of an environmental policy.

After deliberating on the major points of the policy in three meetings, the council has decided for the particularly of the policy.

Air Force's first annual day marked

Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence, Ato Teferra Walwa recently underscored the significant contribution the national defence force made in ensuring peace and stability of the nation, which, in turn was one of the main factors accounting for the substantial economic growth the nation registered over the past few years.

Ato Tefera made the remark at a panel discussion he held with the staff of the Ethiopian air Force on their second day of observance of the Air Force's first annual day celebration.

He described the event as "historical" because it is the first annual day to be celebrated at a time when the country enjoys peace and stability, democratic governance and fast economic growth.

The celebration concluded later in the week with the graduation of pilots and technicians as well as a huge exhibition organized to depict this defence wing's history spanning 50 years.

Ethio-DPRK relations

At a meeting with the visiting Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) deputy prime minister and foreign minister Mr. Kim Yong Nam, Prime Minister Meles Zenawi recently expressed Ethiopia's wish to further strengthen relations with the DPRK. Prime Minister Meles said that Ethiopia gives high regard to its relation with DPRK, according to a spokesman to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The DPRK deputy premier and foreign minister has on his part expressed his country's Republic of Korea have agreed to cooperate in the areas of construction and irrigation development activities.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Science and Health;
40 million Ethiopians live in malaria prone areas


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - About 40 million Ethiopians live in malaria prone areas, as 1.5 million people are annually infected by the disease, health professionals reported.

The professionals speaking at a panel discussion organized at the Ministry of Health day, said only one third of those affected by the disease get treatment at health institutions.

According to the professionals, malaria which surfaces during rainy seasons attacks people of all age groups. 

The ministry in cooperation with the World Health Organization (WHO) is making efforts to build capacity and strengthen manpower in regional states, they added.

The professionals said preparations are under way to boost-up control of the disease with the financial support of WHO.

Malaria surfaces twice a year as epidemic in Ethiopia in the months of September, October and November, as well as April, May and June, they revealed.

Meanwhile, the Tigray Regional Health Bureau said fruitful results have been recorded during the past years in the field of health service carried out in line with the new health policy.

A report to the health professionals conference held over the past three days said encouraging activities have been made in the construction of health institutions, manpower training, medicines and budget utilization and sanitary health education.

During the past five years, 95 health institutions including hospitals have been constructed and others renovated with the material and labour contribution of the people, the report said.

With regard to disease preventive measures, health attendants were trained at the kebele level to enable them to teach the public while mother and child health care services were given even at field sites, the bureau said.

The bureau added the opening of malaria prevention centres has resulted in the decline of the spread of the disease and no malaria outbreak is observed in the region.

The conference which was attended by 150 health professionals assessed the situation of health service activities in the region.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

196 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Meeting Convened to Examine Inter-African Cooperation on Labour


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The minister in charge of social and administrative affairs in the Office of the Prime Minister, Dr. Kebede Tadesse has underscored the need for strengthening Inter-African co-operation in labour and related services so as to solve the economic, social and political problems prevalent in Africa.

Opening the 20th Ordinary Session of the OAU Labour and Social Commission here yesterday, Dr. Kebede noted that the regular exchange of experiences between and among African countries in human resources development, employment creation and overall programme formulation as well as promoting the full participation of women and investing in youth would be instrumental in alleviating the continent's travails in these areas.

Dr. Kebede further stressed the necessity for establishing peace and stability, fostering sub-regional economic integration and taking due account of the impact of rapid population growth when formulating development policies in Africa. He pointed out that beyond creating a conducive environment for sustainable peace, stability, democratic governance and rapid economic development, Ethiopia has made "a remarkable progress in the social sector," and added: "The government of the FDRE has also adopted a national policy which acts as an umbrella for other sector policies such as education, health, culture, social welfare, women, population and others". Also mentioned with regard to labour were efforts made to harmonize economic reform programmes and the workers and ensure that international labour standards are made the guiding principles at all stages of the reform programmes. 

The Secretary-General of the OAU, Dr. Salim A.Salim, on his part stressed on the unemployment problem in Africa and called for the creation of " effective national, sub-regional and regional institutions to formulate, design, co-ordinate, implement, monitor and evaluate appropriate promotion policies and programmes" for employment, creation and improvement of life and work in the continent.

Dr. Salim also empasized the critical need for solving the debt problem in Africa, protection of children from work and at work and ensuring the "active, full and effective" participation and involvement of women in development endeavours.

The Secretary-General further dwelt upon the task awaiting African countries to redouble efforts to prevent, manage and resolve conflicts afflicting the continent as well as implementing the Abuja treaty establishing the African economic community.

The 20th ordinary session of the OAU Labour and Social Commission which is expected to wind up Saturday may well finalize the modalities of a merger between the Labour commission of the OAU and the conference of African Ministers of Social Affairs in order to make the former one of the pillars of the OAU Economic and Social commission as stipulated in the Treaty Establishing the African Economic community, an OAU press release meanwhile said.

LANGUAGE: English

197 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Science and Health;
Ethiopia monitors seismic activity to tackle earthquake


BYLINE: Asfaw Gemmeda, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Addis Ababa - A one-day symposium on earthquake, organized by the Ethiopian Association of Seismology and Earthquake Engineering to upgrade the know-how and capacity of specialists in the field, was conducted yesterday at the Faculty of Technology of Addis Ababa University. The one-day symposium was attended by 70 specialists and opened by Ato Assrat Bulbula, Ethiopian Scientific and Technology Commissioner.

Dr. Fekadu kebede, President of the Ethiopian Association of Seismology and Earthquake Engineering, aid in a welcoming address that earthquakes are an expression of the continuing evolution of the earth and its surface. He further noted that they are "the most deadly of natural disasters" affecting the human environment. "Catastrophic earthquakes have indeed marked the whole of human history, accounting for 60% of global casualties associated with natural disasters," he pointed out. 

According to him, economic damage caused by natural disasters and by earthquakes in particular are increasing with time. the long-term effects of a catastrophic earthquake (the disruption of the economic chain, human resettlement, the reconstruction to modern standards, etc.) may last for decades and absorb a considerable part of a national budget Dr. Fekadu added.

Among the most disastrous earthquakes which caused enormous damages to property and losses of human lives in Ethiopia, Dr. Fekadu mentioned: the 1961-Kara Koe, 1969 - central Afar, 1987 - Southern Ethiopia, 1989 Dobi Graben (central Afar), 1993 - Nazareth, 1985 Langano and 1995 Awasa earthquakes.

According to the president of the association, a good data base collected over several years is necessary to tackle the problem scientifically. for this purpose, he noted, a continuos monitoring of seismic activity and collection of data is going on at seismic stations inside and outside Addis Ababa.

The papers which were presented at the symposium were expected to look deeper into the problem again from different angles and make the members and concerned organizations aware of the problem and progress, Dr. Fekadu said, and expressed his hope that the results will make a basis for future revision of the building code or the country.

Finally, Dr. Fekadu thanked the Ethiopian Science and Technology Commission, Addis Ababa University, and the Building Design Enterprise for their financial help in organizing of the symposium and the Faculty of Technology for hosting it.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 8, 1997


Business and Finance;
Waltons set to post gloomy results


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - Cape-based stationery and office furniture company Waltons is not expected to show any improvement over its interim results when it reports results for the full year to February.

Speaking at a presentation to journalists and investment analysts yesterday, Pepkor chief executive Jan le Roux said a lot of things had gone wrong at Waltons and "we can be accused of not acting earlier to protect this very sizeable investment".

However, Mr Le Roux said a thorough investigation was being conducted into the various businesses of Waltons whereafter "we will work very closely" with Waltons' management to restore the company to acceptable levels of profitability. 

Carel Stassen, a director of Pepkor, has been given the responsibility of safeguarding Pepkor's investment in Waltons.

Pepkor owns 44 percent of Waltons' parent company Walhold as well as a 12 percent direct stake in Waltons.

But Waltons' poor performance was about the only sore point of the presentation for the Pepkor group. The presentation was held to reassure the investment community that Pepkor chairman Christo Wiese had not "lost interest" in his retail investment arm in favour of his banking interests.

Mr Wiese recently resigned as chief executive of Pepkor and handed the reins to Mr Le Roux, Pepkor's third-largest shareholder and its chief financial officer in the past.

"Perhaps the best answer to some of these questions is to refer to what we see as the future structure of Samgro," Mr Wiese said.

Samgro is currently the holding company for Mr Wiese's interests in NBS- Boland.

"One of the options under consideration is that Samgro will house all my personal interests in the retail and financial services sectors," he said.

"Samgro will thus have two legs, very distinctive and independent, but nevertheless compatible and synergystic. The most obvious link will be in- store banking."

Mr Wiese hoped to have in-store banking up and running in Shoprite stores before the end of August.

But Mr Wiese believed the "real benefit" of in-store banking lay with the " millions of people" who shop at Pep and had no banking experience.

Mr Wiese pointed out that there were twice as many Pep outlets in South Africa as post offices and was in a unique position to bring banking its customers through its tills.

But the future for Pep's traditional business of selling clothing, footwear and textiles to the mass market also looks promising.

Mr Le Roux said it was the Pep customer who would benefit most from the recent Budget.

"We strongly believe the effect of Pep's new information systems ... coupled with an agressive new store development programme and agressive advertising campaign will see an annual increase in turnover of 20 percent over the next three years."


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

199 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


South Africa;
Calling last round not the answer (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Big business and crime fighters are at loggerheads over a campaign to sell wine and beer at supermarkets and grocery shops after hours and on Sundays

If some of the most Draconian liquor legislation in the world - which regulated not only when, where and how but also who was allowed to partake of alcohol - was unable to stop South Africans drinking for the best part of this century, it is highly unlikely that restricting sales in this age of individual liberty will make any difference to consumption.

Western Cape Attorney-General Frank Kahn argues that the shocking level of crime will soar if more shops are allowed to sell wine and beer and sales are permitted on Sundays. He says alcohol plays an overwhelming role in criminal behaviour, from driving under its influence to domestic violence, murder and rape. 

Limiting the places where legal supplies are available or cutting them off for one day a week is not going to help. A hangover from a time when sales were even more strictly controlled is the fact that if one wants liquor, one can get it regardless of the lateness of the hour or day of the week. In shebeens everywhere, willing sellers will supply willing buyers almost around the clock at prices competitive with legal outlets.

Liquor legislation has already been significantly relaxed in line with the new South African philosophy of less, not more regulation. More shops are selling liquor, opening hours are longer and some outlets are licensed to sell on Sundays. It is therefore perfectly reasonable for the three supermarket chains about to challenge Liquor Act restrictions in the Constitutional Court - and for that matter the grocer on the corner - to demand their share of the economic action and for their customers to insist on the additional service.

While it may be a contributing factor, there are far more social ills at the root of crime which need serious attention than liquor.

Calling the last round on Saturdays is not the answer.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


200 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Leslie McKenzie: voice of experience on people's wavelength


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Cape Town - They should call him "The Voice". I'm talking about Leslie McKenzie - broadcaster and radio journalist for more than 30 years.

Tune in to Fine Music Radio and you will hear his deep, well-modulated tones - the perfect radio voice.

Does he know this? 

"Yes I have been told that. I don't agree with it. I hate listening to myself. I cringe each time I hear it on the air if I have made a recording. I try and listen to it because I've got to pick up the mistakes.

"The confidence I think I gained at the microphone was in realising that it's actually a lot of fun ... you really are an ordinary person talking to ordinary people.

"I'm not qualified in anything. I passed matric and that's all. I didn't have any other qualifications. I couldn't afford to go to university.

"I read quite a lot and when possible I read the newspapers to try and keep up with current affairs.

"But I'm an expert in nothing and a dabbler in everything."

What Leslie doesn't say is that he is very much an expert when it comes to broadcasting and radio.

He has been with just about every radio station of note in this country (having begun with the old English Service in Cape Town). His afternoon talk- show on Radio South Africa, Talkabout, was one of the most popular programmes and won several awards during the six years that he produced and presented it.

In 1995 he was snapped up by Cape Town's Fine Music Radio and he now runs the programming and presentation side of that station.

But how nerve-racking being on radio must be; so unforgiving, I suggest.

"I always say to myself, 'Look, if there's a disaster you can't die'. The worst that can happen is that there's a bit of silence while you say there appears to be a bit of a problem ..."

But it's McKenzie's natural and marvellously robust sense of humour that I enjoy most.

He has a knack of lampooning himself (and sometimes others) - maybe subconsciously. "I can't take a meeting seriously. When people sit in a meeting and get terribly intense about it (he tightens the muscles in his face mockingly), I try and look for the funny side, and it's very difficult not to come up with an off-beat comment and not take the mickey out of somebody or something that is being said."

He's a great admirer of Churchill.

"He's been my hero, maybe partly because I have a similar bulldog look. As a kid I was likened to a film star at the time called Butch Jenkins. I never knew him as a child, but I could imagine the ugly little freckled face that must have appeared on the screen.

"I was always a chubby little person with freckles, which I was always conscious about.

"And yet he was a star and I thought, 'Well, if he can make it, I can too, but not in movies.'

"And once I got into radio, I had a little bit more confidence in myself and I decided: 'Let yourself just believe in yourself'."

Perhaps because he didn't come from a well-to-do home, Leslie still has the common touch.

"I have a particular concern for youngsters who are not able to achieve the very basics of what they want out of life and relationships ... kids from disadvantaged or poor homes ...

"I know the traumas and the peer pressures, the awareness of the fact that you can't afford the new shoes that your friends have."

McKenzie says his worst fault is his short temper.

"It's very easy to lose your temper in this job.

"I have a very short fuse. I lose patience with people very quickly, in situations where people are too set in their own ways and too dogmatic and will not listen to another side of the story.

"I often wish that I were a dictator, so that I could listen to various sides and then make a decision and say, 'That's the way we do it.' Boom! Finished!"

Does he have any regrets when he looks back at his life?

"None at all. I've had a charmed life. I say thank you to the Maker frequently and quietly."

By anybody's standards Leslie McKenzie has been immensely successful.

But his career has been one of waxing and waning, he points out.

When he became head of the then commercial service Springbok Radio 21 months after joining the SABC, he says, he felt triumphant.

He loves what he does because "it's more than just a vocation. It's actually a hobby that enables me to pay the rent and the electricity, and buy a little bit of food now and again."


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

April 8, 1997


Sports - General;
Singer's Olympic Fever is catching


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town singer Jennifer Jones is filling the air with Olympic Fever her contribution to the city's bid to host the 2004 Games.

Jones, backed by Gauteng soul group Family Factory, is the lead singer of the song Olympic Fever written, composed and produced by Selwyn Shandel and Stan Lurie to project an upbeat message about the bid and generate public enthusiasm. 

Jones made her mark as a top South African talent when she performed the theme song for the 1995 rugby World Cup at the opening ceremony at Newlands. She also sang the song to commemorate officially the adoption of the new constitution.

Her Olympic Fever record also features rhythm guitarist Louis Mhlanga and Cape Town sax maestro Robbie Janssen.

The lyrics, by Shandel and Lurie, seek to rally the public behind the " chance of a lifetime" project.

The second verse projects the essential message: The Mother City/with beauty so bold/star of Africa/reaching for gold/c'mon everybody/let the Games begin/let's make it happen/we're all gonna win.

The song could be put out for commercial release soon.

Africa News


April 8, 1997


Sports - General;
Inkatha MPs join Cape Town Games bid support group


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - Inkatha Freedom Party MPs have joined the informal committee of "MPs in Support of the Olympics 2004" formed last week to generate public support for the bid.

The MPs are also helping to clear bureaucratic obstacles in the way of bid- related development. 

The politically non-aligned committee, formed by African National Congress MPs recently, has now been joined by four IFP MPs. They are Farouk Cassiem, Buyisiwe Nzimande, Eric Lucas and Ahmed Ally.

Other parties have been invited the back the initiative.

Mr Cassiem said: "We are keen to support any initiative to promote the bid, which we believe is an important opportunity for South Africa. We encourage all MPs to support this initiative."

The group has committed itself to:

* Generate "an atmosphere of excitement" about the bid, encourage popular support and the formation of similar informal committees in education, business, sport, the churches and among ratepayers.

* Help wherever possible to overcome bureaucratic or other obstacles in government to the bid.

* Monitor conditions in Cape Town and highlight things that needed to be done to improve the city's chances in the five-city contest for the Games.

* Conduct spot inspections at proposed Olympic locations and facilities "to ensure they are in good shape".

* Monitor and recommend improvements on the transport network, a critical feature of the Olympic plan.

* Try to "facilitate" whatever further resources were needed to ensure a successful bid.

All Material (c) copyright Independent Newspapers 1997.

Africa News


April 8, 1997


South Africa;
Storm cloud over tourist voyages to Robben Island


BYLINE: Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Robben Island's transformation from political prison to premier tourist destination has brought more than its fair share of problems as people clamour to get the hottest tickets in town.

Another controversy involving the Robben Island museum erupted at the weekend, this time over the advance sale of tickets to people visiting the island.

A Canadian couple were incensed at having to stand in a queue of about 150 people for more than an hour-and-a-half on Friday, only to be told that just 30 tickets for the island were available that day. 

Robert Yaccato and his wife Patricia were angry that most of the tickets had been bought beforehand from tour operators, although they had been told they could buy tickets only on the day of the trip from the museum's Waterfront offices.

The couple were unable to get tickets and had to cancel their trip.

They say that they should have been told the tickets were already sold out, saving them from queuing unnecessarily. They also say they should have been told by the staff at the Waterfront where to get tickets in advance.

A Robben Island spokeswoman said large crowds thronged the Island's Waterfront office over Easter and over the previous weekend, resulting in many people being turned away.

She denied that only 30 people were allowed on to the island on Friday, saying that the normal quota of about 300 had been accommodated.

Normally about half of the tickets available were sold in advance and the rest were allocated to people in the queue. She added that people were told when the tickets were sold out and did not have to stand in the queue unnecessarily. The island's management had always sold tickets in advance.

The opening of Robben Island to tourism has been plagued with problems. Soon after its opening, island authorities blocked the prison entrance to stop hundreds of passengers from four charter boats which had taken them to the island in defiance of regulations.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


204 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


South Africa;
ANC challenging Western Cape's constitution


BYLINE: William-Mervin Gumede, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress is challenging clauses of the Western Cape's proposed provincial constitution in the Constitutional Court.

The provincial legislature recently adopted the constitution, which still needs the court's ratification.

If the ANC's objections to the clauses are successful, the court could throw out the constitution, as was the case with the KwaZulu Natal provincial constitution. The ANC has problems with the clause providing for cultural councils as it is in conflict with the provisions of the national constitution. 

Spokesmen said cultural councils were a smokescreen to bring in cultural apartheid through the back door.

The constitution did not have enough safeguards to prevent Premier Hernus Kriel kicking ANC members out of the provincial cabinet when the constitution had been ratified by the court.

Speculation, vehemently denied by Mr Kriel, has been mounting that the premier intends reshuffling his cabinet and replacing ANC ministers with National Party and Democratic Party members.

"The provincial constitution, although securing the number of ANC portfolios until 1999, does not secure the integrity of the ANC portfolios. Thus Premier Kriel could after certification (of the provincial constitution) throw out ANC ministers after consultation," the ANC said.

The party said it also objected to provisions allowing the premier to appoint four more provincial ministers. It also objected to the clause stipulating that 60 percent of the legislature may, after the next elections, vote to continue a government of provincial unity, which the ANC wants to end in 1999.

The party said the inclusion of the clause providing for a constituency- based electoral system, which differs from the national electoral system, reduced the prospects of the provincial constitution being certified by the court.

The ANC also wanted a clause specifying that previous labour practices of all companies tendering for government contracts be considered before they were awarded contracts.

The ANC also called on the Communist Party and the Congress of South African Trade Unions to lodge separate objections with the court.

The costs of implementing all the provisions of the provincial constitution has been conservatively estimated at R112-million.

This includes the cost of a different electoral system, four extra provincial ministers, new provincial commissioners and cultural councils.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 8, 1997


South Africa;
Police, army patrol Flats in bid to curb gang wars


BYLINE: Asheley Smith and Johan Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - Heavily armed public order police and soldiers in camouflage uniforms are patrolling the Cape Flats at night to prevent war between anti- drug vigilantes and gangsters.

The patrols were implemented after clashes between supporters of People Against Gangsterism and Drugs and the Hard Livings gang in Manenberg on Sunday and attacks on homes of suspected drug dealers yesterday.

In the latest incidents, a man was killed in a drive-by shooting near his Steenberg home, several people were injured and nine Pagad members were arrested. 

Last month homes of gangsters and Pagad leaders were attacked with petrol bombs and handgrenades. Gary Lotz of Brooklyn was killed. It was suspected that he had been mistakenly identified by gunmen apparently looking for a neighbour.

Police spokesman Hendrik Pistorius said no incidents involving the two groups had been reported last night or early today.

Police Casspirs and armoured army vans drove from Manenberg police station about 6pm to patrol hotspots.

Newspapers received two false alarms last night when false messages about attacks on the home of a drug dealer in Lincoln Estate, Athlone, were sent to a pager service in the name of Pagad spokesman Sharief Khan. No such attacks occurred. Mr Khan was unavailable for comment.

Areas where gangsters have been active were earmarked for visible patrols, including Manenberg, Woodstock, Mitchell's Plain, Brooklyn and Sea Point. The joint army and police patrol watched Kings Road flats in Brooklyn, where Mr Lotz was shot, but everything appeared quiet.

Superintendent Pistorius said police co-operation with the army could be extended to include policing of areas of high crime.

Police investigating attacks on Pagad and gangsters have compiled a comprehensive data base of incidents and the profiles of people involved.

They hope this will help curb bombings, firearm attacks and illegally-held marches. Provincial police spokesman John Sterrenberg said the authorities appreciated the community's involvement in fighting crime and trying to rid the Peninsula of drugs and gangsterism.

"But it is a recipe for self-destruction to take the law into your own hands," he said. "The community and police together could be a formidable united front against crime, but when people out there fight crime with crime, it is a step backwards that wastes valuable time.

"There are proper channels of communication between the community and the police where information about illegal activities can be reported," he said.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


South Africa;
Cape Town's Roads of Death


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss and Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town's highway to hell - that is the grim reputation of Vanguard Drive, on which more people die than on any other road in the city.

Part of the road, from the Viking Way intersection in Epping to Mitchell's Plain, is highlighted in the latest traffic accident statistics as the scene of the highest number of fatalities in Cape Town.

There have been at least 18 accidents there in the past year in which people died. 

Several crossings along Vanguard Drive are among the 10 worst intersections in the city for collisions. These include Viking Way (73 accidents), Jakkalsvlei Road (48), Klipfontein Road (55) and Highlands Drive (37).

Residents near accident hotspots along Vanguard Drive are demanding an end to the carnage. Some point fingers at minibus taxi drivers, whom they accuse of speeding, jumping robots and reckless driving.

Others blame traffic authorities for failing to maintain a visible presence.

Danny and Ruth Adonis of Vanguard Estate are so incensed by speeding on roads in their area that they are considering a petition to have speed bumps built.

"Accidents occur at regular intervals. This piece of road is like a race track; speed bumps will help a lot," said Mr Adonis.

Shamiela Hartzenberg, who lives on the corner of Vanguard Drive and Jakkalsvlei Road in Bonteheuwel, said there was an accident at the intersection virtually "every second day".

"It is very dangerous on these roads. Traffic cops should control the area and ticket offenders immediately. I have seen many pedestrians being knocked down on these roads," said Mrs Hartzenberg.

Her sentiments were echoed by her neighbour, 18-year-old Lizette Organsie, who said traffic officers should be more visible in the area. "There are a lot of accidents around here because a lot of people just go through the red robots as they please and disobey the rules of the road."

Jean Rossouw of Vanguard Estate said roads in the area were so dangerous she hardly crossed them any more.

"I think taxis are the main cause of accidents on these roads," said Mrs Rossouw.

Details of the worst accident spots were released to the Cape Argus at its request, in a move which signals a new approach to traffic management in the city. New traffic manager Mark Sangster has vowed to target the worst accident spots as a priority.

Ironically, some of the other accident hotspots are virtually on the doorstep of the traffic department headquarters at Gallows Hill in Green Point.

Main Road in Sea Point and Green Point and the notorious double intersections in Buitengracht Street are among the worst roads for accidents.

The stretch of road experiencing the most collisions in one year is Main Road in Green Point and Sea Point - with 387, two of them fatal.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


207 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Sudan;
Sudanese Rights Group Protests Torture Cases


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Geneva - The International Secretariat of OMCT requests your URGENT intervention in the following situations in Sudan.

Case SDN 090497 -- Brief description of the situation:

The Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, a member of the network, has expressed its grave concern over the arrests of 13 officers who are being held incommunicado in a detention centre in Juba since October 1995. The government is intending to court martial these officers in front of a military court in Juba. All the officers are accused by the government of dereliction of duty following an SPLA attack on Mugwa and Farjuk in October 1995. 

The officers arrested are: 1 Brig. Ali Esawi 2 Col. Ibrahim Abdel Aziz 3 Col. Balla Abdel Fatah 4 Lt Col. Mohmed Hassan Khalifa 5 Lt Col. Mohmed Abdulla Fadul 6 Lt Col. Saif El Din Awad 7 Lt Col. Ibrahim Adam 8 Lt Col. Bashir Mohmed Said 9 Lt Col. Murgani Mohmed El Sayed 10 Lt Col. Ali Suleiman Huori 11 Maj. Murgani Abdel Noor 12 Maj. Omar Ali Osman 13 Maj. Salah Abdel Rahman

The International Secretariat is gravely concerned for the physical and psychological integrity of the 13 officers detained. According to the information received, they have all been subjected to ill-treatment.

Action requested : Please contact the Sudanese authorities urging them to:

i. take immediate measures to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of the 13 officers arrested and all other people detained;

ii. immediately release the 13 officers if they are being detained without valid charge or, if such charges exist, bring them before a competent and impartial tribunal and guarantee his procedural rights at all times;

iii. guarantee in all circumstances respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in accordance with national laws and international standards.

Case SDN 100497 -- Brief description of the situation:

The Sudanese Victims of Torture Group (SVTG), a member of the network, has expressed its grave concern over the arrests by Sudanese government of three lawyers; Adam Mohamed Sharief, Ahmed Abd El Hafiez and Hussein Salih in Nyala town. They are reported to have been arrested in March 1997.Their current whereabouts are unknown.

According to the information, it is feared that the three lawyers may be subjected to torture.

OMCT expresses its grave concern for the physical and psychological integrity of Adam Mohamed Sharief, Ahmed Abd El Hafiez and Hussein Salih.

Action requested: Please contact the Sudanese authorities urging them to:

i. take appropriate measures to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of Adam Mohamed Sharief, Ahmed Abd El Hafiez and Hussien Salih and all other people detained;

ii. immediately release Adam Mohamed Sharief, Ahmed Abd El Hafiez and Hussein Salih if they are being detained without charges or if such charges exist, bring them before a competent and impartial civilian tribunal and guarantee their procedural rights all times;

iii. ensure in all circumstances respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in accordance with national laws and international standards;

Addresses:

His Excellency Lieutenant General Omar Hassan al-Bashir, President of the Republic of Sudan, People's Palace, PO Box 281, Khartoum, Sudan.Telex : 22385 PEPLC SD or 22411 KAID SD - Fax: +249 11 71 724

Brigadier Bakri Hassan Salih, Minister of Interior, People's Palace, PO Box 281, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22842 WZARA SD or 22604 IPOL SD - Fax : +249 11 71724 / 76554 / 77900 / 73046 / 70186

Mr. Abdel Basset Sabdrat, Minister of Justice and Attorney-General, Ministry of Justice, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22459 KHRJA SD or 22461 KHRJA SD (via Ministry of Foreign Affairs) - Fax : +249 11 74 063

Mr. Ali Osman Mohamad Taha, Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, PO Box 873, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22459 KHRJA SD or 22461 KHRJA SD - Fax : +249 11 74 063

Chief Justice, Khartoum Sudan. Telegram : Honorable Chief Justice, Khartoum, Sudan

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nigeria Launches Central Securities Clearing System;
by Goddy Ikeh, PANA Correspondent


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1759 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian Stock Exchange launched a Central Securities Clearing System on Tuesday, which traders say could mark a turning point in the efforts by the exchange to revolutionize its activities.

Inaugurating the scheme, Lt. Gen. Oladipo Diya, the number two in Nigeria's military administration said it was a major step in the process of "jump- starting our economy in order to mark it a concrete and credible player in the international market place."

He said the Nigerian Stock Exchange had, over the years, been highly rated in spite of its limitations.

The exchange, he added, was now capable of processing increased volume and turnover of securities with "greater efficiency, transparency and at reduced cost to investors." 

The president of the exchange, Paschal Dozie, said the new clearing system would serve as a central depositary for all the share certificates of quoted securities.

It would also provide a sub-registry for all quoted securities in conjunction with the registrars of quoted companies, issuance of central securities identification numbers to stock holders and the clearing, settlement and custodial services for local and foreign instruments.

"The dynamics of the Nigerian capital market," Dozie said, "will from today undergo beneficial radical transformation which will unfold with time."

Dozie said the system "will continuously be enhanced and upgraded as the volume of transactions increase and new and varied instruments are introduced into the capital market as the market develops and become more sophisticate."

The scheme, which started in 1989, is expected to enhance the delivery system of the Nigerian capital market, through the introduction of efficient and effective securities clearing settlement and custodian mechanisms with minimum risk.

Before now the transfer of shares and production of new certificates for traded securities between the stockbrokers and the registrar took a few months to conclude, while processing of transactions on the floors of the exchange were carried out manually.

This created delays affecting the operational efficiency of the capital market.

While it took up to seven working days for brokers to pay for transactions previously, the new clearing system requires the selected banks to reconcile the accounts of the brokers as soon as they received instructions from the central clearing system after the day's trading.

Officials of the Nigerian Stock Exchange say the system is to function as a subsidiary of the exchange.

Stockbrokers are required to have enough funds in their accounts with any of the four selected banks before they can engage in trading on the floor of the exchange on any particular day.

Observers say the modernization is expected to boost exchange's growth and enhance its performance.

According to official records, the exchange's market turnover increased significantly in 1996 with a total of 882 million shares valued at 7.058 billion naira. This was in contrast to 397 million shares worth 1.838 billion naira achieved in 1995 (85 naira = 1 U.S. dollars).

Market capitalization of the exchange was put at 285.6 billion naira in 1996 as against 171.1 billion naira recorded at the end of 1995, while the All-Shares Index also rose by 37.3 percent from 5092.15 to 6992.10 in 1996.

The issues market recorded impressive performance with the approval of 36 new issues worth 21.45 billion naira in contrast to 31 worth 7.084 billion naira in 1995.

Following the aggressive campaign by the exchange to attract foreign investors, a total of 32.98 million dollars was invested in the Nigerian capital market by foreigners in 1996 as against 1.137 million dollars in 1995.

Dozie believes that with the introduction of the new clearing system, the turnover of the exchange could hit some 10 billion naira in 1997.

"If we succeed in our plan in reactivating trading in the gilts and industrial bonds, then this estimate will be exceeded," he added.

Under the strategic plan of the exchange, the call-over trading system of the exchange is to be moved to the automated trading system this year.

Efforts will also be made to expand the scope of the internet services of the exchange.

Large price gains have remained in vogue at the Nigerian stock market in 1997 as confident buyers continued to pour money into shares.

But some operators recently called on the exchange to check what they called "the violent equity price fluctuations and the persistent bullish tendencies" on the exchange. "The Nigerian capital market to a large extent is an artificial creation made possible by stockbrokers who control more than 98 percent of market information to the disadvantage of most investors," said Christopher Eze, the managing director of John Holt, a major quoted company.

He said the unsalutary economic environment made it imperative for the regulatory authorities to re-evaluate the indices of equity pricing.

Eze said that unless equity pricing procedures were modified to reflect the dynamic nature of company price earnings ratio, investors, especially unquoted companies, would remain skeptical about the market.

The director-general of the Securities and Exchange Commission, George Akamiokhor, has also warned that the recorded daily percentage increase of equities under the present economic climate might precipitate a market crash.

He called for the intervention of the exchange, especially in stock pricing.

Apart from this worrisome development, the introduction of the new central clearing system and the extension of the internet services of the exchange are expected to position the stock exchange adequately for the challenges of a growing domestic economy and internationalization.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

209 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Media Council Bill Faces Stiff Opposition


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga,, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Suspecting censorship, five Zambian journalists' bodies have opposed a proposal to pass a media council law and have urged all practitioners to reject what they termed an "obnoxious piece of legislation."

Opposing the proposed law are the Press Association of Zambia, Zambia Independent Media Association, Zambia Union of Journalists Zambia Media Women's Association and the Zambian chapter of the Commonwealth Press Union.

In a joint statement issued in Lusaka, the five organizations urged their members to support actions aimed at stopping the introduction of the law. 

The Media Council Bill seeks to regulate the media, introduce the compulsory registration of journalists, set qualifications for journalists and institute a disciplinary body for media practitioners.

The council, according to the bill, published in Monday's issue of the state-owned daily newspaper, the Times of Zambia, will have the power to reprimand, suspend or withdraw accreditation to offending journalists.

Any journalist who ceases to be accredited for whatever reason will be committing an offence which can attract up to three months imprisonment or a fine if he or she continued to practice in the country.

To practice, journalists must have attained the age of 18, hold of a bachelor of arts degree in mass communication obtained from a university or learning institution recognized by the council.

The applicant will also be required to have completed at least two years training in journalism.

The council shall be composed of a journalist employed by the government- owned print media, a representative of the Press Association, the Union of Journalists, a nominee from the private print media, the Media Women Association and a representative from media institutions involved in the training of journalists and the broadcasting industry.

In their statement, the five bodies said the licensing of journalists and such things and imprisonment and fines constituted an infringement of the journalists' freedom of expression.

The journalists said they were opposed to the use of legislation to control the media, whether or not such legislation was driven by the media themselves.

The media bill was announced by President Frederick Chiluba when he opened his second term's parliament in January.

The proposed law has also been opposed by the London-based Commonwealth Press Union and the International Press Institute.

The director of the Commonwealth Press Union, Robin Mackichen, said Tuesday that the protest should be coordinated, on behalf of relevant press freedom organizations, by the World Press Freedom Committee.

The International Press Institute's press freedom advisor, Michael Kudlak, added that the bill contravened Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

The declaration states that everyone has the right to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

210 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Southern Africa;
Namibia Decides To Remain In Comesa


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga,, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Namibia has reversed its earlier intention to withdraw from the 20-nation Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa), it confirmed Tuesday.

The country's trade and industry deputy minister, Wilfried Emvula, said that the problems that were affecting the organization at the time Windhoek wanted to withdraw had now been resolved.

He singled out the vague relationship between Comesa and the 12-nation Southern African Development Community (Sadc), to which Namibia is also a member, as the main reason that had prompted Windhoek to consider reviewing its membership with Comesa.

"After studying a report which was done on how Sadc and Comesa intended to work to avoid duplication of their work, we are now at peace and clear as to how the two groups will cooperate," Emvula told PANA. 

Botswana and South Africa are the only other Southern African states which have never joined Comesa. Ten Sadc members also belong to Comesa, created in 1992 as a market for the east, central and southern Africa, with 300 million inhabitants.

Emvula, who is heading Namibia's delegation at the on-going Comesa Council of Ministers meeting in Lusaka, claimed that Comesa's future was at stake because a majority of its members belong to Sadc.

He said that dual membership to the two regional bodies raised the problems of loyalty, given that there was no clear direction as to which way the two organizations could avoid duplication of their programs.

Donors and some member-states in the organizations have been urging a merger of the two bodies, to avoid duplicating development efforts.

Lesotho and Mozambique announced in December 1996 that they would pull out of Comesa after a year's notice.

Lesotho confirmed Tuesday that it had decided to withdraw from Comesa because of the issue of duplication and overlapping of programs.

Lesotho's principal secretary for trade and industry, Lefa Mokotjo, told PANA that the uncoordinated manner of the program by the two organizations had made it difficult for Maseru to implement Comesa and Sadc programs.

He said that as a small country, Lesotho also felt that it was stretched in manpower resources to manage the ongoing economic changes of the region, at the international level.

"There are rapid changes that have been brought by the World Trade Organization which we have to oblige to. Given that our manpower requirements are quite stretched, we felt better to have a bit of focus on what we can manage," he said.

Lesotho, he said, had opted to remain in Sadc because of its major commitment to coordinating the water development and environment sectors in the region to which the country has been assigned.

He said that it was difficult for Lesotho to absorb Comesa's sector responsibility it had been assigned and also manage its other responsibility from the Southern African Customs Union.

"Our withdrawal from Comesa does not in any way relate to how Comesa is conducting itself. It is no way a reflection of any bad faith in Comesa. It is just a practical move," Mokotjo said.

Mokotjo is leading his country's delegation to the council of ministers meeting preparing for Thursday's heads of state summit in the Zambian capital.

Issues to be discussed at the summit include the envisaged withdrawal of Lesotho and Mozambique from Comesa.

Meanwhile, Mozambique's foreign minister, Leonardo Simao, said the country will not take part in Thursday's summit.

The minister said the Mozambican government's decision aims at dedicating more attention to Sadc, of which it was elected deputy-president in 1996.

"We have already suspended our participation in the works of Comesa," he told the country's news agency, AIM, Monday. "Our withdrawal from the organization has been officially informed to the Comesa secretariat."


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

211 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Business and Finance;
Africa Seeks More Benefits From Oil


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - African countries and institutions are not benefiting from the foreign-dominated oil trade industry despite the opportunities which could propel the continent into making significant earnings and savings from this energy sector.

Instead, some extra-continental countries were using the continent's resources to make a profit out of Africa, a coordinator of the forthcoming African oil trade conference, Clive Mutiso, said Tuesday. 

He told the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency, Ziana, that market deregulation in most of Africa presented opportunities for institutions to explore the non-traditional aspects of the industry, such as finance and insurance.

The conference opens Monday in Harare, the Zimbabwe capital. At least 200 delegates from across the world, representing decision makers and customers, are expected to attend.

The four-day conference is expected to provide details, for the first time, of the infrastructure and financial needs created by national energy strategies.

"We are trying to give Africa and its institutions a bigger share in the profits of the African oil trade," Mutiso said.

African countries, he said, should be able to attract local investors in the form of reinsurance companies and other indigenous concerns, departing from reliance on government, state-owned firms and multinationals.

"For instance, the financing and insurance of oil trade is big business and big profits because the standards of safety are very high," he said.

He cited the example of Zimbabwe where players in the oil trade were paying high insurance premiums. Because there had never been a claim in a long time now, the reinsurance companies abroad were making huge profits, Mutiso said.

Africa, he said, also needed to invest in infrastructure to exploit different kinds of fuel such as liquid petroleum gas.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


212 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 8, 1997


Liberia;
Nigerian Army Chief Visits Liberia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Nigerian chief of army staff, Maj. Gen. Ishaya Bamaiyi, arrived in Monrovia on Tuesday to inspect troops of the West African Peace Monitoring Force for Liberia, Ecomog.

Ecomog said Bamaiyi was received at Monrovia's Roberts International Airport by the regional force's commander, Maj. Gen. Victor Malu. 

Later Bamaiyi assured Malu, also a Nigerian, of Nigeria's continued support. Nigeria provides the bulk of the force's estimated 10,000 men from Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Mali and Sierra Leone. Other troops are expected from Benin, Burkina Faso and Cote d'Ivoire.

Ecomog has said it wants 15,000 men for the period leading up to Liberia's elections.

Bamaiyi said the Ecomog High Command had performed well in bringing peace to Liberia. He said that he was very impressed with the performance of all Ecomog officers and men, especially those of the Nigerian contingent.

Earlier, Malu affirmed that Ecomog was prepared to ensure a free and fair election in Liberia scheduled for May 30. He said the force was able and willing to deal with any threat to peace in Liberia.

May's election will last stage of the Abuja Peace Accord, which was signed by all of Liberia's warring factions, to end seven years of civil war that has caused an estimated 15,000 deaths.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 8, 1997


United States and Africa;
Ghana, United States In Joint Military Exercise


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

MICHEL CAMP, Ghana (PANA) - Ghanaian and United States soldiers began military exercises Monday at Michel Camp, near the coastal town of Tema, to improve their skills in advanced parachuting and infantry warfare.

Code-named "Joint Combined Exercise Training (JCET '97)," the month-long exercises are the fifth to be held in Ghana. Participating are nine officers and 93 men of the Ghana Armed Forces, and two officers and 10 men of the United States Special Forces, the Green Berets.

In an opening address on the exercises, Col. Francis Mahama, Commanding Officer of Ghana's First Infantry Brigade, said the soldiers will exchange ideas in land navigation, interdiction and operation raids.

Other aspects of the exercise are battle drills, ambushes, road blocks, platoon-size operations and marksmanship. Mahama said the joint exercises would put the soldiers in good shape for any eventualities.

He said the U.S. Army had been supporting the Ghana Armed Forces and that, hopefully, cordial relations would continue and be of mutual benefit.

The U.S. Army team leader, Capt. Harry Woodmansee, said the exercise was " once again a great opportunity for us to share experiences and skills with our Ghanaian counterparts."

Woodmansee, who in 1996 took part in a similar exercise in the in northern Ghana town of Tamale, said such build-up exercises were necessary to instil professional discipline in soldiers.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 8, 1997


Southern Africa;
Southern Africa Military Exercise Continues


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Commanders of the much hailed Southern African peace-keeping training exercise dubbed Operation Blue Hungwe, completed a gruelling 36-hour session Tuesday in United Nations peace-keeping doctrines, command procedures and strategies.

The session held at the Zimbabwe Staff College -- and code-named Exercise Blue Tsuro -- was designed to equip commanders with command and control procedures for multinational operations. 

"We are as good and ready for any peacekeeping mission," said Brig. Subusiso Moyo of the Zimbabwe National Army after the exercise, which went throughout Monday night till Tuesday afternoon.

Zimbabwe, which is hosting at least 1,500 personnel from the Southern African Development Community (Sadc), has vast experience in peace-keeping operations having served in the abortive U.N. Somali Mission.

It has a battalion currently on a U.N. peace-keeping mission in war-ravaged Angola.

Maj. Gen. Mike Nyambuya, who is the director of Operation Blue Hungwe, was one-time deputy forces commander of U.N. forces in Somalia. Moyo served as chief military personnel officer in the same mission.

Meanwhile, the peace-keeping exercise, jointly sponsored by the British Military Advisory Training Team and the Zimbabwe army at a cost of some 4.5 million zimdollars (409,090 U.S. dollars), is in three phases: exercises Blue Jesa, Tsuro, and Ijuba.

Operation Blue Jesa is already underway in the eastern district of Nyanga with at least 1,100 troops from the region.

Troops participating in the exercise, which will end April 20, are from Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania and Zimbabwe.

The joint exercise, Africa's first, will also see the training of troops in drills and mock peace-keeping operations.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


215 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Kenya;
Kenyan outrage against Somaia grows


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

NAIROBI - Controversial Kenyan tycoon and Dolphin Group president, Ketan Somaia, failed to appear before that country's Public Accounts Committee (PAC) hearing on tender fraud for the forth time on Monday.

Somaia was requested to appear to explain his part in a R34-million tender fraud eight years ago, when a British company which he represented in Kenya failed to deliver police equipment after being paid in full by the government.

The legal fraternity in Kenya demanded that Somaia be extradited from his base in Dubai following his earlier three refusals to testify and his alleged use of President Daniel arap Moi's name in vain. 

Somaia sparked widespread public debate in South Africa four months ago after he attempted to secure an exclusive monopoly on vast chunks of Mpumalanga's State owned game reserves and other tourism attractions for 50- years.

Following revelations about the proposed deal's possible consequences in the Mail & Guardian, the central government forced Mpumalanga's Parks Board (MPB) to re-negotiate its secret deal with Dolphin.

A revised contract greatly diluted Dolphin's rights, halved the contract period to 25-years and limited Dolphin's activities to just three of the six initial areas targeted by the multi-billion dollar company.

Parliamentary officials in Kenya said on Wednesday that Somaia's failure to appear at the hearing had again delayed the PAC's investigation into the alleged fraud.

Although Somaia reportedly faxed an apology to the committee just before it convened, the PAC has decided to take steps against Somaia.

It will meet on Friday to decide what these steps will be.

Somaia is also facing possible legal action by President Moi's office after he publicly accused both Somaia and MPB chief executive officer, Alan Gray, of "provoking" the presidency by claiming that Moi had written a letter exonerating the tycoon from all dubious business dealings in Kenya.

Gray claimed during a TV interview that he had received such a letter from Moi. He used it to argue against reports about Somaia's questionable past.

Gray has consistently refused, however, to produce the letter - at first insisting that he needed Moi's permission but later saying that he needed legal council from Somaia's attorneys before doing anything.

Kenya's High Commissioner to South Africa, Justice Mudavadi, claims to have been rebuffed each time he attempted to contact Gray on the issue.

After also being rebuffed on a number of occasions, the M&G has forwarded a request for the letter to the Public Protector, Selby Baqwa's office.

Adding to Somaia's woes in Kenya is the demand by a group of Kenya's leading attorneys last week, calling for Somaia to be extradited from Dubai where he now lives, to stand trial on fraud charges.

Meanwhile, both Mpumalanga environmental affairs MEC, David Mkhwanazi and MPB chairman, Dr Patrick Maduna also repeatedly refused this week to answer written questions about the financial value of Gray's business deals with the government.

M&G previously revealed that Gray owns a helicopter charter company and medical rescue company which are both patronised by the MPB without being submitted to tender procedures.

M&G has also referred these questions to the Public Protector, who confirmed this week that his office would be looking into the matter.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
