216 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Catholic Bishops Speak Out on Zaire


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Washington - A Statement by Archbishop Theodore McCarrick, chairman, Committee on International Policy, United States Catholic Conference, April 8, 1997

The turmoil raging in eastern Zaire is having a destabilizing effect on the entire region of Central Africa. We call on our United States government leadership to employ all diplomatic means that will bring about a cease-fire and promote a complete democratization process in order to prevent further loss of life, to bring about regional stability, and to introduce lawful, elected government to Zaire.

In a recent letter to United Nations (UN) Secretary General Kofi Annan, Pope John Paul II said that cooperation between the UN and the Organization of African Unity (O.A.U.) is necessary if representative parties are to bring about conditions for an equitable solution to the interlocking problems which affect the peoples in the Great Lakes region. The recent steps that have been taken by the international community to put together a framework for peace, particularly the recent cease-fire proposal, have been helpful. We believe, however, that bilateral and multilateral negotiation efforts could be more effective if they were coordinated under the auspices of the Special Representative for the UN and the O.A.U., Mohammed Sahnoun, to include regional leadership. Such an arrangement would centralize the efforts of the international community and enhance the movement toward a peaceful settlement. 

Furthermore, more attention should be devoted to supporting the legal institutions based on the transitional Constitution and the political common agreements and commitments. This will ensure the timely implementation of the five objectives enumerated in the UN Security Council Resolution 1097: cease- fire, withdrawal of foreign troops, recognition of Zaire s territorial integrity and that of the other adjoining countries, promotion of the electoral process, and an international conference on peace, security and development in the region.

Finally, we believe that the international community should not remain indifferent to the thousands of suffering individuals, many of whom are severely malnourished, traumatized and stricken with diseases. We urge all governments with regional influence to insist that all groups, including the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Zaire (ADFL), allow safe passage to the Zairian displaced persons and the Rwandan refugees in eastern Zaire, so that they may return to their homes in safety and dignity. That many thousands of deaths have resulted from the current refugee crisis underscores the need to provide regional and international relief and peace- keeping institutions with adequate resources to address such emergencies in the future.

We pray for all the people of the Great Lakes Region of Central Africa, most particularly the suffering in Zaire who are displaced and the Rwandan refugees. We also pray that all people of goodwill, on both sides of the conflict, find it within their hearts to create the conditions for a national dialogue and reconciliation.

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378; Washington, D.C. 20017; Tel: 202 832 3412. Fax: 202 832 9051; email: afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


217 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


South Africa;
Background to TRC Investigations Near Aliwal North


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - STATEMENT BY MR DUMISA NTSEBEZA, HEAD OF THE INVESTIGATION UNIT OF THE TRUTH AND RECONCILIATION COMMISSION

The Johannesburg office of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission received a statement in April last year from a Soweto pensioner who reported that the late Chris Hani had informed her in 1991 that her son had died in a shoot-out in the Eastern Cape in 1981.

In October last year, the Commission was approached by Mr Tokyo Sexwale, Premier of Gauteng, and given information on an investigation carried out by his staff into the fate of four MK cadres, including Mr Sexwale's brother and the person who had been mentioned in the statement received by the TRC in April. Subsequently, in November, Mr Sexwale's father and one other parent made statements to the Commission. As a consequence, we have statements from three of the families involved in the matter. 

TRC investigations have borne out the investigations carried out by Mr Sexwale's family and colleagues. They indicate that two of the cadres died on August 7, 1981, and another two on August 13.

The cadres had been based in the Butterworth/Umtata area but were discovered and attempted to retreat into Lesotho. However, they were stopped at a police roadblock near Elliot on August 7, where two cadres were killed. Two escaped but were intercepted six days later at Barkly Pass, outside Elliot, and also killed in a shoot-out.

Investigations carried out so far indicate that the four were secretly buried on a farm on the Free State side of the Orange River at night. An undertaker, a police reservist at the time, has admitted that he buried the bodies with the help of white Security Police members. The burials took place on the farm of another police reservist.

The Commission is at present looking for the bodies. It will not release the names of those cadres who have not yet been named unless bodies are found and positively identified, and until the next-of-kin have been informed. It will also release only limited information until it is certain that whatever it releases will not prejudice a ongoing investigation.

The Commission will give adequate notice of a full news conference once this stage of its investigations has been completed.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


218 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Dolphin deal runs into opposition yet again


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga's provincial government has ignored requests by national ministers to consult with them before finalising its controversial multi-billion parks deal with the Dubai-based Dolphin Group. The initial 50- year secret deal had to be re-negotiated after the Mail & Guardian revealed that it granted a virtual monopoly of some of South Africa's key tourism attractions to Dolphin before any affected communities had been consulted.

The re-negotiated deal diluted Dolphin's commercial rights, halved the contract period to 25-years and limited Dolphin's activities to just three game reserves instead of the original six.

The historic town of Pilgrim's Rest and the Manyeleti Game Reserve were also expressly excluded from the new deal. 

Environmental Affairs deputy minister, Peter Mokaba, told M&G this week that he specifically asked the relevant provincial politicians and Mpumalanga Parks Board (MPB) officials to forward him their policy guidelines for the commercialisation scheme and to also discuss any re-negotiated deal with him before signing.

Similar requests were, Mokaba said, made by the national Portfolio Committee on Environmental Affairs.

"But, to date, we have heard nothing. We are still waiting for even a copy of the new deal, never mind policy guidelines or consultation.

"The non-consultative approach by the MEC and Board is really testing the limits of concurrent powers and governance," explained Mokaba.

"What worries us is that it appears that the MPB is rushing into this deal because it is afraid it cannot pay its staff salaries. That is not good or even responsible management."

Stressing that he was not rejecting the deal "out-of-hand" but was rather concerned that necessary processes hadn't been followed, Mokaba added that both the motivations for the deal and the way in which it had been concluded were "setting bad precedents for similar initiatives in the future".

"Why all this secrecy? Any government needs clear policies before committing public assets to radical schemes such as this - we haven't seen any such policy," he explained.

"If the financial situation was really that bad at provincial level, more money could have been found nationally. Civil service salaries should never be the motivation for management decisions in this field - the environment should be paramount.

"In fact, I am still not convinced that we need to go into this deal at all. "

Mokaba is not the only one still unhappy with the re-negotiated deal. Mpumalanga's most inclusive rural NGO, the Environmental Justice Networking Forum (EJNF), accused Environmental Affairs MEC, David Mkhwanazi of attempting to misrepresent its stand-point on the issue this week.

EJNF's provincial co-ordinator, Thabo Madihlaba, told M&G that Mkhwanazi had attempted to draft a joint press-release implying that EJNF had dropped its opposition to the deal after a meeting with him.

"I only found out about the press release by chance, when I phoned and a secretary read it to me. It was completely untrue. We did meet, but EJNF at no stage changed its stand-point. In fact, Mkhwanazi pledged that no developments would take place before all land claims on affected reserves had been dealt with," explained Madihlaba.

"Now, for some unexplained reason, he is backing out of his promise to put that pledge into writing."

Stressing that EJNF, which represents 380 community organisations, had had to "battle" for three months to secure the meeting with Mkhwanazi, Madihlaba added that the MEC was also refusing to return calls to discuss the " distorted" press release and the pledge.

"Our representatives and the four delegates from the Land Access Movement of SA travelled hundreds of kilometres to meet with him. We are rural people and this is not cheap. Instead of resolving the problems, his current attitude is undermining our attempts to settle the unease of our communities," he added.

Mkhwanazi was consistently unavailable for comment this week and failed to return the M&G's calls.

While the deal attracts new criticism in South Africa, Dolphin Group president, Ketan Somaia's problems back home in Kenya have also snow-balled.

President Daniel arap Moi accused both him and MPB chief executive, Alan Gray, of "provoking" the presidency by claiming that Moi had written a letter exonerating the tycoon from dubious business dealings in Kenya.

Gray claimed on national TV to have received the letter in January and used it to argue against reports about Somaia's questionable past. Gray has consistently refused, however, to produce the letter - at first insisting that he needed Moi's permission but later saying that he needed legal council from Somaia's attorneys before doing anything.

Kenya's High Commissioner to South Africa, Justice Mudavadi, claims to have been rebuffed each time he attempted to contact Gray on the issue.

Adding to Somaia's woes is the announcement by Kenya's Public Accounts Committee (PAC) that it has re-issued a summons for Somaia to appear before it on April 14, to explain his part in a R34-million tender fraud. Somaia has ignored three previous requests to testify.

Following Moi's denial and the PAC summons, a group of Kenya's leading attorneys last week called for the government to extradite Somaia for Dubai where he now lives, to stand trial on fraud charges.

Meanwhile, both Mkhwanazi and MPB chairman, Dr Patrick Maduna also repeatedly refused this week to answer written questions about the financial value of Gray's business deals with the government.

M&G previously revealed that Gray owns a helicopter charter company and medical rescue company which are both patronised by the MPB without being submitted to tender procedures.

M&G has referred the questions to the Public Protector, Selby Baqwa, with an appeal to assist in obtaining the answers. - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


219 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


South Africa;
Northern Province finally establishes house of traditional leaders


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Pietersburg - On Friday, Northern Province will be the last of South Africa's nine provinces to establish a House of Traditional Leaders after three years of inter-tribal power-wrangling.

The move comes just one week before the inauguration of the national Council of Traditional Leaders which will be addressed by President Nelson Mandela in Cape Town next Friday.

Spokesperson for the Northern Province Department of Local Government, Thomas Lekgothoane, said inter-tribal disputes between the majority Pedi group and the minority Venda and Tsonga groups, had prevented the House of Traditional Leaders from being established sooner, due to minority fears that the Pedi would dominate them. 

"Originally, there were to be six representatives from the six tribal areas, " Lekgothoane explained.

This would have meant that the Pedi would have had 24 represent- atives on the 36-member council, and the Tsonga and Venda a combined representation of 12 members.

"But we've solved the problem by deciding on 18 Pedi representatives, and 18 representatives for the Tsonga and Venda peoples," Lekgothoane said.

Another problem that needs to be resolved is that of ground-level conflict between members of the South African National Civics Organisation (Sanco) and the chiefs.

President of Sanco Northern Province, Moses "Saddam" Malemela, said Sanco supported the establishment of the House, but would initiate a meeting with the still-to-be-elected chairman to draw up a "bilateral" memorandum of understanding.

"The memorandum will minimise tension and prevent the derailing of the development process," he said.

He cited examples of "tension" where Sanco members in the Moletjie district are to appear in court on charges of intimidation after allegedly attempting to convince an induna to use community money for the Mvula water project.

"The induna took the money, but hasn't used it, so the project is on hold. We tried to meet with him, but he refused to talk with us and now some of our members have to go to court," Malemela explained.

He accused another chief of using tribal money to fund Zionist Christ- ian Church meetings, losing the tribe's vehicle and selling the tribe's cattle.

"The only peaceful route to resolve such crises is to develop a memorandum of understanding," he explained.

Malemela said Sanco also wanted copies of the House of Traditional Leaders Act to know how it was constituted, as well as to be informed on the findings of the Ralushai Commission which is investigating the authenticity of certain chiefs in the province.

"In the Lebowa bantustan, many chiefs were crowned, some were not really chiefs, but were crowned only to serve the interests of the past regime," he explained.

"In the new dispensation, the people shall govern and, according to traditional culture, the chiefs are only the announcers of the decisions of his subjects," he said. - African Eye News Service

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


220 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Unions threaten "war" if privatisation goes ahead


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Nelspruit - The Nelspruit town council denied on Wednesday that intends to privatise its water and waste department, insisting that it only wants to enter into a private-public sector partnership with a private company managing its services.

Responding to threats by the South African Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) to stage nationwide marches from May 1 to May 9 in protest against the council's "privatisation" plans, town council spokesperson, Etienne Garnett- Bennett said there had been a communication breakdown between the union's national and local offices.

"This (public-private sector partnerships) has never been done in South Africa before, which probably explains why the unions are reacting this way," he explained. 

He said extensive discussions and negotiations had taken place with Samwu's Nelspruit representatives, as well as members of the Independent Municipal Allied Trade Union (Imatu) since October last year.

He said the unions had also been asked to select representatives to sit on a committee which would advise the Nelspruit town council as to which bidding company should be awarded the service contract.

Garnett-Bennett refuted reports that the council would announce the winner of the tender on April 30, saying that it was the final date for companies to submit their bids for the contract.

Samwu spokesperson, Anna Weekes, said on Wednesday that Samwu regarded public/private partnerships as "an excuse for privatisation".

In a press release, she accused the Nelspruit town council of planning to award a 30-year contract to an as yet unnamed company.

She also challenged Garnett-Bennett's claim that Nelspruit was the first town council in the country to enter into a public-private partnership.

"The truth is that WWSA, a subsidiary of Lyonnaise Des Eaux (who is one of the two main private sector companies currently seeking to control the world's water) is already operating in Fort Beaufort, Stutterheim and Queenstown," she said.

Weekes warned that should a private company be granted a concession for Nelspruit's water and waste services, not only would employees lose their jobs, but water prices would increase and water quality would drop.

Garnett-Bennett said before any company was granted the service contract, it would first have to guarantee the council that it would not retrench personnel transferred during the transaction, and that employment benefits would be the same as offered by the council, or even better.

Weekes said Samwu demanded a complete moratorium on all major contracts and negotiations between local governments and the private sector, and that all information be made available to the union.

Samwu also demands that further discussions regarding the restructuring of the public sector be dealt with through the National Labour Relations Forum.

Eight companies are currently bidding for the Nelspruit contract, including a consortium led by Britain's Biwater, and Sanco Investment Holdings. - African Eye News Service

LANGUAGE: English

221 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Sports - General;
No science can guarantee a winning bid


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Cape Town - The weeks following Cape Town's celebrated ranking as a shortlisted candidate in the race for the Games have seemed anti-climactic, but deceptively so.

While there has been none of the fizzle that attended the build-up to the March 7 announcement, it is actually only the character of the frenzy that has changed.

The Bid Company's task at this juncture is, on the face of it, a simple one: it must persuade at least 54 members of the International Olympic Committee to vote for Cape Town on September 5.

Nothing else matters quite as much as this imperative, yet there are many ancillary factors which have a bearing on it. 

The dynamics of persuasion are complex, almost indefinable - especially in the sense that much of the opinion-forming that will occur in the minds of visiting IOC grandees will be based on perception.

Some perceptions can be anticipated, and countered.

Among them is the international view of South Africa, and Cape Town, as a crime-ridden society, a view, it must be said, reinforced by a number of recent headlines, not least the one accompanying the report on 52 murders and 81 rapes in the Western Cape over the Easter weekend, or, for that matter, this week's "Troops Into Wartorn Flats".

It is for this reason that bid-related crime initiatives are probably among the most important practical measures to be launched and sustained.

There are a number of initiatives, some of which are being launched this month.

Even if crime is not something that will be solved overnight, or before September, it will be vital not just for the bid, but future investment in the region, that these and other initiatives are seen to be efficacious. Doubting IOC members are more likely to be convinced if Cape Town demonstrates the will and the capacity to tackle crime meaningfully, even if it is in the long-term.

The other perception that tends to bedevil particularly European assessments of the South African Olympic project is the view that an African bid - seen, essentially as a Third World exercise - is bound to be inherently deficient.

This is by no means a grave perception, because it is relatively easy to dispel.

Virtually every visitor from the IOC fraternity so far has gone away favourably impressed with the technical accomplishment of the bid plan, and the depth of understanding that exists in the planning team of the tasks that lie ahead.

The city's shortlisting in the race for the Games counts, in fact, as recognition of its ability to stage the event, and there are no major doubts about this within the IOC.

Nevertheless, presentations to visitors will seek to provide assurances that the Peninsula's transport system will be adequately upgraded, that facilities will be "athlete-friendly" and accessible.

What about public support?

This has always been a hot topic, not least because the anti-bid groupings (who, mostly, represent political fringe interests) will simply not accept the results of independent opinion polls which consistently show support at around 80%.

That figure often seems at odds with the expression of opposition in letters columns and elsewhere, but in any debate, vociferous minorities are always noisier.

There is a view that sentiment has actually changed markedly in Cape Town: where, until a month ago, a lot of people were cool about the Olympics and didn't want the Games in the city, they now like the idea, but doubt our chances.

Building on that to create a sense of "excitement" about the bid is the task a multiparty group of MPs, headed by half-a-dozen Western Cape ANC politicians, has set itself.

This spontaneous initiative will clearly do the bid a lot of good in the next few months, but only if the MPs sustain some sort of profile, and make sure that the IOC is aware of their efforts. Visits so far have gone well, by all accounts.

The first visitor, Swedish IOC member Gunilla Lindberg, arrived in the city last month for a three-day assessment which, true to the form that is likely to characterise every IOC voter's visit, was low-key.

The fact that the Swedish capital is one of Cape Town's four rivals in this final leg of the race - the others are Athens, Rome and Buenos Aires - would suggest that Ms Lindberg's loyalty would lie with Stockholm.

The second visitor was Pirjo Haggman, the Finnish IOC member.

Despite Stockholm's being a rival, there are strong fraternal bonds with South Africa in Scandinavia - and indications that Scandinavian IOC members would not automatically vote for Sweden. So these visits are probably more significant than they may seem.

Bid staffers say that during these visits there has been less emphasis on technical information than on perception-forming. Visitors are treated to an extended helicopter tour of the Peninsula to give them what must amount to an impressive overview of the whole plan. This brings home the developmental nature of the bid plan far better than a formal presentation would. The city is hoping to host as many as 76 IOC members, as well as representatives from international sport federations, between now and August.

What has become clear is that the debate about whether Cape Town should or should not bid for the Games - the dominant theme of the past year - has been almost entirely overtaken by the project to win the prize.

In fact, to the extent that the over-arching strategic environmental assessment (SEA) has yet to be completed, the bid is, technically, still on the scales: if, on the basis of the results of the SEA, the public expresses sufficient concern about the environmental, economic or social impact of the Games in an opinion poll to which the specialist consultants running the assessment are committed, the city could find itself in an awkward position.

The poll is meant to indicate whether or not the public believes the bid should continue. Practically, though, it is more likely to serve as a planning instrument, an indicator of the kinds of problems that deserve closer or remedial attention.

One of the concerns raised during the consultative phase of the SEA - when the consultants sought public guidance on what questions the study should pose - was whether the disadvantaged sector of the economy would really benefit from the Olympic project, as it had been promised.

More often than not, detractors trot out the weary argument about the rich getting richer.

In fact, only last week, details were announced of an imaginatively recrafted tendering procedure - which will apply to the seven priority projects to be completed by September - specifically to favour small and emergent businesses and contractors from the previously disadvantaged sector. This gives practical effect to one of the bid's key undertakings, and should go some way to dispel concerns that only the well-off will benefit.

To the extent that the outcome in September is incalculable, there is no science to guarantee a winning bid.

It is not possible, then, to calculate where Cape Town is lying in the race so far - but there is a sound strategy in place to keep the bid in contention.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 9, 1997


South Africa;
Kahn halts crayfish bonanza


BYLINE: Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Cape Town - Hundreds of people eager to lay claim to tons of crayfish lying on the beach at Elands Bay were furious yesterday when they were prevented from doing so by an order from Cape Attorney-General Frank Kahn.

He said people removing crayfish without a permit would be prosecuted.

"If it is going to waste, why can't we enjoy it? It is not fair and it is not right to me. This is pathetic. It' s a lot of bull," said an angry Donald Smith, who travelled from Bothasig to try to get his share of the booty. 

Stellenbosch pensioners Charles and Barbara Dinham had to turn back disappointed, missing out on the crayfish after their long drive to Elands Bay.

"I think it's bloody ridiculous," said Mr Dinham. "If there are thousands of tons of reasonably good food for people, it should be made available to them and the authorities should turn a blind eye.

"We did not come for the crayfish, but to witness the phenomenon. "We were told that it has occurred only once in 30 years."

The chief Sea Fisheries marine conservation inspector at Saldanha Bay, Andries Visser, said about 200 tons of crayfish were taken by people at the weekend alone and 200 tons were taken to the Lamberts Bay Fishing Company to be processed into fish meal.

Another 50 tons were put into containers and put back into the sea. Mr Visser said that his department would, in conjunction with the police, do everything in its power to carry out the attorney-general's order.

Mr Kahn said he had been informed that crayfish were still leaving the sea yesterday and people seemed oblivious to the fact that only four crayfish a person a day could be taken.

"This situation will not be tolerated and the Sea Fisheries inspectorate has now been instructed to apply the law.

"People removing crayfish from the West Coast area without permits will be prosecuted irrespective of whether the crayfish is dead or alive," Mr Kahn said. A large contingent of police, army and Sea Fisheries personnel converged on the area yesterday to enforce the regulations.

One of the lucky ones to get in on the windfall before the ban was slapped on was 20-year-old Elands Bay labourer Nolita Masoyisi.

"God sent us luck, it's like manna from heaven," was her view of the 1 000 tons of crayfish that "walked out" of the sea, apparently because of a red tide.

Nolita, who works on a potato farm and lives in a dilapidated shack with her husband Amos, pocketed R500 in three days by selling crayfish to many people who converged on the town eager to cash in on the freak event.

Although Nolita is over the moon about her windfall, the entire West Coast fishing industry is expected to be affected negatively by the walk-out, which will have a serious impact on commercial quotas.

Fishermen have expressed the fear that after this huge exodus there will be nothing left for them to catch when the crayfish fishing season opens in November.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


South Africa;
Stop the carnage on Cape Town's roads (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Cape Town - More people are killed and injured in motor accidents in the eninsula than by any other violent means. The time is overdue for action to stop the slaughter.

The call from a concerned public for effective action to contain the growing and mindless slaughter on the Peninsula's roads must be heeded. 

In a little under two generations, the death toll has increased sixfold - from 58 in 1958 to 360 people who died last year in road accidents in Cape Town. In addition, many thousands were injured. Apart from the emotional trauma involved, the costs to the city are enormous.

The main reasons for the rapidly increasing accident rate are overcrowded roads, poorly trained and often unlicensed drivers, speeding, driving under the influence of alcohol, selfishness and a growing lack of respect for authority in any form.

This manifests itself in the way in which many motorists, most frequently the drivers of minibus taxis, flagrantly flaunt the most basic rules of the road by speeding, stopping at will, cutting in on traffic queues and shooting through red traffic lights with impunity.

Almost inevitably, when these infractions occur, there is not a traffic officer in sight. He or she usually arrives to re-direct the traffic after an accident.

Cape Town's new traffic chief, Mark Sangster, has said he intends targeting accident blackspots in the city in an effort to restore order on the roads.

He believes, too, in high visibility policing and that this must be accompanied by vigorous enforcement otherwise it has no effect.

Mr Sangster can take encouragement from international policing trends which indicate that firm action against minor offenders - like those who cross yellow lines - ultimately reduces serious offences.

He can also be assured that the Traffic Department will have the full support of the law-abiding public of Cape Town for its efforts.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


224 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


South Africa;
Upgrading of cableway going like clockwork


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Cape Town - "Stringing" of the upgraded Table Mountain cableway and fitting of the new cable cars is due to start towards the end of June, and this part of the R74-million upgrading programme should be complete by the end of July.

Cableway company managing-director John Harrison said this had presented them with a dilemma - should they start taking passengers up immediately the new cars were in place, or wait for the scheduled re-opening date of October 4, the anniversary of its first opening in 1929?

"The company has decided to keep to the original schedule and to use August and September to complete the programme at the upper cable station," he told journalists during a site visit to the lower cable station yesterday.

"This means that, by the time we re-open, all the paths will have been done, the restaurant will be finished and all the containers will have been removed. Remember that we've had 120 people living up there. We had a nightmare two weeks ago when we ran out of water at the top - and so the rain this week was very welcome." 

All the equipment for the new cableway has arrived in Cape Town and most of it - apart from the two new rotating cars, gearboxes and electrical items - is being stored on-site along Tafelberg Road.

Beat Musfeld, the project manager from the Swiss company Garaventa which is supplying the new cableway and supervising its installation, is in Cape Town this week to check progress.

He told journalists the stringing operation would take about six weeks.

A heavy-duty winch would be flown to the top of the mountain by helicopter. Then, a set of three "ropes" (steel cables), each progressively thicker and heavier than the last, would be hauled to the summit in turn until the fourth and final rope, with a diameter of 488mm and weighing 54 tons, was pulled up. The first rope - an old machine cable from the previous operation - is already in place. Otherwise, an ordinary cotton rope would have been used as the first "string", Mr Musfeld said.

The Swiss project manager is currently also responsible for installing cableways in Albuquerque in the US and St Moritz in Switzerland and his company is the biggest of its kind in the world, with projects in Europe, Canada, US, Korea and Japan.

He suggested the round design of the new cable cars, to cope with the problem of wind on Table Mountain, but said this project had presented no other problems.

"And in monetary terms for our company it's about R63-million, which is not a big project," he said.

Mr Harrison acknowledged there had been one "serious" spill from the top cable station when a sand-and-cement slurry had leaked from a catchment area and spilled over the front of the mountain, staining an area about 25m long by three metres wide on the rock face.

"We treated that as a serious spill," he said. "We waited until it had dried and then went in and cleaned it off, brushing it and then hosing it down. Our environmental control officer is entirely happy with the result."

Mr Harrison also announced that the issue of removing sewage from the upper station - one of the most controversial aspects of the upgrading - had been resolved in principle to the satisfaction of the Department of Water Affairs.

Construction at the lower cable station was difficult because of the city council's insistence that Tafelberg Road remain open to traffic. "It's not an ideal construction site," Mr Harrison said. "In fact, it's like being in a lion park and being the lion!"


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Cock-a-hoop Nando's primed for JSE listing


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - Nando's Chickenland could become the world's next MacDonalds, says chairman and co-founder Robbie Brozin.

Briefing analysts ahead of what promises to be a mouthwatering listing on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange later this month, Mr Brozin said the R1-a- share listing was not just for big-time investors but also for all Nando's employees, "right down to the grillers and floor sweepers" and the many " casual" employees, including waiters and waitresses.

The only minor catch was that they would have to have worked for Nando's for a "period of time" yet to be determined. 

"It is my dream that all employees can participate in this listing and, in so doing, participate in the dream of ownership promised in the new South Africa," Mr Brozin said.

He said the group had arranged financing through Standard Bank to help employees buy shares and was also about to embark on an awareness campaign among its 1 750 employees, educating them on their rights.

Nando's is making 10 million shares available to employees compared to the 15 million shares being made available to the public.

He said all employees would be able to subscribe for the same number of shares "from management to floor sweepers".

Turning to Nando's prospects for the future, Mr Brozin said he saw no reason why Nando's could not become the world's next MacDonalds.

Nando's already has 38 overseas outlets from Australia to Canada.

Mr Brozin believes this could quite easily grow to 400 stores "within the next few years".

Nando's is currently looking at expansion in the Pacific Rim countries where Mr Brozin believes there is a huge potential for Nando's brand of spicy chicken dishes and sauces.

Although there is a lot of emphasis on Nando's becoming a global brand, the management has not lost sight of its local roots.

Mr Brozin believed there was a market for at least 200 Nando's outlets compared to the 102 outlets it currently operates around South Africa.

"Nando's is not really about the chicken, but the Nando's experience.

"For us it's not a business, but rather a way of life," Mr Brozin said.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Trevor Jones: film composer finds the old scene has changed


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Cape Town - Trevor Jones sat this week on the stoep of his brother's University Estate home watching the sun rise over the Hottentots Hollands mountains.

It was almost 30 years since he had last done so.

The famous film-maker and composer of film music, whose scores for over 60 films include those for Mississippi Burning and In the Name of the Father, sailed for England on May 17, 1967.

He was 18 and had just enough money to pay his fees and take up a three- year scholarship at the Royal Academy of Music in London. Soon after his arrival he told journalists: "I don't think I will ever set foot in South Africa again." 

Jones, who lives in London but whose work frequently takes him to Europe and the United States, said: "I find it very easy to work in New York or Los Angeles or in Paris, because I'm not rooted anywhere ... I just enjoy the places I'm in when I'm there.

"But in a sense one cannot lose one's roots ... that mountain, that sea ... the space between ... doesn't change. And intrinsically the people don't change."

What has changed very much for Jones is the place where his home once stood.

"I wept when I saw Black River. I said 'Where's my home? Where's my house? Where are those orchards? Where are the people?' It's as if the life that I led here in that apartheid system has been totally eradicated - as if that world didn't exist ."

In the place where his family home once stood is a multi-lane concrete motorway, except for "three trees which were at the bottom of our garden".

Jones describes how as a five-year-old boy he was captivated by films which offered an escape from the harsh realities of apartheid.

"Film taught me about America and Hollywood ... and it was an escape from the poverty and the restricted environment of my home country."

Although he might not have been aware of it at the time, Jones says he was " a product of what apartheid did to my family, which was incredibly mixed.

"I had a grandmother from Irish stock with flaming red hair and piercing green eyes, and cousins with dark skins, so we as a family covered a spectrum of races and religions. And still, irrespective of those differences, we were very close.

"Throughout my life here the one thing my mother never begrudged me was the thruppence or sixpence I needed to go to the Gem or the Avalon or the Bijou or wherever to see films.

"And when I played truant from school, during a traumatic period from the age of about five to 12 after my parents were divorced, that was my way of escaping. At the cinema the lighting used for the projector would burn down - either because the projectionist was drunk or had fallen asleep. The image would go but you could still hear the soundtrack.

"On other occasions the sound system was so bad that it was crack, snap, pop and it would disappear and you would just see the visual image.

"When you are watching films day after day, which I think I did for at least six months, I felt it almost in a subliminal way ... learning about how soundtrack and image worked ... and I fell in love with film."

At the same time Trevor discovered that he had a talent for music. Today he conducts orchestras around the world in addition to writing music for film.

He recalls how, when he was 13, his English teacher at Harold Cressy in Roeland Street asked the class to write essays on what they imagined they would be doing in 20 years' time.

"I said I was off to conduct the London Symphony Orchestra. And on that day, 20 years later, I was at the Abbey Road studios conducting the London Symphony Orchestra with my mother actually there."

Remarkably, most members of that class went on to do what they had said they would in that essay.

Trevor attributes his and his classmates' success in part to the inspiring teachers they had at school and the solid education they received.

The fact that this was at a time when the apartheid system was at its strongest and most vicious also helped in a paradoxical way. "Everything was incredibly constrained and it focused one. We had a situation where people were arrested if they even talked about politics and that sort of climate created a feeling of conspiracy - it was an extraordinary climate to be brought up in."

Why hasn't Trevor yet made a film about South Africa?

"I think it would be very presumptuous of me when everybody is at this time working so hard at building a new society to come in after 30 years and say 'This is this country'.

"Somebody will probably beat me to it and will produce some hideous version!"


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


227 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


South Africa;
Third force' cabinet links investigated


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Cape Town - The Truth Commission is examining the record of a 1986 State Security Council meeting which appears to show that senior apartheid cabinet ministers, including F W de Klerk, helped form a counter-revolutionary "third force".

Commission chairman Desmond Tutu was commenting today on the revelations in State Security Council minutes leaked this week. 

Those at the meeting on May 12, 1986, included former state president De Klerk, who has consistently denied knowledge of such a force, his predecessor P W Botha, and former foreign affairs minister Pik Botha.

"This is nothing new," said Fanus Schoeman, spokesman for Mr De Klerk. He said Mr De Klerk had admitted the National Party government had considered the possibility of a third force, but after lengthy consideration had decided against it.

The minutes are part of a package of information given to the Truth Commission by Durban lawyer Howard Varney, convener of the Investigation Task Board, which oversaw a unit investigating "third force" killings in KwaZulu Natal.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


South Africa;
Fire chief fears inferno in city


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes and Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Cape Town - Hundreds of Cape Town's public buildings are potential fire hazards, as more than 80 percent of them do not comply with modern fire safety rules, the city's fire service has disclosed.

But the department was unable to force property owners to safeguard their buildings, said Neville Evans, senior divisional fire prevention officer.

This was because buildings erected before the 1987 national building laws came into effect were not obliged to comply with new fire safety regulations as long as they satisfied the National Buildings and Standards Act of 1962 or a 1972 Cape Town municipal by-law. 

"I've been horrified to see what some of our buildings in town look like inside. Heaven help us if one of them goes up in flames."

Mr Evans urged owners of commercial buildings to put the safety of occupants first and take urgent steps to safeguard their buildings. The onus was on the owner to ensure the safety of a building in the event of fire or any other incident, he said.

"Unfortunately the new regulations could not be made retrospective - thus they affect only those that went up after that date. The structural requirements in those days were not as tough as they are today."

The fire risk in large office blocks was highlighted by the fire that destroyed most of Munitoria, headquarters of the Pretoria municipality. Mr Evans said fires above the eighth storeys of highrise buildings could not be reached by fire-fighting equipment now available in South Africa.

Buildings more than eight storeys high were therefore a problem for the fire service - there were about 120 in Cape Town, mostly in the city centre and Foreshore.

Fires above eight storeys have to be fought with the help of helicopters. The city fire service can call several helicopters in an emergency, including those of the air force.

New buildings more than 10 storeys high must now be fitted with sprinklers on every floor. This does not apply to office blocks, which are a low risk as they are less likely to contain highly inflammable substances. The Metlife building on the Foreshore was a model fire-safety building, Mr Evans said. It had sprinklers and fire-detection equipment and the fire escapes were well designed.

He refused to name the buildings most at risk of fire.

The city's fire prevention officers conducted regular checks on buildings and recommended safety measures, but if a building did not violate safety regulations, owners were not obliged to act.

Recommendations included installing sprinklers and fire hydrants, which could be costly, as well as fire extinguishers and hose reels, which were fairly cheap.

"Invariably, when we call for sprinklers to be placed in any building in progress, the owners, architects and designers try to get out of it. They would rather cut down on safety and spend that money on the decor. But you can't talk of expense when it comes to lives," Mr Evans said.

"If the regulations say they must have sprinklers, that's the bottom line and we do not budge."

Cape Town's narrow streets caused an access problem for the fire brigade, made worse by illegally parked vehicles blocking entrances.

Fire prevention officers were available to educate occupants of buildings. But Mr Evans disclosed that Cape Town did not have enough such officers - the 16 on the staff were only half the number required.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Journalists Petition Government


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Five Zambian Journalists' bodies petitioned government Wednesday to withdraw a proposed media council, describing it as a "draconian law."

The five bodies said they have rejected the government's decision to impose a legislated media council. 

Those who have petitioned government are Press Association of Zambia, Zambia Independent Media Association, Zambia Union of Journalists, Zambia Media Women's Association and the Zambian chapter of the Commonwealth Press Union.

The media council bill launched Tuesday seeks to regulate media organizations. It has introduced compulsory registration of journalists, set qualifications for them and has also instituted a disciplinary body for media practitioners.

If instituted by law, the council will have the power to reprimand, suspend or withdraw accreditation to offending journalists.

To practice, journalists must have attained the age of 18, hold of a bachelor of arts degree in mass communication obtained from a university or learning institution recognized by the council. Journalists will also be required to have completed at least two years training in journalism.

Speaking after the signing of the petition, journalists reiterated their strong condemnation to the bill which they said would hinder freedom of the press and free flow of information.

The chairman of the Media Liaison Committee, Robby Makayi, said that by introducing the bill, government's agenda was to would make the journalism profession criminal.

"In the government definition of a journalist is a degree holder. If not, he has to be a trained person by not less than two years internship," Makayi said.

He said that journalists were committed to a self-regulatory body which was in line with practices in democracies like Sweden, the United Kingdom and the United States.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
African Workers Call For Faster Economic Integration


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Trade Union Unity (OATUU) says extra effort is needed by political leaders, civil societies and business groups to push economic integration of the continent faster, in the fight against poverty.

As the continent with 37 of the 48 least developed countries in the world, Africa's salvation lies in speedy economic integration, the organizations says in a declaration. 

Failure to integrate will lead to an "economic scramble" for Africa by those who have fully integrated their economies, OATUU's secretary-general, Hassan Sunmonu, said in the declaration. The document was presented Wednesday at the on-going O.A.U. Labor and Social Commission meeting in the Ethiopian capital.

"This type of economic scramble will lead to Africa's economic slavery, which we should all resist and avoid at all cost," he told the meeting.

On globalization, he said, "It is not a divine decree," but a " Frankenstein's monster" that should be fought against when it tries to promote unfair trade rules and investment regimes.

He also said as political instability was inimical to economic integration, African workers had stakes in the struggle for peace, stability, democracy and development in their respective countries.

Sunmonu cited the upheavals in Algeria, Somalia and the Greater Lakes region that had resulted to deaths, hunger and disease.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


231 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia's Premier Airport Gets BADEA Loan


BYLINE: Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Arab Bank for Economic Development of Africa, Badea, loaned Ethiopia 12 million U.S. dollars Wednesday to rehabilitate and enlarge Bole International Airport in Addis Ababa, the nation's premier gateway.

The loan, which will begin to attract a 3-percent interest five years from now, is repayable in 18 years. 

Expansion and modernization of the airport has become necessary with growing air traffic to Ethiopia. The facility is the base of the state-owned carrier, Ethiopian Airlines.

In 1995, Ethiopia received another loan of 110.5 million dollars from six international institutions for expansion of the airport. One of the five lenders was Badea.

At the time that loan was made, the Ethiopian minister of communications and transport, Abdulmeujid Hussein, said that some 130 million dollars was needed for the project. Ethiopia was to cover 20 million dollars of that sum. Wednesday's loan leaves a shortfall of 7.5 million dollars.

Work on the airport, which is due to finish in 1998, includes the construction of and renovation of runways, the passenger terminal, and the air control tower.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


232 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Southern Africa;
OAU Appeals To Comesa, SADC To Resolve Differences


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Africa's top civil servant, Salim Ahmed Salim, appealed Wednesday to two southern African economic bodies, Comesa and Sadc, to resolve their dispute over the duplication of their programs.

"It is important to find a way to ensure the harmonization of the operations which are being undertaken by both Comesa and Sadc for the interest of the two bodies," he said.

Salim, the secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity -- the continent's foremost political body -- was speaking on arrival at Lusaka International Airport. He is here to attend Thursday's summit of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, Comesa. 

There has been an on-going debate on the need for a merger of Comesa and Sadc, the 12-nation Southern African Development Community. Both economic blocs are expected to work toward the economic integration of their members.

All but two members of Sadc -- Botswana and South Africa -- also belong to the 20-nation Comesa. But Lesotho and Mozambique have given notice to leave Comesa in 1998.

However, Namibia's Trade and Industry Deputy Minister, Wilfried Emvula, said in Lusaka Tuesday that the country had reversed its earlier intention to withdraw from Comesa.

He said that the problems affecting the organization at the time Namibia wanted to withdraw had now been resolved.

He singled out the vague relationship between Comesa and Sadc as the main reason that had prompted Namibia to consider reviewing its membership with Comesa, created in 1992.

Thursday's summit is expected to provide direction so that any confusion in the respective roles of the two regional groupings can be resolved.

Salim said the O.A.U. attached great importance to Comesa, a region of 300 million people, as the pillar to the African economic integration.

Malawian President Bakili Muluzi also said Wednesday that Comesa and Sadc needed to cooperate in the implementation of their programs.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


233 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Sudan;
Sudan Militia Recaptures Rebel Area In South Kurdufan


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan's Popular Defence Forces, a militia of volunteers set up by government to help the regular army fight the Sudan People's Liberation Army, has recaptured an important mid-western location in the country.

In a report Wednesday, the government-run daily newspaper, Alsudan Alhadeeith, said that the militia had "managed to purge" the areas of Jabal Abyad, Almur, Jabal A'Awar and the areas of Shamrna, Saraf Addalenj and the Nakar hills of the rebels."

There has been no independent confirmation of this claim. 

The area lies at about 150 kilometres south-east of Delenj, the second largest town in Southern Kurdufan State, mid-western Sudan. It borders war- torn southern Sudan and is part of the eastern Nuba mountains, known in Arabic as Aljibal Alshargiaa.

Southern Kurdufan is largely inhabited by the Nuba people. Since the late 1980s the SPLA has been able to attract many Nubas to their cause and capture wide areas of the primarily agricultural district.

The newspaper said its reporters had accompanied the militia in their sweep of the area and had seen "more than 200 families, including women, children, elders and youths return to their areas," following the recapture.

It quoted Delenj Province Commissioner Abduljabbar Hussein, who has been in the Jabal Abyad area, as saying that "the sons of the area are determined, through this popular campaign, to free all the citizens held by the outlaws in the area."

He said that with the recapture of these areas, he said, some one million acres (404,700 hectares) of agricultural land in Habila and Kerttala will be ready for use.

The area produces sorghum and sesame and is second in agricultural importance to the vast mechanized farming area of Gedarif in eastern Sudan, thought to be the granary of the country.

Returnees described their confinement in the areas held by the SPLA as like being in "a big prison."

The chief of the Kawaleeb ethnic group, Hassan Abdallah Miskein, 58, told the newspaper that since 1987 the SPLA never allowed anyone to leave the area under its control.

"Many of our people have been liquidated for trying to escape the area," Miskein said.

The Kawaleep are a branch of the Nuba people.

The SPLA, Tijani Kalas, said: "used to force citizens to carry ammunition and weapons from their depots in Allir in southern Sudan to the area of Moun, in southern Jurdufan."

Kalas, who is chief of Jabal Abyad, added: "Citizens were forced to walk for a whole month with these heavy loads of big munitions boxes on their heads."

Officials in Taludi, in Southern Kurdufan State, say they have managed to open up the road to Malakal, capital of Upper Nile State, after its closure for 13 years.

Taludi Province Commissioner in Southern Kurduf, Elayyan Ali Mohammed, declared the opening in March of the road linking Kadugli, the state capital, to Taludi to the south.

These reports of government successes follow claims by the SPLA over the past two weeks that it had taken a string of locations close to the southern city of Juba. Now they claim to be approaching Juba from the west and east.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


234 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 9, 1997


Zaire;
Mobutu Under Pressure Appoints New Prime Minister


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zairean leader Mobutu Sese Seko has appointed Gen. Likulia Bolongo as prime minister in a government that is fast losing its grip on power.

Zairean state television announced this Tuesday as Mobutu moved to replace Prime Minister Ethienne Tshisekedi, who was reappointed to this post April 3 by the High Council of the Republic, the country's parliament.

This is Tshisekedi's sixth sacking as prime minister in his long-running battle for power with Mobutu. Tshisekedi had just succeeded Leon Kengo Wa Dondo who was fired March 18 by the transitional parliament. 

On assuming power again, Tshisekedi immediately dissolved the parliament which appointed him and appointed new ministers. But he excluded members of Mobutu's party from the new government, calling only on his party and the anti-government Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (Zaire). The alliance rejected the offer.

When Tshisekedi tried to assume duties Wednesday, under the escort of his supporters, his way to the prime minister's office was barred by government troops. Then, fighting broke out between his supporters and the troops.

Tshisekedi and his estimated 10,000 party supporters -- of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress -- were dispersed with tear gases. He was wounded slightly on his right arm by grenade fragments.

Meanwhile, the commander of the 11th military district of Kinshasa, one Gen. Elese, denied rumors of Tshisekedi's arrest by security forces.

These developments came just hours before reports that the forces of the anti-Mobutu alliance forces entered Lubumbashi on Wednesday.

The city, Zaire's second largest and wealthiest, is of strategic importance to central government. The province of Shaba, in which the city is located, is the centre of diamond, copper and cobalt.

Mobutu declared a state of emergency over two-thirds of the territory still under his control and appointed five military governors.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Tigray said committed to entrepreneurs


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

MAKALLE - Ato Gebru Asrat, President of Tigray Regional State, has reaffirmed his government's strong commitment to encourage and support entrepreneurs who invest in the region, as the two-day investment promotion conference successfully wound up there late Monday.

He reiterated that the regional government is determined to do its level best to clear any obstacles which investors may face now or in future. He reminded them none the less not to expect overnight solutions to deep-rooted problems.

"We are prepared to tackle problems that you may face, those related to legislation in particular but we don't expect a dramatic change in this regard within a very short period of time," Ato Gebru said, adding "together we will none the less eventually solve all problems." 

Ato Gebru assured the participants that some of the views made and complaints raised in the course of the conference will considered with the context of law making process.

Most of the complaints which the investors raised revolved around working procedures in the banks in general and those of the Development Bank of Ethiopia(DBE) and the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE) in particular. Several investors claimed that the latter's procedures lack transparency and that corruption and nepotism have almost become their distinctive features, not to mention the "quite revolting" bureaucratic red-tape.

Representatives of the banks tried to defend their positions. In their views some of the complaints appeared to emanate from simple lack of a clear understanding of the policies of the financial institutions in question.

In this regard, Ato Gebru said that the banks have the responsibility of elaborating on their policies to their customers so as to avoid such misunderstandings. He described some of the grievances as disregarding the banks' role as profit making enterprises.

The president stressed, however, that from the complaints reaching his office constantly, he learnt that corruption and red-tape remain pant in these institutions. According to him, complaints related to the banks were too many to have been taken up in the two-day gathering and needed a special forum.

A number of participants described the conferences as successful and said that it brought the rich and the policy makers closer together, enabling them freely discuss common interests. Many said that such a practice needs to be part of an ongoing tradition and be emulated by other regional states as well.

This reporter approached three participants for their views and all expressed utmost satisfaction with the outcome.

W/t Etenesh Abrha, importer and distributor of medicaments and medical equipment, said that the conference was both educational and informative. "In addition to closely witnessing the progress going on in the region, in Makalle in particular, we learnt that the region is a major reservoir of untapped investment opportunities. It was also an opportune moment for experience sharing between and among investors," he said.

According to this young entrepreneur, the holding of the conference motivated others to contemplate investing in the region in one sector or other.

W/t Etenesh is currently operating a 38-million birr disposable syringe factory project in Addis Ababa due to become operational next month.

The first of its kind in the country, the factory will generate employment for 82 people, it was learnt.

Another participant, Ato Haile-Selassie Kahisay, said that the conference was "simply impressive." although noting the prevalence of some red-tape in some bureaus, Ato Haile-Selassie is none the less confident that this will be corrected in due course. According to him the very preparation of the forum itself meant a lot to him and others. Ato Haile-Selassie had constructed a 1. 5 billion birr hotel in Hawzen which is now operational. he is also finalizing preparations for launching a 20-million birr hotel project here in Makalle. "In realization of the dire shortage of fuel here, I am on the way to invest on a filling station, too," he stated.

A building contractor by profession, engineer Asmelash Hadgu described his very participation in conference as a special privilege, "Everything was impressive," he stated.

What impressed engineer Asmelash most was the demarcation of an industrial zone. "With all the necessary infrastructure in place and connected, this is something of spoon-feeding to the investor."

Currently working in Addis Ababa and Beni Shangul - Gumuz, the engineer said that he was now inspired to expand his firm to Tigrai as well.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


236 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court continues hearing testimonies


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Former President of the Ethiopian Trade Union, Ato Markos Hagos who was imprisoned in 1976, had been murdered by soldiers of the defunct regime, inspite of this release from prison upon the request of the International Labour Organization (ILO), his wife testified to the court yesterday.

The prosecution witness told the First Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court that her husband was killed while taking refuge at her partner's house.

She told the court the deceased has been hunted by different individuals a year after he was released following an eight-month imprisonment at the Military Police and the Guard of Honour. 

She further said he was killed while trying to show up to the Derg soldiers after being requested to surrender at midnight the 25th of March 1977.

The witness said she heard the news of the death of her spouse through the radio which had announced: "We have killed the anti-revolutionary Markos Hagos."

She also testified that the soldiers who killed her husband, had hit her mother and imprisoned her 70 years old father.

Another witness who claimed to have been member of the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Party (EPRP) and had fled the city to take refuge in Menz along with the then EPRP leader Ato Berhane-Meskel Reda, said they were encircled by the army of the Derg and were requested to surrender through loudspeaker.

The witness told the court that he had heard Ato Berhane-Meskel saying, "We could surrender only if our case is treated at a court of law."

He, however said, the soldiers who failed to keep promises killed eight people including Berhane-Meskel and arrested the remaining ones for five years.

Three other witnesses told the court that six individuals who refused to take part in the then discussion forum were also accused of promoting alien religious beliefs among the society and imprisoned from 1983 to 1986. They said the prisoners were never seen since then.

So far 211 prosecution witnesses testified to the court.

The court will resume its hearing tomorrow.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


237 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


South Africa;
Newspaper Gave A False Impression About ANC Finances


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Johannesburg - Mr Newton Kanhema of the Sunday Independence newspaper gave a false impression about the ANC finances this week-end. His article was given prominence both by the Sunday Independent and the Sunday Argus. In the article Mr Newton wrongly alleges that the ANC is in the red by R41 million. This is simply not correct.

The basis of this article is a "leaked" information of what the ANC discussed at its Lekgotla of the 19th of January this year. Whilst the figures quoted were correct then, the situation has since improved and the overdraft was made good. Mr Newton gives the impression that it is a crises and a scandal to run a business on an overdraft. He knows that this is not abnormal even for individuals. As such, the intentions of this article are very dubious. Mr Kanhema should at least credit the ANC for not using government and public funds to boost its coffers. Other ruling Parties easily fall into this trap.

The article also claims that Mr Marcus is a sole director of Freedom Transport. This is different from Mr Newton's earlier allegation that Mr Marcus was the sole OWNER of the company, which we disputed. I am sure Mr Newton knows the difference between ownership and directorship.

He is simply trying to create a scandal. This kind of reporting is not helpful at all. It misinforms the public and seems to have a political agenda. It must be treated with the contempt it deserves.

Signed by: M.A. Stofile Treasurer General (ANC) 9 April 1997

South Africa;
Public Brawl Between Fivaz And Mufamadi


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Johannesburg - The public acrimonious brawl between the minister of Safety and Security and the National Commissioner of the South African Police is a great matter of concern not only to the portfolio committee but to the general public as well.

It is serious given that both the Minister and the Commissioner partly hold the key towards at the least creating a climate for people to go about their daily lives in a secure and safe environment. 

We had hoped that any misunderstanding and differences between the two will at least end in their boardrooms. We do not wish to point fingers as to who is wrong or right, but we feel that in the interest of our country and people such matters are better dealt with inhouse. Now that the matter is public we have decided to request the Commissioner and the Minister to appear before the portfolio committee and therefore parliament to explain what the problem is. Letters have been sent to both of them.

We should also point out that we share the Minister's concern about the frequent and continuous piece meal restructuring of the service by the commissioner. We thought and feel that any restructuring that is far reaching should be done once the personnel and resources utilisation plan is in place and after discussion not only in the department but with the Portfolio committee.

April 10, 1997


South Africa;
Third Force Allegations Against The National Party


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Johannesburg - Exposure of the National Party's knowledge of the creation and activities of the third force aimed at destroying the ANC and its allies is nothing knew to the organisation. This exposure has vindicated the ANC's long held conviction that the former National Party government aided and abetted in the creation of a third force

The ANC has always maintained that the creation of a third force and subsequent activities, which undermined even apartheid laws, was never the work of mavericks within government but was sanctioned at the highest levels of the apartheid state. 

At the heart of the state strategy as confirmed by the documents in possession of the STAR, lay a cold and calculated state sponsored conspiracy to murder, maiming, poisoning , distortions and disinformation against anti- apartheid activists.

In this regard, successive National Party leaders, including FW De Klerk presided over meetings of then State Security Council which had arrogated to itself the right to determine the fate of countless anti-apartheid activists at home and in foreign lands.

The ANC calls for members of the former National Party regime including FW De Klerk to come clean with a full disclosure in the interest of reconciliation on their knowledge or otherwise of the creation and subsequent activities of the third force.

In this context, FW De Klerk's successive submissions to the TRC fell short of the whole truth. De Klerk's continued denials of knowledge of third force activities has been directly contradicted by this exposure and other testimonies during the TRC process.

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P. O Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107 9 April 1997

Business and Finance;
Ethiopia signs prospect, exploration agreements


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Gold and other minerals prospecting and exploration agreements were signed on Tuesday between the Ministry of Mines and Energy and the joint venture of Geodev Plc and Afreds Mineral, Water and Energy Development Plc.

The agreements were signed by Ato Shemsudin Ahmed, Vice Minister of Mines and Energy and Ato Befekadu Balcha, General Manager of Afreds, and Dr. Abebaw Endeshaw, General Manager of Geodev Plc. 

A press release issued by the Ministry of Mines and Energy said the two companies were negotiating for the last few months on the terms and conditions of the agreements which cover the Akobo Valley prospecting and exploration areas.

The prospecting areas cover a total area of 388.89 square kilo meters in Southern Ethiopia and Gambella regional states, the release said.

The agreements give licences and exclusive right to explore for gold and associated minerals in Akobo Valley for the coming three years.

During the initial agreed period, the licenses will spend a minimum of over 1.1 million birr, the release added.

Africa News


April 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Police report rising cases of rape


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The first half of this Ethiopian year has seen an unprecedented increase in rape in various parts of the country including the capital, Addis Ababa, police announced.

"922 women and under aged children in various regional states and 68 others in Addis were raped over the last six months alone," police told ENA.

some 655 of the victims have reported to police while others did not due to social and cultural influences, police said, adding 370 of those who made compliant are children brutally deflowered. 

The majority of the victims are aged 16-18, some 19-30 and others are below the age of 15.

Police say 1,653 people have been charged with rape or being an accessory to the crime. Seventy-nine of them are convicted while charges levelled against the remaining are pending court decision.

The crime is committed in most cases individually, and sometimes in group, by those often aged between 19 and 30, police said.

In the last Ethiopian year 1,067 women and under-aged children throughout the country had been raped, police reports indicate.

In a related news, certain female students in the capital Addis Ababa disclosed that they are alarmed by the widespread acts of rape as teachers asked for stringent punishment against the culprits.

According to the opinion of female students, deflowering of under-aged girls and forced sexual intercourse result in study inconvenience and absence from school.

Lulit Girma, a ninth grade student at the Black Lion Senior Secondary School, told the Ethiopian News Agency that she was saved by her brothers and cousins when gangsters attempted to abduct her at knife point some three years back. Lulit said she was forced then to quit classes for a semester.

Haimanot Merid, an 11th grade student of the same school, said many victims of rape desist from divulging the case due to cultural and other social influences.

Maedot Tesfaye, an 11th grade student of Bole Secondary School, advised female students to wear and decorate decently.

Weizero Bezuayehu Admasu, headmistress of the Addis Amba Elementary and Junior Secondary School, said rapists have disvirgined a 7 year minor and a 14-year girls students of her school.

Ato Hassen Shukri, headmaster of Bole Senior Secondary School, and Ato Gebre-Kidan Desta, a teacher at the same school, told ENA that the present law must be revised and culprits must be stringently punished.

Ethiopia;
Commission trains journalists


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Forty-two police print and radio journalists as well as public relations officers drawn from all regional states received certificates Tuesday on completion of a two-month training organized by the federal police commission. 

The certificates were handed over to the trainees by Colonel Legesse Tegegn, the assistant federal police commissioner. News reporting, public relations, press law and other topics related to journalism were among the lessons the training focused on. The training was given by professionals invited from higher learning institutions and government offices as well as experts in the field, it was learnt.
