243 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia, Italy agree to strengthen cooperation


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

ROME - Ethiopia and Italy have signed agreements halting double taxation and promoting road and bridge construction activities in the two countries.

The agreements signed by Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin and His Italian counterpart Lamberto Danin have also provisions pertaining to investment guarantee.

Meanwhile, Italian Prime Minster Romano Prodi on Tuesday gave a dinner banquet to Prime Minister Meles Zenawi in honour of the latter.

The two prime ministers have also exchanged views on ways of further strengthening the long standing relations between Ethiopia and Italy. 

during discussions the prime ministers have agreed to work together particularly in the sphere of politics, economy, trade and investment.

They have also discussed the situation in the Horn of Africa, the strengthening of the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD) and ways through which Italy and other European countries could work in collaboration with IGAD.

Leaders of the two countries have similar and closer stand on issues they discussed including the need to further the working relations between the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and the European Union (EU).

The delegation led by Prime Minister Meles is expected to meet with Italian investors besides holding talks with government officials and members of parliament.

A statement issued in connection with the working visit said that the visit by the more than 70-member Ethiopian delegation to Italy would be of paramount importance in expanding investment activities between the two countries.

The statement expressed Ethiopia's readiness to further consolidate investment activities by taking advantage of the prevailing peace and stability, adding that Italy, an influential country in Europe, has interests to cooperate in their economic sphere besides its desire to see that other European countries be involved in similar undertakings.

Mayors of the western Ethiopian town of Jimma and Napoli of Italy are expected to sign an agreement aimed at enhancing the growth of the two towns.

In a related development, the governments of Ethiopia and Italy officially announced that they have agreed on the return of the Axum Obelisk.

In a statement they issued here on the return of the Axum Obelisk, the Italian government took the responsibility of returning the obelisk to Ethiopia until the end of this year.

The Ethiopian government on its part said it would give the Italian Government a present substituting the monument as a sign of friendship between the two countries.

The two sides have also agreed to take every precaution to ensure the safe return of the obelisk.

The announcement of the return of the Axum Obelisk, taken from Ethiopia in 1937 EC and installed in Rome, was made following talks between the two governments after the arrival of Prime Minister Meles in Rome.

The two sides have also reviewed the activities of the joint technical committee charged with facilitating the return of the obelisk.

The two countries have been satisfied with the activities of the committee, it was announced.

The committee which compromises elders, experts from the Ministry of Information and Culture, the Mayor of Axum, and headed by Dr. Tekeda Alemu, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs has established the joint committee in Rome last February.

Meanwhile, Prime Minister Meles Zenawi on Tuesday held talks with the chairman of the Italian Parliament.

Prime Minister Meles and Mr. Volante Luciano discussed Ethiopia's efforts for the prevalence of peace in the sub-region, economic relations between he two countries and joint parliamentary cooperations.

Upon arrival at Fumicino airport on Tuesday heading a high-level delegation that comprised senior government officials and members of the business community, Prime Minister Meles was welcomed by senior Italian government officials.

Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin is among members of the delegation led by Prime Minister Meles.

members of the business community who travelled with the prime minister include those engaged in the sale and production of hide and skin, leather products,, textile, meat products, marble, fruit and vegetables, oil seeds, spices, drinks, incense, tea and coffee.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 10, 1997


South Africa;
Statement on Exhumations at Aliwal North


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Cape Town - STATEMENT BY MR DUMISA NTSEBEZA, HEAD OF THE INVESTIGATION UNIT OF THE TRUTH AND RECONCILIATION COMMISSION

Digging at the Aliwal North farm where it is suspected the bodies of MK soldiers were secretly buried in 1981 was suspended this morning when bones, including what appear to be a human femur, spinal cord and ribs, were found.

A pathologist is being summoned from Bloemfontein and we shall wait for his arrival before we continue with the digging. Until now we have been using mechanical excavators but we have brought in men who will dig more slowly with shovels.

Today's discovery was made after we moved to a new location this morning. We identified the spot after consulting with the policeman who brought the bodies to the farm in 1981, with the undertaker involved and with labourers who knew the farm.

Sniffer dogs brought from Durban were used to help find the spot where the bones were found.

The cadres whose bodies we are looking for were killed in two separate shootouts with police near Elliot in August 1981. Investigations carried out by the staff of Mr Tokyo Sexwale, whose brother is suspected to be one of those buried on the farm, corroborated by our investigations, indicate that four cadres were secretly buried on the farm.

The Commission will not release the names of those cadres who have not yet been named unless bodies are found and positively identified, and until the next-of-kin have been informed.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

ANC Statement On Report Of Froneman Commission


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa

Johannesburg - The ANC Gauteng Province supports and endorsed the report of the Froneman Commission of inquiry into the violence and occurrences at Eldorado Park, Westbury, Reiger Park and Noordgesig on the 6th February 1997.

The ANC believes that SOWEJOCA, and in particular, Basil Douglas as leader should be held accountable for the unnecessary loss of life, injury to innocent people and senseless damage to property on that day. 

Flowing from the facts of the report, Basil Douglas is not fit to remain in Public Office and should be dismissed and if necessary, legal action should be taken against him and his organisation by the Attorney General's office.

The ANC Gauteng Province call on the police service to ensure greater efficiency, gathering of intelligence and planning when faced with such situations. In future police should be better prepared to handle all kinds of protests, including situations where violent outbreaks are predictable.

The failure to co-operate between Local Government, Business and Communities will lead to the collapse of our Local Authorities. We therefore call on Local Government, to increase the process of delivery, and business and communities to pay for services rendered.

The ANC believes that the policies of this government will address disparities and inequalities that exist within all our communities, in particular black communities (i.e. African, Coloured and Indian areas).

South Africa;
ANC Statement On Exhumation Of Bodies At Aliwal North


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Johannesburg - The exhumation of bodies of more ANC cadres including Tokyo Sexwale's brother in Aliwal North today, Thursday 10 April, is only a tip of the iceberg of the many secret graves of ANC and other anti-apartheid activists lying all over South Africa.

We salute and dip our banners in memory of these and other ANC cadres who perished in the noble and just cause for a democratic, non-racial and democratic society.

The moral and political responsibility for these cold-blooded murders and secret burials of ANC and anti-apartheid activists lies squarely on the shoulders of the National Party regime. 

No amount of denials by respective leaders of the NP including FW De Klerk can convince the public and the international community that apartheid was no crime against humanity in the face of these exhumations, exposures of aiding and abetting in the creation of a third force and other revelations of gross human rights violations.

It is disheartening to note that NP leader FW De Klerk instead of accepting political responsibility for these acts continues to play hide and seek with the truth.

We demand that leaders of the former National Party government implicated in hatching conspiratorial schemes against anti-apartheid activists in meetings of the State Security Council, break ranks with the past in the interest of reconciliation by providing the TRC with full disclosures of their knowledge of such heinous acts.

We call on members of the former security forces who were misused by the National Party government to bolster the repugnant system of apartheid, to come forward and lay bare the truth about:

* the disappearance of Stanza Bopape, Egy Mthebula and many anti-apartheid activitis.

* train and taxi violence

* inter-communal so-called black on black violence

South Africans anxiously await confessions on the disappearances of many of their compatriots. If the National Party is serious about nation building and reconciliation then they will afford families of these victims an opportunity to bury them in honour and dignity by coming clean on all these issues.

For more information call Ronnie Mamoepa at 082-990-4853

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O. Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107 10 April 1997.

South Africa;
The 4th Anniversary Of The Assassination Of Hani


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - Today marks the Fourth Anniversary of the assassination of Chris Hani, former Member of the ANC National Executive Committee, General Secretary of the South African Communist Party, Commander and Commissar of our erstwhile people's army, Umkhonto we Sizwe.

On this day, four years ago, the evil forces in South Africa and the world over snuffed out the life of Chris Hani with the hope to destroy the birth of a united, non-racial, non-sexist and democratic South Africa.

So far, only two members of these evil forces are behind bars. The ANC demands that the case of the assassination of Comrade Chris Hani be re-opened. The new evidence clearly indicates that the assassination of Chris Hani was not just the maverick work of Derby Lewis and Janus Walus. Their network went beyond the borders of South Africa. All those who were involved must be brought to book. 

The ANC will do everything to oppose the application for amnesty by these criminals. The new revelations linking directly the apartheid National Party leaders, including former State Presidents, P.W. Botha and F.W. de Klerk, in the formation of the former NP regime's Third Force vindicates what the ANC has always been saying.

The ANC demands from F.W. de Klerk that he tells the world what did he and his Third Force regime know about the plans to assassinate Chris Hani and all other Third Force activities, including the stoking of political violence in KwaZulu Natal.

In the meantime, the ANC demands that De Klerk resigns from all public positions and completely dismantles the NP regime's Third Force covert network.

As we mark the assassination of Chris Hani, we take solace in the fact that his death gave South Africa April 27, 1994 as the day for democratic elections which liberated South Africa from the yoke of apartheid colonialism. His death too shifted the balance of forces irreversibly in favour of the forces of peace, democracy, freedom and prosperity.

Chris Hani may rest in peace for the programmes he struggled and died for, The Freedom Charter and the Reconstruction and Development Programme, are being implemented vigorously.

Chris Hani Lives! Forward to 1999 - Unite in Action and Act in Unity!

Issued by the ANC KwaZulu Natal Leadership. For more information contact Dumisani Makhaye at 082 551 9192

Africa News


April 10, 1997


South Africa;
Second 'sex-slave' escapes from taxi drivers after 29-days


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

DELMAS - A second young woman has escaped from captivity in the Highveld region of Mpumalanga after allegedly being kidnapped and kept as a sex-slave by taxi drivers, police report.

The 20-year-old woman, who may not be named, reported to police on Wednesday that she was abducted and forced to have sex with her captors for 29 days before being released by a remorseful taxi driver.

Another 36-year-old woman, who claimed to have been held as a sex-slave by taxi drivers for six days, escaped from an isolated house near Witbank on Monday when her captors forgot to tie her up after spending the night gang raping her. 

Provincial police spokesperson, Captain Benjamin Bembe told African Eye News Service on Thursday that the 20-year-old had been abducted by just one taxi driver on March 10, when she attempted to catch a ride in a taxi on the Grobblersdal/ Benoni road.

"When the taxi suddenly left its normal route and the woman protested, the driver pulled out a pistol and ordered her to shut up or she'd be shot," explained Bembe.

"She was then driven to a different abandoned house in the bush and tied up with rope - just like in the previous case."

The driver then allegedly left the woman alone in the house but would return at odd occasions over the next 29-days and rape her. "Finally, the woman's pleas and assurances that she wouldn't tell anyone after he released her seemed to work and he apologised for keeping her captive," said Bembe.

The man then drove the woman to a road near Delmas and gave her R20 for taxi fare before speeding off in his red BMW. The woman was reportedly too shocked to take down the number plate.

In the previous case, the 36-year-old woman was also kept captive in an abandoned rural house, was tied up with rope and was raped every evening by a group of roughly five taxi drivers.

Police are also investigating a possibly related rape case near Witbank were a woman was dragged into a veld by a taxi driver after she attempted to catch a ride and was raped.

The woman was released immediately after the attack but had to be treated for injuries to her knees.

No arrests have been made yet, but police are investigating. - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

South Africa;
Mpumalanga Farmworkers to march


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Ermelo - Mpumalanga farmworkers will march in Ermelo on Saturday in protest against evictions and harassment by farmers, said ANC spokesperson, Vusi Sibiya on Thursday.

He said "long-suffering" farmworkers would march in support of the Security of Tenure Bill and hand over a memorandum to Mpumalanga MEC for Agriculture, January Masilela, at Wesselton stadium, who would pass the memorandum on to National Minister of Land Affairs, Derek Hanekom. 

"It is a shame and disgrace that whilst the face of South Africa is undergoing massive transformation and democratisation, pockets...called farms, remain untouched," he said.

"The farmowners still remain the masters of their workers, and they can evict and harass them as they wish," he added.

He said the ANC supported the farmworkers' call for the immediate passing of the Land Tenure Bill.

Farmworkers from Carolina, Breyten, Chrissiesmeer, Warbutton, New Scotland, Morgenzon, Davel, Bethal, Sheepmoor, Ermelo, De-Emigrate, Lothair and Damesfontein are expected to participate in the march. - African Eye News Service.

253 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


South Africa;
Sanco wants house of traditional leaders to sign memorandum


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Pietersburg - The South African National Civics Organisation (Sanco) in Northern Province supported the establishment of a provincial House of Traditional Leaders, but wanted a joint memorandum of understanding to be drawn up between it and the house, said Sanco president, Moses "Saddam" Malemela, on Thursday.

Northern Province is the last province in the country to establish a House of Traditional Leaders, which will be inaugurated in Thohoyandou on Friday, after two years of tribal-conflict.

The move comes just one week before the inauguration of the National Council of Traditional Leaders which will be addressed by President Nelson Mandela in Cape Town next Friday. 

Malemela believes the memorandum of understanding would "minimise tension and prevent the derailing of the development process".

He cited examples of "tension" where Sanco members in the Moletjie district are to appear in court on charges of intimidation after allegedly attempting to convince an induna to use community money for the Mvula water project.

"The induna took the money, but hasn't used it, so the project is on hold. We tried to meet with him, but he refused to talk with us and now some of our members have to go to court," Malemela explained.

He also accused another chief of using tribal money to fund Zionist Christian Church meetings, losing the tribe's vehicle and selling the tribe's cattle.

"The only peaceful route to resolve such crises is to develop a memorandum of understanding," he explained.

Malemela said Sanco also wanted copies of the House of Traditional Leaders Act to know how it was constituted, as well as to be informed on the findings of the Ralushai Commission which is investigating the authenticity of certain chiefs in the province.

"In the Lebowa bantustan, many chiefs were crowned, some were not really chiefs, but were crowned only to serve the interests of the past regime," he explained.

Spokesperson for the Northern Province Department of Local Government, Thomas Lekgothoane said inter-tribal disputes over the past two years between the majority Pedi group and the minority Venda and Tsonga groups had prevented the House of Traditional Leaders from being established sooner, due to minority fears that the Pedi would dominate them.

"Originally, there were to be six representatives from the six tribal areas, " Lekgothoane explained.

This would have meant that the Pedi would have had 24 represent- atives on the 36-member council, and the Tsonga and Venda a combined representation of 12 members.

"But we've solved the problem by deciding on 18 Pedi presentatives, and 18 representatives for the Tsonga and Venda peoples," gothoane said.

The Northern Province House of Traditional Leaders will be inaugurated at the Thohoyandou government buildings at 10am on Friday. - African Eye News Service.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


254 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumalanga traditional leaders want more land


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Nelspruit - Traditional leaders in Mpumalanga want the government to grant them additional land to prevent further urbanisation, said chairman of the province's House of Traditional Leaders, Chief Moses Khumalo, on Thursday.

Addressing the opening of the House of Traditional Leaders, Chief Khumalo said tribal subjects were not benefitting from government schemes such as the housing subsidy.

"We make a strong plea to government to make it possible for the current system of Permission To Occupy (PTOs) to be acceptable, to qualify people for the subsidy," he said. 

"If this is not urgenly addressed, we are concerned that there will be a continued influx of people to urban areas which will create another problem for government," he warned.

Chief Khumalo said traditional leaders were still debating the findings of the Steyn Commission last year which recommends traditional leaders receive reduced salaries.

"It is important to report that this debate has not been finalised yet," he said.

"It is hoped the...establishment of the National Council of Traditional Leaders...will help expedite this matter," he said.

He also called for the strengthening of the provincial powers of the Department of Constitutional Development, by either establishing a separate office in the province, or placing relevant personnel in the provincial department responsible for traditional affairs.

"This will assist in expediting matters affecting traditional leadership from provincial to national level, and vice versa," he explained.

Chief Khumalo also called for the clear separation of powers and functions of elected local authorities and traditional leaders.

"We are not against democratic governance as traditional leaders, but would like a mechanism to be jointly and co-operatively worked out between ourselves and government, as to how we should co-exist with the elected local government structures," he said.

In his presentation to the Mpumalanga House of Traditional Leaders, Mpumalanga Finance MEC, Jacques Modipane, said beliefs, values and cultures had to be adjusted to the realities of the modern world.

"We have ruefully clung to our culture, values and beliefs, stuck in an era that has long passed us by," he said.

He said traditional leaders should not to forget their traditions, but at the same time accept the realities of modern democracy.

"We must face it, the globalisation of economies is making the nation state obsolete," he said.

He added traditional leaders should ensure infrastructure set in place by the government was respected by communities, that they support the drive against crime and that they push for the development of their people.

On Thursday, the Mpumalanga House of Traditional Leaders elected three representatives to the National Council of Traditional Leaders which will be inaugurated in Cape Town next Friday.

The Mpumalanga representatives are, Chief Moses Khumalo, King Mayitjha II and King Makhosoke II. - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


255 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Business and Finance;
Brian Cumins: on the first-class route to a second- hand empire


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Cape Town - If your definition of a second-hand store is a run-down building in a dark alley administered by a scrawny-faced old man with gold- plated false teeth and lots of friends in the underworld, think again.

Australian Brian Cumins has made it his life's mission to change that perception and he seems to be succeeding.

Brian is chairman of Cash Converters International, which has 340 franchised second-hand stores in 17 countries.

One sure way of measuring the success of the stores is the fact that they generate a turnover of 2-billion Australian dollars a year (about R6-billion). Not bad for a collection of second-hand businesses. The company is also listed on both the London and Australian stock exchanges. 

"I set out to change the image of second-hand stores and it was very difficult indeed during those initial days. Our stores have to have flair, flavour, presentation and an ambience," said Brian, who was interviewed at the Mount Nelson Hotel, while visiting the Mother City to attend a Cash Converters international conference here.

The first store was opened in Western Australia in 1984 and he readily admits that the road to success has been filled with potholes.

"Setting up the first store cost about a million rands," he said.

Dressed in a dark, pin-striped suit, he dispels any myths that second-hand dealers are not worthy business people, always trying to get the better of you.

"I believe the concept we have developed is universally acceptable as it appeals to nearly all social groups.

"Eliminating this jumble sale mentality, the business of Cash Converters is simply the resale of second-hand goods - an alternative department store, specialising in a wide variety of items ranging from TVs and videos, cameras and sporting goods to computers and jewellery.

"The market for second-hand goods is growing rapidly. Previous consumer reluctance to purchase second-hand items is progressively giving way to the realisation of the value for money offered by second-hand goods."

What is intriguing about Brian Cumins is that he left school at the age of 14, does not possess the Australian equivalent of matric and was bankrupt at the age of 42, when a bakery he owned went under.

That would have been enough to get many other people to throw in the towel, but not Brian. He swallowed his pride, packed his belongings and shepherded his family to Perth, Western Australia.

He went back to the job he had before opening the bakery, and worked for a bed retailer.

As with many things that have happened to Brian in his lifetime, he got into the second-hand goods trade through a combination of good judgment and business instinct. The shop next to the bed retailer was a second-hand store and he began to study its operation.

One day he bumped into the owner and asked him if he could help out in the business. The result was the birth of the first Cash Converters outlet in 1984.

Cash Converters has never looked back and in 13 years has grown to the extent where it employs more than 3 000 people in worldwide operations.

Even Brian, a multi-millionaire, confesses that he buys some of his personal items from his own stores.

"The watch I'm wearing, I bought from one of my stores," he tells me proudly.

Cash Converters ventured into South Africa two years ago, opening a store in Cape Town. It currently owns eight stores in the country, seven of them situated in Cape Town.

Brian said he had invested in South Africa because he was confident of the country's economic prospects. He called on other international businesses that had adopted a wait and see attitude not to hesitate but to go right ahead and invest.

"Mandela has done an incredible job without bloodshed or economic demise to change the entire country," he said.

"It is quite evident that the feeling of economic development in the financial markets is one of excitement. Business people are confident about the new South Africa."

Conferences such as the Mount Nelson one are held every six months in countries where Cash Converters has franchises and this time it was Cape Town's turn to play host.

"We are looking at the strategic planning of our businesses as they change in the future. We are also planning to introduce a set of standards for the stores we have," he said.

Brian is divorced with two daughters. One of his daughters is involved in the family business, as a jewellery valuer for Cash Converters.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


256 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


South Africa;
Let them eat crayfish (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Cape Town - Hundreds of people eager to lay claim to tons of crayfish lying on the beach at Elands Bay have been stopped from doing so by the threat of prosecution

The ecological catastrophe playing out at Elands Bay has disastrous economic implications for poor West Coast communities who make their living catching crayfish.

Why then have the authorities lapsed into traditional South African big stick mode and stopped those communities - and for that matter any ordinary citizen who takes the trouble to drive the long distance to get there - from salvaging what they can before hundreds of tons of good, nourishing food simply rots on the beach?

Attorney-General Frank Kahn has decreed that the full weight of the law will descend on anyone removing the beached crayfish, pointing out that it is illegal to possess more than four at a time and that one needs a permit to do so. 

He is quoting anti-poaching legislation promulgated for the sole purpose of conserving a marine resource. But there is no way the bulk of crayfish ashore at Elands Bay can be regarded as a resource any longer.

By their own admission Sea Fisheries staff have managed to save only 50 tons and return them sea. Another 200 tons were picked up by the public at the weekend and 200 tons were taken to a processing factory to be turned into fish meal.

How can conservation legislation be invoked to protect something which is no longer in its natural habitat and is going to die in the sun or be turned into fertiliser or animal feed? And why waste person power turning these people into criminals when there are murderers, rapists and robbers to be caught?

No Mr Kahn, in this case the law is an ass and should be ignored. Many of the people taking the crayfish, be it to sell or feed their families, probably do not have enough bread to eat. For one brief moment in time, let them eat crayfish.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


257 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Business and Finance;
Cape firm links up with French giant


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Cape Town - Maitland-based DL Petroleum has been chosen by the giant Elf Aquitaine group as a partner in its bid to break into the automotive lubricants market in South Africa.

Elf Lubricants South Africa, jointly owned by Elf Lubrifiants of France and DL Petroleum, would have start-up capital of up to R20 million, DL Petroleum's Stephen Watson told the Cape Argus.

Mr Watson, grandson of the man who founded DL Petroleum in 1937, is managing director of the joint venture. 

"We are looking at initial capital of R15 million to R20 million," Mr Watson said. "But we have a five-year plan and this investment is likely to increase substantially ."

Elf Lubricants South Africa would sell the full range of Elf's automotive products, from monograde and multigrade oils to hi-tech synthetic lubricants and diesels, he said.

"All the products will be locally sourced. We will purchase the base oils and the additives here, the cans will be locally made and the products will be blended in South Africa under the technical guidance of Elf, to ensure compliance with Elf's standards worldwide."

Mr Watson said the joint venture with the French multinational, which nets profits of R5,76 billion a year and employs 95 000 people in more than 100 countries, was "a natural move" for his company.

Created by William Ewart Watson 60 years ago as a lubricants importer, DL Petroleum (named after the founders' sons Derrick and Lincoln) blended and sold the Duckhams range of automotive products until Duckhams was taken over by BP, and then continued marketing the range until the 1980s. The company's association with Elf goes back 20 years through the sale of marine lubricants, which are blended in Durban to supply Elf-contracted ships calling at South African harbours.

"Four years ago we were approached by Elf for a feasibility study of the Elf automotive range in South Africa. The study was completed last year and last August the decision was taken to start a joint venture," Mr Watson said.

The next move would probably be into industrial lubricants, he said.

Light industrial lubricants would immediately be sold to workshops and the range would be expanded soon.

Elf Lubricants South Africa will also sponsor the Elf Racing team and has started a training programme for kart drivers from the townships.

Executive director of Elf Aquitaine in South Africa Alain Terrenoire said the time had now arrived for a much greater involvement and investment in the country.

"We see South Africa as a great base from which to expand our operations, particularly into the southern and sub-Saharan African regions," he said.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


258 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Sports - General;
Contracts for Olympic poll and study signed


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Cape Town - The long-awaited contract to undertake a strategic environmental assessment of Cape Town's bid to host the 2004 Olympic Games has been signed by the Olympic Bid Company and a group of consultants.

The strategic assessment has been commissioned to provide an independent assessment of the short- and long-term implications of the bid, and is one of the "minimum requirements" negotiated between the company and the environmental sector for environmentalists' participation in the bid process.

Another of the requirements negotiated between the company and the environmentalists is an independent poll to test the opinion of residents of the greater metropolitan region on whether Cape Town should continue its bid to host the Games. 

The environmentalists argued that a proper strategic assessment and related environmental impact assessments of all the proposed Olympic sites were essential if residents were to make informed choices about hosting the Games during the poll.

In terms of their agreement, the poll should be conducted a month after the results of the assessment have been released. The actual mechanism of how the poll is to be conducted has yet to be decided.

Issues to be investigated during the strategic environmental assessment include: economic performance; small business opportunities; public finance; public involvement; urban development pattern; transport; nation-building; job creation; price effects; institutional capacity; population growth effects; housing; sport needs; and promoting sustainability.

According to the original programme, the strategic assessment should have been commissioned in February; a draft working report produced by March; a review draft report by April-May; and the final report by the end of May. But the process is way behind schedule.

At the beginning of March the Wildlife and Environment Society, a key player in the environmental sector, wrote to the bid company saying the completion of the strategic assessment was a priority and asking it to ensure it was given priority funding.

Last week, not having had an answer, the society wrote again, asking for an urgent response.

"Recent decisions by city politicians will prevent the full disclosure of the bid company's financial records. This is cause for further concern regarding the funding of the SEA," the society's letter, signed by its Western Cape conservation ecologist, Marlene Laros, stated.

The bid company's environmental planner, Mary-Jane Morris, told the Cape Argus there was a commitment to a strategic assessment, as stated in the Bid Book which had been handed to the International Olympic Committee.

"The SEA was discussed with the Wildlife Society prior to its first letter of March 3 and I explained that there is full commitment by our management team to ensure the SEA is completed," she said.

"The bid company has indicated both verbally and in writing its willingness to deal with any questions any environmental organisation may have, and a telephone query would have been appropriate." A letter of appointment for the consultants had now been signed by chief executive Chris Ball, Ms Morris said.

Mr Ball and the company's financial director, Mike Fuller, had been concerned that funds used for the strategic assessment were spent effectively and there had been extensive talks with the consultants.

"We went through a comprehensive process of looking at all the work that needs to be done, and it has taken us longer than we would have liked," Ms Morris conceded.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


259 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Business and Finance;
Cape Town theft probe targets taxmen


BYLINE: Johann Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - A big scam, possibly involving millions of rands, has been uncovered in the Cape Town office of the South African Revenue Services.

It is the latest in a string of thefts and irregularities exposed at the office.

Last week a VAT expert was suspended when it was alleged he had opened a bank account in the name of a fictitious business and was depositing revenue service cheques in it. 

The scam came to light after authorities became suspicious about large amounts of money flowing in and out of the account.

A high-ranking source in the revenue service said four other officials were being monitored and their work scrutinised.

In February, a senior tax official with about 20 years' service was suspended for allegedly pocketing PAYE payments .

The alleged scam was exposed when her work portfolio was changed. Certain taxpayers' files were taken from her, preventing her from covering her tracks.

The official admitted stealing about R60 000 when the irregularities were found, but to date thefts amounting to "well over" R800 000 have been linked to her, according to a well-placed source in the revenue service.

Fraudulent transactions connected to the VAT official suspended last week so far involve only R25 000, but the investigation is at an early stage.

The source said the amount could be much higher and that internal investigators were going through files with a "fine- tooth comb" to establish the magnitude of the fraud.

The Receiver in Cape Town, Attie Fourie, confirmed that his department was investigating two cases but declined to elaborate. He also declined to identify the suspended officials.

The latest investigations follow the arrest last year of a VAT official who allegedly created a fictitious bottling company to steal more than R400 000 of taxpayers' money.

He allegedly ran the scam for at least a year before he was caught.

Police have announced that fraud in government departments is a top priority. Late last year a meeting between heads of commercial crime units across the country prompted a more unified approach in the previously fragmented network of investigative units to clamp down more effectively on government fraud.

It was proposed that a new agency, the Financial Intelligence Centre, be formed to monitor suspicious banking transactions, in a bid to expose money laundering.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


260 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigeria Falls Back On Reserves To End Gasoline Crisis


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Long lines of cars remained a common sight at filling stations in Lagos on Thursday despite an order by Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, to release gasoline from the National Strategic Reserve.

However, an on the spot PANA check in Lagos showed that more stations had received supplies by Wednesday.

Abacha ordered the fuel release as an interim measure to ease a lingering gasoline scarcity that has crippled economic activities in parts of the oil- producing country. 

Military officials called to try end this embarrassing shortage say Abacha has also directed the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation to end the shortage promptly. The shortages have been blamed on supply and distribution difficulties.

Lagos, Nigeria's economic hub of some six million people, has been in a virtual standstill as a result of the gas scarcity now in its fourth week. The shortage is spreading to other parts of the country, including Abuja, the nation's capital.

Nigeria's chief of defence staff, Maj. Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, held a crisis-management meeting Wednesday in Lagos with the petroleum resources minister, Dan Etete. Other ranking officials of the country's refineries and members of the armed forces and Police Committee on Petroleum Distribution attended.

"Nigerians deserved a lot better than this," Abubakar told the meeting.

Industry sources in Lagos said part of the problem was that only three of the country's four refineries were functioning, and all at below their installed capacity.

Nigeria, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, or Opec, has a daily production quota of 1.85 million barrels. Nevertheless, the Nigeria experiences occasional gasoline scarcities, which are attributed to hoarding, smuggling, distribution or maintenance problems.

However, the domestic shortage does not always affect exports, which account for some 90 percent of Nigeria's total foreign exchange earnings.

In the past, government had to import fuel to augment the shortfall in domestic supply. But industry officials said this practice was stopped in December 1996, following public outcry. Energy experts said imports could be an option to ease the current crisis.

Commuters have been badly hit, with many commercial vehicles forced off the road by the fuel shortage.

Despite the ban on the sale of gasoline in jerry cans or in unauthorized containers, many car owners say the black market is booming. Fuel now sells for up four times the official price.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


261 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Liberia;
U.N. Agency Prepares To Repatriate Liberian Refugees


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Ghana says it has begun preparations for the voluntary repatriation of Liberian refugees, so they can take part in May elections designed to return the country to democratic rule.

The high commissioner's representative in Accra, Chrysantus Ache, told the Ghana News Agency in Accra on Wednesday that his outfit was playing "a pro- active" role to transport as many refugees as possible to Liberia to vote.

Ache, who has just returned from Liberia, said the U.N. agency held preparatory meetings with the outgoing special representative of the U.N. Secretary-General, Anthony Nyakyi, the United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia, the Interim Government, the West African Peace Monitoring Force in Liberian and other facilitators on security and reception for the returnees. 

The meeting assessed the significance and potential involvement of Liberians living outside their home country in the May 30 elections.

It was for this reason, Ache said, that the U.N. agency had decided to work with other agencies to return Liberians home.

"For the elections to be free and fair it is important that as many people as possible, including those living abroad through no fault of theirs, take part in the decision-making process," he said.

The U.N. agency has under its care some one million Liberian refugees in five neighboring countries. They fled seven years of civil war in which some 150,000 people were killed.

The host countries for refugees are Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria and Sierra Leone. Ghana has some 17,000 displaced Liberians at two main camps -- Budumburam in the Central region and Sansuli in the Western region.

Ache said his organization would spend 2.8 million dollars to transport the refugees from Accra to Monrovia.

So far, he said, about 400 Liberian refugees have said they wished to take part in the elections. Voter registration is still in progress.

Those living near the Ivorian border will be transported by road and others by sea.

Ache said the U.N. agency would ensure that the refugees it transports will disembarked only at the officially marked zones. There will be two of these areas, one in Monrovia and the other in the hinterland.

A new wave of Liberian refugees arrived in Ghana in May by sea following renewed fighting when the transitional government tried to arrest Gen. Roosevelt Johnson of the defunct ULIMO-J faction.

Ghana government, already burdened with other refugees including those from Togo, was reluctant to accept more. It relented only after U.N. and aid workers, spearheaded by the UNHCR, pledged to take responsibility for their upkeep.

Based on this pledge, the UNHCR put up new refugee camps and rehabilitated the old ones. When the Liberians go, Ache said, the camps would be put under the care of the government.

"These buildings are assets and could be put to effective use by government, " Ache said in reaction to criticism about investment in the camps.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


262 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Southern Africa;
Defaulting Comesa Countries To Be Expelled


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - African leaders agreed here Thursday that member states of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, or Comesa, who failed to pay membership dues to the organization for five years would be expelled.

The leaders, at the end of their one-day summit, said defaulting states had made it difficult for Comesa to carry out its activities. 

Briefing journalists immediately after the end of the summit, Zambian President Frederick Chiluba, the new chairman of the subregional economic bloc, said that most of the programs which Comesa was undertaking had not been implemented due to lack of money.

The summit was attended by the presidents of Kenya, Namibia, Malawi, Tanzania, Uganda and Zimbabwe. Also in attendance were the prim ministers of Rwanda and Swaziland, and the Organization of Africa Unity secretary-general, Salim Ahmed Salim.

Leaders urged Comesa member-states to resolve any conflicts through the conflict prevention and resolution mechanisms of the O.A.U. and other regional organizations.

The leaders also agreed to undertake consultations with the governments of Mozambique and Lesotho following their decision to leave Comesa. The two countries have given notice to withdraw from the 20-member organization in favor of the Southern African Development Community, also called Sadc.

Leaders agreed that Comesa and Sadc co-exist as autonomous and complementary institutions. Critics say their tasks were often duplicated, a factor that has led to Mozambique's withdrawal.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


263 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Southern Africa;
Civil Wars Worry Comesa Leaders


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Leaders of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, Comesa, began their summit in Lusaka Thursday calling for an immediate solution to the civil strife that has engulfed a number of their states.

A number of Comesa states among them Burundi, Somalia, Sudan and Zaire are engulfed in civil war in which hundreds of thousands have been killed and displaced.

Opening the one-day summit, Zambian President Frederick Chiluba said leaders should not hide behind the notion of absolute sovereignty because internal conflicts had the potential of destabilizing other states. 

"We need, therefore, to implore our colleagues collectively in the strife- torn countries to open up the political arena so as to allow all and sundry to decide on their future," he said.

Part of the solution to the on-going conflicts in the region, he said, lay in allowing society to choose its leaders freely and for these leaders to practice good government.

President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe said unless peace and stability was achieved in the region, then the efforts by member-states in building a regional economic bloc and uplifting the quality of life of the population would fail.

His Malawian counterpart, Bikili Muluzi, told the summit that the influx of refugees threatened the security and stability of most countries in the region. The conflicts, he said, had affected market integration since social and political linkages had been broken.

Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi reiterated the need for the affected countries to respect the sanctity of human life and keep open all avenues for dialogue.

"We ourselves must do the best to resolve the problems. We must work hard to maintain and prevail our dignity even if we are poor," he said.

Africa, he said, should work aggressively for regional integration, as active participants.

The summit's theme is on the "gateway to regional economic integration, growth and development into the 21st century."

It is expected to find measures to strengthen the 20-nation organization, following the withdrawal of Lesotho and Mozambique.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


264 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 10, 1997


Zaire;
U.N. To Scale Down Presence In Kinshasa


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The United Nations has said it will reduce its presence in Kinshasa following increasing anti-government demonstrations in the capital.

U.N. spokesman Juan Carlos Brandt told correspondents in New York Wednesday that 12 of the 67 U.N. international staff in Kinshasa would leave the city in about two days. 

"Staff members who are performing less than essential functions at present will be relocated out of the city in the next 24 or 48 hours," he said.

These are three from the U.N. Children's Fund, four from the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, one from the World Food Program, two from the World Health Organization and two from the U.N. Development Program.

He said that some donor agencies and some people in the humanitarian community may also be planning to leave the capital.

Kinshasa has, in the past few days, been rocked by violent protests against President Mobutu Sese Seko's firing of his newly-appointed prime minister, Etienne Tshisekedi.

The protest marked the latest turn in the crisis facing Zaire, where the Alliance of Democratic Forces For the Liberation Congo (Zaire) have captured at least one third of this country of 905,365 square miles, a country in the heart of Africa almost twice the size of Alaska.

The rebels, who captured Lubumbashi, Zaire's second and richest city on Wednesday, have often said they were fighting to end Mobutu's 32-year reign.

The United States, which backed Mobutu throughout the Cold War, said Wednesday that the era of "Mobutuism" was over. However, Washington denied a newspaper report that it had called on the Mobutu, a self styled field marshal, to resign and go into exile.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


265 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - With the fall of Lubumbashi, Zaire's second largest city, and the change of prime ministerial guard in Kinshasa, Africa's media continued to focus on that country, among other issues.

Dakar's Le Soleil noted that given Zaire's current situation, the United States has not hesitated to drop its erstwhile ally, President Mobutu Sese Seko. Jumping ship, it said, Washington had switched its support to the anti- Mobutu leader now in control of the country's richest third.

"This explains the latent war of influence being waged by Paris and Washington," it said.

This, it added, was the reason for talk of a transitional government and holding of free and fair elections. 

"But is it democratic to push out of power the marshall who has already announced his intention to stand for presidency in the next elections?" it said.

Another Dakar newspaper, Sud Quotidien, expressed horror at the lack of African reaction to the thousands of refugees emaciated and dying in Zaire's forests, because of the war.

"Neither heads of state, international organizations, human rights organizations, nor the civil society have mobilized to stop the human tragedy that is taking place in the forests," it said. "At a time when many Africans have their attention cast elsewhere, Western public opinion is the only one expressing concern, by alerting their governments and demanding that they intervene," it added.

"In fact, what price did we pay for a free Kuwait, devoid of any tutelary influence? Perhaps the African people do not deserve as much?" it said.

Kinshasa newspapers also commented on their country's plight.

L'Avenir was caustic in its comment on the state of emergency declared by Mobutu.

It wondered what Mobutu sought to achieve by extending an already existing state of emergency when it was "evident that the initial measure never prevented Kabila from conquering the North and South Kivu provinces where the military governors only had time to flee head over heels."

By his action, Le Soft said, Mobutu was displaying his determination "to control the war" single-handedly.

Turning to the proposal by Congolese President Pascal Lissouba for a face- to-face meeting between Mobutu and Kabila, the paper said Kabila would appreciate the idea since he had been calling for such an encounter.

However, it said, acceptance of the meeting would depend on the agenda Lissouba proposed.

"If it is a question of going to negotiate Mobutu's departure from power, it is quite absurd to think that Mobutu would attend such a meeting. One does not saw off the branch on which one is sitting," it said.

For its part, the Kampala tri-weekly newspaper, The Crusader, commented on the third anniversary of the Rwandan genocide which in 1994 claimed about a million ethnic Tutsi and moderate Hutu.

"In a situation such as this, everybody must rise up to protect the rights of the endangered group to live and also to punish the perpetrators," it said.

So, it stressed, "the issue of genocide should not be left to the Rwanda government to handle or to commemorate. Genocide is a crime against humanity and it should be the responsibility of the so-called international community to halt it or punish those whose hands are tainted with the blood of innocent victims."

The newspaper castigated the short-comings of the United Nations tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania, and the manner in which Rwandan courts have been proceeding with their trials.

While the Arusha trials are too slow, it noted, human rights groups had questioned the hasty manner in which the genocide suspects in Rwanda are being conducted.

"It is important that justice be done so that individuals do not take the law into their own hands to avenge the deaths of their loved ones. Therefore, Africa and the rest of the world must help Rwanda come to terms with this horrible legacy," it said.

The ideal, it went on, would be for a more efficient and expanded U.N. tribunal to handle all the cases.

The paper cited growing frustration in Rwanda where the Interahamwe are said to be covering their tracks by killing the survivors of genocide.

In addition, it said, fears that the broken-down Rwandan judiciary, sending suspects to their deaths without a fair trial and tragic deaths of Hutu trapped between the Zairean rebels and government troops in the east of that country, were sure embers for a larger fire.

"This is a scenario that portends cataclysmic pogroms," it said, as "there are already accusations of reverse genocide" against the Hutu in Zaire.

And like Sud Quotidien, The Crusader called for action by the governments of the Great Lakes, Africa and the world to "eliminate the ever-present reality and possibility of genocide" in East Africa.

"The best honor we can accord to the memory of the million dead is to ensure that we outlaw genocide from our midst and hunt down the perpetrators. We must not allow any community, be it Hutu, Tutsi or any other socially and politically undesirable group to suffer extermination," the paper said.

Shifting focus, The Times of Zambia commented on Thursday's one-day Comesa summit in Lusaka.

"Nearly 20 years ago, former American ambassador to the United Nations Andrew Young lamented that the trouble with African conferences was that they ended up as talking shops because of lack of follow-up action," it said.

Because Africans lacked the will to implement their resolutions, it went on, their people "still face growing misery and economic decline." It added: " Monumental opportunism, contagious lethargy, unjustified fatalism and the dependence syndrome are just as rife and the future as insidious as when Andrew Young made these remarks."

Therefore, it said, "we hope the Comesa heads of government and representative of members states meeting in Lusaka will not be guilty to past inadequacies and failure to adhere to what they agree to do in pursuit of their cherished goals."

The Post, also a Lusaka newspaper, called for Comesa to emulate Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni.

It said that each head of state at the meeting spoke of the need for peace and stability as essential for economic development. However, as regards Comesa member countries, the issue has to be put in the context of the situation on the ground.

"The reality of the Comesa member countries does not demonstrate peace and stability as preconditions for development," it said. "It is like a pastor who preaches the avoidance of sin as the only key to heaven but continues to live in adultery and transgresses the ten commandments without shame."

It cited 33 years of stability in Zambia, for example, yet the country was " on the brink of economic and political dislocation."

It gave other examples, such as Zaire, saying that in many parts of Africa " peace has only bred and become a cloak for the perpetuation of some of the worst dictatorships the continent has seen."

It added that "virtually in all the Comesa countries peace is working to the advantage of -- not necessarily popular regimes or leaders but -- dishonest leaders.

"Crooks in power are preaching peace to wade off genuine rebellions like that of Zairian patriot Laurent-Desire Kabila," it said.

"It is quite doubtful, therefore, in view of the situation on the ground whether the Comesa program will be enhanced by peace and stability,"

"The only example of a Comesa leader who does not have a narrow definition of peace is Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni," it said.

The Uganda leader, it noted, was using the limited peace in Uganda for economic development and reconstruction.

"The problem with Comesa member-states is not really the absence of peace but (the presence of) corruption." it said.

There was, it said, also "lack of vision and managerial acumen among leaders and the fact that their true priority is to stay in power at all costs and not development."


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


266 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Musician Fela To Face Drug Charges


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's National Drug Law Enforcement Agency confirmed Friday it was holding the country's internationally renowned and controversial Afro-beat musician, Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, for alleged possession of drugs.

The agency's chairman, Maj. Gen. Musa Bamaiyi, told a news conference that Fela and 107 others were arrested Wednesday at his Ikeja residence and nightclub in Lagos for alleged possession of unspecified quantity of Indian hemp.

Anikulapo-Kuti, also called the Afro-beat King, was in handcuffs when shown to journalist Friday. He is to be prosecuted after investigation to determine his role and those of others arrested with him in the "sale and smoking" of the banned substance. 

Bamaiyi said that, if convicted, Anikulapo-Kuti could forfeit his property to the government. Anti-drug agents arrested him in a similar raid at his home in April 1996.

The agency did not press charges then. Instead, it opted to counsel the musician and his band members under a rehabilitation program to wean them from Indian hemp.

Bamaiyi charged that Anikulapo-Kuti's "activities had wrecked many lives in the society."

Bamaiyi said after Anikulapo-Kuti's arrest in 1996, agents visited and counselled him and his workers at home.

But one year later, Bamaiyi said, there seemed to be no change and many more people were joining the habit.

Bamaiyi said the 79 male and 28 female suspects arrested along with Anikulapo-Kuti were mainly teenagers, among them a 13-year-old girl. Some of them said they were not members of the band but lived in the neighborhood.

However, ever defiant, Anikulapo-Kuti said he had smoked hemp for 40 years and that the substance had "medicinal values and helped him to write good music, eat well and sleep well with women."

The frail-looking musician, who has had several brushes with Nigerian authorities, said he was against hard drugs such as opium, heroin, cocaine.

But he insisted that smoking of hemp, which he calls "natural grass", was only a misdemeanor that attracted minor punishment and not the forfeiture of property.

He has been arrested several times for offenses ranging from murder to assault and has always managed to come out unscathed.

But in 1984, he was jailed under a stringent law against currency trafficking.

Meanwhile, the agency announced the seizure about 2,444 kilograms of substances suspected to be prohibited drugs in the country this year. Some 320 suspects were arrested over the seizures.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


267 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Tanzania;
U.N. Food Agency Launches Emergency Food Distribution


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - The United Nations World Food Program says it needs 9.24 million U.S. to obtain, deliver and monitor the distribution of 29,234 tons of relief food to drought-hit regions in Tanzania.

The agency's director in Tanzania, Irene Lacy, said that the food will come from the country's strategic grain reserve and the sale of maize stocks would stabilize market prices. 

Thirteen of Tanzania's 20 regions on the mainland are experiencing food shortages because of drought, affecting the 12.1 million people living in these areas.

The Ministry of Agriculture says that the delayed onset of the long rains will likely reduce food harvests by between 50 percent to 70 percent in regions with a unimodal rainfall regime.

The meteorological department forecast current rains in most parts of the country to last till mid-May.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Women Journalists Honoured


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

DARWENDALE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - An India and a Swed were presented with the International Association of Women in Radio and Television (IAWRT) awards for their outstanding programs. The presentations were made Thursday at a dinner hosted in Darwendale, Zimbabwe. 

Basu Nupur of India won the award for excellence for her television film Dry Days in Dobbasunta. The film depicted women living with breast cancer. It spoke of the vital aspects of the disease of which women were keen to learn.

Addressing guests, jurist Jai Chandiram said Nupur won out of a field of 98 film entries. She said there were 16 entries for the radio category.

Jenny Cole, another jurist from the British Broadcasting Corporation, said the entries reflected the struggles of women in everyday life and touched on aspects that affected all people.

The entries, she said, displayed skill, talent, good editing and were highly interesting.

However, there were five entries worthy of honorable mention, among them Zimbabwean producer Lynet Mawere's program on rape.

Chandiram recommended that the association's board seek rights to the films "so that for the price of one we can have many programs."

She also suggested that the association search for ways to help co- productions to help "overcome the shortage of funds which many organizations face."

The week-long bi-annual meeting, the organization's 27th, was jointly hosted by this body and the Federation of African Media Women - Zimbabwe. It was the first such event in African and attracted 70 participants from the continent, European and Asian countries.

The association comprises broadcast professionals, and those in related fields, from around the world. It seeks to advance the impact of women professionals in the electronic field, develop women in broadcasting and utilize the professional skills of the members to support women in development. The meeting ended Friday.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


South Africa;
Mandela to Alliance Summit


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Johannesburg - President Nelson Mandela will lead an ANC delegation to a Summit of ANC-led Alliance partners on Thursday 10 April at an unspecified venue in Johanneburg. The Summit is a culmination of decisions of the ANC National Executive Committee (NEC) Lekgotla held earlier this year. 

The NEC Lekgotla decided that a Summit of the Alliance partners be held in April as way of strengthening the alliance and improving on communications between the partners.

The Summit will among others:

* share perspective on the transformation process

* discuss the Reconstruction and Development Programme

* and key tasks facing the Alliance

Among other members of the ANC NEC who will attend will be:

Trevor Manuel, Alec Erwin, Gill Marcus, Tito Mboweni, Max Sisulu, Valli Moosa, Frene Ginwala, Joel Netshitendzhe, Sanki Mahanyele, Nkosazana Zuma. A consolidated list of NEC members attending the Summit will be released later.

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P. O Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107 9 April 1997

LANGUAGE: English
