332 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


South Africa;
'House parent' on child-rape charges


BYLINE: Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Johannesburg - Witnesses testified in court this week that a senior children's home official sexually abused several children in his charge, reports Stuart Hess

A FORMER house parent at one of the country's most respected children's homes appeared in court this week on charges that he raped and abused five children in his care.

James Arthur Frazer (50) allegedly touched, sucked and raped the girls at the Johannesburg Children's Home. He pleaded not guilty.

The incidents are said to have taken place between 1992 and 1996 and involved girls aged between 10 and 12 at the time. 

A girl, now 15, who stayed at the home from 1993, testified in the Johannesburg Magistrate's Court that Frazer sucked her breasts and her sexual organs and also asked her to suck his genitals.

"He treated me like he cared about me more than anything else," said the pretty blonde-haired girl.

She did not at first tell anyone because she was afraid they would not believe her. "Arthur told me to deny we had sex so that his wife would not divorce him," she said.

She said he had threatened to send her and a friend, also an alleged victim, to an industrial school if they continued to "tell lies about him".

Frazer was a house parent -a managerial post in which he oversaw several care workers -and the personnel manager at the home in Yeoville for four years. He was suspended on May 20 last year, in connection with the allegations. "He was dismissed from the home following a disciplinary hearing in July," the home's director, Muriel Farren, told the Mail & Guardian.

The home, which presently houses 64 children, was established more than 100 years ago. Its board of governors includes prominent public personalities including former Johannesburg Stock Exchange president Roy Andersen, stockbroker Humphrey Borkum, and SABC stars Adrian Steed and Sandy Ngema.

The home consists of eight cottages, each housing eight to 10 children and each with a child-care worker.

Physically, sexually or emotionally abused children, and those neglected or abandoned by parents, are placed in the home by the courts.

Frazer appeared relaxed as the testimony by the alleged victims was transmitted to the courtroom via television from a small room nearby. The room, designed to make child witnesses as comfortable as possible, has stuffed animals and bright paintings of Disney characters on the walls.

Questions from the court were relayed to the children by a social worker who sat with them throughout their testimony.

A second girl, also aged 15, said she was a close friend of the first witness. "She would tell me everything."

She did not believe her friend when she first heard the rumours because "I had a lot of respect for Arthur".

But she later took the rumours seriously when she saw her friend with a lot of money. Children at the home were given pocket money according to their ages, "but (my friend) always carried notes with her".

She said that Frazer tried to "touch" her. When she refused he called her a "spoilt brat".

A child-care worker, Juliana Hoffman, told the court that she saw Frazer with the first girl in his office. "I looked through the curtains which were about 30cm apart," she said. The girl "was naked and lying with her back on the cabinet while he stood over her performing sexual acts".

Hoffman, who has been at the home since December 1995, worked in the cottage where the girl lived.

"I first heard rumours about Frazer's relationship with her at a braai in March last year," said Hoffman. A man who also worked at the home told her " there were things going on in Arthur's office and I would look through his window after hours".

Hoffman said she later noticed that the girl always visited Frazer in his office after hours -at about 6pm, which was "strange because he never asked other children to come to his office".

She said the girl always returned from the office with a gift but she also looked "very uncomfortable". Hoffman said she did not tell anyone about the incident: "The man is the manager, who will believe us?"

She added: "I had a good working relationship with Arthur and had a lot of respect for him. He was good with children."

The case was postponed on Wednesday until September 15.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


333 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


South Africa;
NEWS IN BRIEF (Column)


BYLINE: Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Johannesburg - Fivaz 'too busy' for Gasa case

WESTERN CAPE police have still to reprimand two officers officially slated over their incompetence in investigating the rape of Nomboniso Gasa.

The province's commissioner of police, Leon Wessels, said this week that he could not implement recommendations from the Independent Complaints Directorate (ICD) until he heard from police National Commissioner, George Fivaz. In turn, Fivaz's office said he had been too busy to attend to the matter. 

Gasa was raped on Robben Island on January 20, and the police have so far failed to make an arrest. The ICD report, released last week, recommended that two members of the initial investigating team, Constable M McLean and Captain Kevin Jones, be "strongly reprimanded". The South African Police Union said McClean and Jones should not be reprimanded. Gasa, wife of African National Congress MP Raymond Suttner, said she was tired of being in the media spotlight, but would watch "with interest" how the ICD's recommendations were implemented.

Ensuring court martial is fair

ATTEMPTS by the Mail & Guardian and the Freedom of Expression Institute (FXI) to have a Cape court martial opened to the public could go to the high court if the South African National Defence Force succeeds in blocking the application.

The application is based on constitutional provisions guaranteeing everyone the right to a fair public hearing in a court or any other appropriate forum. Staff Sergeant Herman Pheiffer and Corporal Desmond Booysen are being court martialled for alleging that their commanding officer was racist, and with leaking sensitive information to a military intelligence officer.

The court martial resumed in Paarl on Monday, and so far the M&G's attorneys -David Dison, Norval and Wheeldon -have succeeded in gaining public access to the hearing of their application. The court martial ruled, however, that the attorneys only have standing in the case through their representation of Booysen and Pheiffer, and not the M&G and FXI -giving only the attorneys, and not the public, access. The application continues.

PAC's vanished millions

The Pan Africanist Congress has failed to ask the police to investigate the disappearance of millions of rands from its coffers -four months after a decision at its annual conference that it should do so.

Secretary general Mike Muendene said this week that the PAC wanted to investigate itself further before turning to the police. He said the PAC had yet to identify individuals involved in "fraud and embezzlement" whose names could be given to the police. Most delegates at the PAC's conference in December voted to refer the issue of the missing funds to the police. It was believed that the police would be able to carry out a more thorough investigation than the PAC.

The report painted a devastating picture of the PAC's financial records and said daily monitoring of all cash-flows was "non-existent". Muendene said the PAC had independent auditors working on the case. He was unsure of their name.

Dolny expected to head bank

HELENA DOLNY, widow of the late housing minister Joe Slovo and special adviser to Land and Agriculture Minister Derek Hanekom, is expected to become the next head of the Land Bank.

The bank, which formerly concentrated on providing cheap loans to white farmers, announced recently it would reposition itself to help "emerging" farmers. It added that it would continue to deal with commercial farmers.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


334 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


South Africa;
Cash no balm to gross human rights abuse victims


BYLINE: Rehana Rossouw, Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Johannesburg - ALL victims of gross human rights abuse who give their stories to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission will be offered the same cash compensation, irrespective of their individual suffering or financial status.

The commission's Reparation and Reconciliation Committee said this week that every victim would be given an equal share of the money available, regardless of the number of times they suffered a gross violation of human rights. Means testing had been ruled out as too expensive. 

The committee also noted that most of the victims heard so far had wanted shelter, medical assistance and an investigation of their complaints. Just 100 of the 9000 victims identified so far wanted cash.

"For most victims, money alone is not enough," said committee member Piet Meiring. "For many people conciliation does not come at a price.

"We cannot attach a value to the life of a husband, wife, son or daughter. We cannot put a price on the length or intensity of a torture.

"Whatever money is available should belong to all the victims equally. A politician on the gravy train would receive the same amount as an unemployed mother whose only breadwinner has been killed.

"It is my personal hope that those who do not need the money will return it for redistribution to those who are more needy."

One reported estimate for the total reparation bill is R3-billion, which would pay for financial and symbolic reparation for the 30000 victims the commission hopes to have on its books by the time its mandate expires in December.

Most of the funds will come from government, via the President's Fund. Foreign governments have already made donations and further funds could be raised abroad, and from the South African public and business community.

Those victims qualifying for urgent reparation are expected to receive help days after the commission hands its final report to President Nelson Mandela next March.

The reparation committee is also formulating a policy of symbolic reparation, holding national and regional workshops as a first step.

There is enthusiasm for the erection of monuments or memorials, museums, archives and peace parks. A structure similar to the Vietnam memorial in Washington has been mooted.

Many also support the call for a national day of remembrance and reconciliation, either using an existing public holiday or creating a new one.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


335 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


South Africa;
Spy scandal stretches to IFP


BYLINE: Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Johannesburg - Documents found in the wrecked car of Internal Security head Leonard Radu led to the identification of two KwaZulu-Natal warlords as alleged agents, reports Ann Eveleth

The spy scandal which erupted this week also implicates Inkatha Freedom Party warlord David Ntombela. The Mail & Guardian has established that the evidence which led the African National Congress to expel warlord and MPP Sifiso Nkabinde for being an alleged spy also identifies Ntombela, his IFP counterpart, as an alleged security police agent who reported to the same police "handlers" in the KwaZulu-Natal Midlands.

Ntombela on Thursday denied the allegations, saying he had "never worked for any police unit" and that he was being implicated because the ANC feared him as much as it feared Nkabinde.

Nkabinde has already denied the ANC's allegations. 

But the M&G has been told that Ntombela and Nkabinde were linked to the security police -and its successor, the Crime Intelligence Service (CIS) -in documents recovered from the wreckage of the fatal car crash in which Internal Security head Leonard Radu died last month. Radu was to fly to Durban to discuss the matter with colleagues when his car left the road.

The allegations against Ntombela come from three separate and reliable organisations, although none were prepared to comment publicly.

However, violence monitors in the province said there was evidence that Ntombela enjoyed close links with the police. The Truth and Reconciliation Commission has already heard testimony from two police constables about Ntombela's links with the Pietermaritzburg riot unit. Ntombela this week denied such links.

The allegations raise fresh questions about the role the "third force" played in fomenting political violence in the area. The two warlords also ingratiated themselves with the province's peace drive.

A University of Natal violence monitor, Mary de Haas, said there were allegations that Nkabinde and Ntombela had colluded to extend their control over the region while boosting their credibility among supporters. "Now they have both become big peacelords but are continuing to consolidate their territory," she said.

In announcing Nkabinde's expulsion, the ANC named seven security policemen alleged to have been his handlers, including the head of the Pietermaritzburg CIS, Superintendent Chris Moolman.

Moolman declined to identify his informers, but confirmed that all but one of the men named as handlers by the ANC had worked for him. Two of them - Sergeant Shane Morris and Captain Jerry Brooks -are still with the unit.

Brooks applied to the truth commission last December for amnesty in connection with the abduction of a person from Swaziland who was to become an askari. The man he abducted was ANC activist Dion Cele whose remains, along with those of two other activists, were dug up last month by truth commission investigators on a farm near Ntombela's Elandskop stronghold.

The allegations also revive questions about the unsolved October 1992 murder of a Midlands ANC leader, Reggie Hadebe. He was the "right-hand man" of the late ANC stalwart Harry Gwala. Hadebe's death opened that position to Nkabinde in 1993.

The ANC report on Nkabinde's alleged spying says: "A new era dawned of prolific reports from (Nkabinde), with 1993 recording a regular flow of information (to police)." Nkabinde had apparently joined the United Democratic Front just four years earlier.

Initial spying allegations against Nkabinde emerged after the 1994 death of an ANC Richmond youth leader, Mzwandile Mbongwa. Two of Nkabinde's self- defence unit members were convicted of the murder.

Monitors say the allegations against the two warlords have been strengthened by the police's apparent failure to pursue them for crimes they are alleged to have committed.

A University of Natal academic and former monitor, John Aitchison, said police appeared to have "allowed certain things to happen" in Richmond -the core of Nkabinde's support base -in order to boost his credibility.

These included a 1991 ambush of IFP attackers by ANC youths, who had apparently been tipped-off and were able to arm themselves after they stumbled on an Umkhonto weSizwe arms cache. The ambush led to the death of 23 IFP supporters, "yet there was silence from the police and the IFP", Aitchison said. "The incident didn't even appear in the police unrest report."

More recently, police are believed to have tipped off Nkabinde about two raids on his Dambuza stronghold, which is apparently flooded with illegal arms. Only six weapons were found in the raids.

Nkabinde has faced growing allegations about his involvement in violence, and a recent report by the South African National Defence Force linked him and Ntombela and several others to paramilitary activity.

The recent furore about alleged informers in the ANC's ranks is understood to have presented the party with the opportunity it has long been seeking to cut Nkabinde loose. Nkabinde will address a rally in Pietermaritzburg on Saturday.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 11, 1997


South Africa;
VERBATIM (Column)


BYLINE: Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Johannesburg - ' I've been through worse situations. They cocked their rifles, but I think it was more to threaten than anything else. '

-Bafana Bafana coach Clive Barker, after Congolese soldiers tried to prevent the team from training

' I feel like a king. '

-Congo striker Younga, after scoring two goals in six minutes to sink Bafana Bafana in World Cup qualifying action

' We can't fight crime any more. It's totally beyond us, so the public will have to do it for us.'

-An anonymous Johannesburg policeman

' Phosa is quite a cool and collected man, who is very articulate and involved in national issues of the ANC. '

-Joe Selau, African National Congress head of information in the North-West province, explaining the province's backing of Mathews Phosa for deputy president

' A killer must be killed. '

-Joni Tsili, widower of a woman allegedly killed by Grahamstown police 17 years ago, speaking before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission

' The best thing Fivaz can do is go home and start a new business venture. In fact, he should have resigned on Sunday if he no longer likes his boss's mbaqanga music. '

-Mpumalanga Safety and Security MEC Steve Mabona

' This time, I believe we can win.'

-IBM computer scientist Hsu Feng-Hsiung, of his computer Deep Blue's chances of beating world chess champion Garry Kasparov in an upcoming rematch

"Mozambique is being given away and citizens don't know about it."

-Land expert Dr Jose Negrao after revelations that US billionaire James Ulysses Blanchard III had been granted concessions to land the size of Israel on Mozambique's south coast

South Africa;
PEOPLE (Column)


BYLINE: Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)

Johannesburg - ARRESTED: New Zealand rugby player Roger Randle, after allegedly raping a woman at the Durban Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza

CHATTING: Bantu Holomisa and the National Party's Roelf Meyer met to discuss the formation of a new political movement

SPEEDING: German engineering student Dirk Auer claimed the world speed record for rollerblading after hanging on to the back of a Porsche doing 247km/h

SPOTTED: Josiah 'Mr Fingers' Rabotapi, the three-time escaped fugitive, was seen using a public phone in Hillbrow

SQUABBLING: Police National Commissioner George Fivaz and his boss, Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi, have engaged in a public row, raising questions about Fivaz's future

SUSPENDED: Former Pan Africanist Congress president Clarence Makwetu was banned from taking part in party activities for violating the PAC Constitution

WOUNDED: Ephert Chari received injuries to his hands, chest and face when he accidentally detonated an anti-personnel mine while clearing brush on a Northern Province farm


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


338 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


South Africa;
Shobashobane: 13 IFP members granted appeal


BYLINE: Ann Eveleth, Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Johannesburg - A JUDGE agreed this week that 13 Inkatha Freedom Party supporters can appeal against their conviction in the Shobashobane massacre.

Durban High Court Judge Hilary Squires granted defence attorneys Shane Matthews, Pieter van der Burgh and Piet Haasbrook leave to appeal against his conviction of their clients on 18 counts of murder and six counts of attempted murder in the Christmas 1995 massacre of African National Congress supporters. 

He did so on three grounds, including: "Whether the trial court erred on the question of common purpose, whether my approach in rejecting the alibis (of the accused) was incorrect" and whether the court has misdirected the charges in relation to four murder victims whose bodies were found at the massacre scene, but no evidence had been led on their murders.

Squires convicted all 13 accused on all counts last month.

He found that their presence in the 2 000-strong attacking mob amounted to a "common purpose" with the aims of the attack, which he said included murder, assault and the burning of homes.

The defence had argued that the state needed to prove each accused had actively participated in the murders.

Squires this week denied leave to appeal on all other grounds cited by the defence.

But he granted convicted IFP Izingolweni leader Sipho Ngcobo and IFP youth brigade leader Zithulele Zuma leave to appeal against their life imprisonment sentences.

In a previously postponed decision, Squires also sentenced a 15-year-old youth -convicted on the evidence of his own father, an ANC supporter, of participating in the mob attack -to four years at a prison youth facility where he will be able to continue his formal education, but suspended half the sentence for five years.

The youth has already spent 14 months in detention.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


339 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


South Africa;
Way opened for death on demand


BYLINE: Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Johannesburg - Draft legislation proposed by the law commission recommends legalising euthanasia, reports Gustav Thiel

The first steps have been taken toward legislation allowing South African doctors to end the lives of the terminally ill. A discussion document by the South African Law Commission, released to the Mail & Guardian, recommends new legislation allowing so-called passive euthanasia -withholding life support or life-saving treatment.

The commission, which is to release its recommendations next week, stresses that its 180-page report should only be regarded as a discussion document. The report is open to public submissions until June. 

But medical experts say the report, which also includes a proposed draft Bill, is likely to lead to passive euthanasia being legalised.

Among the draft Bill's clauses is a provision allowing a mentally incompetent person to hand a third party their right to decide whether they should have euthanasia performed.

Commission secretary Willie Henigan said the topic of active euthanasia - where doctors act deliberately to end the life of a terminally ill patient - remained a delicate subject in South Africa, and so no concrete suggestions on it had been included in its proposed legislation. Active euthanasia is expected, however, to be part of the discussion process prior to new legislation.

Recent research by the medical profession found that one doctor in eight was already practising some form of euthanasia -a breach of current law and their own Hippocratic Oath.

The report imposes strong caveats on passive euthanasia.

Section 5 of the suggested draft Bill, states: "Should a medical practitioner be requested by a patient to make an end to the patient's suffering, or to enable the patient to personally make an end to the patient's suffering by way of administering or providing some or other legal agent, the medical practitioner shall not give effect to this request unless he or she is convinced that the patient is suffering from a terminal illness; the patient is subject to extreme suffering; the patient is over the age of 18 years and mentally competent."

Other caveats include ensuring the patient has been adequately informed about their terminal illness, the prognosis of their condition and of any treatment or care available.

The patient's request has to be based on an "informed and well-considered decision", the commission adds. The patient must be given "the opportunity to re-evaluate his or her request", and he or she must persist in that request. Also, euthanasia must be "the only way for the patient to be released from his or her suffering".

The doctor must also consult with another doctor who knows the patient's medical history before making the decision.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
A History of Early Twentieth Century Ethiopia - Part 14


BYLINE: Dr Richard Pankhurst, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1774 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Liberation Campaign, 1941 - Mussolini's Entry into the European War

At the outbreak of the European war, on 3 September 1939, Mussolini refrained from involving himself in the war. He nevertheless declared that fascist Italy, a close ally of nazi Germany, was in a state of "pre- belligerency". By that he implied that he was committed to eventually participating in the struggle. By postponing his entry into the conflict he obviated having to fight with Italy's neighbour, France, and avoided any immediate Allied attack on the insecure Italian East African empire, where the Ethiopian patriots were still unbeaten. After Hitler's victory over France in the early summer of 1940, however, the Duce anticipated that Germany would rapidly win the war. Anxious to be participate in an ensuing peace conference he declared war on Britain and France, on 10 June. 

Historical Background

Italy's entry into the European war, for which the Ethiopian patriots had long been waiting, had important, and almost immediate consequences, making it a turning point in Ethiopian history. Britain, as a result, of Mussolini's action, found itself obliged to modify, if not entirely to abandon, its long- established, pro-colonial, attitude to Italo-Ethiopian relations. The British Government, it will be recalled, had for half a century favoured Italian expansion in Ethiopia. Britain had supported Italy's occupation of Massawa in 1885, and had thereafter consistently sought to accommodate Italian colonial ambitions: by dispatching the Portal mission to help the Italians after Ras Alula's victory at Dogali in 1887, by recognising Italy's Protectorate claim in 1890, by signing the Tripartite Treaty of 1906, by offering Italy a revision of colonial frontiers in 1915, and by participating in the AngloItalian demarche of 1925 against which Tafari Makonnen had protested to the League. Britain's policy of accommodation had continued into the immediate pre-war period, with the restriction of arms sales immediately prior to the fascist invasion, the limitation of sanctions against Italy and the Hoare-Laval plan of 1935, and, finally, the recognition of the Italian " conquest" in 1938.

Opening of the Liberation Campaign

The opening of hostilities in the summer of 1940 necessarily changed the British perspective. The Italians in East Africa threatened Britain's important sea route to India, and were in a position to overrun three British or British-run territories: Kenya, British Somaliland, and Sudan. The Italians in Libya to the north and in East Africa to the south seemed furthermore poised to occupy Egypt and Sudan, in a pincer operation. This, if successful, would have severed what a contemporary official British publication aptly described as "the wasp-waist of the British Empire". The Italians in East Africa, almost entirely cut off from metropolitan Italy, and gravely weakened by the activities of the patriots, were, however, in no position to exploit the situation in their favour.

British Help for the Patriots

The first, and easiest, British response to Italy's entry into the European war was to offer assistance to the Ethiopian patriots on the borders of Sudan. The British District Officer at Gedaref, on the Sudanese side of the frontier, immediately dispatched twelve already prepared Amharic letters, written in the name of the British commander in Sudan, General Sir William Platt, to patriot chiefs of Gojjam, Armachaho, Walqayt, and Bagemder. These promised the patriots assistance in "destroying the common enemy". On 23 June 1940, Emperor Haile Sellassie was flown from England, and shortly afterwards proclaimed, on 2 July that Great Britain would grant Ethiopia "the aid of her incomparable might". The promised assistance was, however, far less than the patriots expected. Haile Sellassie, in his Autobiography, complained bitterly at its inadequacy, as well as its tardy arrival.

The Emperor's Arrival in Sudan: Wooing the Patriots

Despite such criticism British help proved of decisive importance. News of it, and of the Emperor's arrival in Sudan, had an electrifying effect. Hundreds of Ethiopians trekked across the frontier into Sudan, while many Italian colonial troops deserted.

Sandford and Wingate

The British in the months which followed continued to woo the patriots. On 12 August, a British officer, Colonel Daniel Sandford, entered Gojjam, as head of a small Ethio-British mission, Mission 101, to make contact with the patriots, and to encourage them to join together in a common struggle. Several leaders, then torn by rivalry, shortly afterwards agreed to sign a unity pact. On 20 November a more senior British officer, Major-General Orde Wingate, arrived in Gojjam by 'plane, with promises of speedy, though limited, aid. The patriots, thrilled by his coming, spoke of it as a "sign from the skies". A dynamic, if at times controversial, leader skilled in guerrilla warfare, he had earlier said to General Archibald Wavell, his superior in Cairo: "Give me a small fighting force of first-class men, and from the core of Ethiopia I will eat into the Italian apple and turn it so rotten that it will drop into our hands".

Three Almost Simultaneous Attacks

Anglo-Ethiopian cooperation bore fruit in the second half of January 1941 when the British launched three major, almost simultaneous, attacks on Italian East Africa. The first began on 19 January, when British and Indian troops under General William Platt crossed the frontier at Kassala into Eritrea. They thus began an attack which took them, with unexpected speed, via Karan, site of a fierce battle, through Eritrea into northern Tegray. The second attack, almost five hundred kilometres to the south, opened on the following day, when a much smaller force of Ethiopians, Sudanese and Britons, led by the Emperor, with Wingate and Sandford, raised the Ethiopian flag at the Ethiopian border village of Um Idla. Making contact with the patriots of Gojjam they began an advance to the Blue Nile on the road to Addis Ababa. The third attack, a thousand five hundred miles further south, started four days later, on 24 January, when British and South African soldiers, under the command of General Alan Cunningham, crossed from Kenya into Italian Somalia. They thus began an immense trek via Mogadishu and Harar to Addis Ababa, which they occupied, on 6 April. The advance to the Ethiopian capital, which had taken De Bono and Badoglio seven months in 1935-6, was thus accomplished by the Allies, with patriot help, in little more than three.

The Victories of the Patriots

The Ethiopian patriots played a major, if at the time perhaps not always sufficiently recognised, role in the Liberation campaign. Throughout their previous four year struggle they had done much to isolate, tie down, and eventually weary, the enemy. On eventually receiving British military assistance, they took the offensive and, when provided with British aerial Tsupport, swept across Gojjam to play a significant role in the capture of Burye. The advance of the Emperor's patriot army was so rapid that the British high command began to fear that Ethiopian forces might reach Addis Ababa before their British - and South African - allies, and thus endanger the safety of the city's Italian, i.e. fellow European, population. Royal Air Force support for the Patriots was for that reason no longer forthcoming

Ras Ababa Aragay

In Shawa meanwhile, the patriot leader Ras Ababa Aragay, who had fought virtually throughout the entire occupation, now strengthened his position. Addis Ababa, though guarded by Italian garrison troops protected by pill- boxes and barbed wire entanglements, was virtually surrounded by his and other patriot units. The Italians, terrified that the patriots would break into the capital, were seriously demoralised. Rather than fall into the hands of their Ethiopian enemies they hastened, on 4 April, to surrender to the South Africans, who entered the capital two days later. Central Italian resistance thus came ended. Mussolini's once triumphant army was reduced to a number of isolated, and beleaguered garrisons.

The Emperor, with the patriots, finally entered Addis Ababa, on 5 May 1941, exactly five years after Badogio's capture of the city in 1936. Patriot forces subsequently played an important role in finally "mopping up" operations throughout Ethiopia, from April to November 1941. They were prominent in the capture of many towns, among them Dase, Jemma, Gore, Dabra Tabor, and Laqamti. The patriots also took part in scaling the heights of Amba Alagi, where the Duke of Aosta surrendered, on 16 May. A South African soldier, recalling this operation, observed: "When we, the mighty white conquerors, fell down exhausted, after climbing a few hundred feet", the patriots "stared at us in amazement; that we were unable to walk unburdened while they ran with loads never failed to astonish them". The last battle of the war was fought, one more with considerable patriot help, at Gondar, which succumbed to the Allies, on 27 November 1941. Next Week: Problems of Post-War Ethiopia.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 11, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Visions of Ethiopia's Artists


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - Tibebe Terffa (far right) has thirty-five of his works on sale at the new Asni Arts Veranda in an exhibition, 'Visions of the artist' that will stay open until the end of this month.

The exhibition offers a full range of the artist's works that, whether in water colour or acrylic on cloth canvas, lean towards the abstract. Tibebe had six water colour paintings mostly done in the early '90's that deal with a verity of topics from 'Awe Woman Masked' to 'Berlin Apartment Windows'. An exceptionally displayed mixed media piece 'To Adem' is one of the highlights of the exhibition.

Tibebe's home town of Harar features prominently with two rooms dedicated to his fourteen paintings on this theme. Though the town and its people are the nucleus of the paintings, each piece offers a unique insight into the society; and a closer look will tell yet another story.

For Tibebe, a 1973 graduate of the Addis Ababa Fine Arts School, evolution is a way of life. "There are many conflicts, " he explains, "and I want to draw what is not known. This means there is motion, progress. I enjoy looking at what I don't know." Pushing himself further in search of new ways of expression probably led to his painting on the gate of the German Cultural Institute Director's house that had the whole Addis crying 'demon'. But all that this proves is the power of the artist that brings forth emotion in every individual. A less threatening but nonetheless thought provoking piece of his at Asni Arts Veranda is 'Matter of Opinion'. With its bold, fat yellow strokes it conveys message that every rebel cries at the top of his lung, " It's my life; its my choice."


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
$12m Loan for Ethiopia's Bole Airport


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Arab Bank for Economic Development of Africa, Badea, provided a $12 million loan for Bole International Airport Wednesday 9 to renovate and enlarge Ethiopia's major gateway.

The loan will begin to attract interest of 3 per cent after five years and is repayable in eighteen years. The funds will be used for the expansion and modernisation of the airport including the construction of a new runway and renovation of the existing one. The passenger terminal and air control tower will also undergo renovation. Completion of work is due in 1998.

In 1995, six international institutions, one of them Badea, loaned 110.5 million dollars for expansion of the airport. At the time of that loan, Minister of Communications and Transport Abdulmejid Hussein said 130 million was needed for the project, twenty million to be provided by Ethiopia. Wednesday's loan leaves a shortfall of 7.5 million dollars.

LANGUAGE: English

April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia, Kenya to Increase Border Law


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Addis Ababa - At the end of the 16th Ethio-Kenya joint border meeting, administrators of both countries agreed to enhance co-operation to control illicit trade in firearms and drugs. Cross border raids and looting was also an area where increased law enforcement was agreed upon. Reviving radio communication between police and security officials at border posts was one measure to be taken.

On March 22, a border incident resulted in theft and loss of life. A fact- finding team is to be dispatched to the affected areas 14th April, reported ENA.

Voluntary repatriation of Ethiopian refugees from Kenya was said to be successful and the Kenyans expressed willingness to accept Kenyan refugees in Kenya. The next yearly border and administrators meeting is scheduled for April 1998 in Kenya.

April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Greek Archbishop Congratulates Italy on Decision to Return Obelisk


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Addis Ababa - Greek Archbishop Methodios Fouyas, a member of the International Academy of Religion and former Greek Archbishop of Aksum, has written to the Italian Deputy Foreign Minister, Rino Serri, congratulating the Italian Government on its recent decision to return the Aksum obelisk looted on the personal orders of the fascist dictator Benito Mussolini almost sixty years ago.

In his letter, Archbishop Methodios writes of his "great pleasure that the Obelisk is to be returned to Ethiopia", and congratulates the Italian Government on "its most wise and noble decision". 

"Such decisions", the Archbishop declares, "play an important role in fostering good relations between nations, in redressing the wrongs of the past, and in restoring confidence in the integrity of the international community as a whole".

The return of the Obelisk, he concludes, "will be noted, not only in Europe and Africa but throughout the world, as a token of the determination of the people of Italy to continue to play a significant role in promoting healing amongst the nations, so necessary for the futire progress of mankind. May I express the hope that positive and speedy action will be taken to put this enlightened decision to practical effect".


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


345 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopians are Voting with their Feet


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Ethiopian Diaspora is quite large, the one in the United States, arguably the most favoured destination, is the largest contingent and is estimated by some at 350,000.

A large number of Ethiopians are also to be found in Canada, Europe and Australia.

The hearts and minds of the youth of the nation, especially those of the relatively well-off and well-educated, are in America and the other magnetic destinations mentioned. Ask any nice-looking, neatly dressed, relatively well- fed and well-educated Ethiopian youth what his or her plans for the future are, the inevitable answers would be: going to America, getting a green card there, finding a job to earn money in US dollars and partly paying the way through college. 

So, the talk of such Ethiopian youths is almost boringly always about DV's passports, visas, green cards, friends and relatives in the United States, letters, postcards, pictures and parcels received from their friends and relatives abroad, US and European cities, high-schools and colleges, and money remittance received in US dollars, etc. Some appear to be far better acquainted with places in the US and Canada than in their own country.

The scramble of the youth to fill in the so-called DV's issued annually by the United States Embassy here for a chance to emigrate to the "land of promise and opportunity" reflects more than just a desire to seek one's fortune abroad. It seems to be also a symptom of some nondescript malaise that is driving these youngsters out of their country. The looks on their faces fomented by their greedy avidity to fill in the DV's show no sign of an intention to return home if they are lucky enough to be among the 300-5000 annual winners of the US immigration lottery for Ethiopia!

But why do these youths want to leave the country in large droves? One reason is that most of their relatives and friends who have made it to the US and other favoured destinations in the past have done quite well both economically and educationally. They know this from the inward US-dollar remittances which work wonders here when converted into birr at official current exchange rates of upwards of 6.60 per US dollar as against only 2.07 previously; and from the good English in the correspondence they receive from aboard. This then is the pull factor. The push factor is that the opportunity for good education and well-paying job here in Ethiopia is only about one in a thousand, forcing the youth to vote with their feet!

The Ethiopian youth seem to be fed up with the squalor all around them. They once scarified their own lives to improve the lot of the masses. It now looks as if it was all to no avail. It seems that it is now time to save their own skins. Besides, they don't like the divisive politics currently in vogue in the country. In fact, most members especially females, of the younger generation don't even want to discuss politics at all. A typical female Ethiopian youth yawns widely at the mention of any political subject. She would much rather talk about the nice photo of her sister in America, which shows her as putting on quite a lot of weight. "What is it that they are eating in America", she would rather ponder!

Squalid economic conditions, high unemployment, extremely low wages and salaries, ethnicity polarizing domestic politics, are driving the Ethiopian youth and the educated out of the country. All this is very bad for Ethiopia. We are losing the best and brightest of our people. It wouldn't have mattered if these people were leaving the country for only a few years, with the intention of coming back home after getting all the good education and greenbacks they aspired for.

The problem is that hardly any of them return on a permanent basis. They may come to visit relatives and friends and places in Ethiopia they like, but most return abroad with perhaps greater resolve to stay there longer, maybe never to return home except for occasional visits. The country's loss of human resources in this way is far greater than the size of the Ethiopian Diaspora would indicate. It is usually the most able-bodied, energetic, intelligent and relatively best-educated and experienced Ethiopians that emigrate, seriously eroding the equality of Ethiopia's population stock.

Yes, you've guessed it right! It is a massive brain drain. It is more than that. It is a physique-drain, a beauty-drain and a leg-drain (as in the case of soccer players!). But who is going to solve all the myriad political, economic and social problems here in Ethiopia? who is going to make us feel that we are all the same, old, proud Ethiopian compatriots trying to have our rightful place in the world, not an unwieldy conglomeration of individuals pigeonholed into separate ethnic identities? Who is going to create 500,000 new jobs every year? Who is going to do something effective about the country's social problems such as widespread begging, child prostitution, street dwelling, juvenile delinquency and crime; and about the plight of the disabled and the elderly and about gender problems?

The prospects for success in all these problems areas have become all the dimmer with the kind of brain and talent drain that Ethiopia has been experiencing for well over twenty years now. The question therefore would be: is there anything effective we can do to reverse the exodus? The answer could be an optimistic yes if we are willing to take the following measures:

* improve the political climate by changing the political leitmotif from ethnic politics to Ethiopian politics, which embraces the former as well as several other things;

* unleash the economy's potential by liberating land, nationalized physical capital and credit from the fetters of state monopoly and control, and bureaucratic inefficiency;

* be willing to share political and economic decision-making power with prospectively returning Ethiopian professionals on a merit-system basis.

Otherwise, the cream of the Ethiopian society will continue to vote with its feet, leaving behind a virtually brainless community of zombies, good enough to perform only elementary biological functions such as eating, sleeping and procreating even as resources become ever more scarce! And what is worse, in the absence of the best and brightest, the pets of society take control!


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


346 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Nominations Needed for 'Africa Prize for Leadership'


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - The eleventh annual Africa Prize for Leadership for the Sustainable End of Hunger will be presented at a ceremony in New York on 4 October 1997.

The prize honours African women and men who have exhibited exceptional leadership in bringing about the sustainable end of the persistence of hunger at national, regional or continent-wide level. 

The prize focuses on individuals working in areas such as public policy, science, agriculture, education and health -- whose leadership and policies reflect courage, initiative, creativity and, in some cases, personal sacrifice.

Past winners include the presidents of Senegal, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Ghana and Namibia. In 1994 Nelson Mandela was the recipient, and in 1991, Maryam Ibrahim Babangida received the prize for her role in programmes for women in Nigeria, along with Prof. Wangari Muta Maathai who founded the Green Belt Movement which has employed 50,000 women in planting more than 10,000 trees in Kenya.

Ultimately, the prize is intended to engender a greater appreciation for and support of the effective and dynamic leadership associated with the end of hunger in Africa on a sustainable basis.

In addition to receiving the Africa Prize sculpture, the winners share a US$100,000 award intended to advance their work for the end of hunger.

Addis Tribune has been approached to submit nominations for the Africa Prize. We invite suggestions from our readers to be sent to us. Nominations must reach New York by 15 May 1997.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Ethiopia;
Operation Relieves Woman of 18 kg


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 120 words


 

Addis Ababa - A thirty-year-old woman's weight dropped 18 kg after a two- hour long operation that resulted in physicians removing from her uterus a 9kg tumour and equal amount of liquid substance. 

Doctors currently overseeing the recovery of the woman--married and mother of three--at the Felege Hiwot Hospital in Bahre Dar were quoted by ENA as saying that the tumour and substance probably had been in her body from four to eight years. The woman is said to have felt pain a year ago.

The disease is common in the area, ENA reported.

Ethiopia;
990 Raped in Past Six Months


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 134 words


 

Addis Ababa - Around 990 women and girls have been raped in the country in just the last six months--as opposed 1067 in whole of last year-- bringing the level to a previously unknown high, police reported. 

Of the total, 68 cases were in the capital Addis Ababa, ENA said. Only 655 of the victims--over half of them children-- reported the crime to the police but most kept silent apparently because of the social taboos. Most of the victims are said to be aged between 16 and 18, with those between 19 and 30 as well as those under 15 also likely targets. The criminals in most cases are aged between 19-30 and operate either individually or in groups.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


349 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
SPEAKING OF PEOPLE: Yacob Bekele


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Addis Ababa - Working to Put the 'Customer' in his Right Place of Honour

Walk into a clinic or hospital in this country and you are made to feel by the staff that you are definitely not supposed to be there. So stifling your groans you look apologetically at them, pay up and wait meekly until you are called in to see the doctor. These are not the only places where you pay to be treated as dirt. From the smallest spare parts store to the largest government or private institution (where the harassment as a rule starts with the guard at the gate) the concept of 'customer service' it is unknown. 

So it is understandable if when you meet the general manager of Ethiopia Clinic you find it a bit hard to believe that treating customers with courtesy is high on their agenda . Bubbling with good humour, Yacob Bekele is one of those people you feel comfortable with nearly as soon as the introductions are over. Sitting behind his desk in a tidy office--despite the piles of books on topics as behaviour science and business & strategic management--Yacob explains that is rare to find a health institution where one is treated cordially. That is why Ethiopia Clinic's 20 staff members make sure they are the exception to the rule.

Born in the early 40's, Yacob Bekele, now studying through correspondence for his Doctor of business administration (he cannot wait to also become a 'doctor' he jokes), has held numerous managerial posts before setting up the clinic with two other friends. He spent ten years at the Ethiopian Airlines, mostly in the Addis Ababa Sales region . Among his numerous contributions to the organization, Yacob counts the introduction of a sales tool 'golden lion club' and the wearing of traditional dresses by the female hostesses alongside the usual uniform. He then moved to a travel agency for some four years then became the front office manager in the Ras Hotel.

When demonstrations began in the country a couple of years before the 1974 revolution asking for the "removal of the bosses" Yacob decided to join Sudan Airways.

Soon after though disputes broke out between Ethiopia and Sudan and the latter's ticket office closed down. He found work at the Ethiopian textile enterprise but after just four months decided that this was no fun and went to work for the newly established Kenya Airways. "After we had done much to establish it," Yacob recalls, "I had children by this time and so felt a sense of responsibility I said to myself 'What if one day Arap Moi and Mengistu quarrel will it not mean the closure of Kenya Airways office here ?. ' So he opted for a dependable paycheck and joined the Ministry of Industry. Four years later he moved to the Desta Soft drinks factory as general manager then to the newly set up brewery.

Yacob seemed destined to head one organization after another as he again moved to Gas and Plastic Factory where he worked for six years and was one of those behind the move to expand the production line to include plastic chairs in addition to bottle cases . From 1990-91 he was general manager of Coca Cola factory during which time they managed, among other things, to make operational again the CO2 plant he noted. Following the change in government in 1991, Yacob was retired like many people who had served for twenty years and were over forty-five.

It is only to be expected that someone who has held posts of responsibility in different organizations -- and recalls offhand a couple of achievements at each place--has the stamina to pick up the pieces and get on with life.

Yacob Bekele, married and father of eight, is know one of the founders of Galaxy Tour Agency as well as Ethiopia Clinic (located within his residential compound) .

The clinic which is open round the clock and offers the full list of services including pediatrics, minor surgery, E.N.T., gynecology etc... treats an average of 25 patients a day. With a sense of community, Ethiopia Clinic also gives free medical care to around thirty-two low income individuals from the kebele, Yacob and Dr. Mulugeta Haile Mariam, one of the staff explains. This is not confined to this group as the highly publicized announcement recently regarding a year's offer of free medical treatment for the Ethiopian Olympic committee shows. However, Supplying free medical care to the Olympic team (although a great way of satisfying the nationalistic feeling, not to mention the publicity), Yacob also participates actively in improving the sport nearest to his heart--football. His recent proposal to improve the game--with the introduction of such things as awarding teams for best behaviour as well as best goal scorer etc..-- has sparked interest both within the sport commission and the public.

Yacob is happy to give a tour of the place proudly with the various treatment rooms and waiting rooms. The rooms are enough to give one a sense of peace as they are in more cases than not equipped with state of the art equipment and all equipped with a sink ( "we believe in water" is simply how he explains indicating that along with the courtesy accorded to every patient, Ethiopia Clinic has many passions it follows diligently). We walk into the laboratory and Yacob points to what he noted was one of the first batch of the latest photo-meter (to test blood chemistry) in the country.

The staff are eager to show off their equipment and insist on a demonstration so I choose to have my glucose level tested--which thankfully turned out normal .


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


350 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Meles Asked to Secure Release of Private Journalists


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Addis Ababa - French-based independent organisation working to defend press freedom world-wide, Reporter Sans Frontieres, issued 7 April a letter to Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, protesting against the arrest of journalists and, "the continued detention of others."

Reporter Sans Frontieres wrote that on 24 February Atnafu Alemayehu, editor- in-chief of the privately owned Amharic weekly Tomar, along with Kidist Belachew and Tesihalene Mengiesha, former editor-in-chief and shareholder of the privately owned Amharic weekly A'emrio and Mebruk respectively were arrested. This was, according to the letter, "in connection with news they had published in late 1995 disclosing the relations between a Muslim relief organisation named Blessed Relief and Sudanese religious leaders Hassien Al Turabi and Mohammed Sirage." Kidist Belachew was released on the same day and Tesihalene Mengisha on 14 March after paying bail of 5,000 birr as set by the Federal High Court, but the third journalist was unable to post bail and remains at the Addis Ababa Central Jail, Reporters Sans Frontieres revealed. 

"Without wishing to comment on the facts of these cases," the letter to the prime minister continued, "Reporters Sans Frontieres reminds you that the United Nations Commission on Human Rights considers that detention, as punishment for the peaceful expression of opinion, is one of the most reprehensible ways to enjoin silence and, as a consequence, a grave violation of human rights".

Moreover, Ethiopia has ratified the International (convention) on Civil and Political Rights, article 19 of which guarantees the freedom to inform and be informed, Reporters Sans Frontieres asks you to fulfill your obligations towards the international community..."

Reporters Sans Frontieres specifically asked for the release of Atnafu Alemayehu and the "immediate and unconditional release" of six journalists and one publisher from the private Amharic papers. These are Salomon Gebre- Amlak former editor-in-chief of Mogad,(two years) Alemu Lemma of Mebrek (two years), Dereje Biru editor of Tequami (one year), Sintayehu Abate editor-in- chief of Remet (already completed his one year prison sentence), Lulu Kebede editor-in-chief of Neka (six months), Kassahun Tadesse editor-in-chief of Genanaw (one-and- half- years) and Wesson Seged Mersha publisher of Kitab (six months).

The letter closed with a plea for Prime Minister Meles, "to use your influence to secure the lifting of the detention order against Assefa Beyene, editor-in-chief of Ethiop and Samson Seyum, editor-in-chief of Tequami and grant them a fair trial."

Prime Minister Meles has spoken against the Private press on several occasions questioning their integrity.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Dismissals Within Ruling Party


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa - Dismissals in the various member parties of the ruling Ethiopian Peoples' Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) have continued with the Oromo People's Democratic Organisation (OPDO) kicking out 250 and placing 80 of its members under custody.

The government owned English daily Ethiopian Herald reported that action was taken against the above at a recent appraisal meeting where their performance was apparently evaluated against such yard sticks as use of political power, respect of human rights and nurturing democratic Tnationalism. 

On 24 October last year, Tamrat Layne became the highest official to be ousted from power when a similar appraisal meeting ended with his removal from the Amhara National Democratic Movement (ANDM)--a coalition of the EPRDF- - and subsequently from the post of Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence for "gross misconduct". Just four months after Tamrat Layne was sacked; the OPDO issued a clear signal that its members were going to feel the heat next.

LANGUAGE: English

352 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Airforce Celebrates 50th Anniversary


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - The fifty year old Ethiopian Airforce last week celebrated the first annual day celebration since the fall of the previous government of Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam in 1991.

In the three-day celebration that lasted until Friday 4 April, Deputy PM and Defence Minister Tefera Walwa opened an exhibition showing the airforce's history, and awarded diplomas to graduating pilots and technicians. He also held a panel discussion that focused on the role of the airforce in the present society.

In his comments during the panel discussion, he remarked, "The army's contribution has been particularly conspicous in protecting the development process from anti-development elements" government-owned English daily Ethiopian Herald reported, but failed to clarify what these "anti-development elements" are.

The celebration's 50th anniversary angle, though played down by government media on the most part, was however highlighted by the Amharic-language programme of Voice of Germany whose correspondent was quick to point out the leading role played by the airforce in the past--especially during the Ethio- Somalia war of the late 1970's.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Faster Response Urged for Drought Victims


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Addis Ababa - Donors have been called upon to speed up the response to the appeal for emergency relief food aid for people affected by drought in the south and southeastern parts of the country.

The Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission (DPPC) said Friday 4 that the response to appeals it made in February was not satisfactory. They added that relief food is being transported to the area from its own reserve.

The commission is supplying 33,842 metric tonnes of food out of the 99,575 mt. required. Save the Children UK has pledged 10,000 metric tonnes, other donors however have fallen short of the appeal.

A number of water tanks have been secured from NGOs and the German government, this is still 30 per cent below the required figure, said DPPC. They added that 4.2 million US dollars is needed to sink thirty deep wells and 45 shallow, as well as to prepare 60 traditional water sources and strengthen the supply throughout the affected areas.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Alemaya University Students on Fourth Day of Boycott


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa - Student boycott of classes has gone into its fourth day at the Alemaya University of Agriculture (AUA) without any apparent break.

Efforts to get in touch with the authorities at the AUA in Harar proved fruitless with the university's liaison office here in Addis only indicating that as far as they knew the boycott seemed to be by the whole student body-- totalling over 2,000. 

The boycott was first reported by ENA, which explained that it was brought on as a protest over the quality of AUA's cuisine.

AUA's president Dr. Desta Hamito was reported by ENA to have said that the students' monthly ration had been doubled to 120 birr/person--and if still not satisfied they could easily have lodged their complaints about the food through the right channels while still attending classes.

As we go to press, nursing students at the Zewditu Hospital are on their second day of class boycott protesting that the 120 birr ration was inadequate, Radio Fana reported.

Addis Tribune could find no one in the hospital who could confirm or deny the report.

April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
PM Meles Visit Gives Obelisk Question Momentum


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa - Prime Minister Meles Zenawi will be returning home tomorrow, Saturday 12 April, after conducting a five-day working visit to Italy with a high level delegation of senior government officials and over seventy Ethiopian exporters.

During his stay, Prime Minister Meles spoke with the chairman of the Italian parliament on the current situation in Ethiopia and future co- operation between the two countries especially between their parliaments. A statement was also issued by the two countries relaying the message that an agreement has been reached revealing that long awaited return of the Aksum obelisk will be a reality by the end of this year. Ethiopia has also offered to present Italy with a monument in place of the obelisk taken from its country in 1937 and placed in Rome.

Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin and his Italian counterpart also signed an agreement relating to investment guarantees, halting double taxation and promoting road and bridge construction, ENA reported.

Africa News


April 11, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
LETTER TO THE EDITOR: "What is Happening at ECA"


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Addis Ababa - It is really disappointing to see heaps of ECA documents and important publications being thrown away each day into the garbage. Some of the very useful material printed in bulk is just being shredded. Imagine the costs of printing, publishing, etc. involved!!

Mind you, very recent documents published in 1996 containing some vital information is also being shredded. I am shocked to see the state of affairs, when the UN is going through some economic reform. Some of these documents and publications could have been given to several institutions and universities in Africa rather than being thrown away or shredded. I brought some diplomats from the US and other embassies to witness this operation and they were really stunned!!

An ECA concerned staff employee (Name withheld)


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
