357 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Science and Health;
Ethiopia's Health Matters (Editorial)


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Addis Ababa - The availability of medical care both in quantity and quality is going from bad to worse in Ethiopia. This may be the time to examine how the existing development strategies and policies of Ethiopia can be strengthened to protect and improve the health status of the people, and bring health objectives into the center of current development. 

As the World Health Organization (WHO) would say, health must become an integral part of the political, social and economic issues which are emerging as the current major priorities of development policy makers.

Equity of access to health care, with special reference to the poor and marginalized, such as the rural and urban poor, the unemployed, women, children, youth, the elderly, is basic to development strategies aiming at social justice.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


358 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
20,000 Turn out to Protest Land Reform, Rent Hikes, Arrests


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - The All Amhara People's Organisation (AAPO) called a mass rally at Meskel Square Sunday 6 April to address the issue of the peasant farmers, students, business community and political prisoners.

Approximately 20,000 turned up Sunday morning-- despite the kebele (suburb) meetings scheduled that day as well as a football match on television--to listen to speeches of a peasant farmer, a student and a businessman. 

The demonstrators protested against the land reform in the Amhara region that has left farmers with previous links with the past two governments, a plot of land about one hectare--regardless of family size.

A call was made for the immediate release of all university students still being held after taking part in a demonstration 21 March against land redistribution in Amhara region. According to the Ethiopian Human Rights Council (EHRCO) around seventeen of the 200 initially arrested are at present detained. Addis Tribune tried to contact the police but has been unable to find out when they will appear in court.

The business community also used the occasion to voice their bitterness over rent increases imposed some eight months ago on kebele-owned business premises that the representative explained in detail as "illegal". The more recent rent calculation of 85-100 birr per square meter issued on business premises owned by the Ethiopian Orthodox Church.

The four-hour gathering--given an aura of divinity by the sudden appearance of a rainbow--also called for the release of all political prisoners including AAPO's president Professor Asrat Woldeyes who has been in prison since June 1995.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


359 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Science and Health;
The Grim Picture of Health Care in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

Addis Ababa - H.E. Dr. Kebede Tadesse, Minister in the Prime Minister's office in charge of social and Administrative Affairs, disclosed in his address to the Consultative Group Meeting, held here in Addis in December of last year, the following major features of Ethiopia's health sector:

"Ethiopia has one of the worst health statuses in the world. This is mainly due to the backward socio-economic development resulting in a low standard of living, poor environmental conditions and inadequate health services. The prevailing social conditions have been aggravated in recent years by the high fertility rate and repeated man-made and natural disasters. Infectious diseases and nutritional disorders are widespread. Among the predominantly preventable diseases, upper respiratory infections, diarrhea, malaria, tuberculosis and sexually transmitted diseases, including AIDS, are major problems. The top killing diseases at the moment are malaria and tuberculosis. Health institutions are few and unevenly distributed and their facilities and manpower inadequate, resulting in efficient and ineffective services. There are often shortages of drugs and medical supplies in most of the health institutions. Though the main direction of health was purported to be primary health care organized in a six-tiered system, in practice priority is given to curative rather than to preventive and promotive care. The referral system hardly works and is one of the reasons for the inefficient service and patient dissatisfaction at referral hospitals." 

The health care situation in Addis Ababa fully confirms Dr. Kebede's honest statements about health conditions in Ethiopia in general. This confirmation becomes all the more striking when one remembers that Addis Ababa, being the capital of the nation, has, in relative terms, the most health facilities. Go to any public hospital in Addis and what you observe is more than just disconcerting: the crowds of sick people trying to get cards or to see doctors are legion; the buildings are crumbling; malodors buffet your nostrils from all directions; it is not uncommon to see seriously ill people lying helplessly in corridors; blood splashed on the floors of corridors may be seen; hospital beds are rickety and in most cases unclean; bed sheets may be stained with blood and pus that remain because of inadequate washing; the food is unspeakably insipid and uninviting.

One can talk about hospital bed sheets and food only if one is lucky enough to get a hospital bed in the first place. Many seriously ill people are forced to go back home to their deaths because of the shortage of hospital beds. Doctors, nurses, dressers and lab technicians all seem to be negligent and uncaring because of heavy work loads and insufficient remuneration. Human agony and death have become routine occurrences that have stopped eliciting any visible measure of human sympathy any more. Women in labour are sometimes jeered at with: " You ought to have thought twice before putting your legs up!" Human callousness reaches its height with blistering remarks such as this upon somebody's death: " the world is better off by one parasite less."

That obviously is a very unkind remark, but clearly shows the extent of the human predicament of being taken ill in Addis and elsewhere in the country and of having to go to a public hospital there. Cases have been reported of power cuts in the middle of surgical operations which had to be delayed until the electricity was on again because of the absence of automatically activated stand-by generators. The medical equipment in nearly all the public hospitals is hopelessly outdated and for the most part out of order. Many a patient is told to seek medical treatment abroad precisely because the equipment required to perform an examination is non-existent in the country. Negligence on the part of medical staff runs the whole gamut from prescribing the wrong medicine, and thus sometimes causing death, to the extreme case of forgetting a scalpel in a person's abdomen on which an operation has just been performed! And what is more, there seems to be no legal liability for such gross negligence.

Health problems in the country are further compounded by the ever rising prices of pharmaceutical products. Price deregulation and exchange rate depreciation have been two of the major factors behind the price rises here. It is not uncommon for the price of a medicine which cost only about 2 birr some seven to eight years ago to cost more than 30 birr now! Countless patients in Addis and elsewhere in Ethiopia cannot afford the prices of pharmaceuticals! Access to health services for the poor has gone from bad to worse.

The above account may seem a little exaggerated, but when one sees the ever increasing frequency of the health problems cited, every word said is absolutely true. There is no doubt that a lot of people do manage to see doctors and have the proper medicines prescribed for them and do actually get better. However, the point is that the number of patients who are not so lucky is increasing rapidly, thus making the health problems cited above much more frequent and visible than was the case in the past.

Also, mention should be made of the sizeable number of private clinics and the few private hospitals that have been put up. These have definitely contributed to relieving the pressure on public hospitals, but for one thing many private clinics have been shut down on charges of sub-standard facilities and, for another, the private hospitals set up, apart from being few and far between, are far too expensive for the average patient.

Further, private clinics can only handle minor health cases as they do not have the necessary medical facilities, which is in fact why they are called clinics. In addition, fees at private clinics are also beyond the reach of most patients in the country. This latter problem is further complicated by the frequent practice of some private medical personnel of ordering additional prescriptions and medical examinations which, strictly speaking, are not necessary, the intention being to generate more income and sales for themselves and friends in the pharmacy business. This is a case of pecuniary interests taking precedence over the " Hippocratic oath".

Ethiopia's health profile is one of the darkest on the African continent. Just take a look at the following statistical highlights most of which were taken from Dr. Kebede's speech, on the country's health status:

1. Average daily per capita energy intake

1750 calories (i.e. 80 percent of required amount)

2. Children showing wasting 5 %

3. Children who are stunted 64 %

4. Pregnant and lactating mothers with anemia 17 %

5. Average national fertility rate 6.1%

6. Aids cases per 100,000 people 10.7 %

7. Access to drinkable water 18 %

8. Attended births 14 %

9. Health coverage 35 - 45%

10. People who receive antenatal care 16%

11. Population receiving immunization 40%

12. Population receiving family planning service 8 %

13. infant mortality rate per 1000 live births 130

14. Maternal mortality rate per 100,000 live births 500-700

15. Inhabitants per physician 33,333

16. Life expectancy at birth 48

What is to be done? That is a billion-birr question and no honest person can claim to have all the answers. Some basic principles and guidelines could be attempted, however. First, prevention is better than cure. The population at large should be taught that many diseases could be prevented by maintaining good hygiene standards.

In its barest essentials, this involves no more than boiling water before drinking, cleaning one's home, compound and environment, using soap and water to keep one's personal hygiene, and disposing of human and other waste in a timely and regular manner; second, as one of the major causes of the country's health problems is population pressure, popularizing the advantages of family planning should be undertaken with real commitment on the part of the relevant government institutions; third, the central government and regional administrations should continue to increase their health budgets in order to be able to construct institutions at a pace commensurate with the overall demand for health services, targeting widespread diseases such as malaria and tuberculosis for special attention; fourth, the private sector should continue to be encouraged to invest in the health sector as it could relieve the pressure on public health institutions, especially the pressure coming from those who can afford higher medical costs; fifth, as water-borne diseases account for a large number of the illnesses in the country, the provision of potable water for the population at large, especially for the rural population, should be given high priority in the government's capital expenditure; sixth, attempts should be made to make domestic conditions favouable so that Ethiopian doctors abroad may return home both as investors in the private health sector and as medical practitioners in public and private hospitals and clinics. Well, it may now sound like an uphill task to try and come up with workable solutions to the enormous health problems in Ethiopia, but with a thorough understanding of these problems and real commitment, a start towards a genuine breakthrough can be made right today!


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


360 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1997


Tanzania;
Tanzania News Roundup


BYLINE: Tanzania News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Dar es Salaam - 5m Project to Improve Mwanza Airport

Mwanza airport, a potentially vital component of an air bridge to vast areas of western and northern Tanzania and, more crucially, to Burundi, Rwanda, Uganda and Zaire, is to undergo major improvements so it can accommodate medium-size aircraft.

In the last two weeks consultants from two companies have been engaged to recommend "the most urgent needs", to make the airport accessible and safe for most aircraft, The East African newspaper reported recently. Results of the studies by M. Consult and Scott & Wilson are expected within three months.

The First Counsellor of the European Union in Dar es Salaam, Mr. Alfred Lamers, said the EU, the project financier, had allocated $5 million for the more urgent work at the airport in Mwanza, a provincial on the southern shores of Lake Victoria. 

2. Experts Move in as Flood Havoc Hits Tanzania

A TEAM of experts, including United Nations officials, will fly over Tanzania's southern Lindi Region this week to assess the damage caused by floods which had claimed 46 lives and made 2,000 people homeless by last Friday. The team will establish the amount of relief aid required.

Mr Evarist Kweba, Director of Relief and Rescue Services in the Prime Minister's Office, said representatives of the United Nations Development Programme, the World Food Programme and the Ministry of Health would assess the situation by helicopter. Floods have cut off the region from the rest of the country.

3. Tanzania Coffee Farmers to Get $11.6m from EU

Tanzania's coffee farmers will receive a total of Tsh 7.1 billion ($11.6 million) - roughly $27 each from the European Union in direct compensation within the next two months for the loss they incurred from exports of their 1992/93 crop.

According to an aid agreement between the European Union and Tanzania, which was signed last Friday in Dar es Salaam by Europe's Head of Delegation, Mr Peter Christiansen, and the Minister for Agriculture, Mr Paul Kimiti, 420, 000 individual farmers in 600 primary co-operative societies will receive the cash.

Beneficiaries of the compensation will mostly be growers of mild Arabic coffee around the Kilimanjaro and Arusha regions in the north, Mbeya and Ruvuma in the south and the Robusta coffee growers in the Kagera region west of Lake Victoria.

4. Dar, Kampala committed to Tanga-Musoma rail

Tanzania and Uganda yesterday renewed their commitment to build the proposed Tanga-Arusha-Musoma railway line which has been on the drawing board for several years due to lack of funds.

A joint statement issued at the end of the recent five-day visit to Tanzania of Uganda's Premier, Mr Kintu Musoke said the two countries also vowed to implement the proposed Dar es Salaam-Mwanza oil pipeline project.

The Kyotera-Mutukula-Mwanza project was also among priorities that the two countries want to be implemented as soon as possible to speed up economic development.

5. NBC privatisation tenders in July

The Minister for Finance, Mr Daniel Yona, has said that tenders for privatisation of the National Bank of Commerce (NBC) will most likely be floated in July, this year.

Mr Yona said this at the weekend in Dar es Salaam when asked to comment on the progress so far made to implement government's decision to privatise NBC.

"Remarkable progress has been made towards privatisation. The appointed foreign and local consultants are doing a commendable job," the minister said.

6. IPC approves 50 projects

The Investment Promotion Centre (IPC) committee this week approved over 50 local and foreign projects worth billions of shillings to be undertaken in eight different sectors, it has been learnt.

Sources close to IPC told the Daily News over the weekend that the committee met under its chairman Dr. M. Kipokola who is also the Principal Secretary in the Ministry of Energy and Minerals.

7. 200 biogas tanks installed in Tanga, Morogoro

A Morogoro-based non-governmental organisation has installed 200 plastic biodigesters in different households in both Morogoro and Tanga regions, reducing the use of charcoal in the households by 50 per cent.

The organisation, called the Foundation for Sustainable Rural Development (SURUDE), has also managed to increase awareness on environmental conservation and sustainable development among the rural people in the regions.

8. Special prayers to remember Rwanda victims

Special prayers for victims of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda were held at Saint Joseph's Cathedral in Dar es Salaam on Monday, April 7, the Rwandan Embassy has announced.

The Rwandan Ambassador to Tanzania, Mukanyange Joy used the occasion to condemn the genocide which she said was a shame to Africans.

9. Govt is misinformed on environmental effect of Rufiji prawns project

There has been environmental misinformation to the government by the proposed Rufiji Delta Prawns Project, the Journalists Environmental Association of Tanzania (JET) has said.

Meeting in the city last week for their annual general meeting, JET members accused investors in the proposed multi-million dollars Rufiji prawns farm project and senior government officials of misinforming the Vice-President on the project's pros and cons on the environment.

10. Dar Varsity students start planting flowers at the Hill

Students at the University of Dar es Salaam have started environmental conservation activities by beautifying the campus by planting flowers.

The areas involved included the halls of residence. But the activities will be extended to cover the entire campus, nearby villages and the community at large.

To contact or subscribe to Tanzania News Online, email: AfricaNN@inform-bbs. dk.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


361 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 13, 1997


Science and Health;
Meningitis in West Africa


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Geneva - As at 11 April, a total of 41 699 cases of meningitis with 4498 deaths had been reported in Africa. These were mainly from countries in West Africa where epidemics have continued to occur. 

Burkina Faso with 16 775 cases and 1953 deaths accounted for 40% of the cases reported this year,

Ghana with 13 063 and 1191 deaths for 31% and

Mali with 6 119 cases and 587 deaths for 15%.

Cases were also reported in:

Benin (273 cases, 47 deaths),

Gambia (856 cases, 119 deaths),

Niger (1813 cases, 587 deaths),

Rwanda (13 cases, 4 deaths),

Senegal (13 cases, 4 deaths), and

Togo (2619 cases, 360 deaths).

Gambia, Ghana and Togo were less affected during the 1996 epidemics when Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger and Nigeria reported widespread outbreaks. Burkina Faso reported 42 129 cases, Mali 7254 and Niger 16 145 cases in 1996.

Nigeria, which reported 77 089 cases in 1996, has not yet reported cases during 1997.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

363 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Africa University Students Suspended


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1318 words


 

MUTARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Over 250 students at Africa University, about 15 kilometers (9.3 miles) north of Mutare, were suspended on Monday, following an eleven-day lecture boycott prompted by a 17-percent hike in student fees.

The students met on Monday morning and resolved to issue a 48-hour ultimatum to the chairman of the institution's board of directors, Bishop Emelio de Cavalho, to address them over the fee increase dispute but were surprised to receive letters of suspension in the afternoon.

However, 33 post-graduate students studying for Masters degree in Business Administration (MBA) were not suspended as they resumed classes on Monday morning in preparation for their final year examinations in October.

On April 3, Africa University's board of directors approved an increase in student fees from the current ZD 33,000 (USD 3,000) to ZD 38,500 (USD 3,500) with effect from August. 

The students objected to the increase which the administration said was the first ever since the institution opened its doors in 1992, claiming they came from poor families and would not afford such exorbitant hikes.

Their lecture boycott started soon after the announcement of fee increase and all efforts to resolve the issue failed as students remained adamant that they wanted an audience with de Cavalho.

The administration was unmoved on its stance that de Cavalho could not be summoned by students, instead they should wait for his response to their petition over the fee increases.

The students then decided to issue an ultimatum to the administration on Monday morning and the administration responded by issuing suspension letters in the afternoon.

At 14.00 hours, the university vice-chancellor, Dr. John Kurewa, served the students notices which gave them five days to apply for re-admission. This would be effected only when it met the conditions set by the vice-chancellor.

Among the set conditions was that the applicant should give a written undertaking to pay all the university fees as recently determined by the institution and submit to any disciplinary process the authorities might decide to pursue.

The students said they were finding it difficult to understand why the administration set such conditions as their main complaint was that they could not afford the high fees.

Describing the decision by the administration as cruel and insensitive, some students said they would not seek re-admission as it was practically difficult for them to raise the required fees. The suspended students, majority of them Zimbabweans, were given two hours in which to pack their belonging and leave the campus. Some students were seen walking to Mutare city with their property on their backs while others boarded minibuses hired by the students representative council.

Some foreign students told the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency (ZIANA) they were going to spend the night on the streets as they had nowhere to go, but the president of the students representative council, Sam Mhlanga, said the suspended students were going to the Manicaland provincial governor, Kenneth Manyonda's office.

"We are going to spend the night at the governor's office. We will not go anywhere else as we have foreign students here who have nowhere to go.

"We need government's intervention because the problem is now out of hand. The administration does not want to solve our problems. All it wants to see is us going back to classes," he said.

Over 50 armed support unit police officers were sent to the campus at 14.00 hours (12H00 GMT) to ensure all the suspended students, who have been very peaceful in their lecture boycott and demonstrations, left the campus without destroying property.

In a statement, Africa University Director of Information, Andra Stevens, said the administration suspended the students to restore order at the institution. She said those students who wished to continue with their studies were being disturbed by the lecture boycott by other students and were now given the opportunity to continue their studies in peace.

However, Mhlanga said the students were surprised by the administration's decision to suspend them. He said students expected the Kurewa administration to facilitate dialogue between students and de Cavalho.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


364 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Science and Health;
Renowned Ethiopian Scientist Laid To Rest


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The funeral of a leading Ethiopian scientist, Dar Aklilu Lema, who died at the age of 63 in Baltimore, U.S.A on April 5, took place in Addis Ababa on Monday. The late Dr. Aklilu is credited with the discovery, research, and development and application of an Ethiopian soap- berry plant (endod) into a drug for the control of schistosomiasis or bilharzia.

"His perseverance and scientific career over a period of 30 years won him numerous awards and international recognition," said part of his biography, read at the funeral, attended by numerous mourners, including senior government officials and diplomats. Dr. Aklilu who was born in Jijiga town, Eastern Ethiopia in 1934. After obtaining his first degree at the University of Addis Ababa, he went to the University of Wisconsin and at Johns Hopkins University, from where he obtained his Doctor of Science degree in tropical diseases in 1964. 

On his return home, Dr. Aklilu served as the first Ethiopian Dean of the faculty of science and Associate Academic Vice President for research and publications at the Addis Ababa university.

He also became director of the Institute of Pathobiology, which he founded.

Dr. Aklilu (as he was more commonly known in Ethiopia) was responsible for the establishment of the Ethiopian Science and Technology Commission.

During his lifetime, Dr Aklilu received the Haile Selassie I gold medal award, the 1988 Right Livelihood Award (sometimes referred to as Alternative Nobel Prize) which was given by the Swedish parliament, and an honorary doctorate of science from the University of Toledo.

He was a member of several international organisations and published over 60 scientific papers and reports, five books and is the holder of three patents.

He also worked at the United Nations in New York, where he served as senior scientific affairs officer at the Centre for Science and Technology for Development.

At one time, he also worked as Deputy Director of the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF), the International Center for Child Health and Development in Florence, Italy, and as UNICEF Representative in Kampala, Uganda.

Since 1993, Dr. Aklilu has been at the Johns Hopkins University, as UNESCO chair and professor in the department of international health.

Prior to his death, the scientist was engaged in creating linkages between the Johns Hopkins University and the Addis Ababa and Uganda's Makerere universities.

His task was to promote indigenous capacity building for scientific research and youth focussed HIV/AIDS control in Ethiopia and Uganda.

The late scientist has established the "Aklilu Lemma Foundation" through a donation of one million birr (about 160,000 U.S. dollars) from him and members of his family.

The foundation's objective will be to provide scholarships, research grants fellowships and achievement awards to outstanding students.

Dr. Aklilu is survived by his wife and three sons.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


365 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Stock Exchange Unmoved By South Africa, Zimbabwe Trade Pact


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The recent trade agreement between South Africa and Zimbabwe has had little impact on interest in clothing and textile stocks on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange as financials continue to dominate the market.

The clothing and textile counters continued to play second fiddle to other counters, particularly the new stocks which have been attracting a lot of interest.

Analysts told the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency that the failure by the agreement to scrap quantitative restrictions on clothing exports has not helped to generate new interest in counters like Zimbabwe Spinners and Weavers, or Spinweave, and David Whitehead. These counters have been reeling under punitive import measures by South Africa. 

The two neighbors reached agreement on the rules of origin for clothing and textiles as well as preferential tariff and quota levels for Zimbabwean clothing and textile exports to South Africa.

Analysts said the quotas, at 30,000 tons per producer per annum for clothing exports from Zimbabwe, were unlikely to change, suddenly, the prospects of the clothing sector.

The agreement has been widely expected to make Zimbabwe's ailing clothing and textile sector profitable.

"What has been of interest during the past week, however, is that the NMB (National Merchant Bank) issue has diverted most of the attention from other stocks on the market," an analyst said.

The interest generated by the issue, which is expected to start trading April 17, has made all other stock unattractive thereby slowing down the widely expected revival of the stockmarket.

"The market is just hopeful that once the NMB issue is over and its price, which is currently considered very cheap, starts to increase in the after- market, the issue won't be as attractive so that people will start looking around for other stocks," the analyst said.

Meanwhile, foreign participation continued to wane as investors continued to take profit.

Funds invested by the foreigners since June 1993, when they were first allowed to participate on the local bourse, dropped by 7 percent to Zimdollars 1.1 billion (100 million U.S. dollars) in the week ending April 4, compared to the previous week.

The total combined shares rose by over 12.9 million zimdollars (1.17 million dollars) to nearly 4.44 billion zimdollars (403 million dollars) during the same period.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

366 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Swedish Envoys Review Relations With Africa


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Swedish envoys in sub-Sahara Africa began a three- day meeting Monday aimed at promoting a new relationship in the form of development help Sweden gives to poor countries, in line with the changing political and economic climate.

"It must become more equal -- turn into a partnership," the diplomats said. "Development cooperation is still needed but its character must be changed in order to reduce the negative aspects of aid dependency."

The Lusaka meeting, dubbed "partnership Africa", has brought together at least 40 ambassadors and counsellors in the region who intend to establish a new relationship between African countries and Sweden.

The meeting is also being attended by the assistant under-secretary of state, Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Stockholm, Jan Bjerninger, and the assistant director-general of the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency, department for Africa, Sten Rylander.

An international conference is scheduled for June in Stockholm where some 100 representatives from the cooperating partners in Africa are expected to attend.

Partnership Africa focuses on democracy, the global economy, aid and the present relationships between Swedish society and African countries.

Sweden has now placed heavier emphasis to countries that actually seek to bring about poverty reducing development. In countries where this commitment is weak, the focus is on programmes that benefit the poor, mainly through unofficial channels.

Africa receives a greater part of Swedish development support than any other region. In 1994 and 1995, 35 percent of Swedish bilateral aid went to Africa. Asia received 22 percent, South and Central America 10 percent and the rest went to central and eastern Europe and global programmes.

In Africa Sweden's help go mainly to Angola, Botswana, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Guinea-Bissau, Kenya, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


367 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Nigeria;
Government Disowns Campaign For Abacha's Presidency


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's military government has distanced itself from a raging campaign by individuals and organisations urging the country's leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, to succeed himself at the end of his ongoing transitional programme, in October 1998.

In the first official reaction to the controversy, Special Duties Minister Wada Nas called the campaign "futile flights of fancy," capable of jeopardizing the transition programme.

"In the last few weeks, there have been many sponsored advertisements in some national newspapers by some obscure individuals and organisations claiming to be canvassing for the participation of the head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha, in the electoral race for the presidency in 1998," Nas said Sunday in a two-page statement. 

"These advertisements," he added, "have consequently generated a belief among unsuspecting Nigerians either that they (the adverts) are being sponsored by the government or are done with its knowledge and approval."

Nas said "invariably, unsuspecting people assumed that the contrived presidential ambition of the head of state is a reality and even proceed to spread uncharitable impressions."

These activities are clearly prejudicial to the integrity of the programme for political transition, as well as the sincerity of its leadership in pursuit of its avowed commitment to handing over to a democratically elected civilian administration in October 1998."

Warning that such moves constituted a serious threat to the transition programme, the minister said: "Those behind these sponsored advertisements, including newspapers which publish them for a fee, should be fully aware of the implications as well as the remedial measures available to government in the face of activities inimical to the attainment of its stated objectives especially the implementation of the political transition programme."

He singled out two of the organisations -- the "Youths Earnestly Ask for Abacha '98," and the "General Sani Abacha for '98 Presidency, National Mobilisation and Persuasion Committee."

Nas said experience had shown how the "activities of (such) phantom organisations can jeopardize the smooth implementation of the political transition programme by government."

He was referring to a similar campaign by another shadow group the " Association for Better Nigeria," which led an unsuccessful crusade for former military ruler, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, to remain in power beyond his stated hand-over date.

Babangida was eventually forced by political pressure, over his annulled June 12, 1993 presidential election, to step down from power in August of that year.

Nas cautioned Nigerians against "engaging in frivolous and mischievous exercise of freedom of expression that is capable of disrupting the process of attaining full democracy," in the country.

"The federal government reassures all Nigerians that the ongoing political transition programme is not a charade but a resolute commitment to hand-over to a democratically elected civilian administration in October 1998," he added.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 14, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (04/07 - 04/13)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Geneva - Human Rights Committee of the UN, 53th session, 10.3.-18.4.97, item 7: Right to Self-Determination

The Committee adopted the draft resolution on Western Sahara. It reaffirms that the objective all partners did subscribe to, is the implementation of a fair and free and impartial referendum for the people of Western Sahara. 

It repeats the responsibility of the U.N. regarding this people, declares to be convinced of the importance and utility of contacts between the two parties in conflict and encourages Morocco and the Polisario Front to begin as soon as possible direct talks.

item 8: Detention, Torture and Disappearance

The International Association of Democratic Lawyers made an intervention denouncing the H.R. situation in the occupied territories and specially of the former detainees liberated in 1991 by the Moroccan authorities. Its representative explained that the liberated people are always subject to intimidations. Some of them have been arrested once more and put in the secret detention center of the CMI. They received no compensation for their suffering during forced disappearance. They are under house arrest.

The Association evoqued also the case of Mohamed Daddach and appealed for the creation of an independent inquiry committee about arbitrary detention and forced desappearances in Western Sahara.

08.04.97 Fishing port at Dahkla

Morocco begins the construction of the fishing port of Dakhla, supposed to become the biggest of Western Africa. It will contribute to the development of the region and of the Moroccan fishing fleet. The construction of the port will be achieved in 1999 and will cost 70 millions of $. The Rumanian company Contrasimex is entrusted with the work. This project takes part of Moroccan policy of assimilation of Western Sahara. (Diario de Cadix)

Prepared by ARSO (Association de soutien a un referendum libre et regulier au Sahara occidental). CP 2229, CH-2800 DELEMONT 2. Tel./Fax: 0041 32 422 87 17. E-mail: arso@hei.unige.ch. WWW: http://heiwww.unige.ch/arso/.

Africa News


April 14, 1997


Tanzania;
Zanzibar Threatens Arrest of Unlicensed Journalists


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Windhoek - MISA-Tanzania reports that authorities on the islands of Zanzibar have threatened to order the arrest of practising journalists not in possession of a licence. The Islands' Chief Information Officer, Idrissa Haji, quoted in the March 11 state-controlled Daily News said his information department has so far issued 43 licences but more than 50 other journalists known to be working there were yet to obtain licences. 

On December 13, 1996, Zanzibar Information Services (ZIS) announced the licensing of journalists starting January, 1997. Authorities set February 28, 1997, as deadline. ZIS said journalists executing their duties without such a licence would be fined Tshs 500,000 (U$1000.00) or sentenced to five year's imprisonment. ZIS Deputy Director Rafii Makame said the decision was aimed at enforcing the 1988 Newspapers Act under which licencing of journalists falls. Makame said licencing would be compulsory to both private and state journalists and would cost Tsh6,000 (aboutU$12.00), renewable annually.

MISA-Tanzania, however, says this is the first time Zanzibar has enforced the licencing of journalists since the Newspapers Act was passed in 1988. According to MISA-Tanzania, officials claim licencing was delayed due to a lack of a proper board to enforce the Act but the introduction of the department of information services in April last year has now made it possible.

Located in the Indian Ocean waters, Zanzibar Islands form part of the April 26, 1964, union with mainland Tanzania, called the United Republic of Tanzania. However, Zanzibar still retains internal self-government and can pass legislations independent of mainland Tanzania.

March 13, 1997

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

April 14, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Statement on TRC Subpoena Of Robert McBride


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC has instructed Brian Currin to hold discussions with the TRC regarding our concerns about the timing of the subpoena on Robert McBride and Greta Appelgren.

The ANC reiterates its well known commitment to co-operate to the fullest extent of the law with the TRC as part of its contribution towards reconciliation and healing. 

In this regard, the ANC, through Deputy President Thabo Mbeki will be making a second submission to the TRC on 12-13 May in Cape Town on its command and control of military operations as well as such other information may please.

This submission will include details of a number of Umkhonto We Sizwe (MK) operations including the Magoo Bar bomb. In addition McBride has also applied for amnesty in respect of this operation.

The ANC is concerned of a potential prejudice arising from dual processes in the same forum. It is in this context that the ANC legitimately raised its concern with the TRC to be able to advise both McBride and Appelgren, with the overall objective of assisting the TRC process.

For more information call Ronnie Mamoepa at 082-990-4853

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O. Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107 14 April 1997.

April 14, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Statement on "Informers List"


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Johannesburg - The suggestion as contained in Die Beeld of Monday 14 April, that Minister Sydney Mufamadi removed a list of informers from the late Assistant Polir and handed it over to Deputy President Thabo Mbeki is a classical example of a carefully orchestrated disinformation campaign.

The ANC has discussed the matter with Minister Sydney Mufamadi who has indicated no knowledge of such a list of informers being submitted to Deputy President Thabo Mbeki. 

The ANC is further concerned about the use of so-called anonymous sources by the media to bolster what is essentially a disinformation campaign that seeks to undermine the TRC process, cause confusion and mutual mistrust within the ranks of the ANC.

It has come to our notice that certain elements within the media are trying desperately to keep alive a sensitive issue that is being handled through the TRC and other appropriate structures. We are confident that, as in the past, the reasons behind this disinformation campaign will come to light.

For more information please call Ronnie Mamoepa at 082-990-4853

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O. Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107

372 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Statement on IFP March


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Durban - The ANC in KwaZulu Natal regards the statement from the IFP National Council regarding the killings of more than fifty people in Johannesburg and the attempt to storm the Shell House ANC Headquarters on 28 March 1994 as a sign of panic. The IFP has always called for an inquest on the killings of that day. When the inquest is on, they are trying to pre-empt the findings of the inquest by threatening to take drastic actions if the IFP is not satisfied with the findings of the inquest. 

The ANC has always warned that the day all the truth about the events of March 28 1994 comes to the open, the IFP will be embarrassed. The findings of the inquest may decide the question:- Is the IFP an independent political organisation or has its genuine programmes, policies and organisation been so sabotaged that they are really run by the Third Force elements of the former apartheid security forces. In the vain attempt to shift the blame from the IFP, the IFP leadership is beginning to try and disown its march on that day. The facts indicate that the march was never a Zulu march but that of the IFP.

The application for the march was filed by Mr Humphrey Ndlovu on behalf of the IFP and not of the Zulu people. The political demands of the marchers were those of the IFP. The IFP is represented by lawyers in the inquest. It is an insult to the Zulu people to refer to the IFP march as a Zulu march. The IFP reference to its march as the Zulu march is a fiction that was invented after the event.

For Dr Ben Ngubane to complain about only murdered IFP leaders is being insensitive. The ANC regards the massacre of about 20 000 people in KwaZulu Natal in the last seventeen years as very serious. Their lives were not less important than those of the murdered ANC or IFP members and leaders. All lives are precious.

Issued by the ANC KwaZulu Natal Department of Information and Publicity. 14 April 1997


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 14, 1997


South Africa;
DP Thabo Mbeki To Visit North West Province


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Makikeng - The Deputy President of the African National Congress and the Republic of South Africa will visit the North West Province from 25 - 27 April 1997 as part of the ANC's ongoing programme of interaction with a cross- section of society to exchange views on a wide range of issues and to listen to the concerns of the citizens.

In this connection the Deputy President will be briefed by the North West leader of the ANC and Premier of the North West Province, Popo Simon Molefe and other leaders of the ANC as well as Members of Parliament and the Regional Executive Committee of Mafikeng ANC' on Friday 25 April 1997

On 26 April 1997 (at 09h00) Deputy President Thabo Mbeki and Premier Popo Molefe will take part in the SANDF Parade in Potchefstroom held to celebrate the Anniversary of the SANDF.

At noon on the same day the Deputy President will meet ANC leaders and Councillors to receive briefing on a broad range of issues. 

The Deputy President is expected to address a rally in Motswedi, the home village of Chief Lucas Manyane Mangope at 14h30. They will be accompanied by the North West Traditional Leaders and the ANC leaders.

At 19h00 on 26 April 1997, the Deputy President will address the Afrikaaner businessmen in Lichtenburg at an Education Fund raising Dinner host ed by Mayor Rampine of LIchtenburg. In Lichtenburg Deputy President will reaffirm the commitment of the government to respect for cultural, language and religious rights and acknowledge contribution of the people of Lichtenburg to reconciliation and nation building.

On Sunday morning 27 April 1997 the Deputy President will meet business and professional people of Mafikeng at a venue to be confirmed. At 14h30 he will address the Freedom Day Celebrations together with the Premier Popo Molefe at Atamelang. The public is invited to join the Deputy President. The celebration will be marked by cultural events and traditional dance.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

374 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


United States and Africa;
Consolidated Great Lakes Report No. 30


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4480 words


 

Washington DC - GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report 30, Fiscal Year (FY)1997, April 11, 1997. Note: The last situation report was dated April 4,1997.

Background

Sporadic ethnic violence against the Banyamulenge and the Banyarwanda, Tutsis of Rwandan origin, has erupted in the South Kivu and Masisi regions of Zaire since 1959. The violence escalated in 1995 and 1996, as the former Rwandan army (the ex-FAR) and the Rwandan Hutu militia (the Interahamwe), living as refugees in Eastern Zaire, attacked the Banyarwanda in the Masisi region.

Subsequently in October 1996, the Government of Zaire (GOZ) sanctioned harassment of the Banyamulenge in South Kivu, provoking the fighting which broke out between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Banyamulenge rebels on October 14, 1996. The fighting began near Runingo refugee camp in South Kivu, Zaire, forcing about 220,000 refugees to flee the Uvira/Bukavu region. 

The Banyamulenge joined forces with other Zairian rebels to form the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance), led by Laurent Kabila, a veteran foe of Zairian president Mobutu Sese Seko. The fighting spread, moving up the eastern border of Zaire from South Kivu, and south from Rutshuru to Goma, in North Kivu. On November 14, the Alliance counter-attacked against ex-FAR and Interahamwe elements in the Mugunga refugee camp in the Goma area, forcing them to retreat west and compelling hundreds of thousands of refugees to return to Rwanda.

Other refugees fled north and west into Zaire and remain there. Since then, Alliance troops have steadily advanced across Eastern Zaire: they captured Kisangani on March 15 and Mbuji-Mayi on April 5, expanding their control to an area 1,600 km long and 600 km west into Zaire. Lubumbashi, the second largest city in Zaire, fell on April 9.

USG Humanitarian Assistance for Fiscal Year (FY) 1997 (to date): $131,855, 092

Numbers Affected

In Zaire - Refugees: From figures gathered by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), about 360,500 Rwandans and 42,000 Burundians are stranded in Eastern Zaire. Of the 100,000 refugees who fled from Tingi-Tingi on March 1 to Ubundu, about 96,000 crossed the Zaire River and have gathered at Km 25, Km 41, and Km 82 on the rail line south of Kisangani. The 57,000 refugees estimated to have gathered near Km 25 are the healthiest, while the 39,000 near Km 41 and 82 are in poor condition.

From March 17 to April 3, the U.N. airlifted 2,846 refugees from Tingi- Tingi and Amisi to Goma. On April 1, about 20,000 refugees appeared near Karuba, 13 km west of Sake, and by April 9, 16,244 were repatriated to Rwanda, the UNHCR reported. Another 2,500 emerged in Tongo, to the west of the old Katale and Kahindo refugee camps north of Goma.

In Mbuji-Mayi, Kasai-Oriental, there are reports of 3,000 refugees heading towards Kananga, 140 km to the west, and about 30,000 moving towards Angola. They are believed to be the group last seen in Shabunda/Kindu. About 100,000 refugees in Eastern Zaire are unaccounted for.

Zaire - Internally Displaced (IDPs): 13,000 IDPs are registered in Kisangani. The U.N. estimates there are about 300,000 Zairian IDPs in Eastern Zaire.

In Rwanda: According to the UNHCR, 1,033,405 Rwandan refugees returned to Rwanda from Eastern Zaire and Tanzania from November to December 1996, bringing to 1,300,582 the number of returnees in 1996.

From January to March 1997, another 75,947 refugees returned from Eastern Zaire and Tanzania. There are 9,000 Burundian refugees in Rwanda, the UNHCR reports. There are 3,355 Zairian refugees in Rwanda. In Burundi: Of the 143, 000 Burundian refugees originally in the Uvira area of Zaire, some 93,000 refugees have returned to Burundi. From January through March 1997, 8,192 Burundians returned from Tanzania, and 5,764 returned from Zaire.

In Tanzania: In March, 8,964 Zairian and 5,489 Burundian refugees arrived in the Kigoma region of Tanzania. Recent fighting in Burundi caused 300 refugees to enter Kigoma daily during the first week of April, and on April 6 alone, 800 crossed.

In all, there are 276,483 Burundian refugees in Tanzania, and 88,554 Zairians, for a total of 365,037. Elsewhere in the Region: 4,820 Zairians remain in Uganda, according to the UNHCR. About 8,000 Zairian refugees have fled to Zambia. The Government of Sudan is host to 400 Zairian refugees.

Zaire Political/Military

Representatives from the Alliance and the GOZ held talks in South Africa between April 5 and 7. The talks were suspended on April 8, ostensibly to allow the principals to obtain further guidance for a ceasefire agreement. Attending the talks were Mohammed Sahnoun, U.N. and Organization of African States (OAU) special representative for the Great Lakes, and Thabo Mbeki, deputy president of South Africa. Alliance troops continue their advance in the south, seizing the diamond center of Mbuji-Mayi on April 5 and Kipushi, 30 km west of Lubumbashi, on April 7.

Lubumbashi, the second largest city in Zaire and the key to the nation's mineral wealth, fell on April 9. Alliance leader Kabila subsequently announced a pause in military operations to allow Mobutu to negotiate his departure. In Kinshasa, President Mobutu dismissed Etienne Tshisekedi as prime minister on April 9, a week after his appointment. Mobutu appointed General Likulia Bolongo, the defense minister, as Tshisekedi's replacement. Mobutu also announced a national state of emergency on the evening of April 8 and appointed military governors for the provinces still in his control.

The U.N. Special Rapporteur for Human Rights said in Geneva on April 2 that the Alliance had "undoubtedly" committed massacres during the past six months. He recommended that an international investigative team be sent to Eastern Zaire.

Relief Efforts

In the northern part of Alliance-controlled territory, Alliance officials on April 5 approved a proposal drawn up by the UNHCR for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of Rwandan and Burundian refugees who had fled the Alliance's advances since late 1996. The Alliance's approval came a day after UN agencies issued a public appeal to the rebels, citing the refugees' desperate condition.

The U.N. plan for repatriating refugees from Eastern Zaire has three parts. The most urgent, the evacuation of people from Tingi-Tingi and Amisi to Goma, was completed on April 3, after relief workers flew 2,846 very ill and weak refugees to Goma for eventual repatriation to Rwanda. The second and third parts, approved by the Alliance on April 5, involve passenger flights between other parts of Eastern Zaire in Alliance control: Bunia, Kalemie, Kindu, Uvira, Bukavu, Goma, and other accessible airstrips in areas where refugees are located. The final component is arrangements to move the 96,000 refugees grouped along the railroad south of Kisangani.

The UNHCR proposes to airlift up to 20,000 of the most vulnerable from Kisangani to Goma, and the healthier refugees would be moved overland. The Alliance is restricting air travel to the Kisangani municipal airport, 5 km north of the city. Relief organizations would prefer to use the international airport, 17 km south of Kisangani, because it can accomodate larger aircraft and, unlike the municipal airport, has offloading equipment. It remains off- limits because the area around the runway is mined. Both airports are on the eastern side of the Zaire River, requiring the refugees to cross it from their concentrations of the western side. The ferry they would use must be repaired.

The proposed overland repatriation of the Kisangani area refugees is complicated by the poor condition of the 657 km route from Kisangani to Bukavu, and by the beginning of the rainy season. Whatever route the refugees take on the way from Kisangani to the Rwandan border, they face having to walk part of the route because the 100 km-stretch from Walikale south to Hombo is impassible to vehicles.

The refugees in the corridor are grouped near three kilometer markings along the rail line: about 57,000 people at Kasese, near Km 25, and about 31, 000 at Biaro, near Km 41. The Biaro group and the 8,000 refugees at Km 82, are very weak. During the week, mortality rates have sunk sharply as increasing amounts of food, water, and medicines have reached the refugees: early in the week, relief workers said about 120 people, mostly children, died daily; by April 10, the rate had dropped to 20. Relief workers have made the estimated 600 unaccompanied children (UACs) in the Kisangani-Ubundu corridor their priority for airlifting and repatriation.

The USAID/DART is travelling regularly between Goma and Kisangani to support relief efforts with the U.N. in determining how best to assist the refugees, local populations, and IDPs. After the Alliance seized Kisangani on March 15, USAID/DART succeeded in securing the Alliance's clearance for the WFP's first food flight to Kisangani from Mwanza, Tanzania. In recent days, the USAID/DART has worked with the GOR representative for repatriation issues, Alliance and UN officials on the final version of the repatriation plan.

A group of more than 20,000 Rwandan refugees appeared on March 31 in Karuba, west of Sake, and Tongo, west of the former Katale and Kahindo camps. The refugees, reportedly in good condition, wished to go home. Alliance forces have erected a roadblock near Sake to screen the refugees, and the UNHCR has organized a repatriation that would allow 2,500 people to cross daily into Rwanda from Goma. From March 31 to April 9, 16,244 refugees were repatriated from Karuba.

Reports have reached relief agencies of 30,000 refugees heading south from Mbuji-Mayi to the Angolan border. They may be part of the refugees who had fled Shabunda and Kindu earlier this year. In March, the U.N. repatriated 7, 209 refugees from towns in the Goma region, including Kisharu, Tongo, Kalengera/Rugari, Sake/Mugungu, Karuba, and Kalungu. In Kingulube, east of Shabunda, the UNHCR and the World Food Program (WFP) have set up five way stations in preparation for the transit of refugees.

From March 27 to April 8, five trains, each transporting 120 MT of pulses and cereals, made deliveries from Kisangani to the refugees along the railroad. Relief supply trains now run every two to three days. WFP also has five trucks to take food and relief supplies from Kisangani to the refugee concentrations. WFP is trying to contract a second Ilyushin-76 aircraft, to create a fleet of three transports that would deliver 180 MT daily to Kisangani from Mwanza, Tanzania, and Entebbe, Uganda.

Relief efforts to help the Rwandan and Burundian refugees south of Kisangani began to anger local Zairians, whose food and belongings were taken by the ex-FAR/Interahamwe and refugees in the past month. On April 7, Zairian residents outside Kisangani looted 5 MT of food from a WFP truck destined for the refugees. On April 8, local residents detained five trucks in the same place before local authorities resolved the conflict. To lower tensions, relief workers have begun distributing food to local residents.

The Alliance has approved a plan by the ICRC to return by air about 13,000 Zairian IDPs in Kisangani to their homes, via Goma and Bukavu. The operation began on April 7 and has returned 57 UACs to date. The Alliance has not yet granted access to the Bukavu airport. On April 11 the ICRC plans to assess the condition of refugees and several thousand IDPs in the Kalima-Kindu area.

As air traffic increases in Eastern Zaire, the British Overseas Development Agency (ODA) is establishing an air logistics cell in Goma and, in coordination with WFP, a transportation unit in Kisangani, which will control air, road, and river movements for the repatriation. Humanitarian agencies are working to alleviate fuel shortages in Goma and Kisangani.

Rwanda Current Situation After the Alliance approved the UNHCR's repatriation proposal on April 5, the GOR's representative for repatriation issues announced that returnees arriving by air from Kisangani would have to use Goma airport instead of Kigali, and then travel overland from the border at Goma, instead of arriving directly by air at Kigali. The refugees will spend several days at Nkamira transit center, where they would be screened before being returned to their homes.

A cabinet reshuffle in the GOR on March 28 resulted in the dissolution of the Ministry of Rehabilitation and Social Integration (MiniReiso), with its responsibilities being absorbed by the newly-formed Ministry of the Interior, Communal Development and Social Reintegration. This is significant, as MiniReiso worked most closely with the relief community.

The ICRC registered a total of 102,446 detainees in Rwanda as of March 31. Of that number, 63,920 are in prisons and the rest are in communal lock-ups, which the ICRC describes as particularly overcrowded and steadily worsening.

Relief Efforts Regular U.N. convoys transporting humanitarian assistance under military escort are underway between Kigali and Cyangugu, Kibuye, Gisenyi, and Ruhengeri. The WFP has also instituted regular flights to Gisenyi and Cyangugu.

Changing circumstances and renewed relief efforts in Eastern Zaire have increased refugee repatriations to Rwanda. WFP has moved 60 MT from the border crossing at La Petite Barri re in Rwanda to Goma, and M'decins Sans Fronti res (MSF) and Food for the Hungry are responsible for administering medical assistance to returnees.

Despite increased nation-wide security measures, a USAID/OFDA officer who travelled by vehicle from Kigali to Gisenyi on April 3-4 noticed few checkpoints and bustling commercial traffic on the main road. At the Nkamira transit center there were about 3,000 refugees who had arrived after crossing the border. Returnees from the Masisi region appeared in better condition than those from Tingi-Tingi and Amisi. From March 26 to April 3, 11,649 refugees were registered in Gisenyi prefecture.

The WFP reports that the price of staple foods has increased 30% from the same time last year. The increase resulted from the mass repatriations from Zaire and Tanzania, from poor harvests in Rwanda and southern Uganda, and from the trade embargo against Burundi.

Burundi

Political Developments On March 31, state radio announced that 1,400 huts were burned at the Nyarurama regroupment camp in Kayanza province, leaving 14 dead and about 6,000 people without shelter, food, or clothing. WFP is planning an assessment mission to the camp. State radio also announced the death of five "terrorists" in the Gatete sector of Rumonge, Bururi province, on April 3. In Bujumbura, four anti-personnel mines and an anti-tank mine exploded on April 6. It was the third mine incident in the last month: two anti-tank mines exploded in Bujumbura on March 25, killing at least 20 people, and on March 13, three land mines exploded in different parts of Bujumbura, killing seven people.

Questions remain unanswered about the Government of the Republic of Burundi (GRB)'s claim that rebels killed 135 people and wounded 144 in Buganda commune, Cibitoke province, on March 19. Government authorities reported on March 13 that a plot to kill Buyoya had been foiled.

Relief Efforts

In March 1996, the GRB began forced regroupment in Karuzi province. One year later, the practice spread to the provinces of Bujumbura Rurale, Bururi, Kayanza, Cibitoke, Bubanza, and Muramvya. Local press reports state that military authorities inform Burundians living in particular areas to move to the regroupment sites. If the peasants do not move to the camps, the military considers them rebels, and they risk being killed.

Although conditions in the camps are satisfactory in the beginning, the health of the population is prone to deteriorate from the effects of crowding, inadequate potable water, poor sanitation, lack of medical care, and inaccessibility to farm land. Recently the acceleration of forced displacement of the population has imposed a growing burden on the relief community, imperiling their neutrality.

On April 8, the State Department characterized the GRB's regroupment policy as "highly objectionable," because it disrupts traditional village life and places a vulnerable population at risk of violence, malnourishment, and disease.

On April 9, a U.S. and U.N. delegation, including the U.S. Ambassador to Burundi, visited three regroupment camps in Karuzi province. They also met with the governor of Karuzi to express the USG's objections to the GRB's regroupment policy, and explained the conditions in which humanitarian assistance would be provided to the camps. The provision of USG assistance in regroupment camps based on these criteria: assistance will not be given immediately upon the formation of the camps; a needs assessment must precede any assistance; aid will be restricted to limited emergency activities; and humanitarian workers' safety and freedom of movement must be guaranteed for the duration of the project. African leaders will meet in Arusha on April 16 to evaluate the effect of the sanctions against Burundi.

The leaders will examine the measures taken by the GRB towards establishing democracy, peace, and reconciliation, to determine progress made in these areas. For the first time, Major Buyoya, the Burundian leader, has been invited to the session.

Tanzania

As of March 31, there were 365,037 refugees in Tanzania: 276,488 of them Burundian; the rest Zairian, the UNHCR reported. The populations are as follows: Ngara camps: 97,600; Kibondo camps: 104,411. Both areas hold only Burundians. In the Kasulu area: 117,478, including 44,204 Zairians; Kigoma camps: 44,350 refugees, almost all Zairian. Fighting in Bururi and Makamba provinces in Burundi generated about 300 Burundian refugees a day during the first week of April, and 800 entered on April 6.

In late March, on the other hand, factional fighting among Burundian refugees in the Ngara camps resulted in 2,169 returnees. About 4,000 Zairian refugees requested repatriation from the Kigoma camps.

USG Assistance

BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda from October 26, 1996 to February 26, 1997, and an assessment team to Zaire from February 12-26, 1997. The current USAID/DART was deployed to Nairobi on March 14 and is working in the region. The USAID/DART has installed an information officer in Nairobi and field offices in Goma and Kisangani.

USAID FY 1997 Assistance to date:

To ICRC, for emergency response: $4,750,000

To IOM, for transportation of vulnerables: $250,000

To IRC for its reintegration programs in Rwanda: $2,500,000
