Africa News


April 14, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Body Subpoenas ANC Supporters


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - The Truth and Reconciliation Commission has issued its first subpoenas requiring supporters of liberation movements to appear at investigative inquiries of the Commission.

Mr Robert McBride and Ms Greta Appelgren -- as she was then known -- have been called to appear before the Commission in Durban from April 21. They were convicted of offences arising out of the bombing of Magoo's Bar, Durban. 

The subpoenas were served at Easter.

Archbishop Desmond Tutu, chairperson of the Commission, said in a statement today:

"Mr McBride was told in his subpoena that he would face questions which relate to 'your involvement in, role and/or knowledge of the bombing of Magoo's Bar at Marine Parade, Durban, on 14 June 1985, including but not confined to the extent of the involvement of the military and political wing of the African National Congress (MK) in the planning and execution of the aforesaid bombing...'

"Ms Appelgren will be questioned on the same incident. The subpoenas were issued by our Durban office in terms of Section 29 of the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act, which grants the Commission the power to call upon any person to appear before the Commission to give evidence or to answer questions relevant to the subject matter of the inquiry.

"It is the same section under which a number of former police generals were subpoenaed late last year.

"The law provides that "no person other than a member of the staff of the Commission or any person required... to give evidence shall be entitled or permitted to attend any hearing conducted in terms of this section (of the Act)." However, the Commission is able to release information about Section 29 hearings at its discretion, or at subsequent public hearings of the Commission.

"In terms of Section 34 of the Act, any person who is subpoenaed is entitled to appoint a legal representative. If he is not financially capable of doing so, the Commission may appoint a legal representative to assist him or her.

"Section 39 of the Act provides for penalties for any person who fails to appear in response to a subpoena without sufficient cause, or who 'fails or refuses to answer fully and satisfactorily to the best of his or her knowledge and belief any question lawfully put to him or her...' Those guilty of offences in terms of the Act are liable to fines and/or imprisonment of up to two years."

April 13, 1997


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


376 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Zambia;
CPJ Protests New Zambian Media Bill


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), to President Frederick Chiluba, president of the Republic of Zambia, April 10, 1997.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to strongly protest the government legislated Media Council of Zambia (MCZ) Bill presented on April 7, 1997. The bill sets the minimum age for practicing journalism at 18 years and requires that all journalists hold a degree in mass communication, or a degree recognized by the council in conjunction with two years training as a journalists or proof of having written articles for a media institution recognized by the council. 

Local and foreign journalists are required to be accredited annually by the MCZ, a body appointed by the minister of information and pay an accreditation fee. In addition, the proposed bill provides the Media Council with sweeping powers to reprimand, suspend, expel, convict, sentence and or fine journalists who have not complied with the requirements for accreditation and discipline in their profession, or who have been accused by aggrieved members of the public.

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ protests the spirit and particulars of the media council bill and condemns the state's attempt through this bill to restrict press freedom in blatant violation of all journalists' right to hold and express opinions and ideas. CPJ particularly protests the proposal that the Media Council serve as a prosecutor and judge in cases when the public files a complaint against a journalist and/or media house thereby circumventing an independent judicial process and violating journalists' right to a free and fair trial.

The rights undermined by the Media Council bill are guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, and the 1991 Windhoek Declaration on Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic African Press, all to which, we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Zambia is a signatory.

We strongly urge Your Excellency to do everything in your power dismiss the repressive proposed Media Council bill. Moreover, we urge the state to cooperate with local journalists in efforts to realize the recommendations of the Media Reform Committee of 1993 for sweeping changes in the laws governing the media and to ensure that press freedom is legally protected in Zambian law.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj. org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Zamibia;
Zambian Journalists Demonstrate Against Media Council Bill


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Windhoek - On Saturday, April 12, hundreds of journalists in Lusaka went on a demonstration against government's plans to legislate for a Media Council, reports the Zambia Independent Media Association (ZIMA/MISA-Zambia).

The demonstration aimed at raising public awareness about the impact of the proposed Media Council of Zambia (MCZ) on the public's right to freedom of expression. ZIMA says marching journalists were joined by the general public and representatives of non-governmental organisations. The governement- intiated media council bill seeks, among others, to licence journalists and imposes jail terms on those practising without one. 

According to ZIMA marchers from the state and private media chanted anti- media council slogans, carried placards with messages which read: "Lobby your MP - media council act is draconian"; "Honk for a free press"; "It's your right to write". They also distributed fliers with messages saying: "Do not be held hostage by your own government"; Everybody has a right to know, a legislated media council abrogates that right."

Demonstrators were later addressed by the chairman of the Media Liason Committee (MLC) Robby Makayi, participating NGOs and an opposition party leader. Makayi told demonstrators that by going ahead with its plans, the government was in contempt of the 1995 High Court order which awarded PAZA a " stay of execution" - preventing the government from legislating for a Media Association of Zambia (MAZ) to replace PAZA. As a result of this possible contempt, he said, MLC has initiated legal proceedings against the government. Makayi also lauched a "peoples' petition" which he said would be distributed countrywide to be signed by members of the public in support of the withdrawal of the MCZ bill.

NGOs' leaders and the oppositon parties also condemned the government for its intentions to legislate for a media council. They said such a move would be an infringement of basic human right to freedom of expression. Meanwhile, a similar march in the Copperbelt town of Kitwe failed to take place because journalists there were denied police permission to march. But a gathering crowd was addressed by an official from the Zambia Union of Journalists (ZUJ) who also condemned the proposed law. ends

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, Researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386 Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 15 - Africa (04/11)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2400 words


 

Rome - This report includes: Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania C) Uganda D) Sudan.

EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. Zaire a) ADFL agrees to large-scale evacuation of an estimated 80,000- 100,000 Rwandan refugees currently stranded in eastern Zaire, and allows use of Kisangani airport for the operation. First flight, carrying 205 internally displaced persons from Kisangani to Goma on WFP plane, takes place 11 April. b) WFP delivery of food to the refugees along the Kisangani/Ubundu railroad line continues. Death rate among refugees declines, but is still high. Second air bridge opened, bringing food from Entebbe to Kisangani. c) Repatriation programme from Karuba to Gisenyi ongoing, moving 2,000 to 3,000 Rwandan refugees a day; ADFL rebels screen passing refugees at check-point at Sake. 

2. Rwanda a) With increased repatriation from Zaire, 14,057 persons arriving through Gisenyi registered by UNHCR during first week of April. b) Relief food is being trucked direct from Mombasa to Rwanda to compensate for a reduction in rail despatch capacity from the port.

3. Burundi a) UN/NGO mission visits Cibitoke province with heavy military escort. Some 100,000 people, 60 percent of the population of the province, now grouped in sites.

4. Tanzania a) Heavy rains make roads impassable in Kigoma; food stocks pre- positioned at camps by WFP sufficient for two weeks in Lugufu and four weeks in Kasulu. b) Government/UN mission to Lindi by helicopter assesses damage caused by recent flooding. WFP to deliver emergency food rations and medicine by air from Ngara. c) WFP emergency operation (EMOP 5825) approved, to assist 200,000 drought-affected people with total of 10,080 mt of food commodities, worth USD 2.6 million (total cost of operation is USD 4.2 million). Government in need of donations to provide more relief food and to deliver cereals to markets in affected areas.

C. UGANDA

1. Update a) Joint WFP/Government/donor assessment is taking place in districts facing acute food shortages due to drought. Some 330 mt of food already delivered by WFP following an initial Government assessment and request for food assistance. b) Registration exercise in Gulu district identifies 180,000-185,000 displaced Ugandans. Results of similar exercise in Kitgum expected soon. Security in the two districts deteriorates and food distribution in northern part of Kitgum postponed.

D. SUDAN

1. Update a) WFP airlift to Juba started, to assist increasing numbers of displaced persons and returning refugees. On 10 April, 30 mt of sorghum were delivered, the first relief food to reach Juba since early February. Norwegian Church Council also starts airlift of food to the city. b) Clearance obtained from Government of Sudan and SPLA to deliver 2,500 mt of relief food to Juba by barge convoy. c) WFP/OLS food security assessment mission to Yei and Kajo Keji counties reports 100,000 returning refugees from northern Uganda and needy residents of Yei are in need of urgent relief food and non-food assistance.WFP is delivering maize to Yei.

PART II - DETAILS

EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE, TANZANIA

1. ZAIRE

1.1 Relief agencies are finalising preparations for a large-scale evacuation programme for the Rwandan refugees stranded in eastern Zaire. The Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) authorities have now agreed to the evacuation of an estimated 80,000-100,000 refugees and to the use of Kisangani airport. This complex evacuation operation, which includes the return of internally displaced persons to the Goma area, will involve the use of trucks, train, barges and planes. UNHCR is currently discussing with Rwandan authorities the details for the reception of the most vulnerable refugees, who are to be evacuated by air to either Kigali or Goma. WFP is offering the use of three planes, two Illyushins and a Hercules, for this programme. Update: the operation began on 11 April, when 205 internally displaced persons were flown by WFP from Kisangani to Goma.

1.2 WFP has continued deliveries of food to the refugees who are presently accommodated at Kasese, km 29 south of Kisangani and Biaro, km 39, and other locations further south along the Kisangani/Ubundu railroad line. In addition to rail and truck despatches from Kisangani to the concentration points, and the ongoing air bridge from Mwanza, Tanzania, a new air operation started on 7 April from Entebbe to Kisangani, with two planes, one Illyushin-76 and one Hercules C-130. With these two air bridges, WFP can shuttle to Kisangani 110 mt of food, and some essential medical supplies, daily. During the first week of April, WFP airlifted 270 mt of food supplies into Kisangani. The refugees continue to require urgent food and medical assistance and the death rate, although declining, remains high.

1.3 The evacuation programme from Karuba is still ongoing. An average 2,000 to 3,000 Rwandans are being taken by truck to Gisenyi every day. At Sake, the ADFL rebels have established a check-point for screening the passing refugees. As of 9 April there were still some 15,000 refugees left at Karuba.

2. RWANDA

2.1 Repatriation from Zaire increased over the past week, as expected. During the first week of April, 14,057 persons were registered by UNHCR, mostly returnees arriving through Gisenyi, including 325 unaccompanied children, housed at Nkamira Transit Centre. This centre holds around 7,000 persons, awaiting transportation to their communes. The returnees are receiving one month's food ration before returning to their home areas. Sick and malnourished returnees receive extra food. To date, 25 of these recent returnees have died in Gisenyi hospital due to extreme exhaustion.

2.2 From 31 March to 6 April, WFP distributed 3,350 mt of food in Rwanda. Current stocks in the country amount to 5,579 mt of various commodities. Due to a reduction in rail despatch capacity from Mombasa, over 2,500 mt of maize and beans are being trucked directly from the port to Rwanda.

3. BURUNDI

3.1 A UN/NGO mission comprising WFP, UNHCR, FAO and OXFAM, visited Cibitoke province, in the north-western part of the country. During the last half of 1996, insecurity did not allow any UN staff to travel to Cibitoke and the present mission had to travel with heavy military escort. The mission visited a regroupement site holding mostly persons who returned from Zaire in November 1996. Owing to insecurity, the population does not have access to land and coping mechanisms have not yet been developed. Meeting with the mission, the Governor stated that 100,000 people, or 60 percent of the population of Cibitoke province, are now grouped in sites.

4. TANZANIA

4.1 Heavy rains have arrived in Kigoma, making many roads impassable and affecting all relief operations. Five WFP trucks got stuck in Kasulu during operations to build up stocks in refugee camps. The Government, UN agencies and NGOs involved in assistance to refugees are carrying out spot maintenance, but donor funding will be necessary to ensure that all the work needed can be completed. Fortunately, food stocks had been pre-positioned at all camps by WFP, and are sufficient to meet requirements for two weeks in Lugufu and four weeks in Kasulu.

4.2 The influx of Burundian refugees into Kigoma region is now reduced to 100-150 persons per day. Nevertheless, during the last weekend of March, 800 refugees arrived in Kasulu. At the same time, some 3,000 Zairean refugees have requested to be repatriated to Uvira. Contingency plans are being made for an organised return.

4.3 WFP participated in a Government/UN-organised helicopter visit to Lindi, to assess the damage caused by recent flooding, which has exacerbated hardship already caused by the drought. Some one thousand families were left homeless and in urgent need of shelter, food and medicine. WFP is planning an airlift from Ngara, scheduled to start on 10 April, to deliver emergency food rations and medicine.

4.4 On 8 April WFP approved an emergency operation (EMOP 5825) to assist 200,000 people facing food shortages due to the failure of the short rains. Under this operation, WFP will provide 10,080 mt of food commodities, at a value of USD 2.6 million. The food will be distributed by NGOs through direct feeding or food-for-work activities in the eleven regions identified as needing relief aid. The total cost of this operation is USD 4.2 million.

4.5 The Government has provided another 10,000 mt in drought relief. An additional 14,000 mt of food is required for distribution during the coming months. Donor contributions of TZ Shillings 800 million (approximately USD 1. 4 million) would allow the Government to deliver an additional 30,000 mt of food commodities to the markets, thus ensuring that those in need who still have some purchasing power can have access to food at reasonable prices.

C. UGANDA

1. UPDATE

1.1 A joint Rapid Food Security and Vulnerability Assessment is presently being carried out in ten of the districts of the country reported to be facing acute food shortages as a result of the drought. Following an initial assessment made by the Government and the subsequent request for food assistance, WFP immediately delivered 330 mt of cereals for distribution to the most affected populations in Kumi, Tororo and Soroti districts. The present four-team assessment mission comprises WFP, the Government and donor representatives.

1.2 Between 180,000-185,000 displaced Ugandans were identified after consolidation of the registration exercise conducted in Gulu district. A similar exercise has been carried out in Kitgum and final figures are expected soon. Security in these two districts, particularly in Kitgum, has recently deteriorated and food distribution to internally displaced persons in the northern part of the district bordering Sudan had to be postponed.

D. SUDAN

1. JUBA

1.1 Following the recent upsurge in fighting in south Sudan, further numbers of displaced persons and returning refugees have gathered in Juba. A reported 8,400 recently arrived people in the city (returnees from Uganda and Zaire) require immediate assistance. An additional 10,000 to 15,000 Sudanese refugees from camps in northern Uganda are on the road from Yei to Juba.

1.2 WFP has initiated an airlift operation into Juba to deliver a total of 200 mt of food. On the first day of the airlift, 10 April, 30 mt of sorghum were delivered, the first relief food to reach Juba since early February. WFP has deployed staff to Juba to monitor food distribution. The Norwegian Church Council will deliver a further 300 mt of food by air. In addition, Government of Sudan and SPLA clearance has been obtained to deliver 2,500 mt of relief food to Juba on a barge convoy.

2. YEI

2.1 As previously reported, the fall of Yei and Kajo Keji towns to the SPLA has led to the mass exodus of Sudanese refugees from northern Uganda. A WFP/Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) food security assessment mission to Yei and Kajo Keji counties took place from 27 March to 5 April. A total of 100, 000 returning refugees from northern Uganda and vulnerable persons among the resident population in Yei were identified as requiring urgent relief food and non-food assistance, including agricultural inputs. The most vulnerable group comprises 13,500 displaced residents of Yei town, whose only current available access to food is through relief support.

2.2 During February and March, WFP purchased 300 mt of locally produced sorghum which have been distributed to over 17,000 internally displaced persons and returnees in Mundri, Meridi and Yambio.

2.3 On 30 March, WFP delivered an initial 40 mt of maize to Yei. An additional 20 mt is en route and expected to arrive in Yei 12 April. OLS relief assistance will concentrate on promoting a strategy for self-reliance, with food aid response closely linked to agricultural inputs.

(End WFP Emergency Report No. 15 of 1997 - April 11, 1997)


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


South Africa;
Putting the law on the side of the victim


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1987 words


 

Cape Town - Three years ago, the Government agreed to establish a judicial world-first in Cape Town.

At the initiative of Mr Kahn's office, two special victim-friendly courts were set up to help eradicate the secondary victimisation of women and children exposed to sexual abuse and violence.

According to Mr Kahn, the Children's Court in Cape Town and the Sexual Offences Court in Wynberg have gone a long way in relieving the problem of further victimisation experienced by rape survivors and children who have suffered abuse.

The courts had attracted a vast amount of interest overseas, he said.

The project has been hailed a success, but Mr Kahn's pleas to take it further have fallen on deaf ears. His office has had to wage a battle to establish more special courts against a ponderous bureaucracy, with little support from the Department of Justice, in spite of the "undoubted success" of the first two courts since 1993. The Justice Department had been slow in committing itself to extending the pilot project, he said. 

"Every year I have made the same pleas in my parliamentary report to set up a network of these courts and I have been kicked to touch.

"They have been long in the tooth about expanding on the project.

"They are slowly coming on stream, but we would like them to approach it holistically. After one year, we should have expanded the idea as the pilot courts have more than proved themselves. Instead, it has taken almost four years."

A major breakthrough for the Attorney-General's office last year was accommodation becoming available for the setting up of a new children's court in Parow, and this will be operational in August.

The new development has been welcomed by Shifra Jacobson, director of Resources Aimed at the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect (Rapcan), but she said it fell far short of what was urgently needed.

She said special courts had to be set up in all areas of the Peninsula - and throughout the country - if the judicial system was to improve its handling of cases involving abused children.

A report compiled by the SA Police Service's child protection unit said that a child was raped every five minutes in this country. Crimes against youngsters occurred every two minutes.

The Parow court will be the second one dealing exclusively with child abuse cases and will reduce the huge burden of cases from the northern suburbs dealt with by the pilot children's court.

"The success of these courts is measured by the extent to which the trauma experienced by victims of abuse on appearing in court is reduced. The important factor is that they are victim-orientated," said Mr Kahn.

He is pleading with the Department of Justice for more special courts.

"It's not that costly to set them up. All we need for one of these courts is a hall, a magistrate and two prosecutors," he said.

"We have had moral support from all corners of the world and all sectors of the community, except where it counts - from the Department of Justice. What we want is some commitment there."

The caseloads of the pilot courts are so heavy that more special courts are desperately needed in Athlone, Mitchell's Plain, Wynberg, Paarl and George. " There should be a network of these courts throughout the Peninsula," he said.

"We look forward to starting a second sexual offences court in Wynberg, depending on the commitment of the Department of Justice."

Accommodation has become available in Wynberg and it will be a matter of allocating staff.

Department of Justice spokesman Paul Setsetse said that during his term of office Minister Dullah Omar had established 130 court facilities countrywide for victims of sexual abuse and was in the process of setting up another 70.

"For the first time, sex-related cases can be heard without the victims becoming frustrated when having to appear in court.

"Most magistrate's courts have established a friendly environment for sexual-abuse cases. The minister has always called for victims of this type of abuse to be shown sympathy and treated sensitively in court," he said.

He said Mr Omar had initiated interaction between magistrates, prosecutors and victims of abuse to improve the manner in which these cases and the complainants were dealt with in court.

"But everything depends on finance and the minister indicated these problems could not be solved overnight. What little we could do, we have done. We have never had such facilities available before," he said.

Rapcan's Ms Jacobson said the Children's Court and Sexual Offences Court had helped children tremendously because they offered protection from the perpetrators of abuse.

The young victims did not appear in court. They were kept out of sight in a separate room with an intermediary who relayed information.

"We feel that's a great improvement. The courts have provided a child- friendly space," she said.

However, there were not enough Xhosa-speaking intermediaries to deal with the sheer volume of Xhosa-speaking victims who appeared in court. Nor were there enough children's courts. The two pilot courts had a backlog of six to 12 months and the waiting period was to the detriment of the young victims.

"We very strongly believe children should not have to appear in open court but they do because of the backlog of cases," she said.

"The long wait affects their statements, their memory and the impact the abuse has had on their lives.

"We need children's courts in all areas, especially Khayelitsha, Guguletu and Nyanga. At the moment, these children have to travel to Cape Town or Wynberg."

She said the conviction rate in these cases was still unacceptably low. Children were subjected to the cautionary laws in which they were viewed as unreliable witnesses. Aspects of the legal system were still prejudiced against children.

"There has to be more training of prosecutors and magistrates to understand the impact of abuse on children, the trauma it renders. Children also need access to counselling prior to the court case."

Mr Kahn said the new children's court to be set up in Parow was a step in the right direction towards fighting child abuse, but frustrating problems remained.

He said the child protection unit did not function in areas where child abuse was most rife - such as Khayelitsha, Mitchell's Plain, Nyanga, Langa and Guguletu.

The result was that investigations were not done efficiently and people who lodged complaints of child abuse with police did not get the same service as those in areas where the unit functioned, he said.

A shortage of police vehicles hindered work in this regard and referrals by local police stations to the child protection unit were seldom if ever followed up, said Mr Kahn.

In Xhosa-speaking areas, there was a shortage of interpreters to act as intermediaries and his office was looking into using unemployed or retrenched teachers for this purpose. Many of the child abuse cases heard in the city children's court in 1996 were crimes committed in the Bellville, Goodwood and Kuils River magisterial districts.

Similarly, recent figures showed that most rape cases were lodged with police in Mitchell's Plain, Goodwood, Khayelitsha and Guguletu, he said.

Tilly Brouwer, marketing director of the National Council for Child and Family Welfare, said rape and abuse of children was "way out of control. It's a moral outrage".

The statistics of child abuse represented only the tip of the iceberg, he said.

The child protection unit's report showed a 108% increase in crimes against children under 18 since 1993. Crimes included rape, sodomy, incest, indecent assault, other sexual offences, attempted murder, abduction, kidnapping and public indecency. However, these figures referred only to reported cases handled by the unit and specialised individuals. Last year alone, there were over 20 000 cases of sexual crimes and 8 500 assaults on children.

"These statistics are a national disgrace," said Mr Brouwer. "It is a shame that our children are treated in this way. But as more cases are being reported, it seems our nation is becoming more caring about our future generation."

It costs at least R6 000 a year for therapeutic services for one abused child and the cost of caring for a baby is R17 500 a year, he said.

The calls for help have not been ignored in the Western Province.

Mr Kahn said: "We have done a considerable amount of work together with the moral support of non-governmental organisations such as Rapcan and Rape Crisis, but the pressure we have applied has been ignored for so long.

"Over the years, promises have surfaced only when it became expedient to do so. Everyone pays lip service to the issue and my pleas have fallen on deaf ears.

"These developments haven't come easy. Even now, I've had to go with cap in hand to social welfare."

The go-ahead for the Parow court has been a major victory for his office. " It has shown this province takes the issue of rape seriously," he said.

The two courts have drawn the interest of the Zimbabwean government, which has requested prosecutorial assistance to establish its own victim-friendly courts.

"It's a pity that something as tragic as what occurred on Robben Island must give this impetus, when we have been knocking on the door since 1992 to establish the first two courts," said Mr Kahn.

But at last the Department of Justice was becoming more amenable to the idea of the special courts, he added.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


380 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Rayda Jacobs: in search of the Great South African novel


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Cape Town - When Rayda Jacobs returned to her roots in Cape Town "for good" after a 27-year exile in Canada she little knew she would bring a long-held dream to fruition by scooping a South African English literature prize for her first novel, Eyes of the Sky.

While Rayda modestly says she is "just a story-teller" some critics have compared her literary flair and style to top writers like Andr Brink and Nobel prizewinner for literature Nadine Gordimer.

Rayda, who penned her first story at the age of 12 and submitted it to Springbok Radio, has been awarded this year's Herman Charles Bosman prize of R7 500 for English literature.

She is the first recipient of the prize introduced by Nasionale Boekhandel, a publishing house with several autonomous subsidiary publishers. Books from several authors were submitted for the coveted prize which will be presented to her in Gauteng on April 24. 

In an interview at her Lakeside home soon after returning from her daily walk on Muizenberg beach with her two dogs - a Siberian husky and a Belgian shepherd - she said the award was a "great welcome back present".

Speaking of her house, which she described as the perfect setting for her writing, she said she had always wanted a house nestling at the foot of a mountain.

"I found my ideal home here in Lakeside," she said.

"While taking my dogs for their daily outing it also gives me the opportunity to be close to nature and enables me to meditate and to formulate ideas for my writing."

Of her writing, she says: "I was virtually forced to emigrate to Canada and felt I had to write about the land of my birth to forgive myself. Naturally, like any aspirant local writer, I would like one day to write the Great South African novel.

"On arrival in Lakeside two years ago I found an almost starved and virtually non-existent literary scene, so I started my own weekly writers' and poetry-reading sessions to stimulate writing.

"When I am not glued to my word processor, I manage to play a bit of Scrabble or even pursue my other hobbies like gardening - or fly my 1,3 metre kite."

Her novel, set in the 18th century in a desolate area of the Cape interior, is about identity, betrayal, forbidden love and the coming together of diverse cultures vying for the scant resources of an arid land.

"Basically it tells the saga of the early people of the Cape, who were here first, those who came after and why people did what they did.

"Most importantly, I wanted to give the people that I have most affection for - the Bushmen - a proper place.

"I wanted to show their ways, customs, how they lived, what they had to do to survive and what a gentle people they are."

But things were not always so rosy for Rayda - and she vividly recalls her uphill struggle in pursuing her chosen career after she was uprooted from Diep River, the suburb where she lived and attended school, when it was reserved exclusively for whites under the draconian Group Areas Act.

The incident and subsequent events fostered an abhorrence of South Africa's apartheid policies which was compounded when she had a run-in with the law over Race Classification legislation before she turned 21. When faced with the certainty of a head-on confrontation with the police if she remained, she opted to emigrate to Canada.

"I didn't want to go, but I had no choice really. I left very reluctantly after celebrating my 21st birthday. But all that is behind me now."

After settling in Toronto she married an Iranian and bore him a son, Faramarz, and daughter, Zaida, and pursued her great love - writing.

Her husband objected to this and it eventually contributed to the break-up of the marriage.

Her second marriage, to an Egyptian, was childless and also ended in divorce.

After going through the trauma of two divorces, she has demonstrated her resilience by continuing her literary career.

Her first book, called The Middle Children, was a partly autobiographical and partly fictional collection of interrelated short stories focusing on South Africans of mixed race in the apartheid era.

It was published in Canada in 1994 - 12 months before she returned to Cape Town.

While she still refers to herself as a South African-born Canadian because she believes Canada is very much part of her, she says her roots have been, and always will be, in Cape Town.

She explains: "I never put down anchors in Canada because I didn't go there willingly.

"My heart remained in the Cape and so did my love for the indigenous people of the Cape - with whom I will always associate myself.

"I wrote my novel in Toronto, did my research there, came to Cape Town in 1994 for a six-week holiday to meet some Bushmen at Kagga Kamma in the Cederberg Mountains. My book is dedicated to Oupa Regopstan - in memory of the oldest Bushman in South Africa. I interviewed him on video camera 12 months before he died."

Her latest collection of short stories, Postcards from South Africa, deals with present-day South Africa in the post-apartheid era and she is busy with her second novel - about Cape slaves a few years before emancipation.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 14, 1997


Sports - General;
Carving up Olympic pie so black firms get slice


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town's Community Olympic Forum is to help emergent black- owned businesses take advantage of special tendering procedures for multi- million rand bid-related projects.

Scores of small businesses and new contractors have come forward since the Cape Argus published a report last week on the introduction of an " affirmative procurement policy" devised specifically to target emergent enterprises from the previously disadvantaged sector. For many of them the tendering formalities are daunting. 

Project management consultancy Amsa which is responsible for managing the seven projects said new businesses wanting to compete for work on these projects would be given advance warning of the tender calls and that leaflets spelling out how to tender would be distributed.

Last week the Community Olympic Forum, representing wide-ranging civic and community organisations, said it would also help new and small businesses.

Forum chairperson Brian Williams, former unionist and now director of the Department of Labour in the Western Cape, said: "Small businesses and people who feel they have the skills and could contribute to these projects should contact the forum."

Rather than following the customary route of drawing up a single tender to cover an entire project which means only big companies are able to submit tenders, then sub-contract portions of the work the Olympic priority projects are being split up into as many as 20 "tender packages".

Roofing or electrical work, for instance, will be advertised as a tender package separate from the structural steel work or concrete construction elements of the project.

The projects for which tenders are to be called shortly are:

* a softball facility at the Turfhall Sports Complex in Athlone (R10- million);

* a Belhar community, sports and recreation hall, earmarked for judo during the Olympics (R18,25-million);

* a multi-purpose hall for boxing in Langa (R5-million);

* an indoor multi-purpose hall in Philippi East, earmarked for badminton in 2004 (R18-million);

* an indoor multi-purpose hall in Mew Way, Khayelitsha, earmarked for boxing (R16,7-million);

* a multi-purpose hall in Scottsdene, also earmarked for boxing (R2-million, in this case a contribution from the Cape Metropolitan Council); and

* an outdoor training facility for baseball in Grassy Park (R2-million).

The project managers at Amsa can be reached at 21 2363 and Mr Williams of the Community Olympic Forum can be reached at 460 5170.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
French 'oui' to R500-m boost for Muizenberg


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Cape Town - A top European investor is planning to pump nearly R500-million into the hotel and catering industry in the Muizenberg area, says Western Cape Economic Affairs Minister Chris Nissen.

In an interview with the Cape Argus, Mr Nissen said he would not name the company because negotiations were "at a sensitive stage". The minister secured the investment during a visit to three European countries last month. 

Other investments secured during the trip include R90-million for the upgrading of a city centre hotel, R60-million towards the establishment of a metal cap manufacturing plant by a French investor and R90-million for a company specialising in low-cost housing materials.

"During the trip we told them the Western Cape was an area they could come and invest in because we have the infrastructure and the environment," Mr Nissen said.

The Undivco group of France planned to open a plant manufacturing panels used in low-cost housing.

The Masilly group, also of France, would invest in the metal cap manufacturing plant.

The cap manufacturing plant would be established in Blue Downs, Mitchell's Plain or Atlantis. A decision still had to be made about its location.

The hotel would probably be in the central business district. The investor, whom he would not name, would "probably buy an existing hotel and revamp it", he said.

Mr Nissen did not rule out joint ventures by the European investors with local companies.

"Some of the investors will probably team up with local companies and of course we encourage them to do that," he said.

Mr Nissen added that nearly 600 jobs would be created as a result of the investments.

The minister has always insisted that only investments that create jobs will be considered by the provincial government and his ministry.

He added that it would probably take three months for the companies to enter the country and make the investments.

The Western Cape is aiming to attract R16-billion in investments from overseas by the end of year.

An official in Mr Nissen's office said the province had attracted nearly R13-billion in investments this year.

"It is a very realistic target and we are confident that we will meet it," said the official.

The announcement of the intention by the four companies to invest in the province went a long way towards meeting that target, Mr Nissen said.

April 14, 1997


Sports - General;
Rescue bid for Games environment impact study


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Cape Town - Talks are continuing this week to rescue Cape Town's Olympic strategic environmental assessment, which is running way behind schedule.

This follows delays in finalising the contract between the Bid Company and specialist consultants.

The study appeared to be in the balance last week, when the consultants said they were reviewing their approach and were not ready to sign the contract. 

Earlier in the week the Bid Company committed itself to the next phase of the assessment.

David Shandler of the assessment team said the two sides had met at the weekend and had made progress.

"I'm hoping we will be able to resolve this within the next few days," he said.

Mr Shandler said: "A considerable amount of time has passed since our appointment, and although phase one of the study has been completed, the context and conditions have changed, and we are having to re-look at our approach given these changes.

"We would certainly like to see the assessment going ahead," he said.

The study is intended to provide an independent assessment of the short- and long-term implications of the bid, and is one of the "minimum requirements" negotiated between the company and the environmental sector for environmentalists' role in the bid process.

Another of the requirements negotiated between the company and the environmentalists is an independent poll to test public opinion on whether the bid should continue, based on the results of the study. Details of how the poll is to be conducted have yet to be decided.

The study is to assess the bid in terms of economic performance, small business opportunities, public finance, public involvement, urban development, transport, nation-building, job creation, price effects, institutional capacity, population growth effects, housing, sport needs and the promotion of sustainability.

According to the original programme, the strategic assessment should have been commissioned in February, a draft working report produced by March, a review drafted by April or May and the final report by the end of May.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 14, 1997


South Africa;
Too much room at the inn? (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - All is not well in the tourism industry, particularly in the Western Cape, where growth has been well below full potential

The demise of Cape Town hotels over the past two decades or so - remember old landmarks like the President, the Elizabeth and the Clifton on the Atlantic seaboard - has been reversed with a proliferation of establishments under construction or in the planning stages.

The Table Bay at the Waterfront has just opened, several international chains are building on the Foreshore, hotels at Mouille Point and Hout Bay are planned and work is well under way on the controversial hotel on the White House site at Oudekraal.

These are just a few of the major developments in the mainstream accommodation industry which has also been bolstered in recent years by literally hundreds of bed and breakfasts and guesthouses as Cape Town gears itself for a major tourism boom and possibly hosting the 2004 Olympics. 

But a new word of caution comes in the latest issue of the monthly newsletter Tourism Info which warns that all is not well in the industry and that the Western Cape in particular should be gravely concerned about tourist figures for the 1996-1997 summer holiday season which were relatively poor and far below potential.

The journal reports that debate about the reasons has thrown up several possible causes, one being too high hotel prices, and warns that waning visitor numbers can only aggravate problems for the hotel industry with all the new hotels and resorts planned in the near future.

A lot is happening in the industry with the restructuring of Satour and the setting up of the SA Tourism Business Council which will be working hard to reverse the trend.

But developers and operators of hotels would do well to heed the warning bells and take care to offer service and value for money, not to oversaturate the market, and to beware of competition from destinations which are closer for travellers from North America, Europe and the East.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


385 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 14, 1997


South Africa;
Taxi crackdown nets scores of offenders


BYLINE: Johan Schronen and Andrea Botha, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Cape Town - A clampdown aimed at ending taxi violence in the Peninsula began today when scores of minibus taxi drivers were stopped and fined for not displaying stickers showing their approved routes.

The Cape Town traffic department concentrated on the Cape Town station deck taxi rank. The operation, which began at 7am, will carry on indefinitely. It follows a government announcement of stringent measures to regulate the taxi industry.

A traffic officer said minibus taxi operators had had ample warning and had been given two grace periods in the past two months.

Several drivers who were fined said the stickers were not fair. They threatened to disrupt the public transport system.

But the traffic officer said all operators with roadworthy vehicles and the required permits had been issued with stickers.

Days were numbered for illegal operators who tainted the minibus taxi industry by creating chaos and strife, he said.

Police, the army and traffic police are teaming up to enforce the law requiring minibuses to display the stickers. Operators without stickers were fined R150 but those without permits got fines up to R600.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 14, 1997


South Africa;
Boesak : The missing millions


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Cape Town - Full details were revealed for the first time today of charges involving R8,8-million, against Allan Boesak and his co-accused, bookkeeper Freddie Steenkamp.

They will be charged in the Cape High Court in August with fraud involving R5,7-million and theft of R3,1-million.

Dr Boesak, former head of the Foundation for Peace and Justice, is accused of using R1,1-million of the foundations's money for personal use, and Mr Steenkamp allegedly used R1,3-million. 

The charge sheet was formally handed in at the court today. Dr Boesak and Mr Steenkamp face 32 charges, 12 of fraud and 20 of theft.

Freddie Steenkamp appeared in court this morning and the case was postponed to August 4. He was not asked to plead.

Dr Boesak appeared in the Cape Town Magistrate's Court on March 17.

They are alleged to have defrauded the Coca-Cola Foundation by misrepresenting to the foundation that they needed $50 000 for the Caravan Project in Carnarvon and Van Wyksvlei in the Karoo.

They allegedly failed to disclose to the foundation that the money was to be used to obtain overseas loans for the Cross Times Trust. Dr Boesak allegedly said it would be used for the Caravan project.

They will be charged with fraud in that the Children's Trust allegedly only received R423 000 of R682 000 received from American singer Paul Simon for the trust.

They will be charged with theft for allegedly using part of this money to clear the foundation's overdraft instead, without the permission of the trustees of the Children's Trust.

They will be charged with stealing the balance.

They will be charged with stealing money donated by Swedish aid agency Sida for an audiovisual project to make 12 videos. Sida donated R762 000 for the videos for rural voter education. The money was allegedly used to build a studio for Dr Boesak's wife, Elna.

Dr Boesak allegedly misrepresented to Sida what he was to use the money for.

He and Mr Steenkamp face seven charges of fraud relating to misrepresentations in the foundation's annual financial statements from 1988 to 1994.

The charges allege parts of their expenses were allocated to projects by way of journal entries in order to hide from donors and trustees of the foundation the high cost of salaries, transport and staff loans.


LOAD-DATE: April 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


387 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Uganda;
IMF Wants Tax Holidays For Investors Scrapped


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 923 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The International Monetary Fund has asked Uganda to stop offering tax holidays to investors and instead extend to them generous initial investment allowances, the New Vision newspaper reported Tuesday.

The newspaper said Ulrike Wilson, the fund's resident representative in Kampala said Monday the Fund had already expressed its opposition on tax holidays to the Uganda government saying they offer many "giveaways." She said tax holidays robbed the economy of resources, thus leaving investment allowances as the appropriate tool since they are offered selectively. 

"Tax holidays are not an efficient way of encouraging new investments. They are granted to everyone," she told the local NewsLine newspaper.

"What we prefer instead of tax holidays is for instance a very generous initial investment allowance. That is something that targets at attracting new investments," she added.

She did not, however, elaborate on the form of investment allowances although sources say it involves reduction in corporate taxes during the initial investment period.

Uganda is in the process of reviewing its investment laws, and it is likely the donor's idea will not be considered.

Analysts say tax holidays have been instrumental in attracting investment to the country for the last six years.

The Uganda Investment Authority says at least 2,400 projects worth 3.249 billion U.S. dollars have been licensed since July 1994.

Investments worth 1.233 billion dollars are said to have either taken off or are in the final stages of completion.

Officials at the Ministry of Planning, under which the investment authority falls say, however, the IMF position, if adopted, would make the country less attractive for foreign investments.

"We shall resist this position in the investment law. It is less attractive compared to tax holidays," said an official, who did not want to be identified by name.

He said a local investor making new investments of at least 50,000 dollars and a foreign entrepreneur making capital investments or an equivalent in capital goods worth 500,000 were eligible to tax exemptions of between three to five years.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


388 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Zambia;
Government Suspends Tabling Media Council Bill


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Bowing to pressure from journalists, the Zambian government has suspended its decision to table a controversial media council draft bill.

In a statement, the country's information and broadcasting services minister, David Mpamba, said on Tuesday that the bill has been suspended to provide an opportunity for debate and exchange of views with stakeholders.

Mpamba said government took the measure because the draft bill which was published as a discussion paper had generated considerable debate and emotion among media practitioners and the general public. 

The proposed bill which has been rejected by journalists has been the center of heated debate in the country since its publication last week.

The bill has also been opposed by the London-based Commonwealth Press Union (CPU), the International Press Institute and some donors.

In his statement, Mpamba regretted that some diplomats accredited to Zambia have taken it upon themselves to issue very crude instructions to the government on the bill.

Over 200 Zambian journalists from both the government and private media on Saturday staged a demonstration in Lusaka to oppose the plan to legalize the media council, which is aimed at controlling the work of journalists.

The journalists maintained that the rejection of the media council was non- negotiable and to discuss the bill would mean to legitimize what the government wants.

The media council bill, published in a local daily a week ago, seeks to regulate media organisations. It envisages the compulsory registration of journalists, to set minimum qualifications for them. It will also institute a disciplinary body for media practitioners.

The council will have the power to reprimand, suspend or withdraw accreditation to offending journalists.

To practice, journalists must have attained the age of 18, hold a bachelor's degree in Arts or Mass Communication obtained from a university or institution recognized by the council. Journalists will also be required to have completed at least two years training in journalism.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


389 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia Secures Italian Financial Aid


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Last week's five-day official visit to Italy by Prime Minister Meles Zenawi has generated about 60 million U.S. dollars in aid and long-term loan to Ethiopia, according to reports by the local media.

Meles' visit and talks with leading business concerns in Rome and Florence also resulted in two Italian companies signing agreements on joint ventures in a steel mill and granite INL002 from SSS.089 (970415-18:04) QN PANAINL . PANADKR MSG088G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) production, the Ethiopian Herald reported. 

The premier returned home Saturday night. His 70-member entourage included some 50 business people.

Italy agreed to provide Ethiopia with 40 million dollars for the construction of a 260-km rural road, connecting the town of Debrework, in East Gojjam Province, north-western Ethiopia, with Kombolcha, through Mekaneselam, both in South Wollo Province, in Central Ethiopia.

In addition, Italy is to provide Ethiopia with 19 million dollars long-term, low-interest loan.

Over 80 Italian entrepreneurs in Rome and in Florence were said to have shown interest to invest in Ethiopia. Two companies signed joint ventures for establishing a small-scale steel mill for producing building and engineering structures, and for mining granites.

The Ethiopian foreign minister, Seyoum Mesfin, and his Italian counterpart, Lamberto Dini, also signed cooperation agreements between the two countries on investment guarantees and avoidance of double taxation as well as on cultural cooperation.

The latter includes the return to Ethiopia of the 24-meter high Axum Obelisk, carted away in 1937 from the northern Ethiopian historic city of Axum on the personal orders of the fascist dictator, Benito Mussolini.

Italy is to bear the cost of transportation of the obelisk and for replanting in at its original site, where Axumite artisans were said to have chiselled the obelisk from solid granite in the second century. The work is expected to be carried out before the end of 1997.

The obelisk presently stands opposite the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organisation headquarters in Rome, close to the Colosseum.

LANGUAGE: English

390 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Uganda;
Airline Bosses Undecided About Merger


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Kampala, Uganda (PANA) The management of Uganda Airlines Corporation is not keen on the proposed merger with Alliance Air, whose financial position is said to be enviable, the New Vision newspaper reported Tuesday.

The Kampala-based government daily newspaper cited a management position paper to the board which said that Alliance Air had lost 18 million U.S. dollars since it started operations in 1996. 

It said the losses were attributed to use of an expensive aircraft, poor marketing and lavish expenditure by company officials.

Alliance uses Boeing 747 SP on its long haul routes from Johannesburg, South Africa, to Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania; Entebbe, Uganda, and London. Critics says that the airplane which seats some 400 people, owned by South African Airways, has proved expensive on this route and costly to maintain.

Maintenance and fuel costs constitute on average of 60 percent of the costs of a commercial airline.

However, Alliance Corporation Secretary Fred Ochieng Obbo denied that the airline had made losses.

"In fact we are prospering. We have made some money. But of course we are paying off some of the borrowed funds which we initially started with," he said.

The merger has come under stiff resistance, although it is being pushed for by some other quarters. Last week, the Daily News of Tanzania reported that the government in Dar es Salaam deferred endorsement of the proposed merger of Air Tanzania Corporation, Uganda Airlines Corporation and Alliance Air. The Tanzanian government has referred the merger proposal to the Ministry of Transport for further study.

Obbo said the proposed three-way merger was made by the governments of Uganda and Tanzania. Ugandan and Tanzanian transport ministers met February 17 in Kampala and resolved that the three airlines merge before privatization.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


391 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Zaire;
UN Appeals To Zairean Rebel Leader To Negotiate


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

NEW YORK (PANA) - United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan has appealed to the organization's member states to pressure Zairean anti-government leader Laurent Kabila to negotiate a solution to the conflict in the country.

He said Monday that a negotiated solution to the crisis could only be achieved by a cease-fire and sustained talks on the future of Zaire, Africa's third largest country. 

"It is obvious that Zaire is on the verge of a major political change but this change has to be managed, with the support of the international community, in a concerted and focused manner," Annan said.

"In such situations, progress is usually made when the entire international community comes together," he added.

Annan's statement, issued in Rome where he is on a visit, came amid reports that the rebels have begun their advance on Kinshasa, after capturing a sting of major cities and towns.

He said that a durable solution to the war could not be achieved through military means. So, he said it was encouraging that President Mobutu Sese Seko had agreed to talks with Kabila.

"The stakes are high. If we are successful, Zaire could begin to move in the direction of national reconciliation, democracy and prosperity," he said. "If we fail, it will mean misery and stagnation for millions of people in the region."

Annan expressed concern that implementation of the five-point U.S. Peace Plan had not begun, in spite of its acceptance of it by the Zairean government and the rebels.

The plan, endorsed by the Security Council, calls for an immediate cease- fire, withdrawal of all foreign troops, including mercenaries, protection of refugees and reaffirmation of respect for national sovereignty and territorial integrity of Zaire and other states in the region.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


392 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Nigeria;
Fela Sues Nigerian Drug Agency Over Detention


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (pana) - Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, Nigeria's internationally renowned "Afro-Beat" musician, has sued the National Drug Law Enforcement Agency (NDLEA), claiming 1.1 million U.S. dollars in damages over his arrest and detention last week on drug charges.

Fela and 107 others were arrested by NDLEA officials on April 7, at his Lagos residence and nightclub.

He was shown to newsmen two days later in handcuffs at a press conference addressed by the NDLEA chairman Maj.Gen. Musa Bamaiyi. 

At the televised press briefing, Bamaiyi accused Fela of being in possession of an undisclosed quantity of Indian hemp at the time of his arrest.

He said the agency had plans to prosecute the musician for ignoring a previous warning to lay off the substance.

Fela admits to deriving psychological motivation from the use of Indian hemp, which he calls "natural grass." He says the substance has medicinal value.

In a suit filed at a Lagos Federal High Court Monday by his lawyer and friend, Femi Falana, Fela is claiming 100 million naira (about 1.1 million U. S. dollars) as damages for the arrest and detention, which the lawyer called unconstitutional.

Falana also wants the court to declare that the NDLEA lacks competence to charge Fela before the miscellaneous offenses tribunal for possession of Indian hemp.

He claimed the musician was "forcefully removed from his residence contrary to medical advice."

The lawyer is therefore praying the court to order Fela's release to continue his medical treatment.

In the application supported by an affidavit deposed by Femi, his musician son, Fela is also requesting the court to order the NDLEA and its agents to vacate his nightclub called the "Afrika Shrine" pending the determination of the suit.

Making a case for his father's release, Femi claimed Fela had never jumped bail, even though he had faced more criminal prosecutions than any other Nigerian, living or dead. No date has been fixed for hearing the case.

Fela had been in and out of detention in the past for charges ranging from murder to public assault.

He was jailed by a military tribunal in 1984 for foreign exchange trafficking under a stringent law enacted by the regime of former military ruler, Gen. Muhammadu Buhari.

A year ago, the musician was arrested and detained by NDLEA officials on another drug charge. The agency did not press charges then, but opted instead to counsel Fela with the hope of persuading him to give up Indian hemp.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


393 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Zaire Emergency Fact Sheet No. 11


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . ZAIRE - Complex Emergency, Fact Sheet 11, Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, April 15, 1997. Note: The last fact sheet was dated April 10, 1997.

Background: In mid-October 1996, fighting broke out in South Kivu, Zaire between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance) led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting caused Rwandan and Burundian refugees to flee, forcing over 700,000 Rwandans and 62,000 Burundians to repatriate by the end of 1996. 

Hundreds of thousands of refugees also fled west, scattering in small groups deeper into Zaire. The fighting spread north, west, and south, with the Alliance gaining territory on all fronts. The Alliance now controls approximately one-third of Zaire. Following the capture of Mubji-Mayi on April 5, the Alliance seized Lubumbashi, Zaire's second largest city, and the copper-mining center of Zaire, on April 9.

Haut-Zaire Province: Approximately 89,500 Rwandan refugees are clustered in three groups along the 125 km rail line west of the Zaire River, south of Kisangani: 57,000 at km 25, 31,000 at km 41, and 2,500 at km 82. Humanitarian agencies have set up therapeutic feeding centers, water sources, medical facilities, and services for unaccompanied children at each site. The United Nations (U.N.) World Health Organization reports 150 cholera cases at km 25. The cholera strain is not virulent and Medecins Sans Frontieres International (MSF/I) has already begun treating affected refugees in two isolation tents.

USAID's Disaster Assistance Response Team (USAID/DART) field officer flew to Ubundu town on April 13 with WFP, MSF/I, and Oxfam and noted that about 100 of the 325 refugees remaining there are in extremely vulnerable condition. The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) plans to move the refugees by train to km 41 once the weak are stabilized. The U.N. World Food Program (WFP) has begun distributing food to Zairians whose food supply has been affected by the foraging of refugees, ex-FAR, and Interahamwe.

The Alliance and the Government of Rwanda insist that air repatriation of the most vulnerable refugees from the Kisangani area cannot begin until the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has completed its airlift of nearly 13,000 internally displaced persons (IDPs). ICRC and UNHCR transported 57 unaccompanied children and 447 IDPs to Goma in the last week. UNHCR has 35 trucks and five small planes ready to transport refugees. The British Overseas Development Agency is establishing an air logistics cell in Goma and a transportation unit in Kisangani, which will control air, road, and river movements for the repatriation.

Kivu Province: On March 31, UNHCR reported that 20,000 - 30,000 Rwandan refugees emerged at Karuba, 13 km west of Sake. Another 2,500 surfaced at Tongo, west of the former camps of Katale and Kahindo, north of Goma. Once the refugees are screened by Alliance forces, UNHCR trucks them directly to the Rwandan border. From April 1 - 11, 20,817 refugees repatriated from Karuba and Tongo. An additional 15,000 refugees have reportedly emerged in the Masisi region. USAID/DART's Goma field representative traveled to Kindu with ICRC to assess humanitarian needs. Of the 909 IDPs in Kindu, 806 are living with families, and 103 live in an old depot in the center of town. The IDPs and locals are healthy with adequate water sources and sanitation. The most important needs are medical equipment, medicines, and chemical treatment for water stations.

Kasai-Oriental Province: At least 30,000 refugees are moving towards Angola. They are believed to be the group who fled the Shabunda area camps in South Kivu.

U.S. Government (USG) Assistance: On March 14, USAID/DART arrived in the region to help advance relief efforts in eastern Zaire. USAID/DART installed an information officer in Nairobi and field officers in Goma and Kisangani. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has seconded two doctors to UNICEF. BHR/OFDA has provided grants to ICRC to assist Zairian IDPs and repatriating Rwandan refugees and to Save the Children/UK for vulnerable Rwandan and Zairian unaccompanied children. The State Department's Bureau for Population, Refugees, and Migration has provided funding to ICRC and to UNHCR for IDPs and refugees in eastern Zaire. Between December and February, BHR's Office of Food for Peace provided roughly 2,500 MT of food to eastern Zaire from the Rwanda Regional Program.

Total OFDA Assistance (to date). . . . . . . . . . . . $5,548,118

Other USG Assistance (to date) . . . . . . . . . . . . $7,750,000

TOTAL USG FY 1997 Humanitarian Assistance (to date). .$13,298,118


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


South Africa;
MEC protests reports on deputy speaker's 'fake' license


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Nelspruit - Police investigations into the alleged fraudulent license issued to Parliament's deputy speaker, Baleke Mbete Kgositsile, in Mpumalanga are expected to expose widespread corruption in the traffic departments of the three former homelands which make up the province.

Kgositsile is one of 44 people, most from KwaZulu Natal, who are currently being investigated by the Nelspruit Fraud Unit for possessing fake temporary licenses supposedly issued at the Kabokweni Test Centre in KaNgwane.

Although police continued to refuse to comment on their "highly sensitive" investigation on Monday, sources within the province's Safety & Security Department told African Eye News Service (South Africa) that the investigation was expected to reveal well organised syndicates which used former homeland traffic officers and government officials to issue "legal" driver licenses.

Some of these officials are reportedly now senior provincial administrators and test centre heads. 

Kgositsile insists that she was legally tested for her license at the Delmas test centre in Mpumalanga on October 1 last year, after the provincial Safety & Security MEC, Steve Mabona, specially organised the test for her "to save me from standing in queues, as I am a very busy person with children scattered all over the country, a job in Cape Town and a constituency in KwaZulu".

Kgositsile said in a press release on Monday that she welcomed any police investigation into illegal licenses but insisted that to the best of her knowledge the temporary license issued to her was a legal document.

She supplied the press with copies of her ID and the temporary license to the press but refered all further queries to MEC Mabona.

Mabona, who says that he sent his own vehicle and bodyguards to fetch Kgositsile for the test from Johannesburg on October 1, insisted that it was not irregular that there were no official records of either Kgositsile's test or temporary license at the centre where she was supposedly tested.

He also insisted that it was not irregular or illegal that the license currently being used by Kgositsile was actually issued 350km away from Delmas, at Kabokweni, and without the knowledge of Kabokweni staff.

Both Kgositsile and Mabona say that the test at Delmas was personally conducted by provincial traffic head, Director Henry Brazer, but Brazer repeatedly refused to discuss the issue for fear of "incriminating myself".

Insisting that the media coverage of the investigation was a deliberate smear campaign by African Eye News Service (South Africa) investigative reporters, Mabona said in a press statement on Monday night that "the report was made by a ignorant reporter who has never served in the Government administration or any other administration" (sic).

Dismissing initial reports on Sunday as a distortion of the facts aimed at embarrassing Kgositsile, Mabona added that reporters writing on the issue " lack objectivity and impartiality .. and have alternative motives".

"As political head, I would like to state that I am satisfied and convinced that the license issued to Kgositsile was legal," he added.

Mabona also alleged in his statement that details about the investigation had been leaked to the press by principal traffic officer, John Muller, who was "a biased official against whom the department has taken action because of his failure to report for work, ... his racism and insubordination".

Denying that his department had ever halted an internal investigation into the allegations against Kgositsile last year, Mabona said that neither he nor his departmental head had even received an official complaint about the matter.

Mabona did, however, acknowledge that a request was forwarded to department head, Advocate Stanley Soko, for an inspection of the 'master' license books at Kabokweni.

"(Muller) is a mere principle (sic) traffic officer who does not have any authority and competency to demand the books from other offices. Such books can only be obtained by the Head Office through proper channels and protocol," he explained.

"The department head issued instructions that no books should be given to him."

Although Muller played a key role in earlier investigations which led to the arrest of 11 government officials for selling licenses to the public and also brought the government's attention to the fact that Director Brazer had admitted to irregularly using State funds to go on holiday with his family to the USA, Adv Soko decided not to follow up on Muller's allegations.

"Look, I did quiz Brazer verbally about the charges but was satisfied with his explanation," explained Soko. He admitted that he did not bother to check Brazer's explanation with either the Delmas or Kabokweni test centre heads.

Charging that Muller had failed to turn up at work for 24-months but had insisted on being paid, Mabona repeatedly labelled Muller a racist in his press statement, who had "run to the opposition to exert pressure to get his salary and who was engaged in a vendetta against the department."

Mabona's press release, however, failed to address the fact that there are no official records of the license at Delmas, that the license was issued contrary to national regulations, outside the magisterial district of Delmas, in Kabokweni without the knowledge of staff there.

He also fails to explain why initial complaints of fraud involving prominent politicians, whether formal or not, were not followed up on or reported to the police by his department.

Muller declined to comment on the issue, saying that he awaited the results of the police investigation and that he had refered the allegations of racism to his attorney.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 15, 1997


South Africa;
Quest for bad luck cure ends in death


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

THOHOYANDOU - Police have launched an inquest into the death of a 26-year- old woman who died after a self-proclaimed prophet from the Golgotha Zion Apostolic Church in Northern Province allegedly overdosed her with traditional medicine to cure her of bad luck, at Tshilungoma II near Thoyandou on the weekend.

Virginia Muthelo died from severe diarrhea which fatally dehydrated her over an 18-hour period, leading to total kidney failure.

She was given the 'cleansing' herbal medicine by the 44-year-old prophet to clean what he called her "filthy intestines" after complaining of two years of bad luck. 

Witnesses report that almost immediately after drinking the liquid herbal brew, Muthelo "lost energy, rushed to a outhouse toilet and stayed there for hours before dying on the toilet".

"Five other elderly people also drunk the medicine, but only Virginia died. We are therefore confused, because she was the youngest and therefore supposedly the strongest," said police spokesperson, Captain Ailwei Mushavhanamadi.

It was uncertain, he added, whether all five people drank the same kind of medicine.

The pint-sized prophet remained adamant on Tuesday that his medicine could not have killed Muthelo but that "the extreme coldness she must have experienced in the outhouse toilet" was probably responsible.

He told police that he had been treating patients for at least five years, insisting that no one died before.

"That's bullshit! My daughter was strong and healthy, I do not believe that she died of coldness," France Muthelo (52), the deceased's father told African Eye News Service (South Africa).

"My daughter had been looking for help to rid of her bad luck two years. Just when she thought she had found a solution, it killed her."

According to investigating officer, Detective-Sergeant Mpfariseni Ligunuba, the prophet is expected to bring his medicine to the police station on Wednesday to be tested.

"We are waiting for the postmortem results before the prophet can be detained as a suspect." Said Sergeant Ligunuba.

The other people who also received treatment from the prophet include Virginia's mother, Tshinakaho Muthelo (49), Johannes Makatu (66) and three other elderly people. (South Africa)

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Sports - General;
ANC lauds Thugwane's third place medal


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 133 words


 

Nelspruit - The African National Congress (ANC) in Mpumalanga lauded South African Olympic gold medalist Josaya Thugwane on Tuesday for his "sterling" third place medal in the London Marathon on Sunday.

Pointing out that Thugwane had broken his personal record set at the Atlanta Olympic games last year, ANC spokesperson Vusi Sibiya said that this proved that the Olympic win "was not just a stroke of good luck".

Stressing his importance as a role-model for disadvantaged children in Mpumalanga, Sibiya added that Thugwane also served as a excellent international ambassador for Mpumalanga. (South Africa)
