Africa News


April 15, 1997


South Africa;
Game ranger acquitted for double murder


BYLINE: Benjamin Shabalala, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Nelspruit - A 33-year-old game ranger from the Kruger National Park was acquitted of murder by the Nelspruit Circuit of the Supreme Court, after the State failed to prove that he purposely gunned down two of his colleagues while they watched television last year.

Freddy Mashele was arrested after the two men, Ephriam Mavundla and Thembani Mashaba, were repeatedly shot in the chest with an R1 rifle while they were relaxing at the private Nwanetsi Camp in the Kruger National Park on February 29, 1996. 

The court found that while Mashele had pleaded guilty to shooting the men, the State had been unable to prove that he had consciously planned or intended to shoot them.

Pointing out that Mashele had been very drunk at the time of the incident and the witnesses admitted that he'd not been "consciously" in control of his actions, the court ruled that he could therefore not be found liable for murder.

The prosecution had alleged that Mashele confronted his two fellow rangers in the camp's staff recreation quarters after an earlier argument and shot them with his R1 service rifle before they could defend themselves.

Mavundla died immediately after the metal tipped sharp point R1 bullets hit his heart and lungs. A medical report submitted to court said that the bullets completely shredded his heart and left-hand lung.

Mashaba survived the initial shot but died while being rushed to a clinic at the Kruger Park's Setara Camp. A medical report said that Mashaba died of massive internal shock and a complete collapse of his blood circulation system after R1 bullets hit him in the abdominal aorta vein. (South Africa)


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 15, 1997


South Africa;
Police tear gas students as fist fight ends meeting


BYLINE: George Mthethwa, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

EMPANGENI - Police had to fire tear-gas to disperse hundreds of students who attended a student council meeting at the University of KwaZulu Natal on Monday after a fist fight erupted between Student Representative Council (SRC) members and opponents from two other student organisations.

No arrests were made and no injuries were reported, but the campus remains tense with both the South African Students Congress and the Pan-Africanist Students Organisation accusing the SRC of betraying student's interests by collaborating with campus management. 

SRC president and Azanian Student's Congress member, Mbongiseni Ndlela convened the meeting to report that the SRC had managed to register a record number of students at the university for the 1997 academic year.

He denied allegations of collusion with campus management, however, with regards to the new fee structure system, whereby students are charged for every subject they take.

There are also separate accommodation, catering and material fees.

When students from opposing organisations began screaming for the SRC's unbanding and for new elections, Ndlela attempted to close the meeting.

Instead, angry students jumped onto the stage and began beating SRC members, while small scuffles also broke out in the crowd.

Police, who had been monitoring the meeting, fired one tear-gas canister to disperse the students.

South Africa;
Men appeared in court with R350 00 worth of dagga


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

OGIES - Two young men appeared briefly in the Ogies Magistrate Court on Monday after they arrested with 21 bags of dagga worth R325 000 at Leeufontein-Balmoral gravel Road near Ogies on Sunday. 

France Shabangu (26) and Ernest Ngomane (24) of Kwaggafontein in former KwaNdebele were not asked to pleaded after police confiscated 21 mealie meal bags full of dagga.

The two men testified in court that they are presently unemployed and that were going sell the dagga to support themselves and their families.

Shabangu and Ngomane were not given any bail and their case was remanded to April 30 for further investigation.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


400 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumalanga's finance department's budget doubles


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Nelspruit - The R655-million budget for Mpumalanga's finance and corporate services department for the 1997/ 98 fiscal year is double that of last year's budget, announced provincial finance MEC Jacques Modipane on Tuesday.

The unprecedented increase is as a result of the centralisation of provincial government functions in the department and the transfer of various administrative support functions from other departments into the finance department, Modipane told the provincial legislature during his 1997 policy speech.

The most important objectives of his department, however, remains the eradication of inefficiency and corruption, with the adoption of a harder line policy for prosecuting frauds. 

Conceding that the past year had been "challenging" to his department, with a move to partially completed buildings seriously hampering the department's ability to provide effective services, Modipane stressed his success in increasing provincial earnings from own revenues.

These revenues, which cannot be reclaimed by central government, at least matched the inflation rate, he said.

"Although this may not appear to be all that significant, it must be noted that certain programmes will only bear fruit two to three years down the line, " he added.

"These programmes are notably those affecting the collection of fees, such as licensing fees."

Modipane also announced that in light of previous financial control problems experienced by Mpumalanga, it had become inevitable to appoint internal audit committees.

The most significant infrastructure improvement made during the past year, he said , is the replacement of old computer systems with a more efficient and compatible system, which has already enabled the department to ensure that its expenditure reports for management monitoring had been produced timeously since September last year.

The largest chunk of the 1997/ 98 budget, R468-million, was allocated to the Provincial Treasury, while R15-million will be spent on administration and salaries, R15-million on financial management and R89-million on the construction of government buildings and other structures.

The amount reserved for new buildings includes the initial phases of the new provincial government complex and legislature in Nelspruit.

An additional R65,6-million will be allocated to the various development agencies in Mpumalanga, including the Mpumalanga Finance Corporation and the discredited Mpumalanga Development Corporation. (South Africa)


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


401 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


South Africa;
Eight Applicants Granted Amnesty


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Cape Town - The Amnesty Committee of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission has granted amnesty to another eight applicants, including members or supporters of the African National Congress, the United Democratic Front, the End Conscription Campaign and the Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging.

The applicants all applied for amnesty in respect of offences which do not fall within the definition of a gross violation of human rights, as laid down in the law governing the operations of the commission. As a result no public hearings were necessary and the Committee took its decisions in chambers. (The law defines killing, abduction, torture and severe ill-treatment as gross violations). 

The following are the details:

1. Abel Bhila

Abel Bhila, 29, who describes himself as a member/or supporter of the African National Congress and Umkhonto weSizwe, was sentenced to six years' imprisonment for unlawful possession of firearms and/or handgrenades. He said in his application he was found in possession of a handgrenade in a bag he was carrying in central Johannesburg on March 24, 1993.

2. Saul Barrie Batzofin

Saul Batzofin, 27, a member of the End Conscription Campaign, was sentenced to 18 months' imprisonment in 1989 for refusing to serve in the former South African Defence Force. He has completed his sentence but told the Commission that he wanted to apply for amnesty to clear his criminal record. He said although he was proud to have been a conscientious objector, the record caused difficulties with visa applications for foreign countries.

3. Reginald Jameson

Reginald Jameson, 38, who described himself as a UDF supporter, also applied for amnesty in respect of a sentence which he has already served. He told the Committee he was jailed for a year on arson and public violence charges after student unrest in June 1976. He said he had taken part an arson attempt at Modderdam High School, Bonteheuwel, in the expectation of a new, better school being built.

4. Mncedisi Mzolisi Klaas

Mncedisi Klaas, 27, an ANC Youth League organiser, applied for amnesty in respect of charges of robbery, malicious damage to property and sabotage. He told the Committee that the offences were committed during the course of a conflict over services between township residents and the local authorities in Motherwell, Port Elizabeth, in 1992. He said the vehicles which were the subject of the robbery and damage to property charges were targeted because they were government vehicles. The sabotage charge arose out of damage to electricity lines and the sub-stations. He was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment.

5. Duke Wellington Moilwanyane

Duke Moilwanyane, 24, who described himself as a ANC supporter, was convicted on charges of public violence and malicious damage to property after a confrontation with police at Ikageng, Potchefstroom, on March 24, 1993. He said he was among protest marchers who clashed with police at the entrance to Ikageng as they attempted to march to the office of the former Department of Education and Training in Potchefstroom. He was jailed for four years on the public violence charge and 2 years on the charge of damaging property.

6. Alison Motsopi

Alison Motsopi, 27, described himself as a member of ANC Youth League. He told the Committee he had possessed handgrenades in Vosloorus on the East Rand in 1992. He said his actions should be viewed against the background of conflict with the IFP in the region at the time. He said in his amnesty application that although the charges had been withdrawn at the time, police had later re-opened the case.

7. Kevin John Trytsman

Kevin Trytsman, 28, of Sandton, was granted amnesty in respect of charges of illegal possession of firearms and ammunition, vehicle theft and perjury. He said in his amnesty application that he was found in possession of an AK- 47 rifle, two magazines and a car on a farm he was renting near Knoppieslaagte. Trytsman was given a suspended sentence for possession of the firearm, a fine for the possession of the magazines and a five-year jail sentence for vehicle theft. He told the Committee he had given the court false explanations for possessing the material -- in fact he had been storing them on behalf of Umkhonto weSizwe. Mr Trytsman was sentenced in 1994.

Motivating his application relating to the perjury charge, Mr Trytsman said that while awaiting trial on the other charges, he had been approached by one Ferdi Barnard and one Eugene Reilly regarding information about his MK commander. He had "to a certain extent" become friendly with Barnard and Reilly. Barnard had bragged to him that he had shot Dr David Webster and that Reilly had been driving him at the time. Mr Trytsman said he was called to give evidence at the inquest into Dr Webster's death but had failed to tell the inquest of Mr Barnard's statement.

8. Albertus Francois van der Merwe

Albertus van der Merwe, 58, who describes himself as an AWB member, was jailed in 1994 for eight years on charges of sabotage and the transport or storage of explosives. He told the Committee he was a member of the explosives unit of the AWB's special task force which was responsible for explosions during November and December 1993 at a government weighbridge in the Krugersdorp district, at an electrical sub-station at Munsieville, Krugersdorp, and at the shop of a suspected ANC supporter at Burgershoop, Krugersdorp. He had also been involved in attempting to cause an explosion at a sub-station near the Voortrekker Monument in Pretoria.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia: Legal, illegal exchange of dollar becoming equivalent


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - the narrow margin in the value of dollar between banks and the black market is an indicative of the fact that Ethiopia's economy is displaying health progress, a senior government official in the Office of the Prime Minister has said.

Ato Fantaye Biftu, head of the trade and finance supervision bureau in the office with the rank of a minister, said it is illegal to exchange dollar outside banks and added that the illegal exchange of dollar is of no benefit as the margin between the value at banks and the black market has already narrowed. 

As some offices are privileged to get foreign exchanges and travellers are entitled to earn foreign currencies at commercial banks, the black market would soon die its natural death, Ato Fantaye said.

He also said the prevalent economic order has enabled importers to earn foreign exchanges at the weekly auction.

The head said the country's foreign exchange reserve which had been a serious threat previously, has now reached the level it could meet the demand of bidders at the auction.

Ato Fantaye said the trial to earn foreign exchanges could possible entail loss by amassing fake notes, adding that exporters are now privileged to open an account in foreign exchanges.

According to the head, the reserve requirement for private banks is 5 percent where as it is 8 per cent for government banks.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Ethiopia;
Supreme court president, seven other justice staff dismissed


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Gambella (ENA) - Supreme Court President of Gambella Regional State and seven other justice bureau staff have been dismissed from their posts for abuse of justice and maladministration. 

Ato Assefa Mustafa, representative of the justice, police, law and security affairs in the regional council, said the persons were fired because they have employed workers contrary to government regulation, committed maladministration as well as spent government money for personal purposes.

He further said the supreme court president used to dismiss and appoint judges on his own will, while undertaking court activities individually when it should have been done together with the administrative council.

The dismissed persons were also accused of spending money meant for construction activities, for their personal purposes.

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Ethiopia;
Religious fathers condemn rape, child molestation.


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Leaders of various religious institutions have condemned the ever increasing practices in the country of rape and molestation of under aged girls.

In connection with the escalating records of rape in Addis and other regions, the religious fathers told the Ethiopian Penal Code on the practices of rape and child molestation, which they said is very much lax, should be tightened. 

They described the molestation of sexually immature girls and raping of women as bestial. Head of Gospel Teaching Department of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, Kesis Dagnachew Kassahun said the church strongly opposes such cursed practices.

Kesis Dagnachew indicated that the EOC is giving spiritual teachings about the necessity of chastity until marriage.

Secretary of the Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Eyesus, Reverend Megersa Guta said strong measures should be taken on rapists and child abusers.

Reverend Megersa said Mekane Eyesus is giving teachings against rape, women adduction and other harmful practices. He called on the public to condemn such practices.

Chairman of the Region 14 Islamic Affairs Supreme Council on his part called for joint efforts of religious institutions and the public to uproot the aforementioned practices which, he said, are cursed.

Deputy head of gospel service at the Catholic Church Cathedral Lideta Mariam said societies should voice their opposition in unison against such inhumane practices.

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Ethiopia;
Gode irrigation development project well underway


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Ministry of water Resources says the Gode Irrigation Development Project being undertaken on Wabi Shebelle River would enable the cultivation of over 155,000 tonnes of various crops annually.

The project covering 27,560 hectares of land and for which the government has already expended 62.3 million birr would come into effect later in June this year. 

The project enables the production of 74,000 tonnes of maize and sorghum, 45,000 tonnes of cotton and 40,000 tonnes of oil seeds per annum.

The Ministry says the project would help meet the raw material demand of factories and create employment opportunity for the people in the region.

The irritation project would also assist efforts being made to enable the over one million pastoralists to engage in agricultural activities, the Ministry added.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


406 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Ethiopia;
Meles, Prodi meet in Rome


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Rome (ENA) - Ethiopia and Italy yesterday expressed interest to work together by further consolidating the existing friendly relations.

Prime Minister Meles Zenawi and his Italian counterpart Romano Prodi said during talks that, the relation between Italy and Ethiopia did not to date get the attention it deserved and added this would rectified in the future.

During the talks, Prime Minister Meles said Italy's new move in giving due attention to Africa is praise-worthy and consultations between Italy and Ethiopia will be of great political importance.

Prime Minister Meles also gave briefings on Ethiopia's efforts in seeking solution to the problem in Somalia by bringing closer the political movements in that country. 

Ato Meles and Mr. Prodi have also discussed way of strengthening Ethio- Italian economic relations. The Italian Prime Minister observed that Ethiopia is not benefiting from its tremendous tourist resources.

The two leaders discussed the reinstitution of the Axum Obelisk, with Prime Minister Prodi stressing on the timely return of the historical relic.

Mr. Prodi has accepted Prime Minister Meles's invitation to visit Ethiopia.

Prime Minister Meles on Thursday visited I Florence a library called " Biblica Lorensia." The works of the renowned Italian painter Michael Angelo and ancient Ethiopian heritages are present in the library established in the 14th century.

In a related news from Florence, an Italian community for international organisations has appreciated Ethiopia's efforts in attaining food self sufficiency.

Officials of the community said at a panel discussion organised in cooperation with the African and Oriental Institute that Ethiopia's efforts in attaining food self sufficiency and the increase in the amount of agricultural produces are encouraging.

They said it was their strong conviction that the encouraging results were gained as a result of the prevalence of peace and stability in the country over the past six years.

One of the officials, Senator Rino Seri said that results registered in attaining self sufficiency in food is not only appreciable but also serves as an instrument to attract foreign investors to the country.

He also said the contribution of Prime Minister Meles Zenawi to conflict resolution and peace making in the Horn of Africa in particular and in Africa in general enjoys the support of Italy and that of other European countries.

The senator said Prime Minister Mele's leadership as chairman of the OAU from 1995 to 1996 has also contributed a lot in avoiding various problems.

During the panel discussion attended by noted Italian scholars, Prime Minister Meles on his part responded to questions regarding the current situation in Ethiopia and Africa as a whole.

Meanwhile, Prime Minister Meles on Thursday afternoon met with Italian Defence Minister Benamino Andreta and discussed bilateral and African issues.

They have also discussed ways through which African countries could upgrade their capacity in order to establish strong force meant for the containment of conflicts across the continent.

A spokesman to the Italian Defence Ministry said Mr. Andreta has told the visiting Ethiopian Prime Minister that Italy is considering the need to support Ethiopia's efforts in building efficient defence force.

They have also exchanged views on the situations in Somalia, Sudan and the Great lakes, according to the spokesman.

Prime Minister Meles on Thursday visited the historical town of Florence and held talks with its officials.

While in Florence, the Ethiopian delegation responded to questions posed by industrialists regarding investment opportunities in Ethiopia.

The Prime Minister during the discussion said the entrepreneurs could invest in Ethiopia either privately or in cooperation with counterparts and added that the two parties would benefit from the investment activities.

The Italian entrepreneurs have also made separate discussions with Ethiopian businessmen and heads of economic institutions who are members of the high-level Ethiopian delegation. During the talks, the two parties discussed areas of future joint ventures.

As part of his five-day working tour, the Prime minister has visited the municipality of Florence and signed on the book of honour.

The prime minister said on the occasion that the Ethiopian delegation visited Florence because it has multitudes of handicraft products suitable to Ethiopia.

The two parties should exert unreserved efforts to ensure closer relations between Ethiopian and Italian business communities, the prime minister urged.

Mayor of the town said on his part that the Florence administration encourages businessmen in the town engaged in trade, industry and tourism to invest in Ethiopia.

In a related development, Prime Minister Meles yesterday met and held talks with Pope John Paul and His Foreign Minister in Vatican City.

Meanwhile, the premier has also visited the renowned Ethiopian College of Theology and a Library in the city.

Reverend Theodoros, administrator of the college, told the visiting prime minister that the college built in the 11th century has so far produced many scholars, religious leaders and archbishops.

He said at the time many colleges in Vatican belonging to other countries were closed down, the Ethiopian college was saved by Pope Pios 11th.

The Pope saved the Ethiopian college saying that, "black with white is a good colour combination."

Various religious books of Ethiopian origin are also present at the college.

Prime Minister Meles told students and heads of the college that, "you really deserve appreciation for your commitment to preserve Ethiopia's historical heritages at the college."

meanwhile, businessmen who are members of the high-level Ethiopian delegation have continued discussing future joint ventures with Italian counterparts.

Accordingly, 52 Italian investors have shown interest to open firms in Ethiopia while 19 others expressed desire to undertake businesses in cooperation with Ethiopian entrepreneurs.

Some of the investors belonging to the two parties have already begun signing agreements providing for joint development undertakings.

House of Federation elects deputy speaker

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The House of the Federation during its three-day meeting which ended on Thursday elected its deputy speaker.

According to the office of both houses, Dr. Mohammed Seraheyon who was the only candidate representing the Somali Regional State was unanimously elected.

Ato Zeiyad Bederi who served the House of the Federation as deputy speaker for one year was removed both from his post and membership, the office said.

The House has reached consensus that members of the federation representing regional states discuss programmes of the House and supervise their execution.

The office said each regional state has elected a co-ordinator which reports the effective execution of the House's programmes in cooperation with members and the office of the House of the Federation.

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Sierra Leone;
CPJ Opposes Proposed Press Restrictions in Sierra Leone


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), to President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah of Sierra Leone, April 15, 1997.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to express its concern about the amendment to the existing press law that was introduced in Parliament this week.

Among the proposed changes are requirements that all editors have ten years prior experience in journalism, five of them in an editorial capacity. All journalists will be required to have an educational degree in their field and will receive their certification from the police; to our knowledge, the first instance in the region where police have been granted the authority to certify journalists. In addition, all newspapers which began circulation after February 1996 will be required to re-register. These requirements will effectively dissolve 30 of the country's 42 newspapers. 

As a nonpartisan group of journalists dedicated to the promotion of press freedom worldwide, CPJ takes strong issue over the proposed amendments for their potential to cripple the burgeoning press in Sierra Leone. The proposed amendment is particularly disturbing because it will effectively censor 75% of the country's newspapers and deny most journalists of their right to hold and express opinions and ideas. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind," and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, to which we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Sierra Leone is a signatory.

Your Excellency, we strongly urge you to challenge the proposed amendment to the press laws and guarantee the protection of the media's right to practice its profession freely and safely.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj. org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia News Roundup


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1720 words


 

Lusaka - 1. UNIP IN-FIGHTING INCREASES

Wrangling in UNIP, the former ruling political party continues with more members demanding that its leader, Kenneth Kaunda, steps aside for a younger generation .

The latest attack on Kaunda's leadership has come from Sam Moyo, a member of UNIP's central committee. Moyo, a vocal youth leader and once a die-hard supporter of Kaunda, now accuses him of misleading the party and demands that a national party congress be held to replace the current leadership.

However, the party central committee reacted by expelling Moyo and two other vocal members - former party general secretary Benjamin Mibenge and Arnold Chooka, former advisor to Kaunda. Chooka has said there are several other members of the UNIP central committee who would want the Kaunda-led central committee to step down but fear being expelled from the party. 

A veteran party member, Lavu Mulimba, has resigned from politics after being appointed a member of Zambia's Human Rights Commission. Mulimba, who served in various cabinet posts under Kaunda, says he could no longer continue in active politics as he would now rather concentrate on his non- partisan role of being a Human Rights commissioner.

2. VETERAN POLITICIAN DISMISSES PRESIDENTIAL ASPIRATIONS RUMOURS

The ruling MMD national secretary, Michael Sata, has dismissed growing speculation that he aspires to the presidency in 2001. However, some political observers don't believe his apparent non-interest in the post. Sata also says accusations that he has been holding secret campaign meetings were unfounded. He is among four key MMD figures generally regarded as likely contenders for the party presidency after President Chiluba completes his second and final term of office in 2001. Others are Defence Minister Ben Mwila, Finance Minister Ronald Penza and Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda.

Observers note that Sata is on record as once having said that there was nothing wrong with being ambitious, in response to a query as to whether he aspired to be president of Zambia. He is also remembered for his 1991 MMD campaign statement in which he stated that he had no ambitions of being a minister.

To date, he has held several ministerial positions and is now minister without portfolio.

3. ZAMBIA DEPLOYS CRACK TROOPS ON BORDER WITH WAR-TORN ZAIRE

Zambia has deployed commandos, its crack unit of soldiers, on the border with war-torn Zaire. This follows the arrest of armed Zairian and Burundese soldiers inside the country. Most of the commandos are stationed on the long border stretch of the Copperbelt Province which borders Zaire's Shaba Province whose capital Lubumbashi fell to rebel leader Laurent Kabila's forces last week.

With towns bordering Zambia also having fallen into rebel hands, a steady stream of refugees have been entering Zambia.

4. A. JOURNALISTS REJECT PROPOSED MEDIA COUNCIL BILL

Zambian journalists have rejected a proposed Media Council Bill, drafted by the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, describing it as a government attempt to suppress freedom of expression. All news media organisations in the country - the Press Association of Zambia, the Zambia Independent Media Association, The Media Women Association of Zambia, The Commonwealth Press Union and the Zambia Union of Journalists - have rejected the bill. The Law Association of Zambia has also condemned the bill in its present form saying that if passed into law, free flow of information would be restricted.

Information Minister David Mpamba says that the bill would not be passed into law without consensus with other stakeholders. He said the bill, drafted by his ministry, would be circulated widely for further proposals before being taken to parliament.

4.B. ....AND MARCH IN PROTEST

Scores of journalists took part in a protest march in Lusaka to protest the proposed enactment of the Media Council bill . The 5km march from Lusaka's commercial centre ended at the Lusaka High Court where representatives of the various news media organisations spelt out their rejection of the bill. The march was characterised by chants denouncing the bill as a piece of legislation that was aimed at curtailing freedom of speech and information.

The protest against the bill has brought journalists from both the private and the state-owned media out in an unprecedented united front. The journalists have also engaged lawyers to fight the bill in court and intend to raise the issue with the recently formed Human Rights Commission.

Although government says it is still open to discussion on the bill, journalists say that they do not need a media council in any form. They are particularly angered that government should be proposing journalists have a license to practice their profession.

A similar march planned for Kitwe, Zambia second city, fell through because the police refused to grant the journalists based in the town a permit to carry out their protest. Another solidarity march was planned for the Namibian capital, Windhoek ,where journalists were to picket the Zambian High Commission.

The journalists are concerned that despite the vehement protest, government could still present the bill in the MMD-dominated parliament and pass it into law. Spokesman for the journalists, Robby Makai , said journalists were aware of such a possibility and they were working on counter measures. Last year, parliament passed a Land Bill despite it being roundly rejected.

5. CHILUBA INTERVENES IN STREET-VENDING DISPUTE

It has taken the direct intervention of President Chiluba to diffuse mounting tension in Lusaka between street vendors and local authorities who have been trying to get them off the main roads of the city's commercial centre. The vendors have refused to move off the roads demanding that they be given appropriate selling points.

The vendors, who trade in goods ranging from groceries and toys to clothes, footwear and hardware, have forced some legitimate traders to close their shops because they (vendors) are setting their mini-shops in front of the established ones. The Government is banking on a major market that is being constructed to take all or most of the street vendors off the streets.

6. BANK CLOSURE QUANDARY FOR FARMERS

THE closure of Lima Bank, has thrown the business operations of peasant farmers into a quandary because of the difficulties now of obtaining loans at affordable rates. The bank, which has been put under receivership, was the only remaining formidable lending institution from which peasant farmers could get loans for buying of their necessities.

The bank had been in recent years, however, hit by financial problems caused mostly by failure to recover its loans from the farmers. In 1995, the Co-operative Bank, another lending institution established primarily to assist farmers, closed because of financial problems. The farmers will now have to get their loans, at high risk and higher interest, from commercial banks.

7. BANK OF ZAMBIA WARNS AGAINST FAKE BANK NOTES

Fake bank notes are in circulation in Zambia, and the Bank of Zambia has warned people to be on the look out . A spokesman for the central bank said the fake notes were virtually the same as genuine ones in appearance but some security features were missing. The fake notes detected are in the K10,000 denomination.

Police have also warned residents against tricksters who are cutting K10, 000 and K1,000 notes into half and gluing the different halves together, then presenting the mutilated note as a K10,000. This was detected in Lusaka where an alert shop keeper noticed that one half of the note given to him was K1, 000 and the other half was K10,000.

8. ZAMBIAN SOCCER FANS DEMAND SACKING OF COACHES

After Zambia was held to a 2-2 draw by Zaire in a World Cup qualifying match, Zambian soccer fans are now demanding that the coach Fred Mwila and the technical advisor Samuel Ndhlovu be fired. Some fans pelted the coaches with cans and bottles during the match played in Zimbabwe and others threatened to beat the coaches after the match.

The result of the match drastically reduced Zambia's hopes of qualifying for the World Cup finals set for France next year. Zambia and Zaire have only two points each after three games played while Congo top the group with seven points and followed by South Africa on four points. The winner of the group will qualify for the World Cup finals.

To contact or subscribe to Zambia News Online, email: editor@inform-bbs.dk (Mary Tingay).


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


409 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Zambia;
Violence-Prone University Of Zambia Looks For Solution


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Lusaka - When the University of Zambia was prematurely closed last month, many Zambians were not surprised. The closure of Zambia's highest institution of learning was in fact expected especially when acts of violence had broken out at the campus.

But many Zambians were also disgusted, disappointed and concerned that the institution seemed unable to find a permanent solution to the now frequent premature closures.

In recent years, the frequency of such closures has increased and on virtually all occasions the reason has been "to stem an escalation of violence". When the closures have taken place, students, especially the student union leaders, have either been suspended or expelled. This has allegedly been due to them being regarded as the ring-leaders who incite other students to violence. The closures have not, however, stemmed the rebellious or combative attitude of some students. The atmosphere at the university remains tense. 

The university council, the institution's governing body, admits that the closures are too frequent and also admits that it has been unable to find a permanent solution to the problem. Because of this, the university has set up a special committee to "find a lasting solution". The special committee has been given the task of collecting written and oral public submissions and to find a solution from this information.

Among the key tasks of the committee, which comprises a broad representation of notable public figures, is to investigate and make recommendations on the possibility of re-opening the university as soon as possible. The committee is also to establish causes of student violence and to explore ways of preventing and controlling it. Another priority task is to make recommendations on the present system of financing government sponsored students.

Beston Ng'onga, an economist and former student, feels the cause for the current spate of student violence is money, or rather the lack of it. He notes that in the early years of the institution, student unrest was over national issues and not over the monetary package to which each student was entitled. Ng'onga notes that every student at the institution in the 60s, 70s and the early parts of the 80s, was well funded and did not have to worry about tuition fees, book and meal allowances.

"Students in those days never boycotted classes over a poor diet or inadequate allowances. It was always over serious issues, like when they protested over Britain's alleged support for the rebel government of Ian Smith in the then Rhodesia (Zimbabwe)," Ng'onga contends. He also sites the example of a protest match in the mid 70s when the students showed their solidarity for the MPLA, then still a liberation movement in Angola, while the Zambian government backed the UNITA movement. Even then, however, students resorted to violence, often clashing with police which would then often lead to the institution being closed.

Elias Mpondela agrees. He is another former student and noted that money was never an issue among students until government decided to start giving each government-sponsored student his or her sponsorship dues, which included meal allowances, book allowances and tuition fees. Previously, the government gave such sponsorship dues directly to the institution.

This is the system of financing to which some concerned observers would like government to revert, saying that it worked well before the decision to give the students cash, and that it was still working well in other higher institutions of learning in Zambia. A former minister in both the previous and the current government, Andrew Kashita, suggests that the money should be given directly to the institution which would then facilitate the student's needs, including meals and books.

The argument is that most students are irresponsible and use the money for other purposes like beer drinking, which contributes to their vicious approach to issues.

The suggestion that students stop getting meal allowances and instead receive meal cards entitling them to eat from the institutions dining halls, has its own demerits. There has been a drastic reduction of students who buy their meals from the university dining halls and because of this only one of the four dining halls remains operational. Most students cook in their own rooms, despite a ban on this. Ng'onga notes that the food must at all times be of high quality because, as was the case in the past, bad food becomes a cause for student riots. "If the food is poorly prepared, you cannot expect the students to just sit back. They would not only boycott the food but also vent their anger on anyone or anything they can lay their hands on," he says.

Commenting on the immaturity of students, Mpondela, who is now a Lusaka business executive, said that it was too much to expect mature behaviour from youngsters of 17-year, the average age for university entrance in Zambia. " Boys and girls straight from school are generally excited about life and are by nature militant. There is not much you can do about such militancy but there is a lot you can do to keep it in check." He added that although there is a high measure of militancy amongst the students, it is not all of them who respond with violence whenever there is an issue about which they wish to express displeasure.

"In 1982 we, the then small Catholic community at the university, rose against our students' union leadership who had been planning a more radical way of protesting, and this proved successful," Mpondela reflects. He says that now the Christian community at the university is even stronger and that this could help chart a more peaceful approach to issues.

However, recent student violence at the university points to violence escalating if students try to keep check on each other. Shortly before last November's presidential and parliamentary elections, the university was closed after some students opposed to the new constitution, beat up some of their fellow students who supported the constitution. Some of the anti- constitution students burnt books and other property of the pro-constitution students and forced them to flee the campus.

But one student, Selisho Walubita, says that it is a misconception to believe that the current crop of students is more violent than those before them. He says that there are only a few violent students in the community and it is on these students the administration must concentrate. "We are over 4, 000 in this institution, and so, if even just a quarter of the student population was violent, can you imagine what sort of damage could be caused?." he says.

Such a divergence of views is what the special committee is expected to piece together to come up with one lasting solution. Whether or not this will be possible, only time can tell.

To contact or subscribe to Zambia News Online, email: editor@inform-bbs.dk (Mary Tingay).


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


410 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Namibia;
Confidence crisis in Justice system


BYLINE: Chrispin Inambao, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Windhoek - There is an urgent need to restore confidence in Namibia's legal system, the Attorney-General's office said in a report tabled before Parliament yesterday.

"The backlog that was built up in magistrates and regional courts in the finalisation of cases, especially in Windhoek, is a major concern for the Office of the Prosecutor-General," stated the report.

Attorney General Vekuii Rukoro said in the document that the need for more competent public prosecutors was becoming increasingly urgent. He also observed that "it is not possible to increase productivity and efficiency without competent manpower and equipment". 

"Many magistrates' offices, including the Regional Court in Windhoek, are equipped with outdated or insufficient equipment and law books," the report said. It cited the example of the Regional Court in Windhoek which does not even have a photocopier, while accused persons needed copies of the contents of case dockets to prepare for their trials.

Matters were made worse by the fact that Rukoro's Office had operated on a limited budget for the past two years and had not been in a position to deal with its ever-increasing workload. "The result is that the Office of the Prosecutor-General is increasingly losing the battle against crime, and a much more concerted effort will be needed to restore some control and efficiency," the report stated.

One of the constraints facing this office is that senior lawyers, with ranks equivalent to under-secretaries, did not have secretaries, resulting in one private secretary serving seven lawyers. Rukoro's personal assistant and his private secretary were assisting in typing lawyers' work, and the resulting workload could only be addressed by putting in after-hours work. On anti-corruption measures, Rukoro stated: "Without analysing the details of each case, it can be said generally that the Government's response has not always met desired standards of transparency and accountability."

The report further said that in some cases, the media and the public were left with the impression that Government either sought to cover up wrongdoing or was not diligent in its efforts to address the problem. The report, however, added that there was a belief among some circles of the community and the press that Africans were generally corrupt, and as Namibia was an African country, there had to be some corruption.

"Such a perception is equally harmful to the nation and grossly unfair to Government and therefore needs to be corrected through a process of education of the public," stated the report.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Namibia;
Suicide cases in North continue to rise


BYLINE: Oswald Shivute, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Windhoek - The disturbing number of suicides in the north of Namibia, which have spiralled dramatically over the past few years, is showing no sign of dropping off.

Already this year at least 44 people have taken their own lives, indicating that the trend is set to continue. Since 1994 there has been an acceleration in the number of people killing themselves in the northern regions, usually by hanging or shooting themselves. 

The Namibian reported on April 11 last year that 42 people in the North had committed suicide, compared to 26 during the same period in 1995. According to Police reports in Oshakati, the number of people committing suicide has shot from 45 people during 1994, to 100 in 1995 and 165 last year, 1996.

Unemployment, loneliness, diseases, poverty, unwanted pregnancies, failure at schools, the loss of important family members are being seen as some of the main reasons why people are taking their own lives. As the spate of suicides has increased, an investigation was launched into the reasons among communities in the North, and it is hoped that the findings of the probe will shed further light on the worrying trend.

The Chief of the Ministry of Health's Social Services division in Oshakati told The Namibian that they had completed their investigation and that the findings would be made public soon. Two more cases of suicide were reported from the North over the weekend. David Natanael, 60, shot himself on Friday morning at Oshinyangwa village, Ondangua, while 20-year-old Rosalia Abed hanged herself from a tree at Ethindi village, also on Friday.

* Those who committed suicide during January were: Daniel Amayulu (34), Oshana Region; Nghishinawa Nepando (34), Oshana; Matheus Gideon (45), Oshikoto; Tobias Naftal (44), Omusati; Erastus Ekandjo (37), Omusati; Consueta Shaningwa (29), Oshana; Dominikus Ashipala (28), Omusati; Kanyemba Vilho (20), Ohangwena; Lukas Nghihalwa (22), Omusati; Martin Lazarus (22); Fillemon Nghilifa Nashipili (12), Onelombo; Sackeus Amukongo Shimana (26), Oshana; Josephina Nekwaya (21), Oshana; Julia Henock Ambondo (22), Oshikoto; Margareta Simon (55), Omusati; Veronika Shigwedha (20), Omusati; and Blasius Amukongo (22), Oshana.

* February: David Shiwana (28), Omusati; Alberina Nuuyandje (24), Oshikoto; Herman Michael (44), Oshana; Victoria Amutenya (24), Ohangwena; and Matheus Jeremia (33), Ohangwena Region.

* March: Matheus Imbili, Oshana; Ngendina Nendongo, Ohangwena; Enock Shimanda (32), Omusati; Aloisius Filippus (57), Oshana; Noag Jonas (37), Omalyata; Hamatwi Eneas (30), Ohangwena; Villa Iita, Oshana; Annatolia Shikongo (39), Iipuku; Kambonde Michael (59), Oshikoto; Helena Isack (32), Oshana; Jonas Kamanya (37), Omusati; Paulus Tuuthigilwa (37), Omusati; Matheus Lucia, Oshana; Mikisius Ningenisheni (27), Oshaango; Elina Silas (45), Oondmabombali Oshikoto; Shinombili Heinrich Ishitile (19), Oshana; and Nuuyoma Nehemia (25), Oshana.

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Business and Finance;
Clicks looks set for bumper year as earnings hit R38,8-m


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Cape Town - Interim profit figures at retail group New Clicks Holdings indicate that the group is set for another good year, says Clicks chief executive Trevor Honeysett.

Net profits of R38,8 million were boosted by "exceptional" performances from Diskom and Musica, a sharp increase in existing store sales, and new store openings in each of the group's core businesses.

Mr Honeysett said that all three of the three trading brands - Clicks, Diskom and Musica - still had huge upside growth potential. 

In the six months to February, sales at Clicks rose by 15,6 percent, at Diskom by 31,2 percent and at Musica by 33,8 percent.

"As we work these businesses more and more under the technology microscope we are finding out a lot about the consumers, their preferences and their trading habits," Mr Honeysett said.

Leading the way in the field of technology had been the phenomenal success of the Clicks ClubCard, a loyalty card which gives customers points for every rand that they spend. The points are redeemed for discounts on later purchases.

Mr Honeysett said there were now 1,25 million ClubCard holders who accounted for more than 50 percent of sales at Clicks stores.

He believed the ClubCard offered a unique opportunity for cross pollination within the group.

"The Clicks Clubcard customer and the Musica customer are more often than not the same customer, so we are now starting to explore the possibility of extending the Musica offers to Clicks ClubCard holders to add more value to the ClubCard.

"We are starting to explore running marketing and merchandise programmes driven fundamentally through Musica stores as ClubCard offers."

Some of the other benefits of the ClubCard as a direct marketing tool were yet to flow through, Mr Honeysett said.

He noted that during the Christmas season, Tesco, a UK retailer and one of the first to use the ClubCard loyalty concept, had for the first time not used any television advertising to promote sales at the time.

"All their Christmas advertising was directed through the database.

"What begins to happen with loyalty schemes is that you start to reposition your marketing expenditure more and more into the area of direct marketing," Mr Honeysett said.

Financial director Peter Green said technology was also bringing changes when it came to making decisions about buying.

This had resulted in changes to the product mix in stores.

"But specifically for underperforming stores, it allows us to remove certain products from the range to get the investment in stock down and so improve the store's performance."

Mr Green said the roll-out of scanning technology had been completed at Clicks and he expected to have the whole of Musica converted to scanning technology by the end of the year.

Diskom would "probably" have between 30 and 40 of its stores using scanning technology by the year end, he said.

Mr Honeysett said the ClubCard concept would not be used at Diskom stores.

"We have seen substantial growth in the sale of Christmas stamps at Diskom. That's the type of loyalty vehicle that that segment of the market understands best."


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


413 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Mavis Taylor: cultivating cross cultural communication in SA


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Cape Town - One play Mavis Taylor will never forget is Bernard Shaw's Saint Joan.

As we sit in the lounge of her Tamboerskloof home, the charmingly eccentric Mavis tells me why.

"My life as an only child was one of constant loneliness," she said.

After her parents had immigrated from England, her headmaster father moved from town to town every three years so that she was "never able to make friends and keep them". 

It was while Mavis' family was living in Mooi River in Natal that she became friends with Valentine Waddington.

"The Waddington family (there were seven children) was a very Victorian family, where nobody was allowed to the main table except the adults. We used to make up plays or rather they (the Waddington children) used to make up plays.

"They were always the prince, the princess, the king, the queen and I was always the funny chamberlain, or the clown - parts they didn't want to do.

"I was a little country bumpkin who found it difficult to adjust to sophisticated city life when I attended Durban Girls College."

Add to this considerable problems in her family life and the young Mavis became more and more introverted until she was "not speaking to anybody and was totally shut off from the world".

At the suggestion of a friend, her parents sent her to elocution classes but her teacher, Elizabeth Sneddon, was forced to confess: "I can't do anything with this child."

Then, Sneddon decided to put Mavis in a play - Shaw's Saint Joan - and that was when things began to change.

"I played the part of the Dauphin, which is a comedy part, and I was the wow of the evening (I think I inherited this dry sense of humour from my father). I was shy and couldn't speak to people but here was something at last I felt I could do."

Later, when her father was headmaster in Umzinto, Mavis would "wander around the school house and stroll into the back of the class".

Although she wasn't yet of school-going age, (she was 4 or 5) she started to learn.

"When I turned 6 and was due to go into Sub A, I was just beyond this.

"They put me into Sub B but I was ahead of that too so they put me in Standard 1.

"So I was 6 years old in Standard 1, which was not a great thing emotionally."

This process continued so that she was emotionally always "too young to deal with the class she was in".

She's been described as "a fighter". Is that so?

"Oh yes. I'm still a fighter.

"I love to fight ... even when I went to university, I was still shy, but if there was an injustice, and this I think comes from my father, I would get in there and fight against that injustice."

Mavis' father, Frank Taylor, was a man who "would never hear anything from anyone that was of a racist nature". He died when Mavis was 15, "so I didn't have any contact with him as an adult".

Bound Apart, her play that is now being performed at the Baxter, deals with inter-racial division and the need to communicate in a post-apartheid South Africa.

Mavis says she "despises liberals, as do most black people".

"I hate the liberal standpoint, it's dishonest. The liberal mind is somebody who says 'Ag shame!' - and then underpays their maid and spends R25 000 to be with Mrs Clinton or whoever.

Well, what would she call herself?

"I wouldn't call myself anything. I'd call myself a person (with a laugh)."

According to Mavis: "The only way ahead for the theatre is to deal with the issues, to engage on the personal, public and social levels. If we do that we'll have a future.

"I've tried to expand on that in Bound Apart. The major challenge is for people to communicate, talk to each other, understand each other's cultures, accept each other's cultures as valid.

"This is South Africa and we have to mix here, otherwise we might as well go and live on our islands - English speakers on one, Afrikaners on another, Xhosas, Tswanas and so on on others. We can't live in a country that is a mixed masala without actually mixing."

Mavis emphasises that her plays are not "two-dimensional entertainment".

"Challenge is what it's about and I'm also challenging all kinds of values in this piece."

> Mavis runs the New Africa Theatre Project, which trains young people to use performing arts as a means of communication. Bound Apart runs until Saturday.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 15, 1997


South Africa;
Urgent call to save 1999 general election


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - Urgent laws and proper maps are needed to save South Africa's 1999 national elections from failure, the Electoral Steering Committee has warned.

It asked Parliament yesterday to pass a series of laws - many not yet drafted. "Time has become critical to the success of the 1999 elections," the steering committee warned. 

But it says new laws are not enough. Unless a sophisticated mapping process is in place by the end of the year, a new barcode scanning system to match identity books with the voters' roll will be useless in the 1999 poll.

The system could save taxpayers about R25-million.

These dire warnings were issued at a briefing by the committee to the National Assembly committee on home affairs.

The steering committee is an interim precursor to the yet-to-be-appointed Electoral Commission, itself a vital cog in the process.

A shortlist of commission candidates is to be announced this weekend and interviews of aspirant commissioners are due to be held in June.

Frederik van Zyl Slabbert said at a meeting of the steering committee: "We have extremely little time to achieve what we have to to have effective elections in 1999." Johann Kriegler, who headed the Independent Electoral Commission in 1994 and serves on the steering committee, called for "a change in dimensional thinking" so that people could appreciate the scale of what would have to be achieved in 1999.

It was estimated that about 25 million people would go to the polls at 10 000 voting stations, a third of which would not have electricity and a fifth of which would not have telephones.

The home affairs committee was reminded that pre-1994 elections involved fewer than three-million voters.

The most significant difference between the 1999 elections and the 1994 poll is that the next elections will be based on voters' rolls.

New laws needed included a wholly new Electoral Act, a decision on the number of seats for each provincial legislature, and on the number of seats for the National Assembly, all of which had to be passed between June 1998 and the end of next year.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Sports - General;
Black men can putt and drive (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - Tiger Woods broke a string of records when he won the United States Masters Golf Championship on Sunday. His victory, however, was more than just another sporting achievement

Tiger Woods became part of a rich sporting history on Sunday when he won the United States Masters. He was the youngest winner, his score was the lowest ever and his winning margin the widest. 

But his victory goes well beyond the mere statistics of golf. It touches the social fabric of America and even reaches across to South Africa where the Woods win holds important lessons.

The Augusta Country Club in Georgia where Woods won the title was, not so long ago, a stronghold of American apartheid. Black players were allowed access only in 1975 and the new champion is only the fourth black player to be invited to the Masters. For us, the story is still all too familiar.

The Americans may have a head start on us, but they are still struggling to come to terms with race.

This week, by coincidence, is also the anniversary of Jackie Robinson's major league debut. Fifty years ago on this very day, Robinson, a black man from New York, broke the colour bar in US baseball. Today he is regarded as one of the most significant racial figures in American history.

Americans see Woods in a similar way. Professional basketball and gridiron football may be dominated by African-Americans and baseball's Major League made up of 40% black and Hispanic players, but barriers remain. As we report in our sports pages today, black American football coaches believe they are getting a raw deal, and have evidence to support their claim.

In South Africa, there is a widespread feeling that sports teams are too slow in reflecting the true make-up of the nation. Tiger Woods's triumph is an example to us as well as a reminder that talent knows no colour.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


416 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 15, 1997


South Africa;
Job shuffle hits 30 000 city staff


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Cape Town - A huge upheaval is about to begin for about 30 000 municipal staff facing job moves, as the city embraces the post-apartheid era and reorganises itself into new municipalities.

The unbundling of the 19 old administrations involves the vast logistical process of matching each staff member to a post in the six new municipalities and the Cape Metropolitan Council.

For thousands of workers this means they will soon be reporting to new bosses and, in many instances, working in different places. The most seriously affected areas will be the core administrations, which will have to split up or merge to serve the new municipalities. Workers in the field will continue to do the same jobs. 

There will be no job losses during this phase, which peaks on July 1, the date set for staff transfers to the new municipalities, but the possibility exists that municipalities will cut staff after restructuring.

In some instances they may have to take on new staff. The guiding principle is that staff will follow function.

The process is being managed under a series of agreements struck at the Metropolitan Restructuring Forum in conjunction with a Metropolitan Labour Forum.

The six municipalities and the metropolitan council are represented on the restructuring forum, and all unions and employers on the labour forum.

Agreement has been reached on provisional post allocations for each new local authority. The next phase, likely to be the trickiest, is putting a name to each of those posts and dealing with disputes. Provisional allocations are 1 600 for Blaauwberg , 1 500 for Helderberg, 1 700 for Oostenberg, 3 600 for South Peninsula and 7 000 for Tygerberg.

Cape Town municipality has about

17 000 staff, but will be shrunk to about

11 000 as it loses several thousand personnel to the Cape Metropolitan Council and the South Peninsula, and a few to Tygerberg and Blaauwberg.

The metropolitan council, which has about 6 500 staff, will shrink to 3 500, losing some to the municipalities and gaining bulk water and sewerage staff from Cape Town municipality. In future the CMC will focus primarily on metropolitan co-ordination and services to consumers will be provided by the six municipalities.

Tygerberg will have to incorporate separate municipalities such as Bellville and Lingelethu West into one administration.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 15, 1997


Namibia;
11 Govt drivers in court


BYLINE: The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Windhoek - Eleven Government drivers were yesterday sentenced to fines ranging from N$250 to N$2 000 after they were found guilty of various charges of fraud.

The cases arose as a result of investigations by the Frank Commission into misappropriation of Government funds.

The drivers furnished false claims of subsistence and travelling allowances between October 1991 and March 1992, one amounting to more than N$8 000. 

Their sentences were wholly suspended on condition that the 11 drivers repay the money, starting in May.

Appearing yesterday were:

* Lucas Uugwanga, 56, who defrauded the Ministry of Works,Transport and Communications of N$8 460, was sentenced to a fine of N$2 000 or two years imprisonment, wholly suspended for two years.

He must repay the money in instalments of N$250 a month from the end of May.

* Fanuel Frans Uushona, 45, was sentenced to N$1 000 or one year.

He must repay N$4 510.

* Lucas Nendongo, 42, defrauded the state of N$4 747,13 and was sentenced to N$1 000 or one year.

* Hiskia Hauwanga, 38, defrauded Government of N$5 136,11.

He was sentenced to a fine of N$1 000.

* Longinus Kahima, 37, Tobias Shihepo, 36, Andreas Angola Nakambale, 45, Matheus Jailus, 40, Lucas Usebiu, 39, and Honecker Kambalantu, 38, were all sentenced to a fine of N$500 or five months imprisonment.

They defrauded Government of amounts ranging between N$1 334 and N$3 396.

Emmanuel Kambonde Ankambo, 50, who made fraudulent claims amounting to N$428-70 was sentenced to a fine of N$250 or 75 days imprisonment.

All the accused were ordered to pay the money back in instalments of N$250 a month.

Diogenus Nakatumbe, who was allegedly President Sam Nujoma's personal driver for about 20 years, was sentenced to a fine of N$500 or five months imprisonment on Monday after he was found guilty of defrauding the State of N$720 in false claims.

All the drivers pleaded guilty to the charges of fraud.

However, their legal representative, Hein van Wyk told the court that they had committed the crimes as they were all new employees who had not been briefed on how subsistence and travelling allowances worked.

Magistrate Albertina Mutilitha presided and Tanya Pearson prosecuted.

All the accused were represented by Van Wyk.

The Frank Commission's report was handed to President Sam Nujoma in 1995, but its contents were never made public.

It is understood that many more people will appear in court soon on similar charges.

Africa News


April 16, 1997


Liberia;
UN Appoints Namibian Its New Representative To Liberia


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

NEW YORK (PANA) - UN Secretary-general Kofi Annan has appointed Tuliameni Kalomoh of Namibia as his new special representative to Liberia.

UN spokesman Juan Carlos Brandt, who announced the appointment Tuesday in New York, said that Kalomoh would succeed Anthony Nyakyi of Tanzania, who has occupied the post since 1994. 

Nyakyi's term of office expired Tuesday.

Kalomoh is currently the permanent secretary in Namibia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

He was Namibia's ambassador to the United States from 1991 to 1996, with concurrent accreditation as High Commissioner to Canada.

Kalomoh is assuming the office at a time of the final phase of Liberia's return to peace under the Abuja Accords, signed in the Nigerian capital by Liberia's warring factions.

The world body has a civilian and military observer force in the country.

Brandt said that Kalomoh would visit the UN headquarters in New York next week for briefings before assuming office.

Kalomoh was educated in Namibia and India, where he obtained a diploma from the Indian Academy of International Law and Diplomacy.
