Africa News


April 16, 1997


Science and Health;
Malaria Kills 500 In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Malaria has killed some 500 people in Zimbabwe since the start of the rain season in November, a Zimbabwean government minister has said.

Timothy Stamps, the minister of health and child welfare, said on Monday in Harare that 255,000 cases were attended to. 

He told some of the continent's top scientists, attending the Medic Africa'97 exhibition, that the health challenges facing African and other developing countries remained "as daunting as ever."

"Malaria remains the biggest killer with Zimbabwe recording over 255,000 cases with nearly 500 deaths since the start of the current rainy season," he said.

The country is enjoying one of its best rain seasons in many years, creating moist conditions favorable for breeding of malaria-causing mosquitoes.

Present malaria deaths compare with only about 200 that had been reported over the same period in 1996, with the final toll that year being more than 2, 000 deaths.

The three-day Medic Africa '97 event is an international medical exhibition which takes place alongside conferences and seminars by mainly laboratory scientists from both Anglophone and Francophone Africa.

Meetings during the convention include updates on HIV/ AIDS research.

"The HIV/AIDS pandemic continues to decimate critical human resources and overwhelm the health care system with no respite in sight," Stamps said.

Coupled with that was the "vengeful" return of tuberculosis, which had since become more difficult to treat and cure. The disease had hitherto been brought under control through immunization and multi-drug therapy.

These challenges and reverses, he said, should spur the scientists to seek new solutions to "old problems."


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


420 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Women Endure Suffering Without Complaining


BYLINE: David Musoke, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

NYABUSOZI, Uganda (PANA) - Deborah Tunakunda, a 35-year-old housewife in Nyabusozi district, southwest Uganda, has been brought up and conditioned to endure pain and suffering without complaining.

"In our culture and tradition, we must learn to disregard pain, and to live with debilitating symptoms and conditions," she narrates.

Deborah and other Ugandan women, like their counterparts elsewhere in Africa, are never acknowledged as sick or unwell until they literally collapse, by which time it is usually too late to do any thing to help them.

According to the traditions of the Banyankole, Tunakunda's ethnic group, a woman must not make noise or cry out when delivering a baby - it is shameful and a sign of bad upbringing. 

"She must endure the pain quietly." Banyankole men will in fact expect to hear only the cry of the new-born, not of the mother.

From the health point of view, according to Uganda's First Lady, Janet Museveni, this situation cannot be allowed to continue, as women are now required to undertake even greater tasks within the African society.

She made this point clear recently when officially opening the first East, Central and Southern African Obstetrical and Gynecological Societies conference on reproductive health towards the next century, which ended in Kampala on April 11.

According to her, even the current talk of women empowerment through education, political representation and legislation, and also through new economic opportunities, cannot be realized if the health of African women continues to be neglected.

"Is it possible to empower human beings whose physical bodies are feeble and ailing?," she wondered, stressing that the question of reproductive health was a pivotal one in the larger issue of development.

At their conference in Kampala, held from April 6-11, the African obstetricians and gynecologists "brainstormed" on how to strengthen reproductive health services, adolescent health, maternal mortality, abortions, the effect of HIV infection on pregnancy and other related topics.

They noted with concern the rising teenage pregnancies which were reported to be the highest in Uganda on the whole African continent.

Participants from Ethiopia, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe and Sweden decried the high mortality rate in their countries which ranges between 200 and 1,000 per 100,000 live births. Out of this mortality, 20 to 35 percent is attributed to induced abortion.

The health experts noted that among adolescents - the future parents - sexually transmitted diseases are higher than among the rest of the population. This includes HIV/AIDS.

These factors prompted Janet Museveni to urge the participants to deliberate upon the causes of such harrowing statistics and the possible remedial measure to put in place to "halt the pace at which we lose such large sections of our population."

"First, there is a great need to re-educate our communities about the need to utilize the health facilities that are becoming more and more available, to teach women the importance of ante-natal and post-natal visits to the clinic," she said.

"The medical personnel, midwives and traditional birth attendants must also be taught the importance of sanctity of life and the fact that they are there to save life and not simply watch as women die while under their care", she added.

But, according to the chairperson of the Association of Obstetrics and Gynecologists of Uganda, Dr. Florence Mirembe, the task of changing attitudes on reproductive health could not be accomplished by medical workers alone.

"Everyone, men, women and the medical profession, we must all be sensitized to do it - from the school room, to the pulpit, to the political podium, to the public performers, to the grassroots leaders," she said.

Among the conclusions of the conference was to erase the separation between economics and health.

The participants said it was impossible to have a strong economy if more than half of the population, "more than half of the work force is in poor health."


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


421 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


Tanzania;
Nyerere Deplores Tanzania's Low Life Expectancy Rate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - As he turned 75 last Sunday, Tanzania's first president, Julius Nyerere, deplored the country's low life expectancy rate of 52 years and challenged authorities to do something to raise it.

He attributed the low life expectancy rate to the loss of millions of working years because Tanzanians die when they are still very young.

Nyerere, popularly known as Mwalimu (teacher), said this in Dar es Salaam in a speech to thank the organizers of his 75th anniversary party, which was attended by over 100 guests in Dar es Salaam. 

He said that the life expectancy in most developed countries was around 70 years. He told the guests that his wish was to see as many Tanzanians reach that age, which, he said, was standard according to the Bible.

"I think the trend to believe that living up to my age is a privilege should stop and instead it should be the age standard for Tanzanians," said the former president, whose head is now all grey.

He told the incumbent president, Benjamin Mkapa, who was among the guests, that to achieve that, the government has to cut down infant mortality to ensure that children survive their first five years after birth.

Nyerere, who is an ardent Catholic, said that although life expectancy has risen from 35 years at independence in 1961 to 52 now, Tanzania was still far behind the Biblical standard which "is four scores" (80 years).

He said he hoped to reach the age of 80 as many members of his family have reached that age. His mother, Mugaya Nyerere, is now 100 years old.

Nyerere, who led Tanzania for a quarter century, after the country's independence from Britain, said he hoped to see the fourth president of the country, after Mkapa (59), who he hopes will complete his two terms of office in 2005.

"I hope I will see the fourth Tanzania president," said Nyerere, who was succeeded in 1985 by Ali Hassan Mwinyi (71). Mwinyi retired two years ago.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


422 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


Science and Health;
Africa Urged To Be Wary Of HIV Trials


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Vice-Chancellor of the University of Zimbabwe, Graham Hill, on Wednesday in Harare, called on African states to be united in rejecting AIDS clinical trials based on skin color.

In a keynote address to the fifth congress of the Association of Medical Laboratory Scientists, Hill said there had to be justification why a particular country is used for such trials.

"Clinical and drug trials have to be exposed to international scrutiny, and justification given as to why a country becomes a center for such HIV/AIDS trials," he said. 

Trials that only involved developing countries and none of the industrialized countries should be treated with caution, and their rationale fully justified before implementation, he said.

"Africa should unite in rejecting, in the strongest terms, trials that are based on the principle of color, for in fact they do not seek knowledge, but seek to perpetuate the inequality of mankind, and proof of idiosyncratic self- appeasing theories," said Hill.

The failure to date by scientists to come up with a cure or vaccine for HIV/AIDSs had led to callous exploitation of people living with AIDS through false claims of cures by money-mongers and quacks.

"Meanwhile, people living with AIDS on such treatment become unsuspecting guinea pigs, and even if they suspect that something is amiss, their condition renders them powerless to do anything about it.

"I call upon all parties concerned to help stop exploitation of people. people living with AIDS have rights like anyone else," he said.

Clandestine research, uninformed consent, over-generalizations, useless drugs and "quacks" had become the order of the day.

"The old problem of Africa being the dumping ground of inferior quality goods and products once again rears its ugly head as most western-based institutions, pharmaceuticals, and individuals expose our people to research methods they don't even carry out in their own backyards.

"And, because of our desperate situation in terms of inadequate resources, facilities and technology, we have often been forced to settle for sub- standard HIV/AIDS diagnostic equipment and materials that do not give us accurate results, and to enter into research collaborations whose intentions are dubious, and not necessarily honorable," said Hill.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


423 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


United States and Africa;
Washington And Lusaka Differ On Good Governance


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's minister without portfolio Michael Sata on Wednesday accused the U.S government of hostility toward the government in Lusaka.

But the U.S Ambassador to Zambia, Arlene Render, and visiting State Department deputy director for Southern African countries, Gerard Gallucci maintained that Washington will not relent on its demand for good governance in Lusaka.

The two envoys made this position clear during an exchange of views with Sata concerning Zambia's current political situation. 

Sata claimed that if the government had not acted with tact, an uprising could have occurred in the country, instigated by what he termed undeclared sanctions by the United States in 1996.

Sata engaged the duo in a heated debate, during which he accused Washington of bias against Zambia by condemning what it perceives as undemocratic activities by the government.

He accused the U.S. government of not taking such actions against unnamed countries in the sub-region whose democratic records were not as impressive as that of Zambia.

Sata cited the constitutional changes of 1996 as one of the issues on which Washington had adopted a negative stance against Zambia and yet the changes reflected the people's wishes.

"You have treated us with utmost political hostility for the past few years, through your undeclared sanctions which have led to reduced levels of aid to Zambia.

"You are too hard on us and we find this to be very unfair because we have adhered to democratic principles of designing policies initiated by the people," Sata said.

In her response, Render maintained that Washington will closely monitor President Frederick Chiluba's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) to ensure that it observes good governance which she said was inseparable with economic performance.

"We will not let you off the hook on good governance and we will knock at your doors whenever we notice slippages on this matter," Render said.

The U.S. government was among other donors that had cut aid to Chiluba's government after the adoption of the 1996 amended constitution, which the U.S claimed was undemocratic because it limited the number of aspiring presidential candidates.

It only allowed Zambian citizens with both parents also born in the country to contest for presidency.

Following the amendment, former President Kenneth Kaunda was barred from standing against Chiluba in the November 1996 presidential election. Kaunda's parents were from Malawi.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 16, 1997


East Africa;
Summit Maintains Sanctions Against Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ARUSHA, Tanzania (PANA) - African leaders who met in Arusha, northern Tanzania on Wednesday decided to maintain sanctions against Burundi.

However, according to President Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, the leaders widened the areas which will not be affected by the economic blockade, which was imposed on July 30, 1996, after Maj. Pierre Buyoya seized power in Bujumbura five days earlier. 

Speaking to Zambian journalists before he left for Lusaka, Chiluba said the exempted imports include food, agricultural produce and implements, medicines and educational materials.

Chiluba said the leaders have decided to maintain the sanctions to compel the military junta in Bujumbura to fulfill all the conditions set under the embargo.

The sanctions were imposed by Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Cameroon and Zambia after Buyoya toppled the civilian government of Slyvestre Ntibatunganya.

They are aimed at among other things, to force the military junta to restore the national assembly, un-ban political parties and undertake unconditional negotiations with all parties to the conflict, including armed groups.

The leaders noted that while some progress has been made to fulfill these conditions, extra efforts should be made by the junta in Bujumbura to realize all the conditions.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


425 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


Mali;
Police Disperse Opposition Protesters


BYLINE: Abdoulaye Traore, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

BAMAKO, Mali (PANA) - Police in Bamako, the Malian capital, on Wednesday dispersed a peaceful demonstration by supporters of 14 opposition parties, who were protesting the results of last Sunday's parliamentary election.

As the protestors dispersed, some groups of youths vandalized shops and stoned state-owned vehicles as well as those of other private motorists. 

Malian opposition parties have since Monday been agitating for the nullification of the first round legislative polls.

They also called for the resignation of the government and the independent national electoral committee, for failing to organize proper elections.

Wednesday's demonstration had been outlawed by the the ministry of territorial administration and security, which said it would do its best to ensure the security of citizens.

Opposition parties have complained that last Sunday's polls were not free and fair because the organizers failed to provide enough voting materials including voters' cards registers, ballots papers and ballot boxes.

But the electoral commission attributed the failure to all Malian political actors.

Preliminary results indicate that the ruling coalition of President Oumar Konare, the Alliance for Democracy in Mali (ADEMA) was leading in several constituencies.

Opposition parties have already said they will not take part in the run-off election on April 27 as well as in the presidential poll scheduled for May 4, unless there is proof of transparency.

LANGUAGE: English

426 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Former state prosecutor sentenced to 27 years in jail


BYLINE: Benjamin Shabalala, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Nelspruit - A former Kempton Park regional court prosecutor was sentenced to 27 years in jail by the Nelspruit regional court on Wednesday in connection with hijacking a van carrying more than R300 000 in pension money, and attempting to murder three policemen in Bushbuckridge four years ago.

Gundo Justice Lidhovo (33) of Pageview, Johannesburg, has no previous convictions, and was a monitor for Independent Electoral Commission during the 1994 election and is a trustee of the South African National Civics Organisation (Sanco) in Pageview.

Lidhovo was found guilty of hijacking a van carrying R351 601 in pension money on March 11 in 1993, and firing at three escort policemen at Casteel, near Bushbuckridge. 

He was arrested shortly afterwards at the Pietersburg/Zebedelia T-Junction by Sgt SGP Oosthuizen, who heard about the robbery over the police radio network and saw Lidhovo standing with another man next to the boot of a white Jetta sedan.

The man allegedly ran away when Sgt Oosthuizen approached them.

Sgt Oosthuizen arrested Lidhovo on finding a trunk containing the stolen R351, 601 and pensioners' vouchers, an AK 47 rifle and a firearm in the boot.

Lidhovo pleaded not guilty, saying he had been hijacked on the way to Pietersburg and that the hijackers could have loaded the weapons and money into the boot of his car.

"I have never possessed any ammunition, rifle or fire-arms in my whole life, " Lidhovo told the court.

The prosecution speculated that Lidhovo was part of an organised gang, which used the van as a getaway car.

"The only reason you were caught is because you were at the wrong place at the wrong time and otherwise would've gotten away with it," Magistrate Albertus le Roux said.

Lidhovo was sentenced to an effective 10 years for stealing the money and the van, 12 years for attempted murder, three years for the unlawful possession of a firearm and five years for the unlawful possession on an AK 47 assault rifle.

Lidhovo has appealed against the sentence.

Lidhovo was awarded his B Juris at the University of the North in 1985 and, in 1986, received his LLB from Unisa, and began his career in 1987.

Lidhovo was an advisor to a parastatal attached to the Venda Development Corporation, which advised communities on how to use VDC resources for land purposes.

He was also a director of Moweni, a legal advice bureau in Venda which assisted detainees, helped establish trade unions and referred cases to Lawyers for Human Rights.

Lidhovo also led a project creating political awareness in the community before the 1994 elections and established an education project which helped students acquire bursaries.

He also worked as a legal officer for national insurance company, Old Mutual.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Financial record keeping still serious problem in provinces


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Nelspruit - The persisting pension payout problems and inability of government officials to submit acceptable financial statements timeously are indicative of serious record keeping and capacity problems in Mpumalanga, said the Auditor General, Henri Kluever, in Nelspruit on Friday.

Speaking at the official opening of the Provincial Auditor General's offices, Kluever said that similar problems occurred in other provincial governments and had to be tackled immediately if politicians wanted to ensure efficient and accountable local government.

"It is a great pity that, as auditors, we cannot always be positive. But unless these issues are recognised and addressed they will only grow. By pointing them out, we have no ulterior agendas or double agendas - only our public accountability," he explained. 

The problems, which are largely due to poorly trained or motivated staff and not necessarily corruption, was being addressed by the introduction of open sessions of Public Accounts Committees, he added.

"The opening of these committee sessions to the general public is possibly one of the best innovations of our new democratic government. By being there and participating directly in keeping officials accountable by asking questions, officials suddenly realise that they must answer to the tax-payer for their financial management," Kluever said.

"Tough public accounting goes hand in glove with any strong democracy and also ensures value for money for service from the lowest clerk to most senior politician."

The new Nelspruit offices unite the various units or components of the AG's office which operated in the former home lands of KaNgwane and KwaNdebele, as well as the eastern part Transvaal, for the first time under a single Provincial Auditor, Douglas Maphiri.

Maphiri and a team of specialists from the AG's corporate services office in Pretoria are currently concluding a special report on alleged wide-scale financial mismanagement at the Mpumalanga Development Corporation (MDC).

The performance report was launched after allegations that the MDC's controversial managing director, Patrick Mogorosi, had defrauded the parastatal.

Mogorosi recently resigned and took a package rather than face an internal disciplinary hearing.

The AG special report will be released in roughly two to three weeks time.

"This type of investigation is part of our new pro-active approach to auditing in South Africa. We have to remain relevant and make meaningful contributions both on the normal accounts and on matters of public interest," explained corporate services executive manager, Louis van Rooyen.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


428 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Police announce fraud investigation into national Deputy Speaker


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

Nelspruit - When South Africa's popular deputy speaker of Parliament, Baleke Mbete, accepted an offer by Mpumalanga politicians to "make it easier" to get her driver's license, she thought it would simplify her life.

Instead, she is now one of 44-people being investigated by the police for possession of a fraudulent license.

Mbete did go through the motions of testing for the license on October 1 last year, after being whisked from Johannesburg to Delmas by the personal car of Mpumalanga's safety and security MEC, and escorted by his personal bodyguards.

But, despite being met and tested by the provincial traffic director, Henry Brazer, himself, there are no official records of the test.

And the temporary license which she now uses to drive her car wasn't issued in Delmas as per Department of Transport regulations. 

Instead, it was secretly issued one day earlier more than 350km away in the former homeland of KaNgwane, sometime during the night of September 30.

Police have refused to comment on the case but a Sunday Times investigation has also found that Brazer may not be qualified as a testing officer, as he is not listed as certified on the national NATIS traffic data system and that licenses issued at Kabokweni are still governed by old K52 regulations, while those at Delmas fall under more recent legislation requiring the more difficult K53 test.

An internal departmental investigation into the irregularities was, however, quashed by senior officials and politicians in the safety & security department, while the man who brought the incident to their attention, John Muller, is currently facing disciplinary action and possible dismissal for " non-attendance" at work.

Mpumalanga's director of traffic, Henry Brazer, who Mbete insists personally tested her in Delmas, refused point-blank to even discuss the matter this week for fear of "incriminating myself".

"I am not prepared to give you any information at all - the police are investigating and I am not going to incriminate myself either to you or in court," he said when Sunday Times finally tracked him down in Cape Town on Friday.

"It doesn't matter that I'm a public servant, I will not talk to you or anyone else. As far as I am concerned the matter is sub-judicae."

Refusing to accept that cases are only sub-judicae once they are in court, Brazer refused to say whether he was in Delmas on October 1 or to explain why Mbete's license was issued at the Kabokweni Test Centre in KaNgwane - after normal work hours and without the knowledge of staff there.

Brazer also refused to comment about another internal government investigation into his admitted irregular use of State funds to pay for a family holiday to the USA while he still worked for the former KaNgwane traffic department.

Although he signed a confession admitting to misusing State funds at the time, he was promoted to provincial traffic head after simply repaying the money.

Claiming to be unaware of the police investigation, Mbete insisted this week that the license test had been personally set up for her by Mpumalanga safety & security MEC, Steve Mabona.

"I am a very busy person with children scattered all over the country, a job in Cape Town and a constituency in KwaZulu. I don't have time to stand in queues," she explained.

"So, because every time I saw Steve in Cape Town, he was always insisting that I should come to Mpumalanga for my license, I took him up on the offer."

Stressing that she had already written her Learner's License in Cape Town, and that she had paid for the Delmas test, Mbete denied any knowledge that the license had actually been issued in Kabokweni.

"How can this be corruption? I am not required to stand in queues at airports and things, and this was just like that - just a little facilitation to make life easier," she said.

MEC Mabona also vigorously denies that there is anything wrong with either the special arrangements to have Baleke tested or with the fact that there are no records at Delmas and that her license was actually issued 350km away from where she wrote it.

"The people in Pretoria, who say that it's a problem, don't fucken know what they're talking about. I am the boss of traffic here, so you listen to me," insisted an aggressive Mabona.

"I personally organised this thing and know about it. It just doesn't matter if the license was issued somewhere other than were it was tested. And if the officials in Delmas say they don't know this, then they are lying and are racist."

Explaining that because he knew that "most test centre officers and heads are still white and racist, I didn't want this type of thing where ministers are treated like slaves or called kaffirs. So, I made special arrangements.

"You are just targeting Baleke because she is black. If you write this stuff, you are a National Party pawn and are abusing the openness of our new government. But you have an agenda and can fuck off and write whatever you want. I was not made by newspapers, so do what you want," said an agitated Mabona.

Delmas Test Centre head, Pieter Evenson, confirmed that his centre had no file for Mbete on Friday and insisted that she could therefore not have officially been tested in Delmas.

"Look, it's impossible to be tested and not have a file. There's just no other way of doing this legally. And, there is also no way that my files, records or licenses would land up in KaNgwane, because I would simply not send them there," he explained.

"Also, if the provincial director of traffic were to specially test someone here at my centre, the arrangements would have been made through me. I never saw or heard about anything like this."

Safety & security's departmental head, Advocate Stanley Soko, admitted this week that he had been informed about the irregularities just weeks afterwards and that he had written a letter ordering that an internal investigation into the incident be dropped immediately.

He also ordered, in the letter, that Kabokweni's 'master' license books, which had been confiscated to preserve evidence, be returned to the Kaboweni centre.

"I was furious when I heard about the investigation. It was not being done according to the proper channels and was causing friction, so I wrote the letter. I admit that there was no formal investigation after this but I did verbally quiz Brazer and was satisfied with his explanation," explained Adv. Soko.

He then admitted, however, that he did not bother checking Brazer's story with either the Delmas or Kabokweni test centre heads or with the traffic officer, John Muller, who brought it to the department's attention.

This, despite the fact that Muller has previously the same officer who played a key role into fraudulent license investigations which landed 11 government officials from three departments in court for selling driver's licenses.

Muller was also instrumental in re-opening the inquiry into Brazer's State paid holiday.

"Muller is a trouble maker. He causes tension and friction in the department and just never turns up for work. He claims it is because he is being victimised by Brazer for this holiday thing, but I cannot tolerate a public official getting paid for not being at work," Soko said.

"I have stopped his salary and we have started disciplinary steps aimed at dismissing him for non-attendance and mis-conduct."

Adv. Soko claimed to be unaware of the police investigation and insisted that because no formal complaint had been made by anyone he had not been obliged to investigate the allegations.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Witbank forced to spend R2,5-million for water pipeline


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

WITBANK - The cost of supplying water to Mpumalanga's biggest town, Witbank, is set to increase after the South African Bureau of Standards (SABS) informed the council that it would have to replace a major R2,5-million water conduit between the town and the Witbank Dam.

According to SABS inspectors, the existing pipe is so badly rusted and corroded that it can no longer be used economically and may also influence the quality of water supplied to Witbank. 

The additional expenditure for the pipeline comes shortly after the council was forced to pay R11 600 to replace one of four water pumps servicing the pipeline.

According to council spokesmen, it costs Witbank Town Council at least R27, 9-million per year to provide water it its residents.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


430 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Police recover 'most dangerous' escapee's getaway vehicle


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

SECUNDA - Police have recovered the police vehicle stolen by one of Gauteng's most dangerous prisoners, who escaped from police custody on Wednesday, while being transported to court.

Petrus Dan Molefe (32) allegedly overpowered his police guard before stealing the officer's police vehicle, pistol and cellular phone, African Eye News Service (South Africa) reports.

Molefe also took a police two-way radio and three fully loaded Uzi machine- gun magazines with him. 

Police spokesmen said on Friday that they had recovered the stolen Opel Astra in Duduza, Thokoza, near Thembisa in Gauteng late on Thursday evening.

Although the vehicle was undamaged, none of Sergeant Jan Hattingh's (26) possessions were recovered. There was also no sign of Molefe himself and police have warned the public that he is dangerous and should not be confronted.

Molefe escaped from police custody while being transported from Boksburg Prison to Volksrus Magistrate's Court to be trailed on armed robbery and vehicle theft charges. Molefe, who is already serving a prison term for a R100 000 bank robbery, is also wanted in connection with bank robberies in Mpumalanga and North West Provinces. AK47s were used in all the robberies.

The still shaken police escort, Sergeant Jan Hattingh (26), spoke to African Eye News Service (South Africa) shortly after the escape and told them that Molefe waited until the vehicle they were travelling in was on a deserted stretch of road before pulling a pistol from under his shirt.

"He was hand-cuffed and I don't know where he got the weapon, but he meant business. Knowing his history as one of the most dangerous prisoners in Gauteng, I was so scared that I did exactly as he commanded. I thought he was going to kill me," Sergeant Hattingh.

"He took my stuff and ordered me out of the car. Then, still hand-cuffed, he drove off towards Springs."

Immediately after Hattingh notified police about the incident, police helicopters from Gauteng were diverted to hunt for the missing Opel Astra stolen by Molefe.

"We still don't understand how Molefe, who was picked up by the escort directly from his cell at Boksburg Prison, could have got hold of the pistol he used to over power his guard," added Mpumalanga police spokesperson, Captain Benjamin Bembe.

Describing Molefe as "very dangerous and violent", Bembe said police were still conducting a province wide hunt for the escapee, as well as a search of Soweto's Zone 2, where Molefe comes from.

Police are also investigating Molefe in connection with one murder, one attempted murder, one rape and previous escape charges.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


431 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Billy Graham's son makes the kids' day


BYLINE: Mario Wyngaard, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - American evangelist Franklin Graham is making thousands of Cape Town children smile.

The son of renowned veteran evangelist Billy Graham, Franklin Graham yesterday visited Nomlinganiselo Primary School in Crossroads, where he distributed 1 200 of 20 000 gift-wrapped boxes he has brought to the city.

The gift boxes contain T-shirts, toys, sweets, stationery and other items packed by children in the United States, Britain and Canada. 

"There is a lot of work to be done in Africa," said Mr Graham.

He is making an evangelical tour of South Africa, as his father did years ago. Franklin Graham has previously been to several African countries, including South Africa, which he first visited 14 years ago as president of Samaritan's Purse, an international Christian relief organisation. With his wife Jane and daughter Sissy, he is on a mission to bring hope to the needy and underprivileged.

The gift boxes for needy children are part of Operation Christmas Child, a Samaritan's Purse project. Last Christmas a million children in 36 countries received gifts from the project.

The American entourage includes journalists, bodyguards and a singing cowboy. The guests were welcomed at Nomlinganiselo by enthusiastic pupils and were entertained by the school choir and pupils performing traditional dances.

Mr Graham brought his own one-man choir in the form of giant singing, guitar-strumming cowboy Dennis Agajanian.

"We decided to come to South Africa because the country is one of the great nations in the world and has so much natural beauty. Everyone is looking to South Africa because it is the key nation in Africa," said Mr Graham.

Mr Graham travels the world overseeing relief projects through Samaritan's Purse, and conducts at least 10 campaigns each year for the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association, of which he is first vice-chairman.

He will conduct services at Newlands cricket ground on Friday and Saturday at 7.30pm, and on Sunday at 3.30pm.

Special arrangements have been made for the disabled and senior citizens. Extra trains and buses have been organised throughout the Peninsula to transport people to and from the stadium.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


432 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Is our new democrazy really working? (Commentary)


BYLINE: Pieter Dirk Uys, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Cape Town - We citizens of the new democratic, non-racial, non-sexual, non- sensical South African are all suffering from an overdose of reconciliation.

Ever since Nelson Mandela came out of his 27 years of hell and gave us three years of heaven, everyone has been sighing a gasp of relief. We made it! No exile, no bloodshed, no retribution. The rich got richer and the poor think they're in power. Democracy does it again! 

For years, the farewell toast at boere dinner parties was "Next year Paraguay!" And now here we still sit, albeit with a friendly black majority government in power, and very little has changed for us whites.

Irritating things do happen more often. The trains don't run on time like they used to. But then that was also the problem after Mussolini was killed. Whites don't usually take trains; we have cars. Blacks don't take trains either; they prefer taking our cars! Vehicle hijacking rivals robbery and murder in the Top of the Bloody Pops.

There is affirmative action. And so there should be, knowing that whites ran everything while blacks sat and watched.

It all now means that experienced people are sent into the platteland to grow vegetables, while unlettered potential voters become managing directors. Forget not the golden handshakes that are being passed out at the expense of reconstruction and development.

Millions are being paid to the former henchmen of apartheid to get them out of their jobs peacefully, hoping that they won't flood the computer network with computer viruses.

There is no punishment, just early retirement - in itself, sometimes a welcome reward.

Tata Nelson is now best friends with those very Afrikaners who locked him up! He is dinner guest to those Jewish businessmen who kept apartheid going and now support the AN

He is polite to those Dutch industrialists who slyly circumvented sanctions in the '80s by sending their product to Pretoria via Taiwan.

South Africans can now get away with murder. And we do, daily. The amnesty cut-off date for those who admit to committing crimes during, and after the apartheid era ended, has been moved so many times, it is worth killing someone you don't like today. Because tomorrow you're bound to get a new amnesty cut-off date!

Former fascist Broeders are still in control of the most sensitive areas of society. Look at the SABC, military, the police, the arts and business. Now they just say "Comrade!" without throwing up!

Yes, there have been great improvements. Children are going to school hand in hand, in spite of background and colour. Life is going on, despite the culture of negative gossip that will not allow optimism to breed hope. No one can believe that we can have a future in an African democracy.

But what about now, in 1997? Desmond Tutu, our Truth Fairy, has waved his wand of compassion and humanity and made the Truth Commission acceptable to most, no matter how one hates hearing That Truth about our past.

The murders, the torture, the assassinations, the pain and the horror that was our responsibility.

Under Tutu's watchful, often tear-filled eye, the victims only ask for the names of those who killed their loved ones, in order to forgive them! Dear God, where in the world would one find such simplistic goodness?

So is reconciliation working?

Of course it is. I'm still here. As a white Afrikaner I am as guilty as any other white for the dark past. Even though I was anti-apartheid and not anti- South African, there is little memory today of some aspects of our struggle. The parliamentary portrait of that feisty fighter for human rights, Helen Suzman, is lying on the rubbish heap of the past, next to Hendrik Verwoerd's portrait and P W Botha's picture. There is no sentiment, little thanks, scant truth. Just history.

But will history really bother itself with this small hiccup of goodwill? When Nelson Mandela goes - no, when he dies, and sadly he will die - what will happen to South Africa?

Will the lid fly off like in Yugoslavia after the death of Tito?

While there are potentially great leaders waiting in the wings, there are also many upstarts and troublemakers. There is a frightening lack of discipline in our politics. MPs arrive in Parliament filled with passion and care and hope and honesty.

Within months, they are corrupt and decadent and can't be told apart from the old National Party of apartheid.

Violence is tearing us asunder. It is not political violence; it is just criminal madness. Murder and mugging, theft and fraud, have become the way of life and the butt of bitter jokes. The senseless killing of children and their mothers, the horrifying rape of women and innocents, is now being committed just for the fun of it.

We have sowed what we now reap. And because of this orgy of reconciliation, there can be no punishment. After apartheid's culture of death, we dare not have a death penalty for those who in turn create a new culture of bloodshed. No punishment for the rapists who rape every 14 seconds in South Africa.

A nation free of the burden of capital punishment? Yes, a great and noble liberal ideal. But in a confused crossover society, liberalism is as useless as a key without a lock. We have the greatest liberal constitution the world has seen, but no government strong enough to protect it at the expense of its popularity with the people.

Ironically, if any small, silly party fights the 1999 election on the restoration of the death penalty, they might win.

The letters ANC now not only stand for "African National Congress", but "A Nice Cheque"! We have the best government money can buy. Gangsters and drug barons send their dollars to party coffers and move into suburbia unmolested. Beijing offers the ANC a bigger cheque than Taiwan, in exchange for official diplomatic recognition.

Don't be shocked. Don't be alarmed. It's quite normal. It's confused and corrupt; it's enlightened and sublime; it's infuriating and priceless. It is muddied by human touch and clouded with human weakness. It's called democracy and it's working fine! At least South Africa is, at last, being run by us, the people.

And in a democracy like ours, politicians very often are like monkeys. The higher they climb the pole of ambition, the more of their arses we see!


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


433 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Elections: Waiting for 1999 (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - The Electoral Steering Committee has warned Parliament that the 1999 elections could fail if legislation is not processed urgently. New maps are also needed

In 1994 the world looked on benignly as South Africa held its momentous election: so what if there were hiccups in the poll which would forever move the country away from its evil past and towards a democratic future?

In the event there were problems throughout the process, casting some doubt on its eventual accuracy. A similar scenario would probably have been unacceptable in many another country at the time, but the result was accepted as free and fair. The country was close enough to the brink; it simply had too much to lose from a failed election. 

Now 1999 and the second free election approach. It would be stretching a point to suggest that as much will be at stake this time round, but it is not unreasonable to expect the nature of this election to have an impact on perceptions about South Africa.

As the new country proceeds towards the 21st Century it is battling to stave off concerns (mostly unfair ones) that it is vulnerable to corruption. It is also beginning to labour under a belief that it is not exactly a model of efficiency.

A less-than-perfect election in 1999 will strengthen these perceptions. It may be unfortunate, but it is perceptions that often shape critical decisions such as whether a country is worthy of investment.

It is, therefore, vitally important that the government listens to the warnings of the Electoral Steering Committee and gets preparations under way.

And it might bear in mind the small matter of cost. Elections do not come cheap and South Africa will most certainly not be able to afford a repeat if the 1999 election monitors decide that the process has not been a fair one.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 16, 1997


Business and Finance;
KWV's application postponed


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - The KWV was dealt a severe blow yesterday when its application to convert to a company was postponed in the Cape High Court to August 18.

The court ruled that Minister of Agriculture and Land Affairs Derek Hanekom could become a party to the KWV's application to convert into a company, allowing him to complete investigations into issues relating to the conversion. These include the future regulatory environment of the wine industry, the competition implications and questions relating to some of the assets. 

The minister earlier opposed the KWV's application on the grounds that it could lead to the collapse of the regulations controlling the local wine and spirits industry, and would also see it benefit from the "privatisation" of assets which were generated through the exercise of its statutory powers.

Mr Hanekom welcomed the ruling, but added: "I want to make it clear that I do not wish to stand in the way of the KWV's plans to become more competitive, and to be in a better position to develop its foreign markets.

"I do have several concerns about specific details relating to the KWV's proposed restructuring, and the court has granted me the right to address these over the next few months."

He said the extra time would allow him to complete the investigation into KWV's assets.

Harvey Weiner, managing director of auditors Fisher Hoffman Sithole, who heads the investigating team, told the court it would take at least three months to complete the task of determining the nature and value of KWV's " substantial" assets.

The minister said he hoped that it would be possible for the parties to reach a negotiated settlement that would address the major issues in the time granted.

"I would like to see a new dispensation where the interests of everyone - new entrants, growers, producers, workers, wholesalers and consumers - are addressed."

Chairman Lourens Jonker said he was "extremely disappointed" that the KWV's application to convert to a company had been postponed again.

"We agreed in December to give Mr Hannekom three months for his investigations and gave our full co-operation to the three commissions appointed by him," Mr Jonker said.

"It now appears as if the minister and his advisers are ignoring these lengthy and costly investigations and we believe this delay will lead to further abortive expenses for both the KWV and the taxpayers."


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


435 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Clarence Brown: A man who likes to make and share music


BYLINE: Gary van Dyk, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Cape Town - Music icon Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown is a musician who just cannot be categorised and makes no bones about telling you that he plays American and World Music - Texas- style.

With more than 50 years in the entertainment business behind him, he knows what he's talking about.

Brown was in town recently for the announcement of the line-up of the Standard Bank Jazz Festival which forms part of the Grahamstown Festival in three months time.

Brown made headlines when he arrived in South Africa by entertaining fellow passengers with his sublime fiddle-playing for three hours non-stop, when their flight was delayed at Johannesburg airport. At the launch in the Waterfront he demonstrated his consumate skills on guitar and fiddle and it was clear that here was a man who really enjoyed his music. 

Brown is a seven-time Grammy nominee whose career is enjoying one of its hottest streaks and a blaze of nominations during the past two years.

"I'm a man who looks for artistic perfection while blending a number of musical styles and influences to create my music," he says.

"Jazz, blues, country, swing, funk and zydeco, they're all there and I just like taking it to audiences all around the world." This style and class has earned Brown praise from fans and the international media alike and has singularly qualified him as a spokesman for American music.

This may seem strange in a world where the biggest moneyspinners in the music world, at times, seem devoid of talent and rely on trendy videos to catch the customer. But Brown feels that there is a change happening in people's tastes.

"They're growing tired of being fed trash under the guise of creativity and there is a movement towards hearing actual talent and artistry in music.

"Today the recording industry is geared too much towards the fast buck, with one-hit wonder artists popping up all over the place and then you never hear of them again," he said.

"But the proof that talent will always survive over hype is with people like me who are still going strong and whose music is finding new and younger audiences all the time.

"Too much of the music produced for the younger lot is not creative. They're simply covering a lot of the old stuff that happened before and putting it into other packages." said "Gatemouth".

Born in 1924, Brown was raised in Texas and it was his father Tom who introduced him to music, giving him his first lessons on guitar and fiddle.

His father was a specialist in country and western as well as Cajun and bluegrass music but Brown also listened to his blues albums by people like Tampa Red, Blind Boy Fuller and T-Bone Walker as well as the swing of Count Basie, Woody Herman and Lionel Hampton.

It was the music of country artists that left the biggest impression on him.

When he was 16 he joined his first group, playing drums and touring Texas.

In 1949, he joined a 23-piece orchestra playing at the Keyhole Club and two years later he was spotted by producer Don Robey, who took him along to Houston to play at the famous Bronze Peacock Club.

"Don knew that there was something inside me that had hits written all over it and we went to Los Angeles to record on the Aladdin Label," said Brown.

"Unfortunately for them they did not have the same confidence and gave the recording very little promotion.

"Don decided to record me on his own behalf and songs like Okie Dokie Stomp, Boogie Rambler and Mercy on Me became big sellers in Texas and established my reputation as a performer."

Up to 1960, Brown recorded with the cream of the crop of Texas musicians, also touring with Dinah Washington, Sonny Stitt and Gene Ammons.

In 1965 he went into semi-retirement in extraordinary fashion. He became the sheriff of Durango County in Colorado and did not re-surface until the 70s, when he took part in the 1973 Montreaux Jazz Festival.

"I guess I needed a bit of a break from the music business just to gather my thoughts and because I was disappointed after an audition for the Chess Label in 1965," he said. "After Montreaux I felt good about my music and went on to record several albums in France as well as doing stuff with jazzmen Arnett Cobb, Milt Buckner and Jay McShann."

Since then Brown has had little respite, undertaking tours all over the world and garnering many awards for his albums.

In 1982 his release Alright Again won him a grammy for Best Contemporary Blues Album and he was in the news again last year with a nomination for his album The Man. This year he was again on the list of nominations with his album Long Way Home.

"I'm just a guy who likes to make music and share it with the rest of the world," he says. "If it makes you happy it makes me happy, and that is what music is all about."

If you're heading for Grahamstown for the festivities in July you'll be able to catch "Gatemouth" in action at the Monument Theatre on July 8 and 9 and experience that happiness for yourself.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


436 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


South Africa;
Hunt For Missing Pilgrims - SA visitors sought after Haj fire


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Cape Town - A number of South African pilgrims have been reported missing after being swept up in a stampede to safety when fire raged through two tent towns in the Islamic holy city of Mena, killing 217 pilgrims and injuring about 1 300.

Thousands of the two million pilgrims on the annual haj (pilgrimage) to Islam's holy citadel of Mecca were caught in the human tide of panic-stricken people fleeing the flames and were swept away from relatives and friends.

Although none of the 8 000 South African pilgrims in Saudi Arabia for the haj were listed among the dead, some camped in the area were reported missing by relatives and friends trying to locate them early today for the climax of the haj, the Day of Wuqoof - day of atonement - on the plains of Arafaat.

Thousands of fleeing pilgrims were reported today to have reached Mecca, about 11km away. 

Sheikh Abdurahmaan Gafieldien, head of the legislative department of the Majlisush-Shura-al-Islami in Cape Town, described the fire as tragic.

He said: "We all mourn the loss of lives and our sympathy lies with the bereaved families."

Witnesses described mass panic as flames, driven by fierce winds, raged through the white tents, pitched closely together.

Huge palls of smoke blacked out the sunlight on the plains of Mena as the emergency services battled to cope.

Many of the dead - mostly Indians, Pakistanis and Bangladeshis, Syrians, Egyptians, Sudanese, Lebanese, Yemenis and Moroccans - were said to have been crushed in the rush to escape the blaze.

Pilgrim Suzanne Kassem said: "It started off with just small puffs of black smoke. It spread in size until the day looked like night. Gas tanks were exploding everywhere like bombs.

"People were running around. It was mass hysteria. Everyone was running around like cattle. The fire broke out as some of the 2 million pilgrims were beginning to move en masse towards Mount Arafat. Some witnesses said it was caused by a gas canister used for cooking; others blamed faulty wiring in air conditioning.

As news of the main fire spread, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported that a second blaze had broken out in the Iranian encampments on Mount Arafat, 19km south-west of Mecca.

Before the blaze broke out, Saudi television showed pictures of many of the pilgrims in their traditional dress - two simple white sheets for men and long white or black robes plus headscarves for women - carrying umbrellas to protect themselves from the sun as they made the journey to Mena, chanting: " I have answered your call, God. There is no one God but you."

The tragedy was a serious embarrassment for the Saudi authorities, who are the proud guardians of the world's two holiest Islamic sites at Mecca and Medina, and have spent $18,6-billion (R83-bn) extending facilities in Mecca.

Shortly before the blaze, Saudi officials claimed that they had been doing their best to ensure a safe haj for the pilgrims from about 100 countries.

Every able-bodied Muslim who can afford it is obliged to perform the pilgrimage once. But the haj has been dogged by tragedy.

The worst one was seven years ago, when 1 426 pilgrims died in an overcrowded tunnel at Mena, probably because of a breakdown of the ventilation system.

And in 1994, 270 pilgrims, most of them Indonesian, were killed in a stampede in Mecca when the crowd surged forward uncontrollably towards a cavern for the ritual of "stoning the devil".

Fire, hostage-taking, political disturbances and bombings have also taken a huge toll.

In 1987 402 people, most of them Iranian pilgrims, were killed and 649 wounded in Mecca when Saudi security forces clashed with Iranians staging an illegal anti-US and anti-Israel demonstration.

The most dramatic incident was in 1979, when several hundred armed men hostile to the conservative Saudi government barricaded themselves inside Mecca's Grand Mosque for two weeks, taking pilgrims hostage.

The fighting claimed the lives of 153 people and 560 were injured.

A year later 301 passengers were killed when a Pakistani jet caught fire after a passenger lit a kerosene stove in an aisle to brew tea.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 16, 1997


Namibia;
Govt official faces 15 charges of fraud


BYLINE: The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Windhoek - A director in the Ministry of Lands, Resettlement and Rehabilitation, Mukwaita Shanyengana, appeared in the Windhoek Magistrates Court yesterday on 15 counts of fraud.

Shanyengana is charged with defrauding Government of more than N$11 000 through submitting false subsistence claims and travelling allowances between November 1990 and September 1991. 

He pleaded not guilty to all 15 charges.

The State alleges that the Lands director defrauded Government or alternatively stole the money from Government.

The misappropriation of State funds was detected during investigations by the Frank Commission in 1991.

According to the testimony of one of the former investigators in the Frank Commission, Jacques Malan, Shanyengana sometimes allegedly claimed twice the subsistence amount or added an extra amount to his claim.

In one example, the State charges, Shanyengana claimed N$2 926,83 instead of the correct amount of N$2 712,95.

In another case, he allegedly furnished invoices for breakfast at a Windhoek hotel, while he had been out of the city.

It was also alleged that Shanyengana bought bricks and claimed the money from Government and bought personal goods such as parts for his vehicle, leather items and groceries and used the receipts to claim for refunds.

The total amount he allegedly received fraudulently is estimated at N$11 500.

The case was yesterday postponed until May 28 as Shanyengana's legal representative, Petrus Damaseb, requested more time to check all the court documents related to the case.

Magistrate Leonard Simasiku presided and Charles Visser prosecuted.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 16, 1997


Business and Finance;
Namibia ups fish quotas


BYLINE: Chrispin Inambao, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Windhoek - The minister of Fisheries and Marine Resources yesterday announced a Total Allowable Catch (TAC) for pilchard of 25 000 tonnes and a TAC for horse mackerel of 350 000 tonnes, up from 250 000 tonnes.

Hifikepunye Pohamba assured Parliament yesterday that this level of fishing was consistent with scientific information available on stocks, and that this would help support the fishing industry in a lean period.

The House was told that the conditions which had caused catches to dwindle had disappeared and marine environmental conditions off Namibia had returned to normal. 

There were also signs that conditions may have been particularly favourable for spawning in 1996, and these conditions were continuing.

The position was much more favourable for pilchard and horse mackerel stocks, which grow much faster than hake which takes around two years before it can be harvested economically.

The Minister commended Norway and Iceland for providing assistance, especially in the fields of research and surveillance.

Even though Norway was scaling down its assistance to Namibia, its fisheries aid would be extended for a further three years.

In addition, Pohamba made it clear that his Ministry had rejected any strings tied to European Union grants to the fishing sector and stated that joint ventures between local companies and EU partners had been reviewed.

"I can confirm that we have made our policy clear to the EU that any agreement would not involve the allocation of quotas to EU vessels of EU companies." He added that the EU had accepted Government's position on the issue.

Reviewing off-shore diamond mining, the Minister said its impact on fish, especially rock lobster, was an issue that concerned the people of Luderitz and would be given serious attention in the near future.

Commenting on regional co-operation, Pohamba revealed: "Namibia has successfully continued its work in co-ordinating the marine fisheries sector within SADC".

He highlighted some of the progress such as the launching of the benefit programme, which supports a co-operative science plan between Namibia, Angola and South Africa, aimed at improving knowledge on the Benguela Current System.

Another achievement was the completion of the feasibility study on regional needs in the area of monitoring, control and surveillance, and also the implementation of a regional project to assist SADC states in quality control and inspection of fish products.

In addition, the Ministry needed to replace and upgrade vessels for surveillance and research, and to train and recruit more inspectors.

More staff in areas such as economics, planning and law were required to cope with the expected increase in the size of the fishing sector.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


439 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


Namibia;
Fresh allegations of racism rock Gobabis


BYLINE: Christof Maletsky, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Windhoek - Allegations of racism have reared their ugly head at the eastern Namibian town of Gobabis, with a woman who unwittingly rented accommodation in a "whites-only" block of flats being given a one-month deadline to leave the premises.

Newly-appointed Telecom employee, Dianne Arendse, had been in the flat for only two days when some of her white neighbours allegedly complained to the landlords about 'her presence'.

According to sources, they threatened to quit their flats if the Telecom employee was allowed to stay on. 

The owners, apparently an "oldish white woman" and her brother, known only as Mr Blaauw, from Pretoria, bowed to pressure from the tenants.

Arendse has been told to go.

The Mayor of the eastern town, Rehabeam Tjirivanga, has been informed about the incident and confirmed to The Namibian yesterday that he was very angered by it.

"It is totally against the Constitution ... There are still some elements in the town who seem to not respect the Constitution. The Council will not tolerate such people," Tjirivanga said.

Arendse recently took up employment with Telecom at Gobabis and approached Josephine Bailey, an employee of the Blaauws, over accommodation at the block of flats.

Bailey, who works at a bottle store owned by the Blaauws, is responsible for handing out keys to new tenants on instructions from a local auditing firm which handles the Blaauws' financial matters.

Bailey did not inform the auditors that Arendse was "a coloured" as she did not think the flats were allocated along racial lines.

The auditors gave the go-ahead.

Arendse paid her deposit and her first month's rent and happily moved in.

Two days later, Arendse was contacted by Bailey who informed her that the owners were not happy that she had been given the flat.

Bailey told The Namibian that Blaauw had called her from Pretoria to enquire who had given her permission to allow "the coloured", Arendse, to rent the flat.

"He (Blaauw) said I was busy chasing the white people away and that he will come within two weeks," Bailey said.

According to Bailey, the white tenants had lodged a complaint about Arendse, threatening to vacate their flats.

Contacted for comment, Arendse confirmed that she had been informed about her "illegal presence" at the flats.

"I feel they are discriminating against me. I am aware of the Prevention of Racial Discrimination Act which states no one should discriminate against the other. I will take up the issue with Mr Blaauw," Arendse said.

She did not want to elaborate further but said she felt hurt and that it had been a blow to her dignity.

She said not even during the colonial period had she encountered this sort of treatment.

All efforts to get hold of the owners of the flats proved fruitless.

The latest incident comes in the wake of recent efforts by the Town Council to break down racial barriers at the eastern town .

Recently the Wennie du Plessis secondary school was in the news over alleged racism, but the community, together with the Ministry of Basic Education, managed to restore peace there.

Another achievement is that black farmers can now take part in the annual Gobabis Cattle Show, something that never happened in the past.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


440 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 16, 1997


Namibia;
Secrecy over mine deal Rosh Pinah workers 'unsettled'


BYLINE: Tabby Moyo, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Windhoek - A veil of secrecy surrounds negotiations between proprietors of the beleaguered Rosh Pinah Zinc Mine and the mine's mineral rights holders PE Minerals.

Nothing concrete has emerged although new negotiations reopened in January after the Australian mining company, Western Metals, which had indicated interest in purchasing the mine, pulled out.

And workers at the southern Namibian mine say they cannot stomach the uncertainty which has haunted them since 1995. 

Rosh Pinah Mine Manager David Southey told The Namibian yesterday that negotiations were "in progress" between Imcor directors and PE Minerals players.

However, he could not give any indication on when these would be finalised.

"Its a long process and its not easy.

It's not something that can be sorted out in a day or two," Southey said.

It has also emerged that an assurance given to Rosh Pinah employees by Government that the matter would be finalised by the end of last month was now fuelling uncertainty at the mine.

According to Southey, however, the delay in finalising the mineral rights issue had not in any way affected production at the mine.

"We have kept people (employees) focused on the mine since February 1995. In fact we have managed to increase production," he said.

He said mining operations would continue until the rights issue was sorted out.

PE Minerals, a consortium of Namibian and Malaysian businessmen, holds the mining rights for Rosh Pinah but does not own the mine and its assets.

Government's decision to award the Rosh Pinah mining rights to PE Minerals, which did not own the mine, has raised more than a few eye-brows.

Following protracted negotiations last year, PE Minerals and Western Metals failed to to reach an amicable solution resulting in the Australian base metal giant deciding not to proceed with talks.

PE Minerals also failed to reach an agreement with Iscor.

It was established that the deadlock in the negotiations between PE Minerals and Western Metals resulted from PE's stand that it should have the major stake in the mine.

Western Metals, which had indicated that it would pump about N$165 million into the mine if it eventually took over ownership, was not prepared to settle for a minority stake in the mine.

Although the Ministry of Mines and Energy said it would intervene if the negotiating parties failed to reach an agreement on the rights issue this did not happen.

Africa News


April 16, 1997


Namibia;
Money problems slow aviation probe


BYLINE: Christof Maletsky, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Windhoek - A lack of financial resources is blocking the appointment of the Commission of Inquiry to probe "possible problems" concerning the licensing and safety of aircraft in Namibia.

Works, Transport and Communication deputy minister Dr Klaus Dierks told The Namibian yesterday that around N$500 000 was needed to establish the high- level commission.

"There is no foot dragging. The lack of half a million (dollars) is the only reason. Otherwise we would have appointed the commission already. It is urgently needed," Dierks said. 

However, he added, efforts were underway to get the necessary funding.

The probe follows the crash of a Cessna 210 in the Naukluft mountains in southern Namibia at the beginning of the year.

Five people lost their lives in the air accident, which has opened up a bitter public row among pilots and others in the aviation industry over the cause of the accident and the air safety situation in Namibia in general.

The commission will investigate possible problems within the aviation sector and assess how the level of licensing and aircraft safety can be improved through the necessary technical or even legal actions.

Earlier Dierks said his Ministry was in the process of getting high-level international aviation experts to the country in the next few weeks.

"Another couple of weeks and the findings of the Commission will be known," Dierks said at the time.

The deputy minister has not ruled out the possibility that the findings of the Commission might result in changes being made to Namibia's aviation safety laws.

"It can be that our current legislation is not good enough or has loopholes.

The Commission will look into all this," Dierks said.

Accusations and counter-accusations in aviation circles were fuelled by the Cessna crash.

The plane was piloted by the experienced Dirk de Meyer, who was flying passengers Koos Koekemoer (68), his wife Driekie (63), their daughter Martha Bekker and son-in-law Koos Bekker.

They all died.

The Ministry ordered an investigation into the accident and initial reports have allegedly ruled out fire as the cause of the crash.

However, the final report has yet to be released by the Ministry.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 17, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Court Orders University To Reinstate Students


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The High Court of Zimbabwe on Thursday ordered authorities at the Mutare-based Africa University to re-instate more than 250 students who were suspended this week following an 11-day boycott of lessons in protest against a hike in school fees.

The high court, sitting before Justice Chinhengo in Harare, the Zimbabwean capital, declared the suspensions null and void. The judge gave the university 10 days to file its opposing affidavits with registrar of the high court in Harare if it so wishes.

In his ruling, Justice Chinhengo said that the withdrawal of scholarships from the suspended students by the Vice-Chancellor had "no force or effect", and ordered that students be allowed to enjoy the rights and privileges they were entitled to before they were suspended.

He also ordered the university authorities to meet all the costs of this suit.

The suit was filed by the students representative council through their lawyers after the institution, run by the United Methodist Church, failed to comply with the demands contained in a letter sent to the university on Tuesday.

The lawyers asserted that the administration had acted improperly by suspending the students en-masse without specifying the charges against each individual.

A university official confirmed receipt of the letter from the students' lawyers, adding that the response would come through its legal representatives.

Except for 33 students studying for a masters in business administration degree, about 270 students started boycotting lectures soon after the university announced a 17 percent increase in fees.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 17, 1997


East Africa;
Regional leaders Ease Sanctions on Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

ARUSHA, Tanzania (PANA) - Burundi's military ruler, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, has welcomed Wednesday's decision by African regional leaders to ease sanctions against his country, describing the measure as a very important step.

Speaking to reporters after the summit, he said the leaders "decided to lift sanctions on all food items and those things which concern the ordinary people." 

He also said the action was an important step toward peace in his politically and ethnically divided country, although he had hoped for greater concessions from the African leaders.

Buyoya, who attended the summit for the first time since the embargo was imposed July 1996, after he seized power, said the ban had also been lifted on agricultural products, educational and construction materials and medicine.

He said the sanctions only hurt the common people and fuel Tutsi extremism in the country.

The leaders imposed sanctions on landlocked Burundi to force Buyoya to return the country to constitutional rule and open unconditional talks with the largely Hutu rebels.

Buyoya said he is ready for these talks. However, hardliners within the Tutsi-dominated army and the former military ruler, Jean-Baptiste Bagaza, are opposed to such talks.

Wednesday's regional summit on the sanctions was the first attended by Buyoya. He was welcomed as "president" at the talks by host Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa.

Presidents Daniel Arap Moi of Kenya, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Frederick Chiluba of Zambia were at the summit. Others were Prime Ministers Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia and Pierre Rwigema of Rwanda. The Organization of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim and the international mediator on Burundi, former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere also attended.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
