Africa News


April 17, 1997


Sudan;
Army Claims Killing Hundreds Of Ugandan Soldiers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Sudanese army said Thursday it had killed hundreds of Ugandan troops west of the southern Sudanese town of Juba.

"Documented proof, which will be shown on the state television later on, shows that the invading forces moved from (the) Gulu military area where the Ugandan Fourth Division is stationed," it said. 

In a statement read over state-run television, the army said after the western attack failed Tuesday, the Ugandans advanced from the south but were stopped 44 miles short of their target.

The Sudanese army said that it was supported by the militia, called Popular Defence Forces, who counter-attacked the Ugandans from the rear "completely wiping them out, killing over 306 and destroying five tanks and capturing four others, all of them modern."

The Sudanese Army General Command, which issued the statement, said there was no significant participation from the anti-government Sudan People's Liberation Army in the attack.

Sudan has often accused Uganda of supporting the guerrillas in their effort to overthrow the Khartoum government, a charge Uganda has often denied.

The army said that among those killed was the deputy commander of the Fourth Division. It said the commander of the division was killed in an earlier first attack.

The Sudanese army accused "malignant colonization circles" of providing Uganda with state of the art military equipment and with which to capture Juba, the largest town in southern Sudan.

However, there has been no independent confirmation of any of the army's claims.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


445 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


East Africa;
Tanzania-Zambia Paramilitary Forces To Man Border Posts


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - Tanzania has said it will deploy paramilitary forces along its border with Zambia to check arms smuggling from Zaire.

The Minister for Home Affairs, Ali Ameir Mohamed, said that the force would be drawn from the Field Force Unit (FFU).

In an interview, the minister said the force will be dispatched to recover arms already smuggled or likely to be smuggled through the common border. 

He said police officers were already investigating the arms smuggling network starting from the southern border town of Tunduma in Mbeya region and in the western regions of Rukwa and Kigoma.

Ameir Mohamed said the police action was prompted by the rising incidents of banditry due to an incessant influx of refugees from Rwanda, Burundi and lately from Zaire.

"We are in a final stage of launching a campaign against illegal possession of arms, particularly in areas close to our borders," he said, adding that areas to be marked out for special surveillance include Ngara in Kagera region, Kigoma, Rukwa regions and Tunduma in Mbeya region.

He said close cooperation had been sought with the Zambian police force to contain cross border crime. He added that reports suggest that arms were being smuggled into Tanzania through Zambia.

According to the minister, poor liaison among the police in the two countries and lack of communication had led to an increase in cases of cross border robbery and car theft in the two countries.

He said the arms smuggling was being carried out by a syndicate involving gangs of thieves in Tanzania and Zambia. These smuggle the arms from Zaire to Zambia and finally to Tanzania. The triangular border situation serves the syndicates perfectly, the minister said.

Mohamed Ameir said the Tanzanian border town of Tunduma was now reputed to be a major transit point for criminals from the various countries.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ashanti Creates Depository Receipts To Enhance Its Shares


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 960 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - In an attempt to facilitate trading of Ashanti Goldfields Equity on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange, the company has created a facility called the Zimbabwe Depository Receipts (ZDR).

Addressing business people at a meeting held in Harare on Wednesday, Ashanti Goldfields Zimbabwe managing director, Michael Marriot, said the facility would enable shareholders on the Zimbabwe register to exchange each Ashanti share they held for 100 Ashanti-Zimbabwe depository receipts.

The Ashanti ZDRS would be listed on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange and, he said, it was anticipated that the price of a ZDR on the ZSE would be approximately one hundredth of the current trading price of Ashanti shares on the ZSE.

"If all Ashanti shareholders on the ZSE opt to convert their Ashanti shares into ZDRS, it is anticipated that the volume of trading in Ashanti will increase as a result of the fact that shareholders would have more Ashanti securities in which to deal," Marriot said. 

He said in order to set up the ZDR facility, Ashanti had entered into an agreement (the ZDR agreement) with Deloitte and Touche Executor and Trust Company (Pvt) Limited (the depository).

Marriot said some of the main provisions of the agreement were that in respect of every Ashanti share lodged with the depository, 100 ZDRS would be issued and freely transferable. Upon execution of a common form of transfer, a ZDR holder might withdraw his Ashanti shares from the depository at any time, by surrendering his ZDR certificate(s) to the depository on the last day of business each month. A ZDR holder would also receive in respect of each ZDR, one hundredth of any dividend paid on an Ashanti share.

Use of the ZDR facility was voluntary and shareholders were not obliged to use it, but it was recommended as it was expected to produce benefits in terms of enhanced tradeability of Ashanti securities.

With the acquisition of the Freda Rebecca Mine in Bindura, the single largest gold mine in the country, Ashanti Goldfields, one of the top ten producers in the world, became one of Zimbabwe's largest investors.

Since the take over of the British-based Cluff Resources in January 1996, Ashanti has added immense value to the company's operations with major investments in exploration, production and mine development. Speaking at the same meeting, Mark Keatley, the company's chief financial officer said Freda Rebecca, with a ten-year life, produced 100,000 ounces of gold per year at a cash cost of USD 230 per ounce (zimdollars 2,530).

"Since acquiring this mine, Ashanti has achieved an increase of 770,000 ounces in resources and an eight percent increase in annual gold production.

"Expansion of the treatment plant in 1997 will realize an additional increase in production from 1998 onwards," he said.

He said Ashanti had also added value by refinancing the long term debt of the Zimbabwe operations, resulting in a saving in interest costs of one million dollars (ZD 11 million) per year.

Keatley said the company had made rapid progress in exploration in Africa and was active on some 35 projects in 12 countries.

"Including exploration at our mine sites, we plan to spend USD 25 million (ZD 275 million) on exploration in 1997," Keatley.

He said the company's gold hedging programme had been a success with virtually the whole of scheduled gold production this year hedged at USD 445 (ZD 4,895) per ounce.

This, he said, would protect the company's cash flows during the current period of weakness in the gold price.

"We believe the gold market will recover its equilibrium and remain bullish in the long term," he said.

The group's operating cash flow was between usd 150 million (ZD 1.65 billion) and USD 160 million (ZD 1.76 billion) a year and was expected to rise significantly after 1998 with the completion of the Bibiani gold project in Ghana and Siguiri project in Guinea.

The increase in cash flow, together with the programmed decline in capital expenditure was expected to result in INL002 from SSS.069 (970417-16:59) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG068G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) substantial free cash flows which would service the company's debt and fund the next generation of projects.

In the meantime, Keatley said, the company had been drawing on debt facilities to fund their investments.

"We anticipated these needs and that is why Ashanti has been active in the financial markets in the last two years. We have successfully tapped the equity, loan and bond markets to finance our growth.

"We are particularly proud last year to be the first African operating company to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange," he said.

Africa News


April 17, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Media Women Still Face Enormous Hurdles Worldwide


BYLINE: Matilda Moyo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

DARWANDALE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Women have made some in-roads in the field of journalism worldwide, but there are still many hurdles which they have to overcome.

These range from frustrations at the work place and the reluctance by society to accept female journalists in their own right without casting doubt on their moral integrity.

These issues were discussed during the International Association of Women in Radio and Television (IAWRT) bi-annual conference which was held in collaboration with the Federation of African Media Women in Zimbabwe (FAMWZ).

Rinki Bhattacharya, a television film producer from India, said the marginalization of women in society is carried over to the work place where they find themselves isolated in a "man's field". 

"We are seen as people of loose morals because of the work we do," said FAMWZ chairperson Mavis Moyo.

Nonee Walsh, of Australia, said there was an attempt to maintain the field of journalism as a "boys' club" where women are often made to feel lonely.

"The newsroom of today still reflect a 'boys network'. No matter how intelligent a woman is, the men maintain this feel of it being a man's world so a woman cannot fit in," says Norwegian journalist Mette Janson.

Female journalists are often frustrated at work and hardly get promoted even when they excel, said Ropafadzo Mapimhidze a sub-editor with the Herald in Zimbabwe.

Media women feel that their male counterparts travel widely and get major assignments while opportunities for further studies are often reserved for them.

This helps them to qualify for promotion while women remain with basic training often below degree level.

Gender sensitivity is lacking in most media reports because women are not in decision-making positions that enable them to control news and the way womenfolk are portrayed. It has also been noted that some news sources prefer to deal with male journalists whom they have more confidence in, thus alienating female journalists who are just as competent.

Janson strongly felt that women have to work twice as much as their male counterparts to prove their worth while male journalists can afford to be lax and still earn respect.

Isa Edholm said although there are more females attending schools of journalism now, particularly in first world countries, large established newspaper companies are turning to universities for male journalists in an attempt to fend off women.

The women also complained of lack of newspaper space and air time for their articles and programmes.

Inge Von Bonninghausen from Germany, said issues concerning women are normally given attention when they have a negative aspect.

She cited coverage of the September 1995 Beijing conference as an example where most relevant discussions went unreported while confusion and mistakes made headlines.

As a result, women have to resort to having a women's page or a specific slot in order to be heard.

There is, however, a general feeling that these pages and programmes are often ignored by men and could be futile since gender issues require the participation of both sexes.

The women also share the common problem of being unable to market or to get sponsorship for their programs in the face of cheap imports.

These forces working against women in the media have resulted in most female journalists joining public relations houses.

A University of Zimbabwe sociology professor, Rudo Gaidzanwa, noted that it was not only female journalists who face problems, but the portrayal of ordinary women and their participation in the media needed improvement.

She said the ever-increasing emphasis on consumerism that comes with economic growth disadvantages women.

"Increasingly, we are being confronted with advertisements and commercial messages which target girls and women of all ages inappropriately and which market women in degrading images to sell products," Gaidzanwa said.

Simonette Rassampanina of Madagascar said many television programmes stereotype women, particularly in advertisements where they are either seen as consumers or commodities.

According to Janson, however, women display little interest in news because it has very little of their experience and they do not identify with it.

A total of 80 percent of news stories are about men while women take up 20 percent.

Indian university lecturer and journalist Jai Chandiram said even the camera focus on women portrays them as weak and vulnerable while men are shown as powerful, confident and dominating.

To reverse these trends, IAWRT and FAMWZ members passed a resolution recommending that female journalists should distance themselves from programs that stereotype and undervalue women in society.

Programs on social issues should be aired on prime time so that the whole community can participate.

Female managers and producers should generate interest and become the voice of the voiceless and work in solidarity with other women.

IAWRT was assigned the duty of assisting in the collection of the data on the image and development of women in the media.

Journalists should network at all stages from grassroots to international level and female media practitioners should join and work with women's groups.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 17, 1997


Burundi;
Regional leaders Ease Sanctions on Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

ARUSHA, Tanzania (PANA) - Burundi's military ruler, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, has welcomed Wednesday's decision by African regional leaders to ease sanctions against his country, describing the measure as a very important step.

Speaking to reporters after the summit, he said the leaders "decided to lift sanctions on all food items and those things which concern the ordinary people." 

He also said the action was an important step toward peace in his politically and ethnically divided country, although he had hoped for greater concessions from the African leaders.

Buyoya, who attended the summit for the first time since the embargo was imposed July 1996, after he seized power, said the ban had also been lifted on agricultural products, educational and construction materials and medicine.

He said the sanctions only hurt the common people and fuel Tutsi extremism in the country.

The leaders imposed sanctions on landlocked Burundi to force Buyoya to return the country to constitutional rule and open unconditional talks with the largely Hutu rebels.

Buyoya said he is ready for these talks. However, hardliners within the Tutsi-dominated army and the former military ruler, Jean-Baptiste Bagaza, are opposed to such talks.

Wednesday's regional summit on the sanctions was the first attended by Buyoya. He was welcomed as "president" at the talks by host Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa.

Presidents Daniel Arap Moi of Kenya, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Frederick Chiluba of Zambia were at the summit. Others were Prime Ministers Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia and Pierre Rwigema of Rwanda. The Organization of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim and the international mediator on Burundi, former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere also attended.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 17, 1997


Botswana;
Anonymous Caller Accuses Newspaper Of Subversion


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Windhoek - On March 7, an anonymous caller left an "angry message" on the telephone answering machine for privately-owned newspaper Okavango Observer. The paper's editor Caitlin Davies told MISA on April 11, that the caller was apparently not pleased with an article published in a March 7 Edition. 

The paper had reported that the government was offering cash incentives to villagers in the Central Kalahari Game Reserve to move out of the area. It also reported villagers as alleging that the government had threatened to " shoot" those refusing to move out.

The March 14 edition of the Observer quotes the anonymous caller as saying: "... This is about the so-called forced removal of Bushmen... It is surprising really, just why do white people come down from their countries and mess up other people's countries, why can't she (The Okavango Observer editor) mess up her own country? And to tie the death of Mr. Hardbattle with the Basarwa (Bushmen) relocation, I just find it a bit sinister if not subversive..."

Caitlin Davies is, however, a Motswana.

In its response to the message, the paper argued that the public had a right to know that villagers were being offered cash to move away from their ancestral land. Democracy, the paper went on, means freedom of speech, it means every citizen has the right to air his/her views. The paper, however, observed that the anonymous call came when Botswana had just been heralded as a good example of democracy. This was said at the African Commonwealth meeting in the capital Gaborone this February.

For further information, contact David Nthengwe, researcher, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: research@ingrid.misa.org.na

450 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


Zambia;
IFJ Comments on Zambian Press Bill


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

Windhoek - The following are comments by the International Federation of Journalists (IFJ) on the draft Media Council Zambian Bill. The Zambian government has since announced it is temporarily withdrawing the bill.

Comments on the Media Council of Zambia Bill 1997

The International Federation of Journalists is very concerned by the detail and emphasis of the Media Council of Zambia Bill 1997, and the fact that it was drafted without genuine consultation with the profession.

Whereas no reference is made to the rights to freedom of expression and access to information, there is detailed and dangerously wide reference to disciplinary procedures to be taken against journalists. 

The IFJ supports the establishment of procedures to promote the maintenance of high professional standards but these should be created and undertaken by the profession. There should be a clear Code of Principles to which all journalists are bound, and upon which complaints against journalists can be based and assessed.

Provisions to incarcerate journalists should not be contained in a Press Bill. If, like any other citizen, a journalist commits a criminal offence, he should be prosecuted under the criminal law. A Media Council should not have the authority to deprive a journalist of his/her liberty.

The registering of people practising journalism can be provided for, but the granting of permission to practise as a journalist should not be provided for in legislation. Journalists can be accredited through various means, including by press organisations, but accreditation should not be a requirement for the undertaking of journalistic activity.

Registration should not be handled by the same body responsible for disciplining journalists.

Government officials should not be involved in the accrediting or disciplining of journalists.

This Bill, by creating very restrictive criteria for the granting of accreditation and by placing accreditation in the hands of a body which has no codes or rules by which to guide its decisions, other than those it chooses to adopt, ensures the closing down of the profession of journalists to all but the favoured few.

The IFJ rejects this proposed Media Council, and urges the Zambian authorities to consult with the profession to create frameworks for self regulation and to desist from supporting legislation intended to control access to and the exercise of the profession of journalism.

The IFJ also makes the following detailed remarks on certain parts of the Bill:

Composition of the Council

The members of the Council should not be appointed by the Minister of Information. They should be accepted once proposed by their organisations, the Ministry should not be involved in the appointment or supervision of Council members.

Ministry involvement could compromise the independence and efficiency of the Council.

Disciplinary Committee

Article 10

The Disciplinary Committee should be made up of media professionals.

Registrar and other Staff

Article 13(3) is unclear.

n Is the Registrar a member of staff appointed by the Council who then becomes an ex officio member of the Council, or

* is he one of those listed in Article 6 who becomes Registrar, or

* is he ex officio to the Council from some other body?.

This should be clarified.

The first and second versions are acceptable but the latter is not.

Qualification for accreditation as a journalist

Article 15(c) and (d), in our opinion are excessive. Whilst the IFJ fully supports high levels of training for journalists, this proposal does not seem to further this aim in a constructive manner and could lead to the exclusion of many professional journalists from accreditation.

In particular, there is no provision for those who have received in house training, there is an emphasis on academic qualifications but not on apprenticeships or experience. Further, if the requirements contained in this Bill remain, the only way for the profession to be accessible in a fair and pluralistic way would be for the government to guarantee free and open access to the relevant training institutions for all.

Effect of non-accreditation

Does this mean that one can practise as a "non-accredited" journalist?

Why can accredited newspapers only be owned and operated by accredited journalists?

Article 18(2)

This article is too vague. The penalty units should be defined.

Annual Subscription

Article 21 is unacceptable. It would be acceptable for journalists to pay fees to their organisations which may then send a percentage to the Council, but a journalists' accreditation should not depend on his/her financially supporting the Council.

Further, public funds should also be used to support the Council.

Disciplinary Proceedings

Article 23. It should not be up to the Registrar to charge journalists.

There should be a complaints procedure outlined whereby a complaint must be made, whereupon the Council - or a subcommittee thereof - will examine the complaint and should it contain an allegation of a breach of professional ethics, the charge can then be formulated and sent to the journalist concerned.

Before any Disciplinary Proceedings can be included in legislation, there must be a clear definition of what amounts to a breach of professional conduct. We suggest the incorporation of the IFJ Code of Principles as the basis for such proceedings.

De-accreditation of journalists

If a journalist's accreditation is to be removed the voting procedures within the Council must be defined. It is insufficient to rely on the voting rules contained in the first part of the Bill.

For a de-accreditation to occur, there should be a vote of at least two thirds of all members of the Council in favour (and not only two thirds of those present).

Article 27

This article is incomprehensible, which is very serious given that it includes provision for the imprisonment of journalists.

International Federation of Journalists Brussels, 11 April 1997

For further information, contact David Lush, Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia. Tel. +264 61 232975, Fax. 248016 e-mail: dlush@ingrid.misa.org.na

LANGUAGE: English

451 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Zaire Emergency Fact Sheet No. 12


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Washington, DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . ZAIRE - Complex Emergency, Fact Sheet 12, Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, April 17, 1997. Note: The last fact sheet was dated April 15, 1997.

Background: In mid-October 1996, fighting broke out in South Kivu, Zaire between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance) led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting caused Rwandan and Burundian refugees to flee, forcing over 700,000 Rwandans and 62,000 Burundians to repatriate by the end of 1996. Hundreds of thousands of refugees also fled west, scattering in small groups deeper into Zaire. The fighting spread north, west, and south, with the Alliance gaining territory on all fronts. The Alliance now controls approximately one-third of Zaire. Following the capture of Mubji-Mayi on April 5, the Alliance seized Lubumbashi, on April 9. Three days later, the Alliance seized Kananga, 150 km northwest of Mubji-Mayi, and announced it would reach Kinshasa by June. 

Haut-Zaire Province: Approximately 91,741 Rwandan refugees are clustered in groups along the 125 km rail line west of the Zaire River, south of Kisangani: 26,916 at km 25, 30,000 at km 31, 32,000 at km 41, 2,500 at km 82, and 325 in Ubundu town. On April 13, USAID's Disaster Assistance Response Team (USAID/DART) field officer flew to Ubundu town and noted about 100 of the 325 refugees are extremely vulnerable. The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) plans to move the refugees by train to km 41 once the weak are stabilized. Humanitarian agencies have set up therapeutic feeding centers, water sources, medical facilities, and services for unaccompanied children at each site. Although 160 cholera cases have been reported at km 25, the cholera is a non-virulent strain and is restricted to km 25. Medecins Sans Frontieres International (MSF/I) is treating refugees in two isolation tents and is confident that it can treat the cholera effectively.

WFP has chartered two barges, each with a capacity of 250 metric tons, to transport food from the municipal airport to the refugees. On the return trip, the barges can be used to transport refugees acrosss the Zaire river. Currently, the Alliance is not allowing use of the international airport because it was mined. UNHCR plans to commence the air repatriation of refugees on April 18, beginning with 80 unaccompanied children who will be flown to Goma and given care prior to repatriation. Approximately 850 internally displaced persons (IDPs) were flown from Kisangani to Goma during last week. On April 14, the Alliance gave permission to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to use Bukavu airport for airlifting IDPs, many of whom originate from Bukavu. The British Overseas Development Agency is establishing an air logistics cell in Goma and a transportation unit in Kisangani, which will control air, road, and river movements for the repatriation.

Kivu Province: Since April 1, UNHCR has repatriated more than 25,000 refugees. Nearly all of the refugees that emerged on March 31 near Karuba, 13 km west of Sake, and Tongo, west of the former camps of Katale and Kahindo, north of Goma, have been repatriated. Less than 1,000 refugees remain in Karuba, however more are arriving daily. MSF/I provides new arrivals with shelter, sanitation facilities, and blended food for children. In Kindu, west of Shabunda, USAID/DART's Goma field officer found very few refugees and 909 IDPs -- 806 living with families and 103 in an old depot in the center of town. The IDPs and locals appeared healthy with adequate water sources and sanitation. The most important needs are medical equipment, medicines, and water treatment chemicals.

Kasai-Oriental Province: At least 30,000 refugees are moving towards Angola. They are believed to be the group who fled the Shabunda area camps in South Kivu.

U.S. Government (USG) Assistance: On March 14, USAID/DART arrived in the region to help advance relief efforts in eastern Zaire. USAID/DART installed an information officer in Nairobi and field officers in Goma and Kisangani. BHR/OFDA has provided grants to ICRC to assist Zairian IDPs and repatriating Rwandan refugees and to Save the Children/UK for vulnerable Rwandan and Zairian unaccompanied children. The State Department's Bureau for Population, Refugees, and Migration has provided funding to ICRC and to UNHCR for IDPs and refugees in eastern Zaire. Between December and February, BHR's Office of Food for Peace provided roughly 2,500 MT of food to eastern Zaire from the Rwanda Regional Program.

Total OFDA Assistance (to date). . . . . . . . . . . . $5,548,118

Other USG Assistance (to date) . . . . . . . . . . . . $7,750,000

TOTAL USG FY 1997 Humanitarian Assistance (to date). .$13,298,118

Africa News


April 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
Alleged Red Terror perpetrators face trial


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Seventy-five people and Captain Mamo Wolde yesterday appeared in court on alleged involvement in perpetrating the Red Terror in Woreda 16 of the capital through the years 1969 to 1971 E.C.

Written charges were distributed to the defendants whose appeal for government-sponsored defence lawyers was referred to the Prison Administration for verification of their financial status.

The defendants who appeared in court are among the 128 people special Prosecutor accused of allegedly taking part in executing the Red Terror in Woreda 16. 

Professor Alemayehu Tefera and married couples are among the accused who appeared yesterday in court.

The court has given the Federal Police Commission arrest warrants to enable it to bring to justice some other people whom the Special Prosecutor accused of similar crimes.

In an effort to halt unarrested alleged criminals from flying abroad, the court said it would order the Immigration and Refugees Affairs not to give visas whenever it is legitimate.

Only nine of the defendants including Professor Alemayehu Teferra said they would legitimate with private defence lawyers.

453 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
Kberi Dehar to host ESDL-ONLF merger conference


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

JIJIGA (ENA) - The Ethiopian Somali Democratic League (ESDL) and the Ogaden national Liberation Front (ONLF) merger conference is to be held in Kebri Dehar in May, according to ESDL chairman.

ESDL Chairman Dr. Abdulmejid Hussies said Sunday that the conference would be attend by elders, farmers and the general public at large. 

He said the joint committee at a meeting it held Saturday chose Kebri Dehar to host the conference.

The two parties announced the planned merger in January this year.

Dr. Abdulmejid, who is also Minister of Transport and Communication, said members of the two parties are explaining the purpose of the merger to the public and thereby witnessing the positive response of the people.

Meanwhile, he noted that as the Federal Government and various organizations are exerting unstilted effort to contain the drought due to rain failure, the shortage of water is being minimized thanks to the down pour now.

However, he said the relief supply should continue for the coming four or five months.

454 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


Rwanda;
Torture Netowrk Protests Two Arrests in Kigali


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Geneva - The International Secretariat of OMCT requests your URGENT intervention in the following situation in Rwanda.

Brief description of the situation : Working Together for Human Rights, a member of the network, has expressed its grave concern over the arrests of Mr. Frangois Ugirashebuja and Mr J.-Dieu Nsanyurwimo.

According to information received, security services allegedly arrested Mr Frangois Ugirashebuja on 7 April 1997 while he was at work at the laboratory of the Bushenge hospital, prefecture of Cyangugu. 

Mr J.-Dieu Nsanzurwino, judge at the Court of first instance of Kigali, nephew of Mr Frangois Ugirashebuja, was reported to have been arrested on 1 April 1997 whilst the court was in session. According to the same information, Mr Nsanzurwino did not leave Rwanda during the period of genocide and was the target of investigation on the part of the security services before his reappointment to his former position.

These arrests, for which the motives are still unclear, are believed to be connected to the death by torture of Mr Sylvestre Gatera (son of Mr Frangois Ugirashebuja) at Cyangugu on 3 September 1995. He was arrested on denunciation and died at the Brigade of Gisama, prefecture of Cyangugu. Dr Rugumba Ernest, a doctor at the hospital in Bushenge, concluded that Mr Gatera Sylvestre's death was caused by torture. The doctor observed several wounds to the head, body and extremities.

The International Secretariat expresses grave concern over these arrests, specifically due to the fact that Mr Frangois Ugirshebuja had allegedly been subjected to pressure by the Commander of the Gendarmerie Brigade of Cyangugu to contradict the medical expert's report. Mr J-Dieu Nsanzurwimo had taken several steps to ensure that those responsible for his cousin's death are held accountable. Due to this, it is feared that the physical and psychological integrity of Mr Frangois Ugirshebuju and Mr J-Dieu Nsanzurwimo are in jeopardy.

Action requested: Please write to the Rwandan authorities urging them to:

i. guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of Mr Frangois Ugirashebuja et Mr J.-Dieu- Nsanzurwimo;

ii. order their immediate release in the absence of valid charges or, if such charges exist, bring them before a competent and impartial civil tribunal and guarantee their procedural rights at all times;

iii. open an impartial and exhaustive investigation into the death of Mr Sylvestre Gatera and the pressure of which Mr Frangois Ugirashebuja was victim, identify those responsible, bring them to trial and apply the penal, civil and/or administrative sanctions provided by law;

iv. ensure in all circumstances the full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms in accordance with national and international standards.

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 17, 1997


Sudan;
Torture Network Alert on Detainees


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Geneva - The International Secretariat of OMCT requests your URGENT intervention in the following situation in Sudan.

Brief description of the situation: The Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, a member of the network, has expressed its grave concern over the health and safety of 13 detainees who were arrested on 27 March, 1997 and who are currently being held incommunicado in Port Sudan. 

According to the information received, 6 of the 13 persons detained are:

1. Gallal Ismail, businessman, age 58

2. Mutasim Siyam, engineer, age 36

3. Abdulla Mousa

4. Adbel Rahman El Amin

5. Badawi Abdulla

6. Gurashi

The report received also alleges that on 9 April 1997, the 13 detainees were transferred to a local transit, otherwise known as a ghost house.

Gallal Ismail and Mutasim Siyam are reported to be diabetics, while Gallal Ismail also suffers from kidney problems.

The International Secretariat is gravely concerned for the physical and psychological integrity of the 13 persons detained. According to the information received, they have all been subjected to ill-treatment.

Action requested : Please contact the Sudanese authorities urging them to:

i. take immediate measures to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of the 13 persons arrested and all other people detained;

ii. immediately release the 13 persons if they are being detained without valid charge or, if such charges exist, bring them before a competent and impartial tribunal and guarantee their procedural rights at all times

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


456 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


South Africa;
Cooperation with Medical and Dental Council


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by TRC Commissioner Dr Wendy Orr, 16 April 1997.

On the first day of a two day meeting, the INMDC (Interim National Medical and Dental Council) agreed to endorse a decision taken by the INMDC Executive, to present a submission at the TRC's Health Sector Hearings in June. The submission will be made on behalf of the previous SA Medical and Dental Council by the present President of the INMDC, Prof S. Kallichurum, past President of the SAMDC, Dr L. Becker and present Registrar of the INMDC (who was also Registrar of the SAMDC), Mr Nico Prinsloo. 

After discussion, the Council decided that the submission should cover "the functioning of the Council in relation to Human Rights", "action taken or the failure to act in specific issues and cases, such as the inequality of facilities available to various sectors of the population", issues which the Council should have raised with, for instance, the then Dept of Health and, most importantly, lessons which can be learned from past mistakes and how they can be prevented in the future.

In addition, the Council discussed the matter of "amnesty" for doctors. Amnesty granted by the TRC does not extend to amnesty from professional discipline in the case of health professionals. This could deter health professionals who have information about, colluded with or participated in human rights abuses from approaching the TRC, as they would still have to face INMDC disciplinary action.

The INMDC reached the conclusion that it is bound by statute to discipline health professionals found guilty of professional misconduct or negligence, but "full and voluntary disclosure" would be taken into account as a strong mitigating factor, as would an appropriate explanation of the context and environment in which the transgression took place.

The INMDC would obviously consider each case on its own merits, but would apply similar principles to those presently outlined in the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act (the so-called "Norgaard Principles"), in deciding on mitigation and sentence. This offer of mitigation would stand as long as the TRC is in existence (i.e. till 14 December 1997).

Mr Nico Prinsloo is co-ordinating the compilation of the submission and the President of the INMDC called on all past and present members of the INMDC and/or SAMDC to assist the Council in drawing up its submission, by communicating to Mr Prinsloo any issues which should be highlighted or examined.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 17, 1997


South Africa;
Taxis: On the right road at last (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cape Town - The vast majority of minibus taxi operators are law-abiding citizens who provide a vital service. A new initiative that has been launched will, hopefully, promote peace and order in the industry

The firm action taken by Peninsula law enforcers against recalcitrant minibus taxi drivers this week will be welcomed by motorists and law-abiding taxi operators alike.

In a six-hour blitz by traffic officers, army and police, 159 fines were issued for various offences, including 43 for unroadworthy vehicles, 40 for drivers not being able to produce licences and 23 for drivers who could not produce public drivers' permits. 

The main thrust of the operation was to ensure that all taxis were displaying their route stickers, a measure designed to eliminate the violence which has plagued the industry since its inception.

Only seven fines were issued for this offence which seems to indicate that taxi operators are co-operating with the authorities in this important programme to end the tragic loss of life in the so-called taxi wars.

A significant by-product of the operation was, however, the number of taxi drivers caught in the net for other offences.

The vast majority of minibus taxi owners and drivers are law-abiding citizens who play a very vital role in transporting hundreds of thousands of people to and from work every day - swiftly and at moderate cost. If the minibus taxis stopped operating, the wheels of commerce and industry in this city could come off.

However, there is a small minority in the taxi industry who do not obey the rules and quite often openly flaunt them.

These are the operators who put vehicles on the highways which are not in roadworthy condition and which are a danger to other road users.

There are unlicensed drivers, too, and those who display arrogance and contempt for the rights of other road users.

This week's campaign and the warning that those who fail to pay fines or appear in court will be arrested is, hopefully, a clear signal to the anarchists that their era is coming to an end.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

458 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


Sports - General;
Madiba magic on line to boost bid for Games


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Cape Town -Madiba magic is being used to bolster Cape Town's bid to host the 2004 Olympic Games.

President Mandela is to make personal telephone calls to members of the International Olympic Committee especially those in Africa to canvass support for the bid.

This key strategy is among those now coming on stream as South Africa intensifies the lobbying of Olympic votes. With less than five months to go before the September 5 vote, deploying "Madiba magic" has become a strategic imperative. 

Mr Mandela and Deputy President Thabo Mbeki are to give up more of their time for personal contacts with IOC visitors, at least 54 of whom must vote for Cape Town if the city is the win the race to host the 2004 Games.

Maintaining and strengthening contact with the African members of the IOC is critical this 20-strong bloc represents nearly half the number of votes the bid needs to win.

The president and deputy president will seek to assure the IOC of the national commitment to tackle crime head-on, to convince them that South Africa's democracy is stable and that the institutional framework of the state will guarantee political and economic stability in a post-Mandela setting. There are 40 confirmed IOC visits lined up, and the bid team is hoping to increase this number.

There have been four visits so far, and the fifth visitor, Louis Guirandou- N'Diaye of the Ivory Coast, arrived last night.

A bigger role for Mr Mandela and Mr Mbeki in the present critical lobbying phase was one of the main items on the agenda at a meeting this week between Mr Mbeki, other senior government officials and the Bid Company.

A month ago, it was felt especially in Europe that South Africa's inclusion in the shortlist was just a "concession" and a reward of sorts for South Africa's "miracle" transition.

This month, though, the influential international sport newsletter Sport Intern reports that observers now place Buenos Aires last in the race. Furthermore, the editor and publisher of Sport Intern, Karl-Heinz Huba, notes: "Here and there, there is alarm that an appearance by Nelson Mandela before the IOC session (in September) could turn all the technical-rational considerations upside down."

Reacting to this, Nocsa treasurer Kurt Hipper told the parliamentary sport portfolio committee yesterday: "This shows how important the Madiba magic is, and we must work on this now."

Bid Company finance director Michael Fuller and other members of the bid team made it clear that while IOC visitors so far had left with very favourable impressions of the city as an Olympic venue and of the technical details of the bid plan, key concerns were crime and future political and economic stability.

Mr Fuller also made it clear that the bid "desperately needs" more money to run an effective, competitive lobbying campaign over the next few months.

The shortage of money had limited the bid's capacity to make the most of the recent athletics event at Green Point stadium and at events during the recent visit of foreign navies to the city.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


459 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Johnny, Robin and David: talented trio in City Ballet debut


BYLINE: Gill Lord, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Cape Town - Three new, top calibre male dancers will perform for the new Cape Town City Ballet when it makes its debut at the Nico tomorrow night.

Formerly Capab Ballet, this will be the Cape Town City Ballet's first season as an independent company, and the appearance on stage of the trio is a further vote of confidence in the new company.

Johnny Bovang, one of the dancers who will appear in The Story of Manon Lescaut, a ballet specially choreographed by Veronica Paeper, was born in Norway and did his early training there before moving to the Royal Ballet School in London. He joined Pact Ballet in 1983 and was promoted to principal dancer in 1992. In 1996, he became senior principal dancer. 

So what brought him to Cape Town?

"Well, I felt it was time for a change," he says. "It all happened very quickly. I took my voluntary retrenchment package, and the next thing I knew I was looking at Table Mountain between rehearsals."

Johnny, a celebrated classical dancer, has a repertoire ranging from the classics to works by Balanchine, Ashton, Nureyev, Hynd, Goh, Cranko and Fokine.

"I felt I was running stale at Pact after 14 years," he explains. "I want to work with other people, experience other teachers. I'm loving it here. It's just too wonderful. I'm inspired, I'm enjoying my dancing, it's a challenge working with the company and I'm actually improving."

Manon is a ballet he has always wanted to do, he says, but the combined experience of a new company, a new city and a new ballet is proving the big thrill.

"It's completely new and creative for me to be in a new company and be doing a new ballet. What more can I ask for? At Pact we always did repertoire ballets from overseas, and it's wonderful to be able to come here and do something that's fashioned on you. And Veronica (Paeper) is wonderful. She's a very easy person to work with."

Johnny is also intrigued by the other original ballets in the Cape Town City Ballet's repertoire. He's looking forward to giving Orpheus a try, for one. Meanwhile, he'll be sharing the lead role in Manon with Johan Jooste and Hisham Omardien. And getting to know Cape Town.

The second member of the distinguished trio, Robin van Wyk, completed his ballet training at the UCT Ballet School and, after a short spell with Napac Dance Company, joined Pact in 1991.

During his six years with Pact he has danced numerous leading roles and his dance experience has included musicals and extravaganzas.

What prompted him to join the Cape Town City Ballet?

"I guess it was the seven year itch. It was time for a change. I was getting stuck in a rut with the same roles and the same characters. I needed a change.

"It's the first time I've worked with a choreographer who's choreographed a ballet on the company. At Pact we usually got a pre-packed deal, a choreologist just came in and taught the ballet.

"I'm enjoying Manon very much. I love watching it grow and change. It's also wonderful to do a new ballet - nobody can really afford new ballets these days. Manon is different, too, it's got a modern feel, it's not purely classical."

His favourite ballets include La Syllphide, Still Life At Penguin Cafe and Romeo and Juliet - he'd love to dance Romeo one day.

Meanwhile, Robin's enjoying being back in Cape Town as a salaried employee rather than a student. While he says it's wonderful to be near the sea, he notices that the cost of living in Cape Town is higher than Johannesburg.

As far as dancing goes, he's happy and inspired "to work with someone who choreographs her own work".

David Krugel, the third member of the talented trio, is a dancer and choreographer who has run his own company and staged his own productions. Formerly the artistic director of the Bop Dance Company, David moved to Cape Town last year, determined to make his way in this city.

He has founded his own company, the Batho Dance company, but is working towards starting a dance centre at his Mowbray premises, allowing for different teachers to give class on a rotational basis.

Currently he is teaching - when he's not rehearsing or performing.

How did he find himself in Manon?

"Veronica sprung it on me one day. It came out of the blue. At first I was blond, because I was going to be Carol Kinsey's partner."

When principal dancer Kinsey was forced to retire due to injury, David went back to being a brunette.

"Life was different as a blond," he notes. "Blonde do have more fun ..."

But he is quick to point out that right now he is having the time of his life.

"I'm having an absolutely great time. Veronica has left the roles quite free for us to interpret and I think mine is the nicest role in the whole ballet."

He's also choreographing a piece for the Cape Town City Ballet's Baxter season in June. And if that's not enough, he's re-staging his piece, Concerto, for the company, choreographing the opera Sacred Bones and doing a piece for the UCT Ballet School - while still finding time to teach at his own studio.

After June, he's hoping for an overseas trip to "recharge my batteries and see what's going on".

Before that, though, he'll go to the Grahamstown Festival with Sacred Bones. He'd love to perform his own work there, but is doubtful.

"It's almost too expensive for the performers to go there now ... It's ridiculous."

And Manon? "It's an enormous task for Veronica. It's a difficult story to portray and it's up to the company to put that story over to the audience. It's good for the company to portray personalities on stage."

Africa News


April 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
SA labour conciliation commission swamped


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town -The Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration (CCMA) is to increase its number of staff so it can deal with the flood of cases that have come its way since it was launched last year to resolve labour disputes.

The Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) has complained that the CCMA "is drowning in a sea" of cases.

Cosatu spokeswoman Nowethu Mpati said the CCMA was receiving close to 500 complaints a day. Most of them could have been resolved by employers and employees themselves, she added. 

"The situation is so serious that the CCMA employees are apparently going to propose amendments to the Labour Relations Act and ask for the three-month time-frame within which to deal with each case to be extended to six months," Ms Mpati said.

CCMA director Charles Nupen denied this.

Ms Mpati said workers, especially those who were not unionised, "run to the CCMA every time there is a problem at their workplace".

"As Cosatu we want to encourage workers not to take each and every case they have to the CCMA. They must use bargaining forums at their workplaces to resolve such problems," she said.

The CCMA was established under the Labour Relations Act and is charged with conciliating, mediating and, in some cases, arbitrating in labour disputes in the quickest possible time.

Mr Nupen acknowledged that the commission had problems with the size of its caseload.

"We obviously are experiencing difficulty dealing with the volume of cases coming to us.

"But the governing body has approved a budget of R120 million for the 1997/1998 financial year and this will enable us to employ another 40 commissioners."

The CCMA has 80 full-time and 200 part-time commissioners on its staff.

"We are trying our best to deal with the workload and the 40 additional commissioners will be of some assistance in dealing with the volumes coming to us."

Mr Nupen said that in March the commission had received about 224 genuine complaints a day.

During November it received 834 cases and for the whole of March the number had more than tripled to 4 038 cases.

Between November, when the CCMA was established, and March, the commission had received 14 000 complaints.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


461 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


South Africa;
Are we playing games with matric?


BYLINE: Nan Yeld and Leonie van Bommel, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1800 words


 

Cape Town - In 1996, the first provincially set school-leaving examinations were written.

This meant that, for the first time, all the matric students from all the historically segregated education departments wrote the same exams, separated only on a provincial basis.

In other words, for the first time the vast differences in educational provision became visible, and the reality of the effect of decades of educational oppression became clear to all.

>From October 1996 onwards, however, press releases on leak scandals took over from any kind of serious reporting on the examinations.

Articles in the press with headings like "exam paper syndicate" were characterised by outrage and sensation, not by what the public has a right to expect - serious and constructive analysis. 

This is not to point a finger only at the media, though - they report on what their public wants and there is certainly no tradition in South Africa of high quality feedback on public examinations, and thus no expectation of such.

Indeed, questions could legitimately be asked of educationists about their silence on these matters.

A recent nationally based press clippings survey conducted by the authors revealed, however, that press coverage of the school-leaving examinations left much to be desired.

Of the 96 articles surveyed in the period December 1995 to January 1997, only two were based on the views of an official examiner.

Teachers' views featured in only 23 percent of the articles, whereas 48 percent drew on information provided by spokesmen for the Department of Education.

Forty-five percent were classified by the researchers as "sensation" (exam leaks, evidence of cheating, marker strikes and so forth), while only 21 percent could be classified as "stimulating debate", in other words, as containing more than one point of view, or presenting different arguments or theories.

Similarly, only 23 percent of the articles were classified as having a serious level of analysis, with 27 percent being extremely superficial.

Inevitably, this kind of coverage ignored the content-related issues of the examination system in favour of more saleable scandals.

This is not to say that appearance of the exam papers on the market, and related instances of corruption or incompetence, should not be of public concern, and roundly condemned - of course they should.

But such outrageous incidents could be used constructively if efforts were made to determine what exactly went wrong so that the mistakes were not repeated.

In fact, it is now generally accepted that exam leaks have always taken place, particularly in the old Department of Education and Training system, and that at least this time corrective action is being taken publicly.

The problem is that sensationalising problems with the exam only adds to the general confusion accompanying the transformation of the educational system and feeds the distrust surrounding the integrity of the results.

Now that the transformation of the racially based departments into nine integrated provincial departments has taken place, and all matriculants have written the same exam in each province, we need to look at what the school- leaving examination really entails.

Recent announcements on the introduction of "Curriculum 2005" highlight the need to develop ways of raising public awareness and improving debate about school-based issues as these are reflected in the examination system.

What more do we know and understand of the school-leaving exam beside the facts that there were (yet again) leaks, and that the pass rate for the school-leaving certificate was about 52 percent?

Do we know what skills were tested in the exam papers or how the exam papers were set?

Do we know whether candidates are becoming stronger or weaker in these skills - are there trends about which the public should know?

What do examiners have to say about the matriculation exams?

And what did teachers expect from Matric '96?

Are the exams simply a giant lottery, as DET students (and teachers) have long suspected, or is it possible to build public confidence through a careful campaign of public education - starting with the press?

There are a number of compelling reasons for strengthening the school- leaving examination and restoring (or establishing) public confidence in it.

The school-leaving examination is a high stakes examination - by and large, it is what motivates pupils and parents to continue studying against sometimes great odds.

Although not always a reliable indicator of future educational success, at present the senior certificate is still the only realistic gateway to post- secondary education.

It is also still a valued marker of achievement for employment.

The more the value of the certificate is devalued, however, the more likely it is that universities and technikons will begin to develop their own entrance testing schemes and that employers will lose confidence in the certificate.

Removing the "punch" from the end-point of schooling through devaluing the examination would weaken its potential to improve the quality of education.

If serious and skilled effort is put into it, the examination can be used very effectively to support and drive changes in the curriculum.

While perhaps unpalatable, it is a truth nonetheless, that whatever the intrinsic worth of various curricular reforms, and however necessary these are, what the pupils' and the parents' gaze is on, is the examination occurring at the end of the curriculum, and not primarily the curriculum.

Of course, effort should be made to change this - in the meantime, however, it seems foolish in the extreme not to capitalise on this strength of examinations.

In addition, allowing the mass system of education to deliver less information than it could in terms of information about the skills and so forth of its learners, is to waste the taxpayers' money in a most profligate fashion.

The development of expensive alternatives by universities and industry could be avoided to a large extent if the school-leaving examination itself regained credibility. And for a poor country like South Africa, every rand spent on education needs to be carefully justified.

For a better public understanding of the school-leaving examination, the public has to look to the press to provide a lead.

Reports should be written (or commissioned) from a more expert perspective.

Input from official examiners could form a crucial ingredient of a press release on examinations.

Furthermore, teachers' and students' views should be more prominently used in any kind of feedback on the school-leaving examination.

Teachers, particularly, have to be taken seriously as they are directly involved in classroom practice.

After all, it is teachers who form the direct link with matriculants in preparing them for the exams.

Ideally, good feedback on the management, content and significance of the matric exams would come from the new provincial examination panels.

An example of a highly organised feedback mechanism on examinations comes from the Netherlands, where the department of education routinely produces documents in order to keep both the general public and the professional field informed.

Such information (coming from the department that handles the examinations in all its aspects) allows for a high level of analysis in the Dutch press.

As a result of this, the annual school-leaving exams are much more prominent and are followed by the general public.

In South Africa, the new provincial examination panels are accountable to civil society.

These panels should contribute to a better understanding of the school- leaving examinations, by making information around the setting of the examinations, for instance, available to the press and public.

This kind of accountability has not been a feature of the examination system in South Africa and the press could play a valuable role in promoting its development.

However, developing a proper feedback mechanism is just one of the many tasks facing the Ministry of Education.

The problems in education are many and the road ahead will not be an easy one. But in the meantime, non-governmental structures of society - in which the press is a major player - can monitor the ministry's moves and report back to society in a constructive way.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


462 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


South Africa;
New curriculum fiasco feared


BYLINE: Sabatna Ngcai, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Cape Town - Plans to revolutionise teaching will flop unless the Government solves many underlying problems, including big classes and high stress levels among teachers, Western Cape teachers and principals have warned.

They were voicing growing concerns that Curriculum 2005, to be introduced in all South African schools, could be unworkable.

The new education system being phased in from next year is designed to abolish rote learning and encourage pupils to think for themselves.

It will begin in Grade 1 (formerly Sub A) and Grade 7 (formerly Standard 5) next year, be extended to all levels by 2003 and fine-tuned by 2005. Western Cape teachers had their first briefings this week. 

But senior educationists say Curriculum 2005 is bound to fail unless the Government deals with problems caused by rationalisation and redresses imbalances.

They say mounting frustration, big classes, high stress, over-hasty implementation of the system and lack of adequate information could undermine the process.

Lincoln Mali, spokesman for the Education Ministry, said these concerns had been raised previously, but the department could not wait to resolve them before implementing the system, which was aimed at developing education.

"We are working on the problems and we hope to find solutions," Mr Mali said. He denied the department was rushing the process. He said it was treating it "cautiously and with the urgency it deserves".

But teachers are questioning whether the "outcomes-based" curriculum will work in South Africa, where circumstances differ from those in countries from which it has been copied.

Sea Point Primary School principal Philip Gurney, who visited New Zealand, where the system is used, cautioned that it should be handled with great care.

"New Zealand has a population of

3,5 million, a pupil-teacher ratio of one to 20, and highly qualified teachers," he said. South Africa had a much bigger population, language problems, limited resources, underqualified teachers and big classes.

"How are we going to cope if we rush? There are still underlying problems of over-stressed teachers who have to cope with increasing workloads as a result of the teacher rationalisation process.

"We and other schools expect to lose more teachers when phase two of the rationalisation process is implemented. I'm not sure if the curriculum could be implemented next year under those circumstances.

"We like its superb ideals for the country, but the process needs to be slowed down. At least the Government needs to initiate pilot projects in all nine provinces and in different types of schools - rural, upmarket, and so on - to see how it will work," he said.

His view was echoed by the acting principal of Maitland Secondary School, William Jantjies, who said the changes were being rushed and were "bound to fail as long as the imbalances of the past are not redressed".

"The Government should make money available to bring the historically disadvantaged schools and historically advantaged schools to the same level," said Mr Jantjies. "Until the Government addresses those imbalances it will never move forward. A new class struggle will emerge and could plunge the country into revolution".

Many schools had to cope with gangsterism, big classes and few teachers, " then on top of that burden is the new schools curriculum. Teachers are flocking to doctors' surgeries because of high stress levels. How do we implement the new curriculum when we have such problems?"

Mr Jantjies said he was behind the Government's plan to restructure education, but felt it should take more time.

He also complained about lack of information on the eight learning areas, which are to replace existing subjects. "You don't know whether you'll have enough teachers to handle the eight learning areas," he said.

Michele Botha, acting principal of Ellerton Primary School in Sea Point, said the curriculum was balanced, but teachers did not have enough information.

Although most of the principals in black township schools were impressed with the curriculum, some said they did not have any information about it.

Mongezi Memani of I D Mkize Secondary School in Guguletu said he would get clarity only when he attended one of the teacher information sessions being run by the Western Cape Education Department.

The Pan Africanist Student Organisation hit at the Government for trying to enforce the new curriculum while black schools were facing a crisis.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


463 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 17, 1997


Namibia;
Namibia finally acts on killer cattle disease


BYLINE: Christof Maletsky, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Windhoek - The Government of Namibia has at last bowed to mounting pressure to use the T1-44 vaccine to combat the deadly cattle lung sickness prevalent in Namibia's northern areas.

Cabinet this week approved a recommendation by the Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Rural Development that "a small number of cattle" from the Northern Communal Areas affected by the deadly Contagious Bovine Pleuropneumonia (CBPP) be experimentally vaccinated with strain T1-44 vaccine.

The decision was immediately hailed by farmers and veterinarians alike as the first step towards the total eradication of the deadly disease.

Elaborating on its decision, Cabinet said: "This will be done for the purpose of observing any possible adverse effects of the vaccine on the cattle. 

If the vaccine is found to be safe, such treatment would be extended to all affected cattle in the Northern Communal Areas." Those approached for comment by The Namibian yesterday said the decision was long awaited and could only be to the benefit of the country.

They noted that the vaccine had proved to be effective in many other African countries.

It is produced by Onderstepoort Biological Products in South Africa and also at the Botswana Vaccine Institute (Rhone Poulenc) and has proved successful in countries like Kenya, Zambia, Tanzania and Uganda.

Cabinet confirmed that T1-44 had been recommended by the United Nations' Food and Agricultural Organisation (FAO) and approved by the Pan-African Veterinary Vaccine Centre.

The FAO recommendation was actually made as long ago as November 1995, but the Namibian Government ignored an offer made twice by the European Union to pay South Africa N$270 000 for the T1-44 vaccine and donate it to Namibia.

Ministerial sources put the failure to obtain the vaccine down to a combination of "bureaucratic delays and politics".

The vaccine used previously in Namibia had no positive impact and panic set in among farmers, especially in the North, because of the non-availability of an effective vaccine.

Cattle farmers north of the Veterinary Cordon Fence were gripped by fear as they were estimated to be losing more than N$14 million a year through cattle contracting the deadly disease.

At the time they were pinning their hopes on the EU underwriting the purchase of the vaccine from South Africa for use in Namibia.

Last year a 22,6 per cent prevalence of CBPP was detected in more than 27 000 cattle slaughtered at the Oshakati abattoir alone.

Statistics graphically proved that the figure has risen sharply over the last few years.

When the disease first started making itself felt in the country in 1991, only six clinical cases and eight deaths were confirmed, according to the 1991 Annual Namibia Stocks Census report.

In the same year, the number of localities where the disease was reported (FOCI) was five with a percentage of 3,4 in every 100 000 cattle.

In stark contrast, in 1995 the disease had not only spread to 64 localities, but a higher percentage of 20,2 in every 100 000 cattle, was reported.

The 1995 report said the "disease has been spreading alarmingly in the northern regions of the country".

"To add to the problems, it has been discovered that the Mycoplasma strain being used in most African vaccines - including the Namibian vaccine - is not suitable for vaccine purposes," the report said.

Accordingly, the Directorate of Veterinary Services suspended annual CBPP vaccination campaigns in the North until a suitable replacement vaccine could be found, the report said.

A bleaker picture emerged in December 1996.

The Namibia Stocks Census statistics pointed to 98 775 afflicted cattle in Okavango, 154 926 in Kaokoland, 2 500 in Sesfontein and 476 658 in the former Owambo area.

Therefore, the total number of cattle in the affected areas amounts to 732 859 and with a 22,6 per cent prevalence of the disease points to 165 626 infected cattle.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


464 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


Guinea-Bissau;
Guinea-Bissau Joins CFA Franc Monetary Zone


BYLINE: Ali Idrissou Toure, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

COTONOU, Benin (PANA) - Guinea-Bissau was officially admitted as a member of the CFA Franc Zone at a two-day meeting of the Council of Ministers of Finance of France and French-speaking African countries which ended on Thursday in Cotonou, Benin.

The French Minister of Finance, Jean Arthuis, and the Guinea-Bissau delegation signed the additional clause to the existing agreement enabling France to extend its monetary co-operation with the West African Economic and Monetary Union to Bissau.

As from May 2, the CFA Franc is expected to replace the Peso as the official currency of Guinea-Bissau, according to a statement issued at the end of the meeting. 

The Governor of the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO), Charles Konan Banny, said Guinea-Bissau's transition to the CFA Franc zone involved " a heavy financial transaction" necessitating the injection of some 6 billion CFA Francs (about 12 million U.S. dollars into the country's economy.

Guinea-Bissau has therefore become the 15th member of the Franc Zone which already comprises Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal and Togo.

In a related development, the statement said "the replacement of the French franc by the Euro (the European single currency) in 1999 will not affect the exchange rate of the CFA franc and the existing monetary co-operation between France and the African member countries of the Franc Zone".

The French franc has been linked to the CFA (African Finance Community) used by the African countries at a fixed exchange rate which now stands at 100 CFA for one French franc after the devaluation of the CFA franc by 50 percent at a high-level meeting held in Dakar (Senegal) in January 1994.

Previously the exchange rate was 50 CFA = 1FF.

The French Minister told reporters in Cotonou that "the Euro will be a world-wide reserve currency against which the value of the CFA Franc will be determined".

According to the statement, the ministers of finance of the Franc Zone expressed satisfaction at the progressive economic growth rate recorded in the UEMOA countries (around 5 percent) and at similar developments in the member States of the Central African Economic and Monetary Community (CEMAC).

In a Declaration adopted at the end of their meeting, the ministers called for increased private investment in the countries of the Franc Zone in order to maintain high growth on a long-term basis.

According to the Declaration, the commitments made by the Governments, particularly in their structural adjustment programmes, are aimed at " fostering a more stable macro-economic environment".

Among other things, the ministers recommended the harmonization of budgetary and monetary policies, taxation and customs services in a regional framework as well as increased consultation with the private sector on matters concerning the formulation of economic policies".

The Declaration further stressed the need for security of investment, improved infrastructures and state disengagement from productive sectors.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


465 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zaire War Boosts Ugandan Gold Exports


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda has earned a record of 60.32 million U.S dollars from gold exports between the second half of 1996 to date, according to the Bank of Uganda.

It said the earnings from gold exports began rising in the 1994/95 financial year during which gold worth 12.44 million dollars was exported, a substantial increase from less than one million dollars in the 1993/94 financial year.

The exports then tripled to 35.15 million dollars in the 1995/96 after which they hit a record of 60.32 million dollars. 

The 72-percent increase in gold earnings only compares with a slightly higher increase of proceeds from cotton, which brought in 23.8 million dollars, 80 percent higher than the 13.26 million dollars realized in the 1995/96 financial year.

A banker who monitors commodities at the Central Bank said some of the gold could be "leakages" into Uganda from neighbouring Zaire, where normal trading in minerals has been disrupted by civil war.

The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that the rise in cotton exports could also be explained by the fact that the Ugandan cotton which used to be smuggled to Sudan and Zaire was now being sold in the home market.

The rise in gold exports contrasts sharply with export earnings of Uganda's foremost foreign exchange earner -- coffee, which continues to nose dive.

While coffee fetched 456.6 million dollars in the 1994/95 financial year, 404.3 million dollars was earned in 1995/96.

A further slump this year is expected with a projected income from the commodity being at a low of 331.07 million dollars.

Cereals, whose biggest volume exported was maize, accounts for 75 percent increase this financial year and is expected to fetch 12.59 million dollars, up from 9.43 million dollars 1995/96 financial year.

However, a sharp decline in cereal exports was observed, from 109.5 million tons in the 1994/95 to 59.06 million tons in the last financial year.

This year a total 67.08 million tons has been sold, a result likely to reflect the effect of the 1996 famine in many parts of the country.

According to the Bank, over all merchandise exports have increased effective from the 1994/95 financial year but have since stabilized.

Uganda exported merchandise worth 595.26 million US dollars two years ago and 590.53 million US dollars last year. The projection for his year is 588. 38 by the end of June.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
