Africa News


April 18, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Banana Absent At Zimbabwe's Independence Celebration


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's former President, Canaan Banana, was the notable absentee from Friday's celebrations marking the country's 17th independence celebrations in Harare, the capital.

A senior government official told the national news agency, Ziana, that Banana, currently under investigation by police for homosexual rape of his ex- aide-de camp, was not invited to the event at Harare's national sports stadium. The official declined to give reasons.

Banana, as the country's first post-independence president, was conspicuous by his absence from such a high profile state occasion, and if invited, he could have been accorded VIP status.

The former president's alleged homosexual rape of Jefta Dube was revealed in the High Court last February when the former ADC was convicted of the murder of a former police constable.

Dube's defence was that he was not responsible for his actions because of the trauma arising from repeated sexual abuse by the former president at State House in Harare between 1983 and 1986.

He argued that he shot the fellow policeman at a musical concert at Gwanzura stadium in Harare after he had insulted him by calling him Banana's wife.

The alleged sodomy by the international statesman who became Zimbabwe's first black president at independence in 1980 attracted increased attention to this conservative Southern African nation, whose President, Robert Mugabe has verbally attacked homosexuality.

Banana, married with four children is a theology professor at the University of Zimbabwe.

He retired in 1987 to make way for Mugabe following the introduction of the executive presidency.

Mugabe who is unpopular among the homosexual community for his scathing attacks on the practice is being watched at home and abroad if he will live up to this word that Zimbabwe would not tolerate any homosexuality.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 18, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Mugabe Says Zimbabwe On Road To Prosperity


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe, in celebrating the country's 17th independence anniversary, painted a picture of significant economic growth and increased employment, factors he attributed to two consecutive good rain seasons and some sound government measures.

Mugabe, in a speech he read at the National Sports Stadium in Harare and also read on his behalf in the country's provincial gatherings, said Zimbabwe's economy was expected to grow by at least 5 percent, lower than last year's 8 percent.

Zimbabwe, with a population of 11.5 million, has a 45 percent unemployment rate. So, the bulk of the populace is struggling to meet basic needs after suffering negative effects of western-backed economic reforms. 

Mugabe said a policy to cushion the nation against the effects of drought was being developed.

Performance of the agricultural sector, he said, would be stimulated as a 25 year policy framework was now in place to chart the growth, taking into account the country's population growth rate.

"This (agricultural policy) will also benefit from the development of a policy on drought management that treats drought not as an exogenous shock, but as a predictable phenomenon that must feature permanently in policy making and the resource allocation process," he said.

During the country's worst consecutive droughts of the early 1990s, several social and economic development projects, such as economic reforms, were derailed as the government was caught unprepared with no contingency measure to mitigate the effects.

Mugabe said in 1996 the manufacturing sector had grown by about 3.5 percent while the mining sector was negatively affected by low international prices for major minerals.

However, he said gold production for 1996 was marginally higher at 24.72 tons compared to 24.24 tons recorded in 1995. The country had earned 6.1 billion zimdollars (0.55 billion U.S. dollars) from mineral production. This was largely due to the depreciation of the Zimbabwean dollar against the basket of major currencies.

Prospects in this sector were bright, he said, as there were 235 current Exclusive Prospecting Orders and some 215 applications which had been processed by the end of 1996.

"New gold deposits have been found in the Kwekwe area, while new platinum deposits were also found at Unki and Ngezi," said Mugabe.

The mining sector also accounted for 34.4 percent of the 10.2 billion zimdollar (0.92 billion U.S. dollar) worth of 415 projects approved by the Zimbabwe Investment Center, in 1996.

It is expected, he added, that these projects would generate 12,147 jobs annually for five years, and export earnings of some 2.264 billion zimdollars (0.205 billion U.S. dollars).

The Export processing Zone scheme attracted 26 projects valued at 2.5 billion zimdollars (0.22 billion U.S. dollars)and some 2,684 jobs were expected to be created.

An additional 2,208 jobs had been created from the 652 projects approved by the Small Enterprises Development Corporation, or Sedco, which was recapitalized in 1996.

"The pilot micro-finance scheme benefited five hundred groups in the informal sector," he said. This included 1,305 women and created 3,586 jobs.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 18, 1997


Tanzania;
Nyerere, Karume Portraits To Adorn Banknotes


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

DODOMA, Tanzania, (PANA) - Photos of founder presidents of the United Republic of Tanzania, Julius Kambarage Nyerere and Sheikh Abeid Amani Karume, will from now adorn the country's banknotes.

Reporting this Friday, the Tanzanian news agency, Shihata, said the decision was contained in a resolution adopted by the National Assembly in a debate to change the current depiction of a giraffe on the notes. 

Nyerere was founder president of Tanganyika and then of the United Republic. Karume, who was assassinated in 1972, was founder of the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar, following the January 12, 1964 revolution which toppled the Sultanate in the Indian Ocean islands of Zanzibar and Pemba.

The resolution, presented by the opposition National Convention for Constitutional Reform member of parliament, Paul Ndobho, was unanimously passed Thursday by parliamentarians.

They praised the decision by President Benjamin Mkapa to keep his portrait out of the banknotes. This resulted in the motion to have the portraits of the country's founding leaders.

Tanganyika and Zanzibar merged in April 26, 1964 forming the United Republic of Tanzania led by Nyerere. He was succeeded by Ali Hassan Mwinyi in October, 1985.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April 18, 1997


Uganda;
Ugandan Army Says It Killed 60 Sudanese Soldiers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Uganda People's Defence Force says it has killed 60 Sudanese soldiers and captured 114 in a pre-emptive strike in which several rebels were also killed at Lelabur, just inside Uganda's border with Sudan. "The captives are in custody of the Fourth Division in northern Uganda, " said Amama Mbabazi, the Ugandan state minister for defence.

Citing him Thursday, the government-owned newspaper, New Vision, reported Friday that 68 members of the Lords Resistance Army, an anti-government religious outfit headed by Joseph Kony, were killed and 50 others either captured or surrendered. 

Mbabazi refuted claims by Sudan on Thursday that 306 Ugandan troops, including the second in command of the army's Fourth Division, Lt. Col. Nakibus Lakara, had been killed Tuesday in a battle 44 miles south of Juba. Mbabazi said Lakara was alive and still in northern Uganda.

However, he said that two Ugandan soldiers of junior rank, attached to a small special operations unit which has been gathering intelligence information about Kony rebels, had gone missing in action in Sudan.

Mbabazi said that on Monday the Ugandan army attacked a combined force of about two companies of Sudanese forces and two companies of Kony rebels near Lelabur.

"The UPDF also captured an assortment of weapons. This combined force had intention of establishing a base in Gulu or Kitgum for purpose of carrying out intelligence work in preparation for an offensive by the Sudanese Armed Forces and the Kony bandits in northern Uganda," Mbabazi said.

These two towns are inside Uganda.

He said the full names and particulars of the Sudanese captives will be made public "in due course."

Mbabazi, talking to the newspaper later, said Uganda's interest in Sudan was only in intelligence gathering. He declined to give particulars of the two Ugandan soldiers reported missing in action.

Sudan's Radio Omdurman, quoting a military communique, reported Thursday that the Ugandan attack was an attempt to reach Juba, from the eastern side of the Nile after failing to attack the town from the west. When Sudan reported that the second in command in of Uganda's Fourth Infantry Division had died, it failed to give his name and rank.

However, the Sudanese Army General Command said it would display its evidence to the public at the earliest possible time to prove that the " attacking troops were Ugandan and that they came from Gulu."

Sudan claimed that the anti-Khartoum government guerrillas, the Sudan People's Liberation Army, was not involved in the fighting.

But Uganda's Senior Presidential Advisor on Media and Public Relations, John Nagenda, dismissed the Sudanese claims. He said that the Sudanese should show the press the bodies of the Ugandan soldiers allegedly killed.

Commander Pierre of the SPLA, talking to The New Vision from Nairobi, Kenya, said the claims by the Khartoum regime were false.

The SPLA has scored a string of military successes over the last three to four weeks. They are fighting for autonomy and against attempts by the central government to Arabize and Islamize the Christian southerners.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


470 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


Business and Finance;
Branded clothing a hit for LA Retail


BYLINE: Business Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Cape Town - Funky Cape-based clothing retailer LA Retail Stores sees big growth in branded clothing products.

"We have seen a huge surge in demand for branded products," LA Retail chairman AK Peer said at the release of the company's interim results for the six months to February.

"Branded products will dominate the future of apparel in the South African retail industry, and we are poised to harness this growth." 

LA Retail's commitment to the branded apparel market was crystallised in its R115-million purchase of Skye Products last month.

Skye Products is the country's largest marketer and distributor of national branded apparel and footwear.

Mr Peer said he believed the acquisition would significantly enhance the group's growth.

"We are confident that Skye's proven management and branded products will support our growth strategy," Mr Peer said.

LA Retail has already successfully placed its own "LA" brand on the map among the fashion conscious teen and young adult market, and is now reviving the Samson brand of workwear which was previously owned by Ensign Clothing.

Mr Peer said the group was also investigating a new retail concept which he believed would capture a growing market in South Africa.

He was unwilling to expand on what this "new concept" would be, but said it would be as significant as the acquisition of Skye Products.

This is sure to capture the approval of shareholders of LA Retail who have just seen their company notch up half-year net profits of R2,3 million, putting the company firmly on track to beat its forecast

R4,1 million for the full year.

Mr Peer said that the group expected a higher turnover and operating profit during the next six months.

This was due to the higher price and margins on winter wear.

"During the winter period our higher value items, such as jeans and footwear, do particularly well."

Mr Peer also said the group's listing on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange last year had put its expansion programme on track.

Four of the six proposed new stores were already operating successfully.

"Our flagship store opened in Pretoria late last year and has met with overwhelming support from local shoppers," Mr Peer said.

"All four of the new stores have exceeded their profit targets and we are confident that our new and existing stores will help the group to comfortably reach its forecast earnings for the year."

He said the group would be opening its first store in KwaZulu/Natal next month, to be followed soon after that by another store in the Western Cape.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


471 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


South Africa;
Time to stop the money musical chairs


BYLINE: William-Mervin Gumede, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1880 words


 

Cape Town - The battle rages on over the R247-million deficit provincial budget tabled by finance MEC Kobus Meiring, with the Democratic Party and the African National Congress digging in their heels in a tense standoff with the ruling National Party.

The provincial DP joined the ANC in vowing to vote against the deficit budget when it came up for adoption in the provincial legislature.

DP provincial leader Hennie Bester said his party would oppose the adoption of the budget as Mr Meiring could not give any explanations as to how he would cover the R247-million shortfall.

The provincial ANC has declared it will vote against the R247-million deficit. The provincial budget is being debated in the legislature. 

Mr Bester blamed both the NP and the central government for the crisis.

"The answer to cuts in national funds cannot be to cut services, but to find new ways of doing things," Mr Bester said.

Tasneem Essop, the ANC's shadow finance MEC, said that, at the least, the party wanted the budget vote to be postponed to rework the budget to the deficit and change priorities away from administration and salaries to social services.

Mr Meiring's budget slashed education, health, social services and housing.

The largest amount of the R9,5-billion provincial expenses in his budget - 73 percent - went to personnel and administration, which included salaries, costing more than R6-billion.

Mr Meiring said he was banking on central government to bail out the province. Did not central government come to the rescue of the Western Cape in the previous two budgets?.

But Finance Minister Trevor Manuel has told him that this time, with the central government's new commitment to fiscal discipline, there is no way in which it will come to the rescue of the province.

The only route now for Premier Hernus Kriel and the NP is to railroad the budget through the provincial legislature, crushing objections from the DP and ANC in the process.

The provincial budget was bound to say as much about the politics in the province as about its fiscus.

Mr Meiring took the rare step of budgeting for a deficit, in a blunt signal that the NP-ruled provincial government felt it had been punished by the central government.

Whatever the arguments, there is little doubt that the ordinary person in the Western Cape will be hit by the budget. There will be fewer hospital beds for the sick, less equipment for schoolchildren, who will have to be in bigger classes, and even an end to the transport subsidy to bring rural pupils from outlying areas to schools.

Tony Twine, a senior economist at Econometrix, laconically remarked that, given the consummate ease with which Mr Meiring had "balanced" his 1997/98 budget, no politician ever again had to wrestle over niceties such as whether budgeted expenses was covered by budgeted income.

The solution according to Mr Meiring and company, said Mr Twine, was so simple that it was a wonder that budgetary deficits had been such a problem between the United States Republicans and Democrats for all these years.

The problem is thus, argued Mr Twine: South Africa has one central government with nine second-tier provincial governments.

Seven of the nine have ANC majorities in their legislatures - the Western Cape has a National Party majority while Inkatha rules KwaZulu Natal.

Together with Gauteng, the industrial hub of the nation, the two account for more than two thirds of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

The Western Cape contributed about 16,7 percent of GDP and Gauteng 49,3 percent. The two provinces' share of the national budget amounted to only 5,6 percent and 8,3 percent, respectively.

The way the central government allocates its block payments to each of the provinces is by the financial and fiscal commission. The commission is an independent body which checks funds are distributed equally among provinces, taking into account population and historical imbalances among other criteria.

The commission's ultimate aim, in six years' time, is to spread the budget equally among the different provinces.

Each province presents its spending requirements to the commission, and these are panelbeaten into shares of the total available from the national budget.

The provinces then have to rework their spending priorities in the light of having less income than they might have initially budgeted for. That is exactly what happened to the provinces for the 1997/ '98 fiscal year.

Using the FFC formula, the Western Cape share of the national budget increased in nominal terms from roughly R8,37-billion in 1996/'97 to R8,75- billion in the 1997/'98 budget. Measured in terms of allocation per person, the Western Cape received the second-largest share of the national budget, at R2 197 a person, even higher than Gauteng.

The Western Cape average was only exceeded by the Northern Cape. The average allocation a person for all the provinces was R1 755.

When Mr Meiring worked out his provincial budget, he found out the Western Cape had about R780-million less income than it had originally planned for.

Mr Meiring then went back to the drawing board - 10 times - and reworked the budget.

He cut down more on his expenses - and came up with a budget that squeezed out savings of about R620-million, or a net R540-million after the adjustment for pensions.

He calculated that provincial income of R502-million would be boosted by the R90-million charge to other provinces for cross-border services and the 10 percent increase in motor vehicle licences from June 1, which would generate R217,4-million.

An additional R86-milion would come from hospital fees, R26-million from horse racing and R19-million from last year's surplus. Savings of R620- million would come from cutting the education budget by R347-million, health by R255-million, agriculture R23-million, and housing, local government and planning by R9,6-million.

Assistance to local authorities was cut by R40-million.

The savings was offset by the net R80-million increase in the social services budget to give net savings of R540-million. Still, it was about R240- million off the mark.

The problem, said Mr Twine, was that second-tier provincial governments, as well as third-tier local governments, were not supposed to run budgetary deficits on current expenditure.

The provincial Borrowing Act restricts the financing of capital projects under the stern proviso that the means of repayment must be clearly spelled out when any borrowing is undertaken.

Mr Meiring has complained, justly so, that the national government has made no provision for the provinces to boost their own income by raising taxes paid to them.

Such measures should have been implemented already, according to the interim constitution, but will not nowcome into effect before January 1 1998.

Finance Minister Trevor Manuel can help a lot by ensuring that plans for provincial revenue generation are speeded up.

At the moment, provinces are highly restricted in terms of raising their own domestic revenue.

Motor vehicle licence fees, hospital fees, entertainment and gambling taxes, as well as cross-border charges rendered to provinces, make up a rather scanty list of potential sources of income apart from central government funding.

In the case of the Western Cape, 91 percent of the 1997/'98 revenue will come from the central government.

The ANC said the provincial belt could be tightened further than Mr Meiring's efforts so far to produce savings.

For example, there were funds for 2 901 public service posts which had not been filled. Why, asked Ms Essop, should Premier Kriel have to increase his office budget by R13-million, as the office of the premier was a non-delivery department.

Mr Meiring said in a budget speech the money would be used to help Mr Kriel get closer to his electorate.

Ms Essop suggested R12-milion be skimmed off the R16-million increase in the budget of the province's environmental and cultural affairs department.

The ANC said this department should look at rearranging its priorities in line with delivery needs, especially those of disadvantaged communities.

It proposed the Provincial Public Service Commission's budget of R6-million be reduced by R2-million, as the commission was to be phased out at the end of this year and did not need a big budget.

Ms Essop revealed the provincial government had spent close to R3-million on an investigation into provincial budget cuts in the 1996/'97 budget and beyond. This probe, called the Special Investigation Cabinet Assignment, was a waste of money, she said.

The DP's Richard van der Ross summed up the crisis over the provincial budget: "They (NP) are playing a power game to show their supporters how smart they are in shooting down the other side, so that people will vote for them next time around."


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


472 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


South Africa;
The taxi test: how do passengers fare?


BYLINE: Chene Blignaut, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Cape Town - How do foreign visitors rate Cape Town's rag-tag fleet of sedan taxis, their drivers and the fares they charge?

Not very highly, according to a survey of 60 tourists from overseas, half of whom said they had had problems ranging from overcharging to simply not being able to find taxis when they needed them.

In an attempt to find out what sort of service taxi companies and drivers offer visitors, I armed myself with a rucksack and a phoney German accent and took to the tourist routes.

One of the first things I discovered was that taxi drivers seem easily duped. As many as five fell for the accent which I believed would not fool anyone. Not even my obvious questions and feverish note-taking alerted them to the fact that they might not be dealing with a well-heeled German tourist. 

My first stop was the Plein Street taxi rank next to the Grand Parade where I timidly approached a Magicab Radio Taxi driver and asked to be taken to "ze" Bay Hotel in Camps Bay.

I was told it would cost me "thirty-something"rands but that the price would be determined by the meter. The car was neat, but very old, the driver casually dressed and, at first, not very talkative or friendly.

But my inquiry about good shopping venues in the city sparked his interest. He assured me N1 City or Cavendish Square would be my best bets and strongly advised against the Waterfront because it was "too expensive".

He started warning me about unscrupulous taxi drivers who were giving the industry a bad name but in the same breath offered to take me to places of scenic interest for a "special price" in his own car.

On a short trip such as from my hotel to the Waterfront, this could save me R10, while I would pay R150 less for a trip to Cape Point or Stellenbosch which normally cost around R400, he said. (A bus trip to Cape Point or Stellenbosch costs between R145 and R185, including entrance fees, leaving at 8.30am and returning at 5.30pm.)

I paid R35 for the trip along Plein Street and over Kloofnek although the meter reading was closer to R31.

On formal inquiry to the Magicab office later, I was told a trip from Plein Street to the Waterfront cost R50 and to Cape Point in the region of R350.

My rating for this company is "fair".

My next trip was with a Marine taxi from the Bay Hotel to Captour's offices in Adderley street, roughly the same distance as the first trip.

After waiting for 25 minutes, a very polite and neatly dressed driver collected me, opening the passenger door and apologising for the delay. The car was clean and in a very good condition. I was told that the trip would cost me in the region of R50. When asked if I would prefer the scenic or mountain route, I played dumb, asking for whichever would be the quickest. He assured me the distance was exactly the same. Naturally, we took the scenic route.

Again I was advised not to go near the Waterfront. "You won't find what you are looking for there, it is very touristy." His recommendation for shopping was Tyger Valley. The trip would cost me R150.

His tariff to Cape Point was R850, but for me he would make a special price of R600.

After assuring me that crime was no longer a problem in the city, the talkative driver proceeded to tell me he never travelled without a gun, had been involved in seven shoot-outs with criminals and had survived as a taxi driver for so long only because of his combat training.

"But that's part of life here," he tried to reassure me, warning me not to walk around alone at night.

A spokesman for the Marine Taxis office told me a trip from the Bay Hotel to Adderley Street cost R55 and he estimated a trip to Cape Point at R750.

This company deserves no more than a "fair" rating.

>From Captour, I went to the Waterfront in a Waterfront bus at a cost of R1, 10.

A taxi ride over a similar distance, from the Victoria and Alfred Hotel to the Cape Sun Hotel, cost me R14 in a run-down, rusty old car. The driver, dressed in jeans, T-shirt and cap ,was not in the mood for conversation, apart from advising me to steer clear of the Waterfront.

We travelled along Coen Steytler Avenue, around both circles in Adderley Street and right into Strand Street to the hotel. When I wanted to pay, he had no change for a R50 and could offer no alternative. I eventually "found" the right amount in my purse.

No company name was displayed on the side of the car and the driver refused to give me a card or telephone number.

Naturally, I have to rate this taxi as "poor".

The next expedition was from the Peninsula Hotel in Sea Point to Cape Town International Airport on a Saturday night with my German husband in an attempt to make my performance more credible.

For this trip the Intercape airport shuttle charges R30 a person.

A Sea Point Taxis driver arrived within two minutes of my call and we were greeted by a friendly, elderly woman in a white uniform in a neat, clearly marked car.

She said the trip would cost us about R90. Her rate to Cape Point was R500, but she recommended we rather take a bus because it would be cheaper and more enjoyable.

She chatted all the way to the airport, answering all our questions and doing her best to promote the city and the country.

"The Waterfront is really a blessing because you can go there any time, even at night and when the weather is bad," she said.

Crime in Cape Town simply was not a problem, except in the townships where people still killed one another, she assured us.

The best place for shopping in town was the Green Point flea market where you found the best bargains but the Waterfront also offered a good selection of shops, she told us. She advised us not to use minibus taxis "unless you are really desperate".

The trip cost R106 but she asked if she could make out the receipt for R110, to which which my husband agreed.

My official inquiry to Sea Point Taxis owner Ernest MacDonald confirmed the rate to the airport as between R110 and R120 and to Cape Point as about R500.

We both agreed this company's performance was "very good".

At the airport we flagged down another taxi to get back to the Peninsula Hotel and to our surprise the driver was also a woman.

No name was displayed on the side of the car but we were told the company was called J S taxis. The driver, dressed in a casual track suit, told us the trip would be between R120 and R130.

Her rate to Cape Point was R600, but she advised us not to take a taxi but a bus or a rented car.

Her recommendations for shopping included the Green Point flea market and Tyger Valley centre. She said the Waterfront was expensive for shopping, but the restaurants were quite reasonable.

Crime was not a problem, apart from pickpockets "who are among the best in the world", she said.

She warned us against unscrupulous taxi operators, adding that her own boss would rather drive a long route to try to make more money out of tourists. Other drivers would activate their meters from the time they received a call and, in one instance she knew of, a driver charged a couple R150 from the airport to Bellville, which should cost no more than R50.

"But I don't believe in cheating people," she said.

We paid R150 for the trip.

I could find no trace of JS Taxis in the telephone directory and nor could Telkom's directory inquiry service.

My rating for this company's service is "fair".

Although most drivers appeared helpful and friendly, my experiences clearly illustrate the need for training, standardisation of rates and services and proper control over the industry from the authorities.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Sports - General;
UK-SA talks in city may net millions for bid


BYLINE: Michael Morris and Chene Blignaut, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Cape Town - Multimillion-rand joint venture opportunities in tourism, development and Olympic-related projects are expected to flow from intensive discussions in the city next week between top British executives and their South African counterparts.

The Britain Means Business workshops from Tuesday to Thursday hold the promise of injecting substantial British expertise into the preparations for the Olympic project, the development and expansion of tourism and mobilising investment capital nationally. 

The high-powered 50-strong delegation, led by the Duke of Kent, reflects Britain's determination to forge stronger trade and investment links with South Africa.

Delegates include leading architect Norman Foster; Gordon Edington, chairman of the company that runs Heathrow and Gatwick airports near London; Gareth Evans, head of the British Tourist Authority; Raymond-Pierre Chigot, vice-president of Hilton International; Brian Pearse of Lucas Varity PLC; and Alastair Morton, honorary president of the Eurotunnel Group.

Africa News


April 18, 1997


South Africa;
Rushing into the future (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - Educators have warned that the introduction of the revolutionary "curriculum 2005" next year is destined to fail unless the government solves the underlying problems in education

When teachers and school principals express concerns about the haste with which the far-reaching changes to the school curriculum are to be introduced from next year it is time to sit up and take notice.

They fear the new system is destined to fail unless the many underlying problems already heaped against education are solved. 

Teachers with expertise and a commitment to making the curriculum work are vital but in the Western Cape alone some 6 000 of the most qualified educators have been lost to the profession by the teacher rationalisation programme which even the Minister of Education has admitted contained serious flaws.

And there are other problems: mounting frustration among teachers; large classes; the loss of more teachers when phase two of rationalisation begins; high stress levels - none of which are conducive to what should be an exciting phase in the evolution of South African education.

Teaching children to think for themselves instead of learning by rote is an admirable ideal which should be welcomed enthusiastically by parents, educators and future employers.

But the system becomes vulnerable when the teacher-pupil ratios soar and teachers' experience and qualifications are not up to standard.

It is evident these problems cannot be achieved quickly. Surely it is a matter of great enough importance to deserve a series of pilot projects to evaluate its merit in the South African situation at this time.

Not unreasonably, educators have called for the process to be handled with great care. This sentiment will be shared by all who have the interests of the country's future - our children - at heart.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


475 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


South Africa;
Rhoda Kadalie: a strident voice for South Africa's oppressed


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Cape Town - Imagine being asked to submit with your university application a full-length photograph of yourself in a swimming costume.

This bizarre request by the University of Cape Town's physiotherapy department 25 years ago irrevocably changed the course of Human Rights Commissioner Rhoda Kadalie's life.

So outraged was she that she defied the coloured elite's advocation of entering formerly all-white tertiary institutions and under protest went to the then-unfashionable "bush" University of the Western Cape (UWC), where the white Afrikaans-speaking lecturers unashamedly fed black students apartheid propaganda.

Ironically it was here that the obedient daughter of a lay minister was transformed into a strident voice for the oppressed. 

Time spent with the outspoken Rhoda can be an empowering experience. Petite and businesslike, she has gained many supporters. But her refusal to show reverence to authority has irked many people.

"I am too honest for my own good and I have often got into trouble, but I don't regret it. My driving force is justice. If something is just and true, I will fight for it. I will not say the politically correct thing," she said.

The granddaughter of trade unionist Clements Kadalie who was instrumental in launching the first black trade union in 1908, Rhoda was born in District Six in 1953.

Her father Fenner worked for the city council as a clerk and in reaction to the frequent absence of Clements during his childhood, eschewed politics to become a missionary. As a result, she had a strong Calvinistic upbringing.

For 16 years the only girl among seven boisterous boys - her parents kept trying until they had another daughter - she was the apple of her father's eye.

"I always had to assert myself in a male household. But I was never led to believe I was inferior or secondary to men," she said. "We could speak openly at home and early on we began to question taboos."

Rhoda describes herself as an intellectual Christian who had to discover God for herself. "I think the way the church often depicts God - as male and white - is blasphemous. God doesn't identify with patriarchy or sexual violence."

She became politically inclined and rebelled against typically feminine career choices, choosing library science and gaining a four-year degree with honours in anthropology.

She became a junior lecturer in anthropology in the late 70s and her rebellion continued. "I was subversive and quite radical politically. I got the students to do innovative projects like interviewing political detainees."

Rhoda became intensely involved with the United Democratic Front at a time when the Black Consciousness Movement was strong. Simultaneously she became aware of the extent of sexual harassment. On campus the struggle against apartheid gained momentum but no such fight was being waged against gender inequality. So she took up the cudgels.

Rhoda became a campaigner for women's equality for academic, administrative and general staff alike on campus.

"What I did at UWC was to watch the men in power and use the same ploys they did, to subvert and undermine their authority. But at the same time I provided them with the facts that proved injustices existed."

What angered her later was that on occasion some male professors would ask her to bring up an issue they wanted aired as they did not have the courage to do so themselves. She despised this.

"The very men who didn't like me for my feminism used me for my courage," she said. "A lot of men are crippled by ambition. They won't rock the boat for fear of jeopardising their career. I don't give a shit about rising to the top. My driving concern is the truth."

Rhoda co-ordinated UWC's gender equity office from 1993 to 1995. Many people around her felt that their cause was at last being taken seriously and she won strong support from the staff.

She married a fellow lecturer, with whom she had a daughter, before they later divorced. Because the Immorality Act decreed she could not marry across the colour line the couple skipped to Namibia for the wedding .

"We bought a house in Observatory and before we moved in we introduced ourselves to our (white) neighbours. One of them said: 'Don't worry - your neighbours are either drunkards or dykes. You'll just fit in,'" she burst out laughing.

The timing of her appointment in October 1995 was perfect: "I always said when I turned 40 I wanted a new career. But I was very surprised to get this position."

Rhoda was the successful candidate out of 83 nominees for the position of human rights commissioner.

"My work at UWC trained me to be analytical and critical. It inculcated in me a fearlessness in campaigning around issues. I have never been a political lackey and because of this was not always liked. Yet I think the qualifying factor for my appointment was my independence," she said.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


476 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


South Africa;
Bad service is harming city's image for visitors


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Cape Town - Poor service from many sedan taxi operators in Cape Town is harming the city's image among foreign visitors, who say this international mode of transport is often not up to scratch.

This is according to a report on a service measurement pilot project undertaken for the Cape Town municipality as part of an initiative to jack up service in the tourism industry.

The project identifies an urgent need for corrective and preventive measures to close the "service gaps". 

Sixty foreign visitors from more than 10 countries were asked about their experiences in metered taxis.

Half said they had had service-related problems, ranging from attempts to overcharge, deliberately taking people to the wrong addresses and unnecessary detours, to difficulty hiring taxis from certain places and having to make use of "pirate" (illegal) taxis. Eight percent of participants would not advise others to use sedan taxis in Cape Town because of dissatisfaction with the service or prices.

The visitors interviewed had, on average, made more than four trips by metered taxi in the city and some had made as many as 20.

The average participant spent about R3 000 on accommodation, meals, tours, transport, entertainment, shopping and sundry expenses during his or her stay, and some spent as much as R8 500.

More than 50 percent were professionals, many in management positions. Older visitors and younger women are two important groups who used taxis.

The report stresses the "increasingly important role of meter taxis" as traffic flows in the inter city increased and streets get more congested during the Olympics, if Cape Town hosts the 2004 Games.

Metered taxis form a vital part of inner-city transportation networks world- wide.

There are believed to be about 400 sedan taxis in Cape Town, many of which operate illegally. In many instances poor service is the result of "deep- seated economic problems", increasing competition from tour buses and problems arising from illegal operators, the report says.

The situation is further compounded by low morale, lack of skills and poor communication with other tourism industries.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


477 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


Business and Finance;
SA squeeze on foreign workers


BYLINE: Jovial Rantao, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Cape Town - The unemployment crisis had compelled the Government to adopt a much tougher approach to admission of foreign workers, Home Affairs Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi told the National Assembly yesterday.

Opening a debate on the Home Affairs budget vote, Chief Buthelezi said this had resulted in the Aliens Control Amendment Act, which stipulated that work, study and work-seeker's permits must be applied for from abroad (not after arrival in SA). 

"These more stringent control measures have had an overwhelmingly positive effect, as foreigners who previously entered South Africa on holiday permits with the intention of seeking employment are now compelled to obtain work permits before entering South Africa and employment opportunities are, therefore, better secured for local residents," he said.

He said he was committed to apprehending and removing illegals.

The illegal alien population in South Africa, estimated between 2,5 million and 5 million, had put socio-economic resources under severe strain. He estimated illegal aliens cost the Government billions of rnds annually.

The Cabinet had appealed through the media to foreign companies operating in South Africa to demonstrate support for the RDP by refraining from appointing alien employees to positions which could be filled by South African citizens or permanent residents, unless this was absolutely necessary, Chief Buthelezi told the assembly.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


478 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Investor installs 14mln. birr factory

BAHIR DAR (ENA) - an entrepreneur is investing 14 million birr to install a flour mill and edible oil factory in Bahir Dar.

Owner of the factory under construction, Ato Asrat Mekonen said the factory would commence production at the end of this Ethiopian year.

The factory with a capacity of producing 12,000 quintals of flour daily opens job opportunity to 120 people, he said.

The edible oil processing factory uses maize as raw material which the owner is preparing to cultivate on 350 hectares of land in Awi Zone. 

He appreciated the regional government and the regional investment bureau for their cooperation and creating conducive situations for his endeavours.

During the past five years, 280 projects with investment capital of over 1 billion birr have been licensed in Amhara Regional State.

Projects lag behind schedule in South Omo

JINKA (ENA) - A team of assessors reported that there is no coordinated mechanism helping alleviate problems of project execution in South Omo Zone.

The team led by the head of the economic sector of South Ethiopia Regional State disclosed that the weakness of various development offices to submit timely information to the concerned bodies and regional bureaux must be avoided in an effort to facilitate conditions for the execution of different projects.

It also said agricultural experts must also raise the awareness of peasants to sow various crops during the main harvest season.

According to the team, it is necessary to undertake intensified activities in a bid to make operational the projects within the time set for the purpose.

Executive offices said the activities of the projects undertaken at a cost of 7.3 million birr remained below the target due to the absence of standaridzed contractors as well as lack of vehicles and roads.

France plans to launch irrigation development project in Tigray

MAKALLE (ENA) - The French ambassador to Ethiopia, Mr. Alrin Rouque said his government has plans to launch an irrigation development project in order to contribute its share to the ongoing development activities in the region.

He said France is ready to support the efforts being made to attain self sufficiency in food.

Ato Gebru has also urged for the resumption of archaeological studies in central Tigray Zone that is being undertaken by French experts.

The ambassador who paid a three-day working tour to the region has reportedly visited a cement factory, a hydroelectric power supply project, the Makalle University, the Mesfin Industrial Engineering and other institutions.

Bureau registers job seekers in Addis Ababa

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The labour and social affairs bureau of Region 14 administration disclosed that it is conducting a special restoration to facilitate pre-conditions for liaison between jobless professionals and employer and training organizations in Addis Ababa.

The registration being conducted at the bureau and other branch offices of the bureau includes those having practical skills without formal education, vocational graduates from secondary schools, as well as diploma and degree holders from tertiary institutes.

Woizero Worknesh Meseker, Team leader of the job assignment and man-power research section of the bureau, said the response by government and private organizations to impart information on vacancies or the need for further training is encouraging.

After the completion of the one month registration that stays from April 9 to may 8, pamphlets listing professional skills and gender will be distributed to interested organizations, the team leader added.

According to Woizero Worknesh, the bureau expects to register over 16,500 jobless professionals.

She said 651 of the 9,000 job seekers registered in the past six months are now employed.

According to a study conducted in 1994, there are 260,900 job seekers in the metropolis.

Metropolitans express sorrow over recent bomb blasts

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Some residents of the capital have expressed sorrow over the recent bomb blasts which, they said, victimized innocent people and children.

The residents told ENA reporters that the bomb attacks occurred at three separate places were inhumane.

Ato Sentayehu Beyene, a teacher who was shopping around Tana supermarket before the accident said street vendors engaged in petty trade, most of whom were children, became victims of the blast.

Abebe Berhanu and Jemal Kedir who are working at a building materials shop near the supermarket, said the affected children who used to sell plastic bags do not have a penny for medical treatment and expressed pity over the tragic incident.

Two intellectuals who asked for anonimity, said the government in close cooperation with residents is responsible to safeguard the safety of the public and described the perpetrators as criminals.

An employee of a bank in Merkato also called for a coordinated and intensified security activity especially in the busiest market places.

According to legal advisors of the supermarket, windows were partly damaged while parts of the building cracked.

Maintenance on the damaged parts of the building has already begun and it will be operational within not more than three days, the head of the supermarket said.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


479 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


Ethiopia;
Alleged Red Terror perpetrators appear in court


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Alleged Red Terror perpetrators whom the Special Prosecutor accused of torturing and murdering people tagged as "anti- revolutionary and anti-people EPRP members" in Woreda 9 and 13 of the capital yesterday appeared at the Federal High Court.

the charge levelled against 49 defendants including Kelbesa Negewo, the then chairman of both Woreda Nine Administration and the Revolutionary Campaign coordinating Committee who is being tried in abesnita, says the alleged culprits had tortured and killed people involved in a certain political circle.

The charge says the defendants are responsible for the killing of many people through "Zemecha Mentir", "Netsa Ermija" and the Red Terror. A girl who lived in Woreda 9 Kebele 09 was shot to death on 19 December 1977 and laid by a roadside, according to the charge. 

It also says Kelbesa Negewo and Woizero Simret Biru, then secretary of the Woreda 9 Kebele 10 administration and member of the Revolutionary Campaign coordinating Committee, with their accomplices had been shooting many people to death usually at midnights around the Muslims' Cemetery, Shola, Kelemework School, St. John church and other places.

The charge contains lists of names who, it says, are suffering from illnesses caused by brutal torture.

According to the charge, Kelbesa Negewo and his accomplies who are made responsible for 64 different charges; had allegedly committed extrajudical arrests ranging from three days to three years, besides searching the houses of two deceased people without court order.

The defendants are also accused of taking cars, money, gold, books and video cassettes from people whom they intimidated, the charge elaborates.

Ato Zenebe Ayele, chairman of the Revolutionary Campaign Committee of Woreda 13 from 1969 - 1977, and 72 collaborators are responsible for the death, physical injury and detention with the intent to cause death on people in the woreda, the charge file stated.

Citing a specific incident, the file alleged that the accused has shot to death 13 individuals whom they detained in different areas of Addis Ababa in December 1977.

In a similar summary execution prepared in February 1978, the chairman and his collaborators have gunned down 12 individuals near the Menlik Hospital and in Kebele 06 of the woreda.

A persecution witness told the court that a third year student of the Addis Abab University named Senay was burnt to death following the inhuman torture and beating in a Kebele of woreda 13.

The witness said five people were killed on March 6, 1978 (5:00 A.M. local time), with two of them at Ras Mekonen Bridge, the other one near Nazareth School and the rest near Yekatit 12 Hospital.

The charge levelled by the Special Prosecutor says the Woreda 13 defendants allegedly committed crimes against innocent citizens including burning and torturing which resulted in internal and external bodily harms.

The defendants of the two woredas appealed tot he court they can not afford to hire defence lawyers and the court ordered them to produce letter of justification.

Police were also ordered to search for others who are at large and bring them before the court of law.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 18, 1997


Ethiopia;
CETU general assembly to be held soon


BYLINE: Derese T/Wold, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The coordinating committee on the reorganization of the Confederation of Ethiopian Trade Unions (CETU) announced here yesterday that it has completed preparations to hold its eighth general assembly, reportedly scheduled to be conducted during 22-24 April 1997 at the assembly hall of the Ethiopian Roads Authority.

The executive committee members - Ato Aregawi Kebede, Ato Zenebe Kebede and Ato Yemane Binega - gave a briefing to local newsmen that the meeting is expected to discuss at length the newly draft regulations and structural contents of CETU as well as elect new leaders and audit committee members. 

The committee noted that the dissolution of the former CETU was the result of lack of requisite provisions in the statute. the restructured confederation is expected to be national in form and the content would be democratic institutions which passes decisions not on individuals but popular basis, they added.

The organizing committee, which is drawn from among eight trade union federations and comprising of 16 members, has been conducting various meetings on revising status of the former CETU with basic trade unions in Addis Ababa and the various other regions which more or less unanimously voted in favour, it was disclosed.

The committee meanwhile noted that members of the Construction and business Bank and the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia said to await court decision on whether the former CETU was illegal and thus deserved tocontinue representing the country's organised labour.

It is to be recalled that CETU was established formerly, in 1986 (E.C) but denied legal status due to conflict of interest among the top leadership.

April 18, 1997


Business and Finance;
Preliminary petroleum exploration under way in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Preliminary works to start petroleum exploration in several regions of the country are well underway, an official of the ministry of Mines and Energy said yesterday.

Surveying and geological mapping for petroleum exploration in Abay Valley and Makalle area are in their final stage, said Ato Mesfin Asnake, a representative of the petroleum works department of the ministry. these areas would be immediately made available to investor who want to engage in petroleum exploration on completion of the preliminary works, Ato Mesfin added. 

Ato Mesfin said that petroleum containing rocks have been found on extensive territories of land in these areas.

Applications to conduct explorations in Gambella and Ogaden by foreign companies are under examination, he noted.

In Ogaden, Hunt Oil, an American oil company, has been searching for petroleum during the past five years, and has renewed its license to extensively conduct geological and geophysical works, Ato Mesfin said.

Many foreign companies have expressed interest to engage in petroleum exploration in Ethiopia, it was disclosed.

Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


482 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


United States and Africa;
Urgent Action Needed On Foreign Aid Authorization


BYLINE: Washington Office on Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Washington - African sustainable development efforts will be greatly affected by decisions on the foreign assistance budget now scheduled for April 23, 1997.

The House International Relations Committee chairman Ben Gilman is proposing $18.8 billion for the overall Fiscal Year (FY) 1998 international affairs budget, which is $500 million above the FY97 level but $700 million below the President's current request. Despite a potential increase, Gilman is proposing to cut bilateral development assistance programs by a total of $180 million below the FY97 level. 

In the past two years the average overall cuts to the foreign operations budget have been 10-11%. But the line items that are most important to Africa have suffered disproportionately severe cuts. The Gilman proposal for FY98 would cut child survival and disease programs by $45 million*, family planning by $57 million, and the Development Fund for Africa (DFA) by another $100 million from their FY97 levels. DFA has already been cut 16% from $802 million to $675 million over the past two years. The African Development Foundation (ADF) has been cut from $16.9 million to $11.5 million over the same period, a 32% reduction. Gilman's proposal would keep refugee and migration assistance as well as disaster assistance at the same levels as FY97. Unprotected programs in "remaining DA" (e.g. microenterprise, democracy, environment, agriculture, and economic growth) look to take even deeper cuts.

This proposal would be devastating, because it will set a marker for the budget and appropriations committees as they determine their numbers.

Action Needed:

Call toll free 1-800-962-3524. When the operator answers Capitol, ask for the Representative by name and they will transfer your call to the Member's office.

Tell Members of the House International Relations Committee that Representative Gilman's proposed cut in development assistance is unfair and unacceptable. With a large percentage of the poorest countries in the world, Africa should not be expected to bear the brunt of further disproportionate cuts.

At an absolute minimum, Congress must adopt the Administration's request for development assistance ($66 million above FY97 levels). If the foreign assistance budget is to be increased, then development assistance should be the top priority for a restoration of funds. Poverty eradication for the most marginalized and vulnerable peoples and countries should be a priority within the accounts, since these programs have been cut so deeply already.

The Administration's request is still too low for development program needs, but it is the highest proposal under consideration. Gilman has stated on many occasions his public support for development programs and the PVO community, and we need to encourage him to demonstrate that support by raising the funding levels. The policy makers need to hear from you this week before markup!

(* Note: For more information on health funding in particular, please contact Chuck Woolery, National Council of International Health, 1701 K St., Washington, DC 20006-1503; tel: 202-833-5900 x206; fax: 202-833-0075; e-mail: chuck@igc.org)

Distributed by the Washington Office on Africa (WOA), a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: woa@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


483 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


South Africa;
President's Budget Vote


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Johannesburg - President Nelson Mandela's Budget Vote in Cape Town over the past two days has once more highlighted that the democratic government has the best policies, and the political will and determination to meet the basic needs of the people.

Indeed as the opposition parties concede, policies of the government developed in the theatre of mass struggles are unassailable. What is critical is the need to address the capacity, skills and orientation of the civil service to enable government to fast track delivery.

The ANC will endeavour to form a forum which will include Cosatu and our allies with a view to developing a comprehensive strategy towards real and meaningful transformation of the civil service to ensure it is people and service oriented. 

In this respect, we concur with the President that we owe no-one an apology for struggling in the same trenches with COSATU, the SACP and SANCO. It is an alliance which cannot be exchanged for any monetary gain.

On the contrary, we will continue strengthening and consolidating the individual and collective components of the alliance with the sole aim of mobilising the majority of the people and deepening our democracy.

In deepening this democracy we will remain seized with discussions and debates on the best model of governance and representation. In this regard, the issue of proportional and contituency based representation must constantly be looked into to ensure it continues to reflect the needs of society in general. The ANC is not married to one single model but to serving the needs of the people.

We further note the preparedness of all political parties to confront racial patterns of voting. This remains the legacy of the past system of apartheid. Part of our transformation process and the movement towards a truly non-racial and democratic society is the need to deracialise all sectors of our country including changing the mindset of all our people.

In this regard, the democratic movement has always been motivated by the need to redress the imbalances created by the apartheid system by equalising opportunities among all people of South Africa.

Whereas government is miles ahead in the implementation of affirmative action, we remain concerned that not all sectors - particularly the private sector - are moving in tandem with changes permeating our society. Various measures have to be looked into with a view to making business march in line with the rest of society.

Such reluctance on the part of some sectors, including calls for rent and rates boycotts such as in Sandton, can only undermine reconciliation, peace and nation building. For them it is business as usual. We must effectively mobilise the broadest sections of society to strengthen government policies in this respect and undermine such notions.

We remain convinced that those who are against reconciliation and nation building constitute a tiny minority of our population and, as in the past, their reasons will come to light.

With regard to the issue of informers. we give our unequivocal support to the TRC as the only legitimate structure tasked with the responsibility of handling such a sensitive matter of national importance.

The ANC gives its unequivocal support to the government's national crime prevention strategy premised on the need to mobilise the broadest sections of our population, including business, against forms of crime as well as white collar crime which constitutes the biggest threat to our democracy. We remain convinced that both Minister Sydney Mufamadi and Commissioner George Fivaz are equal to the task at hand.

We reject with contempt calls for a national state of emergency. Calls from some quarters for 'quick fix' solutions like these, indicate general ignorance in opposition circles about the causes and depth of crime in society. Such measures would do much for political expedience, but very little to address the core problem. The government must be complemented for standing its ground on this issue.

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107 17 April 1997


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


484 of 797 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 18, 1997


Ethiopia;
A History of Early Twentieth Century Ethiopia - Part 15


BYLINE: Dr Richard Pankhurst, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

Addis Ababa - We saw last week how Mussolini's entry into the European war, on 10 June 1941, led directly to Ethiopia's Liberation, and to the country's occupation by British troops. Now read on:

The collapse of fascist rule, the termination of Italian investment, upon which the Italian East African empire had hitherto been based, the demobilisation of colonial soldiers, many still in possession of their weapons, the disruption of the economy, the consequent drying-up of trade, and hence of government revenue, created major problems for newly liberated Ethiopia, in 1941.

Neither the Emperor, whose pre-war administration had been disbanded five years earlier, nor the British, who lacked any experience of the country, were well equipped to run an efficient post-liberation state. Ethiopian administration was further handicapped by the fact that a significant section of the educated class had died, in some cases been massacred, during the occupation, and because education of "natives" during that period occupation had largely ceased.

Post-liberation problems were compounded by the Ethiopian Government's virtual inability to raise taxes, as well as by the presence in the country of 40,000 Italian civilians. The latter were enemy nationals, and hence a security risk, but were expected, in accordance with then contemporary racial values, to be provided, as Europeans, with food, and medical facilities, at the level to which they were accustomed. 

The politics of the immediate post-liberation era were further complicated by the widespread diffusion of Italian arms, many in the possession of former colonial troops, and by the fragmentation of the Ethiopian elite into three different groups: the Returnees, who had been in exile with the Emperor, and were therefore to some extent out of touch with the situation in Ethiopia; the Collaborators, who had worked with the invaders, and were therefore better informed, but held in disrepute in patriotic circles; and the Patriots, who had played a major role in the liberation, but were in many cases unfamiliar with modern administration. All three groups expected, and to some extent received, posts in government service, as a reward for past services, or in recognition of their influence, or loyalty to the monarch.

Tensions between the central government and the provinces had to some extent been acerbated by fascist policy, which had tried to divide the " native" population on both ethnic and religious lines. This disintegrative tendency had, however, been largely counter-balanced by other developments of the occupation period. These included the improvement of roads, and the installation of a public radio address system in the principal towns, as well as an awakened sense of Ethiopian patriotism. The political power of the centre was likewise much strengthened by the triumphant return of the Emperor, and by the visible support he received from the British, who in the immediate post-war period enjoyed a virtual monopoly of military power. Like previous rulers he also exercised many forms of patronage, not only, as in the past, in respect of land and political appointment, but now also in the allocation of school places, and scholarships abroad.

A not-insignificant rebellion was, however, soon to flare in Tegray.

The Emperor, after his return to Ethiopia, was largely preoccupied with relations with the British. The latter, who had entered the country as liberators, had in fact replaced the Italians as an occupying power. Relations between the Ethiopians and the British were from the outset ambiguous. British policy towards Ethiopia was first enunciated, in general terms, by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, who told the British House of Commons, on 4 February 1941, that his government "would welcome the re- appearance of an independent Ethiopian State and recognise the claim of Emperor Haile Sellassie to the throne". Official British policy was further clarified in high-level talks, held shortly afterwards in February and March. These were based, in accordance with Eden's statement, on the "rejection of any idea of a protectorate", or of "the provision of a strong western administration of the country".

After the Emperor's return to Addis Ababa, in May, there was, however, considerable tension between the Ethiopians and the British. The two parties differed greatly in their views on the country's future government. The Ethiopians expected to assume full sovereignty without delay, whereas the British considered the country's independence only as a long distance objective. A first clash on this question occurred as early as 11 May 1941, when the Emperor appointed his first post-war cabinet. The British representative, Brigadier Maurice Lush, sternly informed him that such appointments could not be made "until a peace treaty has been effected with Italy" Haile Sellassie was, not surprisingly, indignant. A compromise was, however, duly effected, whereby the British accepted the appointment of the ministers, but "chose to regard them as merely advisers" to the British military administration of the country.

It was symptomatic that the Emperor's private mail was for a time subject to British censorship, and opened by British censors. His Imperial Majesty, we are informed, was not amused.

Tension was further increased by the decision of the British military authorities to appropriate, and take out of the country, some of the principal factories earlier installed by the Italians, as well as weapons, and military and other transport. Ethiopia was thus very visibly empoverished by its liberators, who soon came to be popularly regarded as its looters. Friction was also created by the presence, in the Ethiopian capital, of white South African troops, who attempted to perpetuate the strict colour bar earlier instituted by the Italians.

British opinion in relation to Ethiopia's independence varied greatly. Sir Philip Mitchell, the chief British Political Officer in the Middle East, sought to impose particularly strong control over Ethiopia, but others in London took the view that Great Britain should demonstrate to the world that it could liberate a country without imposing political strings. Sir Philip, because of his official position, was nevertheless able to press the Emperor to abide by British "advice" in "all important matters, internal and external, touching the government of the country"; to levy taxes and allocate expenditure only with "prior approval" of the British Government; to grant British courts jurisdiction over foreigners; "to raise no objection" if the British Commander-in-Chief "found it necessary to resume military control over any part of Ethiopia"; and not to raise armed forces, or undertake military operations, "except as agreed by His Majesty's Government's representative". Taxation, expenditure, communications, and the jurisdiction of foreigners were to be under British control. In return for this extensive control he proposed that the Emperor be offered a subsidy, British advisers, and the opportunity of discussing proposals for a treaty. British Economic Controls

Ethiopia, as a result of its liberation by the British troops, was at this time firmly under British economic as well as political control. The country was incorporated into the British-based Sterling Area, used British East African Shillings, was dependent on a British bank, Barclay's, and was served exclusively by the British Overseas Aviation Corporation, B.O.A.C. Virtually all political power was likewise in the hands of the British military, who went so far as to censor the Emperor's private correspondence. The local British officials were so bent on perpetuating that paramountcy that an American Government memorandum of June 1941 bluntly asserted that Britain was seeking to "establish a protectorate over Abyssinia".

Some British officials at this period, and for the next few years, moreover sought to partition the country. In the north there were plans to unite parts of Tegray with the adjacent highlands of Eritrea, to form a new state under British protection. In the south-east the British Government proposed incorporating the already British-occupied Ogaden with British-occupied Somalia, to create a Greater Somalia, under British trusteeship. British official thinking also for a time envisaged the partition of Eritrea, with the western portion annexed to the then Anglo-Egyptian Sudan.

For all the above reasons, the fund of Ethiopian good-will towards Britain, the Country's Liberator, was steadily dissipated, giving way to fear, suspicion, mistrust, and even anger.

Next Week: Post-War Problems with the British.


LOAD-DATE: April 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
